HEADLINE: U.S., Having Won Changes, Is Set to Sign Law of the Sea

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
After two decades of on-again-off-again negotiations, the Administration announced today that it would sign the Law of the Sea treaty, which Republican Administrations have condemned as hostile to free enterprise.
In announcing the decision, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said the Administration had negotiated broad changes that make the treaty friendlier to business. 
 The decision is expected to significantly strengthen the treaty, which sets comprehensive rules on sea-bed mining, fishing rights, oil exploration, conservation, scientific research and other matters. Sixty-one countries have ratified the treaty, which takes effect in November.
President Reagan angrily rejected the treaty in 1982, saying it clashed with free-enterprise principles by requiring mining companies to pay hefty royalties and share sophisticated technology with poor countries.
"We have been successful in fixing all the major problems raised by the Reagan Administration," said Wesley Scholz, the chief American negotiator.
Pentagon officials were eager for Washington to ratify the treaty because it guarantees the right to pass through straits and specifies that countries have full sovereignty over the seas within 12 miles of shore. The treaty also gives countries control of fishing and oil and gas rights within 200 miles.
Administration officials said they hoped they could win Senate confirmation, but they acknowledged that some Republicans oppose it.
Conservative groups attacked the treaty today because, they said, even the amended version places too many burdens on business.
"We've taken all these sea issues that could have been solved easily through bilateral agreements and instead we have created this massive superstructure," said Doug Bandow, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, who was a special assistant to President Reagan. "I think the Senate has a duty not to ratify it. This treaty comes out of an era when socialism ruled in the third world and all the talk was redistribution of wealth."
In talks that ended early this month, the Administration persuaded other countries to delay setting royalty payments and to drop production quotas that the treaty set for private sea-bed mining companies.
Mr. Scholz also said that under the amendments, the United States and other industrial nations would have an effective veto over decisions by the International Seabed Authority, to be based in Jamaica.
For more than a year, the Administration has negotiated with more than 50 countries to amend the mining section of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.
Testifying to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Christopher said, "It's an extremely important treaty, and I think it's very desirable that we have been able to obtain from the other members satisfactory amendments to the seabed mining provisions that enables us to approve the treaty as a whole."
On other topics today, Mr. Christopher made these points:
*The United States is prepared to return to the Security Council to seek sanctions if North Korea uses coming negotiations to stall for time to continue its nuclear program.
*He will go to the Middle East on July 17 as an intermediary in indirect talks between Syria and Israel.
*Washington supports a war-crimes tribunal to prosecute those responsible for genocide in Rwanda.
 
Basic Premise Disputed
 The Law of the Sea treaty has generated disputes between rich and poor countries because of its underlying premise -- that the oceans and the sea bed are a "common heritage of mankind," to be shared through "a just and equitable economic order."
This premise disturbed President Reagan, but Clinton Administration officials say the amended provisions seek not to redistribute wealth, but to create incentives for sea-bed mining.
Under the amendments, companies would no longer have to pay $1 million a year to explore for minerals on the ocean floor. The Administration, joined by other industrial nations, also persuaded poor countries to drop provisions forcing the transfer of mining technology.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Touches a New Low Against the Yen in Tokyo

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slid below 98 Japanese yen in trading in Tokyo early today despite efforts by Japan's central bank to prop it up.
The dollar touched a new record low of 97.73 yen , then rebounded to 98.52 yen in early afternoon trading. Earlier in New York yesterday, it settled at 98.49 yen, down from 98.80 yen on Wednesday. 
 Currency dealers in Tokyo said investors were dumping dollars for a variety of reasons, from a swelling United States trade deficit to fears of higher American inflation. Investors are also concerned that the leading economic powers will be unable to agree on a way to support the American currency at a coming meeting.
Intervention by the Bank of Japan did little to stem the fall last night.
 
 
Dollar Up Against Mark
 In New York trading, the yen rallied once again across the board, although the dollar edged up against the German mark and other European currencies. the dollar advanced to 1.5875 marks from 1.5855 marks.
The dollar also managed a slight gain against the British pound. In New York, the pound slipped to $1.5440 from $1.5460. And the Canadian dollar was steady at 72.31 United States cents.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said he was delaying sanction proceedings against Japan until July 31. The decision was motivated in part by the change in political leadership in Tokyo and by the fact that bilateral trade talks are still underway.
 Traders said the dollar remained under pressure because the postponement of the sanctions did not preclude an escalation in the trade dispute between Washington and Tokyo that would most likely hurt the dollar further.
The worrisome slide of the dollar against the yen and the trade tension between the United States and Japan are seen casting a shadow on the summit of the Group of Seven main industrial nations, scheduled for July 8-10 in Naples.
Analysts have speculated that the nations may consider some coordinated action to shore up the dollar.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen fueled such speculation Thursday, saying lower Japanese and German interest rates would help the dollar and stimulate world economic growth.
 
 
Calling on the Bundesbank
 "I'm not trying to tell the Bundesbank what to do," Mr. Bentsen said. "But, obviously, lower interest rates would help."
Tim McGee, an economist with Tokai Bank Ltd. said, "There still was some hope of some G7 action," largely because of what he called "a yen problem" as much as concern over the dollar's slide.
Mr. McGee noted that the dollar's recent declines should not be interpreted as a crisis because "on a trade-weighted basis, the dollar has actually appreciated," mainly against the currencies of the United States' main trading partners, Canada and Mexico.

HEADLINE: Mayor Presses Revamping School Board

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would push the city's Board of Education to redistribute many of the powers of its central headquarters to borough offices and local school boards. He said he wanted the changes to begin by September.
His proposals, if adopted, would amount to the most sweeping changes since the 1970 decentralization of the system. The changes include the elimination of some offices and divisions at the board headquarters. 
 Mr. Giuliani's comments on his plans for changing the school governance system were his most extensive since he received a draft report on the subject last week from Edward N. Costikyan, his special adviser on school reform. At the time, Mr. Giuliani and his aides declined to comment on the report, but yesterday, speaking in a telephone interview, the Mayor endorsed "the spirit and direction" of Mr. Costikyan's recommendations and said they would be at the top of his summer agenda.
 
Short of Goals
 Mr. Giuliani said that while his administration had made major progress on issues like reducing crime and rejuvenating the city's economy, it had come up short in changing the school system.
"We could not achieve all we wanted on school governance," he said, "so most of the next three to four months will be spent on that."
Since taking office in January, Mr. Giuliani has effectively controlled the seven-member Board of Education through his influence with its four-member majority. But the death early yesterday of Michael J. Petrides, the board's Staten Island member, has raised uncertainties about the future cohesion of the majority faction. [Obituary, Page A23.]
Mr. Giuliani is not the first mayor to seek a revamping of the city's school system. But he is the first to prepare to use his influence with the Board of Education and his budgetary control to enact a wide-ranging administrative decentralization. Previous mayors have largely limited their efforts to seeking action on legislation in Albany to change the school system.
Mr. Petrides forged the faction two years ago and held it together despite recent tensions between the other three members, Ninfa Segarra, Irene H. Impellizzeri and Carol A. Gresser, the board president. Mr. Petrides had also been a crucial intermediary after Mr. Giuliani's relationship with Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines deteriorated in battles this spring over the school budget.
Mr. Giuliani yesterday called Mr. Petrides's death "a great, great loss to the board."
 
'Points of Compromise'
 "Michael knew how to build consensus," he said. "He had the great ability to see the other side in debate and to see points of compromise."
The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, said yesterday that he would not consider whom to appoint to replace Mr. Petrides on the board after Mr. Petrides's funeral on Saturday. Mr. Molinari is one of Mr. Giuliani's closest supporters, and he will doubtless choose someone supportive of the Mayor's agenda.
Mr. Giuliani, who can also count on the support of his own two new representatives on the board, Ms. Segarra and Dr. Impellizzeri, said he was confident that the board majority would continue to support his positions.
But several educators said the unity of the majority faction after Mr. Petrides's death was not a forgone conclusion.
Although Mr. Giuliani endorsed Mrs. Gresser's re-election for board president, she has declined to commit herself to supporting the Mayor's agenda, and during Mr. Giuliani's public battles with Mr. Cortines over the school budget, she took Mr. Cortines's side. She is also known to believe in the need for a board that is independent of mayoral control.
As for Mr. Cortines, his relations with Mr. Giuliani remain tense, and the Chancellor acknowledged in an interview last week that his own agenda and the Mayor's differ dramatically.
On the board, Mr. Petrides had helped to moderate the differences among Mr. Giuliani, the Chancellor and the board president.
To build consensus for his school revamping proposals, Mr. Giuliani said he planned to meet this summer with the borough presidents, union officials, board members and other political leaders.
"Our plans will be subject to some negotiation," he said.
Also, Mr. Giuliani said he would seek sponsors for legislation in Albany to revise the school system along the lines of the Costikyan report, which calls for abolition of the seven-member board and replacement of the chancellor with a commissioner of education appointed by the mayor.
Mr. Giuliani expressed particular enthusiasm for another recommendation in the report: creation by the board of "a special district for schools ready for school-based and school-budgeted management, free of the oversight of the central bureaucracy."
"What I have my eye on is the flow of the money," Mr. Giuliani said. "What I hope to achieve is that we come out with a governance system that has a much greater flow of money to the schools."
Mr. Giuliani said he hoped that in the next year the board would create the new district and encourage the formation of "30 or 40" new schools that would be independent of the central or any bureaucracy. Similar schools in some parts of the country have been termed charter schools.
 
'Should Be Manageable'
 "These would be schools run by principals and a business officer, with independent budgets they would have to justify each year," he said. "We have 1,100 schools. We should have 1,100 budgets. The schools should be manageable small businesses, with budgets of $8 million or $10 million."
He estimated that it would take three or four years to change the system's structure sufficiently to free large numbers of schools from bureaucratic control.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: BEHIND THE SCENES;
Choices Painful for Hartford Politician

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
In her 14 years in Congress from Hartford, a district where 50,000 people work in insurance, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly of Connecticut has always known how tempting it would be for her colleagues to typecast her as the Congresswoman from Aetna.
So she has worked hard as a member of the Ways and Means Committee to involve herself in other issues, like overhauling welfare, compiling statistics on people attacked in hate crimes and increasing access to mammograms for older women. And she has chosen her shots carefully. 
 The work has paid off: She has as safe a seat as any member, is one of four chief deputy majority whips and is the highest-ranking woman in the House.
But as the committee groped its way through long caucuses and late-night debates toward passage of a health care bill this week, Mrs. Kennelly personified the painful choices faced by House Democrats. She has voted time after time -- giving her final aye today -- for sweeping health insurance changes that are not only guaranteed to anger many of her constituents but are also far from certain to pass in the full House, let alone the more conservative Senate.
 
'Best Judgments'
 "I've spent a great deal of time knowing that I could be looked at as a member of Congress with only one issue," Mrs. Kennelly (pronounced kuh-NELL-ee) said Wednesday in a few stolen moments in the Ways and Means library. "I wasn't going to have people saying, on the biggest bill, 'All of a sudden, she won't give. She's going to stand in cement because this is what they want.' " She acknowledged that some people would be annoyed, but said, "What you try to do is give your best judgments."
Mrs. Kennelly's goal has been to reconcile her longstanding belief in the need for universal health coverage with her desire to preserve an active private insurance industry.
This week, her best judgments included helping to broker a compromise that would delay until at least the year 2001 the imposition of Federal price controls on health care if states exceeded spending limits. The committee's acting chairman, Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, had proposed that the fee schedules take effect in 1999, but Mrs. Kennelly and others wanted to give private competition more time to bring costs under control.
"She's not in the leadership by accident," said Liz Robbins, a lobbyist whose clients have included social welfare and health agencies in New York State and New York City. "People look to Barbara on this stuff. You can count on her to know her stuff and not flinch."
Mrs. Kennelly's vote was important because the committee Republicans gave the bill no support, forcing Mr. Gibbons to muster 20 Democratic votes for every measure. To do that, the committee has retreated into closed party caucuses to thrash out each proposal -- 11 hours on Tuesday alone -- before reappearing for public votes. It is in these private sessions, her colleagues say, that Mrs. Kennelly's personal and political skills have been most apparent.
 
Some Victories
 She won on several fine points. When Representative Richard E. Neal, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed lowering to 100 employees the threshold at which companies would be allowed to insure themselves, Mrs. Kennelly argued successfully that such companies should also be allowed to buy private insurance based on an "experience rating" of their claims, rather than a broad community rating. If such employers had to pay rates based on an entire community's risk, she contended, they would have strong incentives to insure themselves, leaving private insurers to compete for only the sickest, most risky populations.
Mrs. Kennelly, who will turn 58 on July 10, also secured a provision that would allow mammograms every year for women over 65, instead of one every other year. The original bill called for annual tests only for women between the ages of 50 and 65. "I said, 'I need this one,' " she recalled, noting the increased risks of breast cancer for older women.
 
Born to Politics
 "Her father must have injected her and her mother must have fed her political milk," said former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, one of her old friends, "because she really has this sixth sense. Obviously, she's going to be concerned about how something affects her district, but she looks at the bigger picture."
Indeed, Mrs. Kennelly has been surrounded by politicians her whole life. Her father was John Bailey, the legendary Connecticut Democratic boss and chairman of the Democratic National Committee under Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson. She is married to James J. Kennelly, a former Speaker of the Connecticut House. Her first political job was as a member of the Hartford City Council, and she went on to become Secretary of State for Connecticut, bucking the party's pick to win the nomination and then an easy general election. She won her House seat in a special election in 1981, after the death of the longtime incumbent.
Mrs. Kennelly speaks quickly but quietly. Even in a casual conversation, she refers to her colleagues with exquisite but unforced formality as "Mrs. Johnson" and "Dr. McDermott." She was the first woman on the House Intelligence Committee and is now the senior woman on Ways and Means, and she was picked by Speaker Thomas S. Foley as a chief deputy whip in 1991. She has often been touted as a potential candidate for Governor of Connecticut, but she decided last fall to pass up the chance. Next year, she will run for vice chairman of the Democratic caucus, but she laughingly deflected questions about that, saying members have other things on their minds.
"She's in a special spot" because of pressures in her district, said a committee colleague, Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan. "She has been courageous and strong, and won and deserves the respect of the group."
Mrs. Kennelly put it tersely: "You're never going to make everybody happy. That's how I've kept the respect of the committee. They know I won't be a flack without policy reasons."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The economy of the Hartford district that sends Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, Democrat of Connecticut, to Congress depends heavily on the insurance industry. But Mrs. Kennelly, the highest-ranking woman in the House, has voted repeatedly for health insurance changes that are likely to anger some constituents, even as she has pushed for changes that will protect insurance companies. (Karin Anderson for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "DIARY: Health Care Developments"
 
YESTERDAY
 
CONGRESS
 
The House
 The Ways and Means Committee, the most influential House committee in the health care debate, passed a measure meeting President Clinton's goal of universal coverage and requiring employers to pay most of the cost of insuring their workers. But the margin of victory was slim, 20-18, and strictly along party lines, suggesting that passage of a similar measure in the full House would require party discipline it will be difficult for Democrats to maintain.
 Republicans engineered a vote on Clinton's original 1,342-page Health Security Act. After an occasionally angry debate, 19 Democrats voted present; 3 Democrats and all 14 Republicans voted no.
 
The Senate
 In a blow to the White House, the Finance Committee rejected a plan proposed by its chairman, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, that would have required employers to provide coverage to workers if changes in insurance regulations did not produce universal coverage by 1999.
 Instead, it adopted by a vote of 12-8, a proposal to let a National Health Commission recommend remedies to Congress if 95 percent of Americans are not insured by 2002. The plan would seek to force Congress to vote on any recommendations.
 On this issue and on others, the committee reluctantly followed proposals made Friday by a bipartisan group headed by Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican, and John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat.
 
The White House
 President Clinton called the Ways and Means Committee's action "a giant stride forward."
 He attacked a proposal by Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, that would alter insurance regulation and offer some subsidies to make insurance easier to obtain and more affordable for the very poor. Mr. Dole's proposal, supported by 39 of the 44 Senate Republicans, "is politics as usual," Mr. Clinton said today.

HEADLINE: Victory Over the Doubters;
Once, Whitman's Budget Plan Was Ridiculed. Now Other Governors Follow Her Lead.

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 30

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman, the Governor of New Jersey, has an admirer who will never vote for her -- unless she runs for President.
It's George E. Pataki, the Putnam County State Senator and Republican aspirant for governor in New York. Mr. Pataki is consulting with Mrs. Whitman on campaign issues and has all but embraced her program as his own. 
 A New York pol crossing the Hudson seeking advice? What more satisfying tribute could a Jersey governor ask?
"She's doing the right thing, she's doing it well, and it's something that we're going to have to emulate," Mr. Pataki declared. Even Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, seeking a fourth term, has adopted a Whitmanesque kindliness to business as a mantra.
 
'It's About Keeping Promises'
 In her first year, Mrs. Whitman has delivered the cuts in taxes, state spending and state agencies that have made her a role model for Republicans across the country as well as across the river. In the 38 races for governor under way this year, Republicans and even some Democrats are campaigning on similar platforms. Governor Whitman did not create this new tide in American politics, but she was quick to capture the wave.
Today, as she signed her first state budget into law, flanked by the Legislature's Republican majority leadership, Governor Whitman wasted no time in declaring victory over the scoffers and doubters who nine months ago, as she campaigned for governor, disparaged her proposed budget cuts as irresponsible and undoable.
"This budget is about doing what I said I would do," Governor Whitman declared at the signing. "It's about keeping promises."
Other governors have imitated Mrs. Whitman's politics and policies right down to the catch phrases. "Virginia is open for business," Gov. George F. Allen intoned before a Republican audience two weeks ago, five months after Mrs. Whitman had made "New Jersey is open for business" her slogan. On the stage with Mr. Allen, she could only smile.
"She's leading the parade," said Steven D. Gold, an expert on state government at the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute in Albany. "She's the new kid on the block, and her ideas that government needs to be smaller and smarter sound right to people."
 
Other States Consider Cuts
 As late as last September, the state's first female Governor was being written off by the political establishment as a stumbling, amateurish candidate, clutching at an outlandish plan to slash state taxes. But following in her wake, at least 19 other states, including Connecticut and New York, have enacted or are considering tax cuts this year, Mr. Gold's research indicates. Eleven of the states are headed by Republican governors.
Mrs. Whitman's $15.3 billion budget reduces income taxes by 10 percent, or $285 million, the first full installment of her promised, and once much derided, 30 percent rate cut over three years. It cuts 400 state jobs, out of 65,000, and eliminates the Department of Higher Education, freeing state colleges to be more self-governing, and the Office of the Public Advocate, which represented citizens suing the state.
By all accounts, it was the easiest installment to deliver. Jim Florio, her Democrat predecessor, helped by leaving a $400 million surplus. And stymied by a Republican legislature, he also hurt by borrowing heavily to finance his initiatives. The state's direct debt service will more than quadruple to $400 million next year.
On her way to today's achievement, Governor Whitman rolled over feeble objections from the Democratic minorities in both legislative houses, who voted in bloc against the spending plan but never found an effective way to oppose tax cuts. She ignored noisy protests by public employee unions, which predict that her reductions in state pension financing will haunt future governors and future taxpayers. Indeed, she may have welcomed the protests as reinforcing her image as a fighter against entrenched interests.
 
'Will Have to Be Paid Back'
 Some people nevertheless believe the state employees had a point.
"She is stealing from the pension fund, which will have to be paid back by future governors who will have to be braver than she is," said Richard C. Leone, a Democrat and former New Jersey State Treasurer. In effect, he said, since by law Mrs. Whitman could not propose a state budget in deficit, she bridged the gap by diverting pension contributions.
"I do not think it shows you anything about character or philosophy to do popular things without doing the unpopular things that pay the bills," added Mr. Leone, who headed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey during Governor Florio's term.
Mrs. Whitman, of course, has heard for nine months the charge that her economics do not add up, beginning with the chorus of derision that greeted her original tax cut proposal last September.
Business leaders, now her champions, then worried that the tax cuts would simply shift taxes to localities -- and that yet may happen. Newspapers editorialized against the program as shabby electioneering. Mr. Florio, who had sharply increased taxes to cover a looming shortfall and help the cities, derided his opponent by waving her three-page tax cut program in the breeze as a visual proof of its insubstantiality.
Studiously gracious, Mrs. Whitman spurns any credit for the wave of tax-cutting that grips the imaginations of so many politicians. She notes that two other Republican Governors, William F. Weld of Massachusetts and John M. Engler of Michigan, preceded her in trimming spending. In fact, Mr. Gold pointed out, states frequently cut tax rates as their economies recover from recession, as is occurring now, just as they raise taxes to cover income shortfalls during recessions.
 
A Center of National Attention
 "For a while, New York was to some extent protected from further job losses because of Florio's tax increases, which made business take a second look at moving to New Jersey," Mr. Pataki said. "Governor Whitman's emphasis on economic competitiveness is going to restore New Jersey's edge, and I think it just makes it clear that if we want to restore economic competitiveness in New York, we will at least have to follow suit."
With her iron-clad ideas and air of faint amusement at the interest she has excited, Mrs. Whitman becomes a center of attention at national events like the National Governor's Association meetings in Washington. When the governors meet in July in Boston, she is expected to play a prominent role.
She is seen as moderate on social issues, a supporter of abortion rights, proudly but pleasantly feminist, a personable campaigner from a midsize industrial state. Her name has begun to pop up in Republican discussions of future national tickets. Though she publicly scoffs at that ambition, she has done nothing to discourage her national prominence. She has been a frequent guest on Washington political talk shows, and George Will, the conservative columnist, ventured to Trenton to extol her philosophy.
 
A Powell-Whitman Ticket?
 This talk got louder when William Kristol, the Republican Party theoretician, proposed pairing Mrs. Whitman as vice president with retired General Colin L. Powell at the head of a Republican "dream" presidential ticket.
In May, when the General and the Governor addressed a business conference in Princeton, General Powell joked, "Let's see, am I supposed to call you, or are you supposed to call me?" Later the General sent Mrs. Whitman a note, saying he had enjoyed the meeting -- and included his telephone number.
Mrs. Whitman, who has campaigned for Republican tickets going back to 1952 (as a young girl, she sold lemonade to benefit Dwight Eisenhower and Richard Nixon), is a walking melange of modern Republicanism. Relaxed and approachable, she combines the assurance of a Nelson A. Rockefeller with the minimalist-government religion of Ronald Reagan. On occasion her complicated syntax brings back memories of President Eisenhower.
Mrs. Whitman, whose inner circle is notably but not exclusively female, has brought more women into the state's executive branch than any previous governor. Her staff says she is easy to work with, rarely vexed, though that ease may reflect the on-stage amiability that is second nature to a woman who was raised in wealth and who cherishes such freedom and privacy as public life permits, sometimes eluding her state trooper security escort. She spends most nights at home on her farm in Somerset, rather than in the governor's mansion outside Princeton.
 
Policy Off the Cuff
 Mrs. Whitman has won all this prominence less than six months into what is only her second elected office. She was once a Somerset County freeholder. She has yet to do enough in public life, good or bad, to reveal a genuine political philosophy. As Governor, she sometimes seems to create policy off the cuff, as she did when she responded to anti-Semitic remarks by a Nation of Islam leader by suggesting that everyone see "Schindler's List," a movie about the Holocaust.
As yet, she has experienced no state crisis acute enough to test her equanimity, her canniness or her command over the gears of government. No one in the Legislature seems to fear her. No legislator has yet tested whatever appetite she might have for getting even. In surveys, her approval ratings are high and notably few voters voice disapproval of her performance.
Mrs. Whitman has never presented herself as a political intellectual. Her stance on answering New Jersey's problems with enduring economic development is garden-variety suburban Republicanism: "One of the reasons this is an expensive state for business is, obviously, that we're heavily unionized, which has been very successful in protecting union membership but that also has a cost in doing business," the Governor said in an interview this week.
"We're also the most densely populated state, our property costs are high, and we've had this attitude that we can be even tougher than the national Government on some regulations, which unfortunately has not resulted in something that is better for the population of the state."
As for her goals -- and for next year's budget plan, the first that will be entirely her own -- Mrs. Whitman often reaches for the opaque language of corporate management and big-business Republicanism, a world where she and her family, with its considerable wealth, are quite comfortable.
"I won't call it reinventing government, because that's overused," she said when asked to look ahead. "It's reconstituting government, putting departments on performance-based budgeting, starting to set goals, making intelligent programmatic choices. All of those initiatives have got to be part of the overall direction of this administration."
At the same time, the Governor will face new problems that will make squeezing another quarter-billion dollars in income tax cuts all the harder. Not only will the state's debt payments quadruple in the coming year, but the deadline for compliance with Federal clean air rules (which New Jersey is far from achieving) also approaches, and state courts are expected to order a large increase in state aid to urban school districts.

HEADLINE: Ferrer Urges HUD to Revise Aid Plan in Bronx's Favor

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Making an end run around Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a powerful Harlem Congressman, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx appealed directly to the Clinton Administration yesterday to include more of the Bronx in an "empowerment zone" New York City has proposed as a target area for Federal aid.
Mr. Ferrer's bid is a direct challenge to Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the fourth-ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee, who wrote the legislation creating the Federal empowerment-zone program and whose district is expected to benefit most from the grant it hopes to win. 
 Having failed to get the distressed Bronx neighborhoods of Mott Haven and Melrose included in the city's proposed empowerment zone, Mr. Ferrer and Jose E. Serrano, the Democratic Congressman who represents the South Bronx, asked Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to alter the New York officials' proposal -- which was the product of lengthy negotiations -- in favor of his own plan.
The request was seen yesterday as a brash gambit by Mr. Ferrer that mayoral aides said could scuttle New York's chances of getting any grant. Mr. Ferrer's proposal arrived in Washington on the deadline for cities to apply to the program. It came after months of negotiations among Mr. Rangel, Mayor Giuliani and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that produced the boundaries of the city's proposed empowerment zone.
 
Pressing His Case
 A spokesman for Mayor Giuliani, Forrest R. Taylor, said that if Mr. Ferrer persisted in pressing his case in Washington, "he runs the risk of creating confusion and thereby jeopardizing the entire city application when it arrives in Washington."
Mr. Taylor said that before Mr. Giuliani became Mayor the agreement between Mr. Rangel and then-Mayor David N. Dinkins included none of the Bronx in the empowerment zone. Mr. Giuliani reopened the discussions to include the area around Yankee Stadium and the industrial strips of Port Morris and Hunts Point, giving the Bronx about 16 percent of the proposed zone.
Mr. Rangel brushed aside Mr. Ferrer's bid for the attention of Washington officials. "I drafted the legislation," he said. "These are not applications in which borough presidents and city councilmen can say, 'Include me.' "
Mr. Ferrer noted that the announcement of the awards was expected just around the time Mr. Rangel was up for re-election. And Mr. Rangel, in turn, suggested that Mr. Ferrer, who is often mentioned as a possible mayoral contender, might simply be seeking media attention with his proposal.
But Mr. Ferrer said he was simply trying to stick up for the Bronx. And he said he thought he was making headway with Mr. Cisneros and officials in the Housing Secretary's office, with whom he said he had had frequent discussions.
"My impression is they are very receptive to the fact that the poorest of the poor are being left out," he said.
Mr. Ferrer said that the zone proposed by the city included the area around the home of the richest franchise in baseball, but not the most distressed neighborhoods in the Bronx.
As with Mr. Rangel, there was flexing of political prowess by Mr. Ferrer yesterday.
Ticking off his recent successes -- the resurrection of a dying plan to build a new police academy in the Bronx and the staving off of a city attempt to alter the design of a large housing development in the Bronx -- Mr. Ferrer suggested that he was on a roll that might continue with a victory in the empowerment-zone fight.
"I'm beginning to think the Yankees are having a good season," Mr. Ferrer said. "I'm beginning to think I'm having a pretty good season too. I doesn't hurt to have the merits on your side."
The Federal Empowerment Zone program is the centerpiece of the Clinton Administration's urban redevelopment agenda. Under that program, the Federal Government will designate six urban areas in the country as eligible for $100 million each in social-service grants and tax breaks for employers who hire local residents.
In Mr. Ferrer's proposal to Mr. Cisneros -- which is backed up with three bound volumes of data, maps and community comments -- the Borough President asks that neighborhoods with about 25,000 people to be included in the zone.
That would mean either taking some areas of Harlem and the Yankee Stadium area out of the zone, or waiving the 200,000-person limit set by the Federal Government for each empowerment zone. Under Mr. Ferrer's proposal, the number of Bronx residents covered by the zone would increase to 59,000 from 33,000.
In applying for the zone designations, officials were asked to design a strategy to address a range of problems, including employment, the environment, housing and recreation. In New York, the Federal funds intended for the empowerment zone are expected to be supplemented by $100 million each from the city and the state.
Yesterday, the state seemed to be one player in the equation not miffed by Mr. Ferrer's action. Alan Sullivan, the executive deputy director of the State Department of Economic Development, said the state would be happy if the Federal Government waived the 200,000-person limit and if the zone could include both Mr. Ferrer's request and Mr. Rangel.
Mr. Sullivan said he was not offended by Mr. Ferrer's request. "Freddie's an effective communicator and he wants to communicate directly with the people who are making the decisions," he said. "Who can tell Freddie what to say?"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Drop To Nearly 6-Week Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday to their lowest in nearly six weeks after stronger-than-expected economic data and a continuing slide in the dollar.
The economic reports, which showed faster growth, renewed concerns of rising inflation and higher interest rates. The selling of government securities intensified as the dollar was again battered in the global currency markets, said traders. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 11/32 , to 846/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.61 percent, from 7.50 percent on Wednesday, and the highest since May 9, when it was 7.63 percent. The long bond's yield, however, is still in its three-month trading range, traders noted. But it is close.
 
Speculation of a Rate Rise
 Greg Jones, an economist for MMS International, a market research and analysis firm, said the economic data and weakness in the dollar raised speculation of an iminent interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
"While the reports themselves were in fact stronger than expected, they were not terrible," he said. "Some price components captured the market's attention and raised the concern of some investors about future inflation." For instance, the Purchasing Management Association of Chicago report's index of manufacturing fell to 65.6 in June from 67.3 in May and 67.6 in April. The association's June index of prices paid by manufacturers surged to 69.7 from 63.6 in May. Analysts say a reading of above 50 is consistent with economic expansion.
The combination of continued strength in the purchasing management report, and the Conference Board's help wanted index, up 6 points in May to 123, which made some people nervous about next week's employment report, helped to keep bonds on the defensive.
Mr. Jones said an increase in interest rates by the Fed would come sooner, rather than later, and the increase could be as much as 50 basis points. "Our bet has been for a 25- basis-point hike, but the dollar's weakness has increased the risk of a 50-basis-point hike," he said. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Much of the weakness in bonds yesterday was caused by investors and dealers trading on expectations of what could happen next week. The Fed's policy-making committee meets on Tuesday and Wednesday, and the employment report for June will be released on Friday, which should give a clue about the strength of the economy.
In addition to the strength in some economic data, Treasury prices also came under pressure from a jump in precious metals, which pushed the Commodity Research Bureau index, a basket of 21 commodity prices, up by 1.01 point, to 230.39. Oil prices surged as the war in Yemen threatened to disrupt production and supplies. The Public Securities Association, the main trade group for the public debt industry, recommended that the government securities market close at 2 P.M. today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday.
Elsewhere, municipal bonds were little changed or lower, with investors holding back from making any purchases while Treasury prices are on the decline. Traders said many investors were even hesitant about selling with a drop in supply expected.
The Bond Buyer reported yesterday that the amount of new tax-exempt bonds scheduled to be sold in the next 30 days was down to $2.49 billion, the lowest this year.

HEADLINE: Incomes in U.S. Advanced by 0.6% in May

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The income of Americans rose for the fourth consecutive month in May and spending nearly kept pace, the Government said today. A separate report showed that factory orders increased for the month.
The reports, along with the latest data on claims for jobless benefits, demonstrated that the economy expanded at a comfortable pace this spring, analysts said. 
 "The basic message is that the economy has downshifted to a slower growth pace," said Robert Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "I think the consumer will come back. But the great spurt is behind us."
The Commerce Department reported that Americans' personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May -- as it did in April -- helped by job growth, a longer average workweek and higher hourly earnings.
Consumer spending increased four-tenths of 1 percent, slightly higher than anticipated, after dipping a revised four-tenths of 1 percent in April. Spending, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, has risen in 12 of the last 14 months.
Incomes rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.71 trillion in May from $5.67 trillion in April. Spending was up to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.61 trillion from $4.59 trillion.
Disposable income -- income after taxes -- rose 1.2 percent above the April rate. April's figure was down because of a new Federal law that required the wealthiest Americans to make retroactive tax payments by April 15 of about $30 billion at an annual rate.
The combination of incomes and spending meant that Americans' savings rate -- savings as a percentage of disposable income -- climbed to 4.7 percent in May from 3.9 percent in April. But analysts said the latest figure was misleading because of the timing of the tax payments.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said today that the number of initial applications for state unemployment benefits was unchanged last week from the previous week. A seasonally adjusted 353,000 people filed first-time claims in the week that ended on June 25.
"Once again, the economic data indicate the U.S. economy is not overheating but instead growing at a pace consistent with stable inflation," Donald Straszheim and Bruce Steinberg, economists with Merrill Lynch & Company, said in a statement.
In the manufacturing sector, the Commerce Department said orders to United States factories rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May, after a revised two-tenths of 1 percent increase in April.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Investors Finance a Trump Project

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
A group of Hong Kong investors stepped in yesterday with the money that Donald J. Trump needs to begin building the first towers of Riverside South, a project that could profoundly alter the Upper West Side of Manhattan by creating homes for thousands of wealthy residents on what is now an abandoned riverfront rail yard.
Construction could start within a year, Mr. Trump said yesterday after he signed a financing deal and joint-venture agreement with a consortium that includes the New World Development Company Ltd., headed by Y. T. Cheng and his son, Henry, and the Shui On Group Ltd., headed by Vincent Lo. 
 "Now, we're at the really productive level," Mr. Trump said, 10 years after he took control of the 75-acre site along the Hudson River, from 59th to 72d Street.
The new "multi-billion-dollar joint venture" -- the partners would be no more specific about the amounts of money involved -- represents a high-profile plunge into the New York market by Hong Kong investors.
"We've traveled to various cities," said Daniel K. S. Yiu, president of Polylinks International Ltd. of Hong Kong, which advises private and public companies, including New World. "With all the potential, the people, the demographics, we really think that New York can't be substituted."
Their arrival is not only crucial for Mr. Trump, who has been struggling to emerge from millions of dollars of debt, but is also a "solid vote of confidence in New York City," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said.
"Development of Riverside South will mean the creation of thousands of construction jobs at a time when that industry is at nearly 50 percent unemployment," Mr. Giuliani said in a statement released by his press office. "It will create thousands of permanent jobs and will brings hundreds of millions of dollars in sales and other tax revenues to the city."
Mr. Trump and his new partners said no final decision had been made on which parcels would be developed first, or how many. For now, they said, they are contemplating a mix of rental buildings and one condominium tower for the opening phase.
Under plans approved by city officials in 1992, there may ultimately be 5,700 apartments in 16 towers. At least 12 percent of the housing must be set aside for moderate- and low-income residents. There would be 1.8 million square feet of commercial space at the southern end of the site. A waterfront park would be built in phases, along with construction of the towers.
"We have no intention whatsoever of changing the original plans," Mr. Yiu said.
 
Money Talks, but Quietly
 The developers would not disclose anything about the amounts of money involved in yesterday's deal, citing a confidentiality agreement with the Chase Manhattan Bank, which holds the mortgage on the property. Mr. Trump would say only, "Essentially the mortgage has been purchased by this group, so we don't have any debt."
Mr. Yiu said the Polylinks group was formed a little over a year ago to look for investment opportunities in the United States, particularly in New York, San Francisco and Honolulu. New World bought the Renaissance hotel chain in 1989 and the Stouffer hotel chain last year.
"We put more of a focus on New York," Mr. Yiu said. He said Polylinks has already purchased large blocks of condominium apartments in Park Avenue Court, at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street, and the Horizon, at First Avenue and 37th Street.
Because of the size of Riverside South, Polylinks sought other investors as well, including Shui On, a diversified company involved in hotels, construction and development; the Edward Wong Group, and the Far Eastern Consortium Ltd., whose holdings include the Warwick Hotel, at Avenue of the Americas and 54th Street.
Frankie Y. L. Wong, a group managing director of Shui On, attended yesterday's signing, along with Mr. Yiu. Afterward, he said: "New York is coming out of the recession. So is the United States. We see a big potential for property development."
When asked what attracted Shui On to Riverside South, Mr. Wong simply pointed across the room to Mr. Trump. "You see him there," he said.
But Mr. Wong also said the sheer size of Riverside South made it unusual. "You don't find such large-scale projects easily in New York or in the United States," he said.
Until the arrival of the Hong Kong investors, it was not exactly clear how Mr. Trump would realize his $3 billion vision for the old Penn Yards site, given the debt he was carrying.
But yesterday, he said he was "just about finished" retiring that debt, crediting in part the income from his Atlantic City casinos and hotels, which he said "have broken every record" in the last two years.
For Riverside South, Mr. Trump and his partners may take advantage of the "80-20" mixed-income housing program. Tax-exempt bonds are available to finance projects in which 20 percent of the units are set aside for lower-income tenants, with the other 80 percent available at market rates.
Mr. Trump's original plan for the site was something far grander: Trump City, which was to have had 7,600 apartments, a regional shopping mall and the tallest building in the world.
This highly unpopular proposal was withdrawn in 1991, after Mr. Trump entered into an unusual alliance with several civic, neighborhood and environmental groups, including the Municipal Art Society and the Parks Council: the very people he had been battling over Trump City. Under the name Riverside South Planning Corporation, this alliance devised the new plan.
Although Riverside South was opposed by the local community board and the local Councilwoman, Ronnie M. Eldridge, it was approved by Borough President Ruth W. Messinger and the City Planning Commission. It passed the City Council in December 1992.
The executive director of the Parks Council, Linda Davidoff, said about yesterday's deal: "The financial wizardry involved is beyond my ken. But the net result -- that an investor is prepared to build -- is thrilling and a great step forward in building a new and marvelous waterfront on the West Side of Manhattan."
There are still many critics of the project. Among their concerns is that Riverside South would add to the already overtaxed North River Sewage Treatment Plant in Harlem. A group led by the Coalition for a Livable West Side has filed suit in Federal court seeking to prevent further hookups to the North River sewage treatment plant and another one on Wards Island.
Mr. Yiu said yesterday that the investors had reached "a certain comfort level that this issue can be resolved over time as the project moves along."
Mr. Wong added that "city officials have already done a lot to reduce the flow, so there is a lot of capacity."

HEADLINE: U.S. Closer to End of Ban On Alaska Oil Exports

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration moved closer yesterday to recommending that the ban on exporting oil from the North Slope of Alaska be lifted, issuing a study that showed that such exports would create jobs and stimulate domestic production.
Hazel R. O'Leary, the Secretary of Energy, cautioned, however, that some trade issues would first have to be resolved before Congress could be asked to lift the 1973 ban. 
 The study by the Energy Department concluded that if the ban was lifted, Alaskan crude could be exported to Asian nations -- Japan, in particular -- creating thousands of jobs and stimulating new investment and production in Alaska and California. These gains could be attained without increasing gasoline prices on the West Coast, the report said.
 
Looking to Japan for Sales
 Japan, which imports all its oil at the rate of about 4.38 million barrels a day, would be the most likely foreign customer of Alaskan crude, the report said.
"The energy and economic issues clearly compel lifting the ban," Mrs. O'Leary said.
Yesterday's statements were the strongest yet from the Secretary in favor of lifting the ban, which she described as an "economic anomaly" left over from the energy crisis of 1973. The Administration has indicated in the past that it supports lifting the ban, and in a recent meeting with lawmakers from energy states, President Clinton said he would favor ending the ban if trade issues could be resolved.
Mrs. O'Leary said the Administration would have to resolve whether the exported oil would continue to be shipped on American vessels, using American crews, as required by law. Such a requirement, aimed at preserving maritime jobs, could complicate attempts by the Administration to ease trade restrictions with other nations.
The 1973 ban was included in the law authorizing the construction of the Alaskan pipeline and was aimed at cutting the nation's dependence on imported oil. Limiting the oil for domestic use was also a concession to environmentalists, who had opposed the pipeline.
But the chief effect of the ban, yesterday's report said, has been to provide California refiners with crude oil cheaper than oil on the world market. The Deputy Energy Secretary, William H. White, said yesterday that the ban created "a subsidy" for California refiners that had not been passed on to consumers.
Lifting the ban would raise Alaska crude prices to world market levels, which should attract investment to Alaska's oil fields, where production has been falling.
The Energy Department said it was concerned about the increasing loss of jobs in the domestic energy industry as many oil companies have been and are cutting back on domestic production and shifting investment into exploration abroad.
Lifting the ban is expected to help in particular small independent oil refiners in California, which buy crude on the open market.
Carol Currie, a spokeswoman for the California Independent Petroleum Association, a trade group, said that the smaller producers have lost about 32,000 jobs in the last nine years.
Some oil economists and California refiners have challenged the assumption that the price of crude would rise in California if the ban on exports from the North Slope of Alaska is lifted. They have argued that there is now little difference between the world price and prices for crude coming from California fields.
The Energy Department's study also found that no environmental problems would be created by lifting the ban. It noted that the Clinton Administration remained firm in opposing exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

HEADLINE: Bail Denied In Slaying Of 2 Children

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., June 30

 BODY:
A father charged with slaying his two children while they were on a weekend visit to his home pleaded not guilty today in New Jersey Superior Court here.
Judge Sybil Moses ordered the father, Avi Kostner, 50, of Teaneck, held without bail. She denied bail because, she said, John J. Fahy, the Bergen County prosecutor, is considering seeking the death penalty if Mr. Kostner is convicted. 
 Law-enforcement officials are exploring the possibility that the children were drugged before they were slain, Mr. Fahy said. He said further tests were being done to determine if they were drugged.
He said the bodies of the children, Geri Beth Kostner, 12, and her brother Ryan, 10, showed no sign of injury or struggle, suggesting they were unconscious when they were killed by suffocation last Sunday.
Autopsies have determined that Geri Beth was murdered about 4 A.M. and Ryan at 1 P.M. Their bodies were found about 9 P.M. Sunday under a sleeping bag in the rear seat of an Isuzu Trooper parked behind the Teaneck Police Headquarters. Their father was at the wheel.
 
Treated for Depression
 Mr. Kostner is unemployed and under treatment for depression.
During his brief arraignment, Mr. Kostner's eyes welled up for a few seconds and he sniffed twice. But he remained calm and composed during the hearing and answered "Yes" firmly to Judge Moses' questions about his understanding of his legal rights. The judge also ordered a psychiatric evaluation.
Mr. Kostner's acquaintances have said he was disturbed that his former wife, Lynn Mison, of Wayne, N.J., had planned to move to Florida with the children on July 1. Since Mr. Kostner and Ms. Mison were divorced in 1988, they have fought in the courts about custody, visiting rights, child support and how the children would be raised.
Whether the children were suffocated with bare hands or with a plastic bag, pillow or other object remains uncertain, Mr. Fahy said. Where the children were killed and their whereabouts in the hours before their deaths also remains a mystery, Mr. Fahy said.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Tumble; Dow Skids 42.09

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market closed mixed, but sharply lower for blue-chip stocks yesterday, as the turbulent second quarter ended and Wall Street professionals headed out of town for the long Fourth of July weekend.
Bond yields approached the record-high levels of May, coaxing money away from stocks and exacerbating the fall in stock prices. 
 Other factors were also at work. Commodities prices rose, inflaming traders' inflation fears, and the dollar continued to fall against the yen, discouraging foreign investors.
 
Bonds More Appealing
 But with the leap of the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 7.61 percent, fixed-income instruments are now an attractive alternative to stocks.
"I can just see people calling in on their cellular phones from the Hamptons," a popular weekend spot for New Yorkers, said Harrison Roth, senior options strategist for Cowen & Company. "They ask how the long bond is doing and they yell, 'What do you mean it's 7.6!' "
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 42.09 points, to 3,624.96, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index declined 3.36 points, to 444.27. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 1.95 points, to 705.96.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was about normal, with 293.4 million shares changing hands, but the volume may have been lifted by the expiration of a variety of stock options tied to the S.& P. 500. Exercising options requires the purchase or sale of shares.
In connection with the options expiration, the New York Stock Exchange counted large sell-side order imbalances for at least six companies, the largest of which was United Healthcare, at 1.5 million shares.
United Healthcare, an operator of health maintenance organizations, was the exchange's most-active stock yesterday, with 8.4 million shares changing hands. Its price dropped 2 3/4, to 45 1/8; other H.M.O. stocks like U.S. Healthcare fell as well.
The industry fears an "any willing provider" provision passed by the House Ways and Means committee yesterday, which might hurt the industry's ability to control costs by restricting access to select doctors and hospitals.
 
CBS Soars on Merger Talk
 Blue-chips stocks like I.B.M. and conglomerates like Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing fell. But over-the-counter stocks like Microsoft and QVC Network rose.
CBS, which is negotiating a merger with QVC , saw its shares rise 50, to 313, after an initial delay in the trading of its stock.
The dollar continued its fall. It declined to another post-1945 low of 98.49 yen, from 98.80 yen at the close in New York on Wednesday. But it rose to 1.5875 German marks from 1.5855 marks. While stock traders, at least for now, do not seem as concerned as before about the dollar, it remains important. A weak dollar makes dollar-denominated assets like stocks less attractive, particularly to foreigners.
The Commodity Research Bureau index rose 1.01 points, to 230.39, led by rising futures contracts for silver, cocoa, and copper. Also, crude oil set for August delivery rose 54 cents, to $19.37 a barrel, in part because of a civil war in Yemen that might disrupt that country's modest output of oil. The demand for crude oil is rising.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.56 points, from 245.16, with declining stocks outnumbering advancers, 1,275 to 951. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.60 point, to 424.08.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 25 fell, led by Caterpillar, which dropped 2 1/8, to 100. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 313 fell, led by General Electric, which fell 1, to 46 5/8.

HEADLINE: $2.7 Billion Merger for Big Railroads

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
In a move that would create the nation's largest railroad, Burlington Northern Inc. and the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation yesterday announced a plan to merge. The new railroad, with a reach even more expansive than its name, would be called the Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Railway Company.
The proposed merger calls for a stock swap valued at $2.7 billion. The owners of Santa Fe and Burlington Northern stock must approve the transaction. The deal must also be approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission, which may not make a decision until late next year at the earliest. 
 The merger would create a company with more than $7.1 billion of revenue and 31,000 miles of track in the Midwest, Southeast and West. The companies have not determined how their combined 45,000 employees would be affected or where the combined company would be based.
 
 
A Merger Trend
 The two companies' desire to join forces adds new life to a consolidation trend that has reshaped the railroad industry since it was deregulated in 1980. In an effort to cut costs, many railroads have merged to achieve economies of scale and more efficient operations that cover vast swaths of the country.
"Ever since we have been deregulated, we sink or swim based on our product, and customers want as broad a product range as possible," said Robert D. Krebs, the chairman of Santa Fe who would be president and chief executive of the merged company. The parent of the merged railroads would be called the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation.
Gerald Grinstein, chairman and chief executive of Burlington Northern, would be chairman of the merged company.
Industry analysts said the two railroads would help each other in several ways. Santa Fe, based in Schaumburg, Ill., specializes in intermodal services, which involves moving goods by rail to be delivered locally by truck. That business is growing fast but has low profit margins. Burlington Northern, based in Fort Worth, carries heavy commodities like coal, grain and timber, a business with higher margins but slower growth.
"It's a complementary mix for both entities," said Thomas M. Galvin, a transportation stock analyst at C. J. Lawrence.
Santa Fe's rail lines also stretch into Mexico and Burlington Northern also operates in Canada, thus brightening the combined company's prospects for winning business from customers taking advantage of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
 
'Little Overlap'
 "The combination of Burlington Northern and Santa Fe is a predominantly end-to-end merger that will benefit shippers and the public," Mr. Grinstein said. "There is very little overlap between our rail systems." That fact improves the companies' chances of winning approval from the commerce commission, analysts said.
The Union Pacific Railroad Company, based in Omaha, is currently the nation's largest railroad, with $4.85 billion in revenues last year.
The most recent attempted railroad merger of comparable size was in 1983, when Santa Fe sought to buy the Southern Pacific Company in a stock swap valued at $5.2 billion. The commerce commission reviewed the application for five years, then rejected the proposed merger on antitrust grounds.
Yesterday, Standard & Poor's raised its ratings outlook on Santa Fe and Burlington Northern and on their railroads to "positive" from "stable," citing the broader and more diversified commodity mix of the combined companies. Shares of Burlington Northern fell 12.5 cents, to $53.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Santa Fe shares rose 25 cents, to $20.625.
 
 
Another Railroad for Sale
 For now, the two railroads' decision removes them from consideration as the most likely suitors for Kansas City Southern, the nation's 12th-largest railroad. Its parent, Kansas City Southern Industries, said in May that it was considering selling its railroad so it could focus more on mutual funds and other financial services. Mr. Krebs and Mr. Grinstein said yesterday that they would be too focused on shepherding their merger proposal to consider other possible acquisitions.
Mr. Krebs said Santa Fe had been considering a merger partner for more than two years out of concern that it lacked the geographical coverage to be competitive as the industry evolved.
Burlington Northern was the first choice because of its route network, but Santa Fe had been hamstrung in pursuing a merger until recently because it operated a gold subsidiary that Burlington Northern did not want. Santa Fe recently spun off that subsidiary.
The executives said there had been little discussion about which railroad's name would come first in the new company's name. After all, Burlington Northern is about twice the size of Santa Fe.
"It really wasn't an item of disagreement," Mr. Grinstein said. "We didn't even flip a coin."

HEADLINE: 30 Drown as Haitian Police Fire on Refugees

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 30

 BODY:
A police launch fired on a 60-foot boat carrying Haitian refugees early Wednesday, causing a panic in which at least 30 refugees drowned, two foreign journalists said today.
The journalists, Edward J. Barnes of Time magazine and Simon Dring of the BBC, who arrived at the scene Wednesday afternoon, said witnesses had told them that most of the victims were women and children. 
 Mr. Barnes, quoting witnesses, said just three shots from four policemen riding in a motor launch caused the panic. The refugee boat capsized about 300 yards offshore from Nan L'Etat, about 15 miles east of Les Cayes, a southern port.
[Mr. Barnes's report was circulated on Thursday by America On Line as part of Time Daily, a news bulletin prepared by Time magazine. According to the report, monitored in New York by Reuters, the refugees were among about 400 Haitians waiting in surrounding coves for boats that would take them to sea.
["The boat people froze in fear," the report said. "The refugees tried to stay quiet and hide, hoping the boat would pass. Then three shots rang out in the darkness and there was chaos," with panicky passengers pushed others into the water. The boom on the refugees' boat broke free, knocking women and children into the sea.]
 
No Confirmation
 There was no independent confirmation of the account.
It was the first reported instance of soldiers trying to stop a refugee vessel since the surge in boat people began a week ago. Since then about 4,700 Haitians have been intercepted at sea by Coast Guard cutters and Navy warships; at least 1,056 were picked up today, a Coast Guard spokesman, Rob Wyman said.
Most of the 38 boats intercepted today were off Haiti's southern peninsula, he added.
The military-backed Government threatened in May to arrest anyone leaving on a refugee vessel. On May 21, about 50 people in Petit-Goave, 40 miles west of Port-au-Prince, were arrested when they tried to board a boat and flee. Others have been arrested on La Gonave, an island that is another common departure point.
 
50,000 Boat People
 More than 50,000 Haitians have been intercepted at sea by the Coast Guard since the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was overthrown in September 1991. Father Aristide, who lives in exile in Washington, said this week that he could not restrain Haitians from fleeing the military repression in Haiti, which he called "a house on fire."
Intensified economic sanctions on Haiti and a new, liberalized Clinton administration refugee policy may have provoked the refugee wave.
The Coast Guard, backed by warships enforcing a trade embargo on Haiti, has deployed 15 cutters and patrol craft in its biggest operation since Vietnam. The Administration has repeatedly appealed to Haitians not to risk their lives at sea and to apply instead for asylum at United States consular offices in Haiti.
Before June 16, Haitian boat people were repatriated without a hearing to determine whether they were fleeing political repression. Criticism by human rights groups and increasing political violence prompted President Clinton to change the policy. Washington has moved the Navy hospital ship Comfort, with 1,000 beds for refugees, to Kingston, Jamaica, where refugees now get hearings.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Inching Toward a U.N. Force
 UNITED NATIONS, June 30 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Security Council tonight adopted a resolution that would prepare for an expanded international presence in Haiti if and when the United Nations thinks it necessary.
The resolution, adopted unanimously, did not specify how this would affect the military Government of Haiti, which would presumably have to leave if a large international force were to be landed.
The resolution was a result of more than a week of talks between United States officials and senior United Nations administrators. The chief United States delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, has met several times with Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
The United Nations currently has about 90 relief workers in Haiti.
The resolution also calls on Mr. Boutros-Ghali to report to the Security Council by July 15 on the need for further action.

HEADLINE: Japan's First Socialist Premier Appoints a Familiar Cabinet

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 30

 BODY:
Japan's new Socialist Prime Minister appointed a Cabinet today in which the most important positions went to members of the conservative Liberal Democratic Party, a signal that the new Government might not make radical departures from past policies.
The naming of the new Cabinet by the Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, helped quell some of the sense of panic that accompanied his election on Wednesday night by an almost unthinkable partnership of Socialists and Liberal Democrats. 
 Today, some of the Cabinet members, in their introductory news conferences, issued assurances that they would maintain continuity with the policies of previous Governments, particularly in foreign affairs. Mr. Murayama suggested to reporters on Wednesday night that he would not undo the reform of electoral system that was perhaps the most significant accomplishment of the previous governing coalition.
 
Cure for 'Murayama Shock'
 A sense of relief in the business sector, which had been aghast at the idea of a Socialist Prime Minister, was reflected in the Tokyo Stock Exchange. When trading opened, the market went into what one trader called "Murayama shock," with the Nikkei average quickly plunging more than 200 points. But by the end of the day the market had rebounded and closed at 20,643.93, up 162.93 Currency markets remained jittery, however, with the dollar closing at 98.95 yen, a new low for Tokyo.
In addition to being cheered by the news that the Cabinet would be dominated by the pro-business Liberal Democrats, stock market investors were encouraged that the Cabinet was formed so quickly, dispelling some fears that the new coalition would be marked by bitter infighting.
Still, many important policies, particularly concerning Japan's attitude toward the North Korean crisis and its willingness to cooperate with Washington militarily, remain in doubt. The new Cabinet members do not seem to place much priority on economic deregulation either. And many here think it is only a matter of time before the Socialists and the Liberal Democrats, who were archrivals for 40 years, are back at each other's throats.
In the new Cabinet, Yohei Kono, president of the Liberal Democratic Party, will be Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister. Ryutaro Hashimoto, a well-regarded Liberal Democratic Party stalwart who has had several Cabinet positions, was named to head the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. The new Finance Minister is Masayoshi Takemura, the chairman of the Harbinger Party, a smaller party that is also in the new coalition.
 
Donations and Doves
 The Socialists took control of the Construction Ministry, which regulates the industry that traditionally has been a huge contributor, sometimes illegally, to politicians.
Mr. Murayama had said he would create a "dovish" Cabinet, implying one that believed Japan should not change its pacifist Constitution and should not send troops abroad.
Mr. Kono, the Foreign Minister, and Mr. Takemura, the Finance Minister, fit that description. But Tokuichiro Tamazawa, the Liberal Democrat named to head the Defense Agency, had been a leader of the right-wing students in the 1960's when left-wingers were protesting the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty.
Asked today whether he was a dove, Mr. Tamazawa replied, "I consider myself a Japanese."
 
A More Traditional Look
 Morihiro Hosokawa, who was the first Prime Minister in 38 years who was not from the Liberal Democratic Party, had tried to shake up the formation of the Cabinet by giving seats to two people who were not members of Parliament. He also appointed three women to posts.
But the Murayama Cabinet is more traditional in look and formation. Jobs were apportioned to the various parties, and to the various factions within the Liberal Democratic Party, according to their numbers. In all the Liberal Democrats hold 13 seats, the Socialists 6, including the Prime Minister, and the Harbinger Party, 2.
There is only one woman in the Cabinet, Makiko Tanaka, the daughter of the late Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, who was disgraced for taking bribes from Lockheed Corporation. Miss Tanaka was named director general of the Science and Technology Agency.
Many of the appointments went to people who had played an active role in forging the partnership between the Socialists and Liberal Democrats.
 
Seeds of a Clash
 One appointment that could lead to a clash is that of Mr. Takemura as Finance Minister. The Government has promised to cut income taxes to stimulate its economy, a move sought by the United States as well as by Japanese corporations. The Finance Ministry believes that the lost revenues from the income tax reduction should be made up by increasing the sales tax.
But the Socialists are against a sales tax increase because it hurts the lower income people most. Mr. Takemura, when he served as the chief spokesman in Mr. Hosokawa's Cabinet, had objected to Mr. Hosokawa's decision to raise consumption taxes. Their split on that issue was the beginning of the rupture between the two former allies.
Today, Mr. Takemura expressed his opposition to raising sales taxes, saying the Government should first look at cutting Government spending to compensate for the income tax cut.
