HEADLINE: Russians in Estonia Feel Lost in a Baltic Limbo

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TALLINN, Estonia

 BODY:
They've turned off the eternal flame at the Soviet-built memorial to those who fought Fascism in World War II and long ago removed the plaques with the names of the dead for "cleaning."
Pavel K. Voronin, who commanded a Soviet antiaircraft battery during the war and retired from the army at the age of 65, seems shocked at everything in Estonia, once again sovereign, which is running toward the West as fast as it can. But the mothballed memorial appalls him. 
 "Now the Estonians say we shouldn't have bothered defending them, as if they would have preferred it under the Germans," Mr. Voronin said. "They're forgetting how much we helped them."
Of course Estonians don't recall the Soviet occupation with quite the same sense of gratitude. Many thousands of Estonians were killed or deported as Russians and other "loyal Slavs," like Mr. Voronin, were sent in to crush the Estonian state, dilute the population and hold the ground for the Soviet Union. Today, non-Estonians, most of them ethnic Russians, make up about 37 percent of the population of 1.6 million.
To make a gesture toward the plucky Baltic nations, President Clinton will stop in Riga, Latvia on July 6, the first American President to visit the Baltic republics since the collapse of the Soviet Union. He will find in Latvia a new furor over questions of citizenship and language rights of the ethnic Russian population that are so prevalent in Estonia.
 
Lost in the Translation
 Now 75, Mr. Voronin feels out of place in the new Estonia. But that's precisely the point; he's supposed to. In Soviet days, when asked by vacationing Russians for directions, Estonian residents of Tallinn would politely direct them, in the Russian they had to study, to the city dump.
Now, naturally enough, the Estonians have made their own language dominant, and Russians who want to become citizens must show a degree of competence in it. Written Russian is slowly disappearing from the streets of Tallinn, and English is now the favored second language for study in schools. There are some local Russian-language newspapers, but the main Russian television channel, Moscow-based Ostankino, is no longer available to everyone, supposedly because of the cost, though it is still offered to those 60 percent or so with cable.
"Younger Estonians really don't speak Russian any more," said Tarmu Tammerk, editor of The Baltic Independent newspaper. "It's quickly becoming a foreign language. Many choose not to learn it at all."
Nina V. Makarova, 61, is now studying Estonian to try to pass the citizenship exam, and said she feels stupid trying to learn a language at her age. But she never bothered before, and now she knows she must. There is anti-Russian sentiment, "but it's okay," she added, "so long as you don't watch television or read the newspapers."
 
Withered Bouquets
 Mr. Voronin's wife, Valentina, said: "We're no longer sure of ourselves here. I can ask for bread or rolls in Estonian in the shops." But that's about it, and the prices in the new, free-market Estonia frighten her. Her husband, who belongs to a club of army veterans, says most members come without their medals: "They're afraid to wear medals in public. People swear at them. They used to throw flowers at us. Now they throw words."
Still, despite the complaints, most Russians are coming to terms with the new Estonia, where nearly all have chosen to stay. Many ethnic Russians don't have any clear place to go in Russia, they say, but they also admit that this is a cleaner, more modern place to live just now than turbulent Russia, and the economy is in much better shape.
Nikolai A. Yugantsev, 44, is head of the Representative Association of the Russian-Speaking Population, with offices at the Tallinn Garrison's Officers Club. He says that only about 48,000 ethnic Russians in Estonia have opted to become Russian citizens, while some 65,000 were already entitled to Estonian citizenship even though not all have taken it. The rest are dangling between the two countries or planning to naturalize.
After the breakup of the Soviet Union, Estonia reinstituted its prewar citizenship laws, which set conditions for non-Estonians to become citizens. Those who are neither Estonian nor Russian citizens are considered in Estonia a form of resident alien. Those non-Estonians with Soviet passports do not necessarily have permission to re-enter Estonia without a visa.
"Estonia wants to push them out, but Russia is not eager to have them back," Mr. Yugantsev says, an assertion Estonian officials deny publicly but shrug about in private.
 
Russians in Tears
 Russians are less worried about deportation these days, but there are a lot of rumors and bureaucratic problems, especially about travel documents and the need to pass Estonian-language competency tests in order to keep jobs. Larisa T. Yakovleva, Mr. Yugantsev's secretary, said, "All I know is that Russians keep coming here in tears, and I don't know what to do for them."
She asserts that some ethnic Russians without Estonian passports are strongly encouraged to take Russian citizenship to be able to travel. The nannies at the day-care center in Maardu, a small, mostly Russian town near Tallinn, worry that if they don't pass their Estonian language test by September they'll be fired and the centers closed.
Both Estonians and Russians say the segregation among the two communities, especially among the young, is almost total, but it is also without serious conflict. Prime Minister Mart Laar thinks it's improving, however.
"In the Soviet period, there was real hate then and no contact," Mr. Laar said. "Differences exist but they're not getting larger. Now more Russians are becoming more loyal to our state and learning the language. If an Estonian hears a Russian trying to speak our language, they're very happy -- what matters is the attitude, not the skill."
 
Aug. 31 Withdrawal Planned
 These issues are not the focus of negotiations with Moscow, however, which concentrate on the rights of military retirees and the final withdrawal of the last 2,000 or so Russian troops by the end of August. In an effort to win for their military retirees an automatic right to settle here, as in Latvia, where the two sides have agreed on an Aug. 31 withdrawal date, the Russians have talked tough. The Estonians insist on case-by-case decisions, which annoys the Russians, who want more certainty.
Senior American diplomats, trying to mediate, think compromise is likely and the Aug. 31 date will be met. Not only has Russia raised the level of talks, naming Deputy Foreign Minister, Vitaly I. Churkin, as their chief negotiator, but President Boris N. Yeltsin will be in Berlin on Aug. 31 bidding a formal goodbye to Russian troops stationed in the former East Germany.
"Yeltsin doesn't want to stand in Berlin and have Russian troops still stationed in Estonia," a senior American diplomat said. "It would be too embarrassing."
The Americans say the 10,000 or so military officers and their families who retired before the failed coup of August 1991 should be able to stay, though without guaranteed titles to their current apartments, to which they had privileged access. The Russians agree, but want an automatic right to settle; they also want help with housing those officers who will leave.
 
U.S. Housing Vouchers
 The Americans have promised housing vouchers, to spend on an apartment in Russia, to the uniformed officers of the troops still in Estonia who will retire and leave this summer. So far, the number of those is about 620, and Russian units have been providing lists of those officers who qualify.
Those who retired between August 1991 and Jan. 28, 1992, when Mr. Yeltsin took over formal control of the former Soviet military, are another problem. Latvia let them stay; Estonia says no. Washington has offered to provide this group of about 260 officers housing vouchers, too, to help them leave.
The Estonians have stressed the danger of another group, some 950 officers so far who have left the army after January 1992 and remain here, some of whom have engaged in crime. Western diplomats think these fears are exaggerated, but believe that Russia will not try to protect them from deportation -- so long as Estonia does it in small groups, without embarrassing Moscow.
Tunne V. Kellam, the deputy speaker of Parliament, agrees that relations between Estonians and Russians are fraught, and may create new difficulties for an integrated state. He urges the West not to forget the moral question, of an Estonia brutally occupied by the Soviet Union and now full of foreigners, but admits that Estonia needs to come to terms with the future too, and its special security problems.
It would help if fully recognized Estonia as a sovereign state, Mr. Kellam said. That's why the final withdrawal of Russia's troops is so important, he said. "Their leaving will be a crucial symbol that Russians here must take our independence seriously and integrate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Retirees danced around the room at the old Russian Officers Club in Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, singing an Estonian folk song to help them learn the language and culture. Most of them have lived most or all of their lives in Estonia, but know little about the country and its language. (Otto Pohl for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
City of Pittsburgh Digs Deep to Offer Pirates an $8 Million Loan. Will It Be Enough?

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Is baseball dying in Pittsburgh? The Pirates have a mediocre 38-38 record, but those numbers aren't the ones that count these days.
The team is wheezing financially, losing money by the day, and looking far removed from 1990-92 when they were champions of the National League East. 
 On Wednesday, the Pittsburgh City Council voted by 7-1 to bail out the Pirates with an $8 million loan. What's surprising is that the team may not take it unless the city renegotiates its lease at Three Rivers Stadium.
Since 1991, the team has reported operating losses of $24 million.
The Pirates owe $26 million ($6 million in interest) to the city, which put up half the purchase price for the team in 1985, another $34 million from dipping into a credit line that is available to all major league baseball teams through Citibank. The $20 million city loan does not have to be paid back unless the team is sold, but the first payment on the Citibank loan is due in August.
 
Shrinking Corporate Base

 Pittsburgh has a long tradition in baseball, but today, the market is not overly supportive of the Pirates. The corporate base isn't big. Local media revenues are small, about $7 million. The cushion of about $14 million a year in national TV money is gone, with teams expecting $6 million each this season.
Not surprisingly, no credible local buyer has surfaced. "Howard Baldwin offered to buy us, with very little cash," said Jim Lachimia, a Pirates spokesman, referring to the owner of the Penguins.
To the City Council members who unenthusiastically voted for the bailout, the Pirates' financial plight is not the equivalent of better-financed teams holding cities ransom for better stadium deals or new ball parks. The Chicago White Sox squeezed out a sweetheart deal from the state of Illinois for new Comiskey Park with a well-orchestrated plan to defect to St. Petersburg.
But the council members don't view the financial drama being played at the confluence of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers with a happy face.
"It's a bad situation," said Councilman Alan Hertzberg, who voted for the loan. "We tried to get every other governmental entity to help. And it's a tough nut for us. Our bond rating was just lowered because of a $20 million shortfall in our anticipated revenues."
 
Hoping Against Hope
 So why the bailout? The $80 million in regional economic impact the Pirates produce, said Bob O'Connor, another councilman. "The average person doesn't want to give them money, but doesn't want to lose them, either," O'Connor said.
The council is not happy with the management of the Pirates, and is hoping, perhaps naively, to stabilize the franchise through the city loan, $8 million more that the ownership has pledged in matching funds, and the adoption of revenue sharing and a salary cap by major league baseball owners and players.
"Sure, it's a hope," said O'Connor, referring to revenue sharing and a cap, the dual subjects of fierce disagreement between labor and management.
 
More Concessions Sought
 But the Pirates may say thanks, but no thanks, to the city if they don't receive substantial givebacks on cash from stadium concessions, luxury suites and parking. According to Financial World magazine's study of team values, the Pirates received the least in such revenues of any major league team, $2.3 million in 1993, compared with $21.8 million for the Toronto Blue Jays.
O'Connor said he believed that the loan and the lease negotiations were not intertwined. "We thought this was one issue at a time," he said. But Mark Sauer, the president of the Pirates, said, "The loan is part of the negotiations." The Pirates' board is meeting today to consider the loan.
Lachimia said: "The loan is a temporary solution. A new lease, revenue-sharing and a salary cap are the long-term solution. We don't want to draw on the $8 million if we can't use it to get to the long term."
This is somewhat strange. The Pirates are playing hardball with the city as the vicissitudes of its daily operations are weakening the team. But the Pirates have the leverage of being a major league franchise in a city that would feel as if it drove its baseball team into the arms of wealthier markets like Charlotte, St. Petersburg or Phoenix if it did not contribute what it probably can't afford to keep the team afloat.

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '94;
Soccer's Study In Contrasts

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MISSION VIEJO, Calif., June 30

 BODY:
Diego Maradona scored his first goal in Argentina's opening game of the 1994 World Cup, and he kept running until his face nearly pressed into a television camera behind the net, his jaw clenched in celebratory defiance. His look was predatory, like a shark poking his snout into a diver's cage.
Soccer's most riveting and difficult superstar was back. Or so it seemed. The critics who once said he was overweight, over the hill, would soon retreat into fawning obeisance as Maradona attacked with renewed ferociousness. 
 "Diego is in very good physical condition," Alfie Basile, the Argentine coach, beamed after his team had routed Greece by 4-0. "His touch is still magic."
But this magic could never make the dark, troubled side of Diego Maradona disappear. Today, he was withdrawn from the World Cup by the Argentine team after testing positive for the banned drug ephedrine. If his expulsion was unsettling to Argentina's chances of winning the World Cup, it could hardly be called shocking.
If he was the best player of his generation, Maradona was also the most volatile. He experienced drug problems, weight problems, legal problems and emotional problems in the grand, lamentable melodrama that has been his career.
Twice before, the enormity of his skills had been obscured by the shadow of drugs. While playing for Naples in the Italian League, Maradona tested positive for cocaine in a routine post-game doping exam on March 17, 1991. He received a 15-month worldwide ban from the game by FIFA, soccer's world governing body.
Upon returning home to Buenos Aires, Maradona was arrested in a police raid and charged with cocaine possession. He said he would retire, and entered a drug rehabilitation program.
Some fans forgave him for his transgressions, but others remained suspicious. Japanese authorities, citing his drug record, prevented Maradona from entering the country to play in exhibition matches before the 1994 World Cup.
There was a striking contradiction to his personality and his career, one of peerless accomplishment and repeated disgrace.
 
Incomparable, Indifferent
 He was a child of the Buenos Aires streets, a boy who grew up in the slums, then amassed enough of a fortune to throw a $1 million wedding in 1989, chartering a 747 jet to ferry hundreds of friends to the ceremony. He was a doting father of two daughters with his wife, Claudia, and a restive husband who was accused in two paternity suits. He was an incomparable player and an indifferent athlete, whose body was often as bloated as his ego.
Maradona could dribble a ball in traffic and thread an impossible pass with unruffled calm, but he was equally prone to violent outbursts, often directed at journalists. He punched out a photographer before his wedding, and, in March of this year, fired an air rifle at journalists outside at his home in suburban Buenos Aires, slightly injuring five reporters. After the latter incident, he was ordered to undergo psychiatric treatment.
His weight fluctuated like his temper. In the past year, he has gained and lost 25 pounds at least twice, leading to speculation that he went to extraordinary, perhaps illicit, means to get his weight under control for the World Cup.
Reared in a shantytown, Maradona had, by age 16, become the youngest player ever called up to the Argentine national team. He was an emerging star at the 1982 World Cup, then established himself as perhaps the game's most spectacular player at the 1986 World Cup in Spain, where he fashioned the tournament into his own highlight film for the ages.
In a tense, dramatic quarterfinal match against England -- the first meeting between Argentina and Britain since the Falklands War -- Maradona broke open a scoreless game in the second half with a dribbling foray into England's penalty area that resulted in the most infamous goal in World Cup history.
A British defender peeled the ball from Maradona's foot and lobbed it back toward the English goalkeeper Peter Shilton. Only one problem. Maradona arrived at the ball before Shilton did, slashing inside for the interception, leaping and heading the ball into the net.
At least it appeared that he used his head.
 
A Helping Hand
 Replays showed clearly that Maradona used a forbidden hand to cuff the ball into the net. He never owned up to the infraction, saying only that the goal was accomplished "partly by the hand of God and partly with the head of Maradona."
Maradona has long had a bellicose relationship with soccer authorities. After commanding a record transfer fee of $7.5 million from Barcelona to Naples in 1984, Maradona led Naples to a pair of Italian League titles, but not without numerous impetuous eruptions.
He once reported to training camp a month late; later, Maradona avoided practice as if it were a communicable disease. His weight ballooned. Eventually, Maradona demanded to be traded. Then, in 1991, he failed a drug test in Italy and his career began a precipitous decline into scandal.
 
Nation Needs Him
 His suspension ended, Maradona returned to club play in 1992 with Seville in the Spanish League. He was fired after one season, his welcome expiring just before his $7.5 million contract did. He fought during a game, developed a familiar truancy from practice and was even cited for reckless driving as his wayward career appeared to careen toward a dead end.
Maradona retreated to Argentina and signed with a club team, Newell's Old Boys, but the national team ignored him until it lost a 5-0 qualifying game to Colombia in Buenos Aires in September of 1993, and came perilously close to not qualifying for the World Cup. Facing national disgrace, all of Argentina, even President Carlos Menem, knew what had to be done.
Like a reliever called in from the bullpen, Maradona made a confident re-entry a month later in a playoff series against Australia. True to his indomitable spirit, Maradona set up Argentina's lone goal in a 1-1 draw in Sydney; Argentina won the second game, 1-0, and clung to the final World Cup berth by the slimmest of threads. Argentina had made it, but had Maradona?
After missing numerous practices with his club team, he was sacked by Newell's Old Boys in early February. When reporters showed up at his country home outside Buenos Aires to ask about his release, a distraught Maradona fired at them with an air rifle, shouting, "If you don't get out of here, we're going to start shooting real bullets."
Media support withered and Argentine psychologists questioned his emotional state.
But, like soccer's Rasputin, Maradona was not finished yet. Though his weight again mushroomed, so apparently did his enthusiasm and desperation for one final chance to star on soccer's international stage. Maradona went into seclusion with a personal trainer and melted away 26 pounds of suet.
The cup arrived and so did a reinvigorated Maradona. He scored a goal against Greece, and slid a quick pass to Caniggia to catch his opponents flat-footed and unprepared in a 2-1 victory over Nigeria. Every pass seemed made with deliberate purpose and marvelous economy. Maradona appeared to waste nothing. Until today, when he wasted a final chance to renew himself and his reputation in the World Cup.

HEADLINE: New Era, New Pie

BYLINE: By Robert D. Hormats; Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, helped prepare eight economic summit meetings as a Presidential adviser.

 BODY:
The Group of Seven industrial democracies will celebrate the 20th anniversary of their annual summit meeting at Naples next week. The leaders of the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada should seize the occasion to take a hard look at the international trade and financial system and begin to work together to shape its evolution into the 21st century -- especially by incorporating large emerging economies into the world market system.
Since they possess nearly 70 percent of the world's gross domestic product and the world's key currencies, these countries bear a special responsibility for a stable global economic order. 
 Russia's unsettled economic status makes premature its request to join as a full member. Moreover, bringing in Russia could divert attention from other urgent issues: how to maintain growth in the global economy, how to increase jobs in the Group countries, how to bolster currency stability and how to maintain momentum in world trade liberalization now that the Uruguay Round of trade talks is over.
But Russia and China should be invited to become associate members for next year's summit meeting, in Canada. A very limited number -- about half a dozen -- other important emerging powers such as India, Mexico and representative key countries in East Asia, South America and Eastern Europe could be added in due course.
Under this proposal, Group of Seven leaders would meet after their own sessions with leaders of associate members, as they have done on an ad hoc basis with President Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev before him.
Core and associate countries together would meet with heads of the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and the new World Trade Organization. These officials would focus the summit leaders on priority issues and press them to consider the views of non-summit nations that are members of these large global institutions, thereby reducing their resentment at not being at the summit table. The heads of these institutions would try to avert any tendency toward narrow nationalism or protective regionalism that would fragment or weaken the global economy.
Integrating newly market-oriented economies smoothly into the world economy, as Japan and Germany were after World War II, would harness the enormous productive power and market potential of more than three billion people. That would transform the global economy and give an enormous boost to world growth and be a powerful antidote to divisiveness and instability. The supreme test of the Group of Seven as we move into the next century will be its ability to manage this integration.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Pay the Money, Sam

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Vive la France! A good strong vive from everybody, please, to the French for taking on what no other country would touch -- flying troops into the hell of Rwanda to save African lives.
The French do not want to occupy the country -- they have not suddenly gone mad -- and there is no economic or strategic gain to be found in that land of corpses. They went in because their stomachs could not stand it anymore -- that's the reason and it does them credit. 
 Now, a good strong vive for the Secretary General of the United Nations. Who? Boutros Boutros-Ghali of Egypt? The man American diplomacy so loves to blame for everything from war in Bosnia to monsoons in Bangladesh? A vive for our own whipping boy?
Correct -- the Secretary General has been screaming, pleading, begging for members of the U.N. to do something more useful about Rwanda than look shocked. It is pure churl not to recognize grace and courage in the French and the first Secretary General since Dag Hammarskjold to speak his mind, or even know it.
No, I did not want American troops in Rwanda -- the U.S. plate over floweth. But I think it should embarrass Americans that at the United Nations, the richest country in the world, the nation that aspires to leadership by right of power and democracy, has become a champion welsher in payments to the U.N. peacekeeping forces and the U.N. in general. We are hanging around the U.N. bar, looking for a free drink and acting as if we were buying rounds on the house.
As of June 15, according to U.N. figures, the United States owed $531 million to the U.N. general budget for years of arrears, and $748 million to the peacekeeping budget.
American figures are somewhat less because they deduct some general budget arrears that Washington expects to pay by the end of the year. All right, so taking all the accounting breaks, round it off as one billion dollars, without a penny of interest ever. We are lucky they don't throw us out of the place.
For decades, the U.S. took it as a matter of honor to pay up on the due date or before and properly looked down at countries that welshed. But in the 80's, the Reagan Administration got annoyed at the U.N. for then being a center of anti-American agitation. It was. But the Reagan people took a strange way of upholding America -- refusing to meet U.S. financial obligations.
During the Bush Administration, the welshing continued for other excuses, including the demand that the U.N. overhaul its budgeting and spending, which it has been doing.
What's the excuse now? The Clinton Administration says it wants to catch up. Madeleine Albright, the U.S. chief delegate, does her very best -- making special trips to Washington to urge members of Congress to put the checks in the mail.
Clintonians say the problem is that a poor-mouth Congress won't vote the money. But isn't that a Democratic President down there, with a Democratic House and a Democratic Senate?
In private moments, Administration people concede that getting Congress to pay up is not "very high on the President's priority list."
If national honor is not enough to push it higher, how about this: American welshing cripples peacekeeping missions for which the U.S. voted and shifts the burden to far less wealthy nations.
Some of them are not as keen on that as they used to be. Because of U.S. defaults, sometimes the U.N. cannot pay poorer peacekeeping nations the money it legitimately owes them for expenses -- which means it will be a long day on the East River before those countries volunteer again.
The U.S. is not self-destructive enough to want to do away with the U.N. and never has been. Whatever any Administration in Washington says in complaint, American diplomats and most politicians are sophisticated enough to know that the U.N. is simply the will of its members, that among those members the U.S. is the most powerful and effective, that the U.S. gets much of its payments back in U.N. money spent in America, and that the world is at least a somewhat safer place because nations can meet, negotiate, cool down and even occasionally reach agreement at the U.N.
Put the check in the mail, pay for your own drinks -- what is so complicated about that? We will feel a lot better and so will all our friends.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Offering Forces UAL to Dip Into Its Cash

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Air Lines, sold $1.15 billion in bonds and preferred stock yesterday, after being forced by reluctant investors both to raise interest rates and to cut the amount of preferred stock being sold.
As a result of the shortfall, the company has said it will contribute $300 million from its cash holdings to shareholders if they approve a sweeping reorganization giving employees majority control of the airline in return for wage and benefit concessions. 
 Shareholders will vote on the proposed employee buyout on July 12.
 
 
Question of Rates
 Underwriters led by Merrill Lynch sold only $410 million of preferred stock, at a rate of 12.25 percent, down from the $765 million originally hoped for. Seth Waugh, a managing director of Merrill Lynch, said the entire amount could have been sold but only at a rate higher than UAL was willing to pay.
UAL also sold $370.2 million of 10-year notes, at a yield of 10.67 percent, or 3.35 percentage points higher than 10-year Treasuries, and $371 million of 20-year bonds at a yield of 11.21 percent, or 3.55 percentage points higher than 30-year Treasuries.
In both cases, the rates were slightly higher than the underwriters had wanted.
The issues had to be sold by yesterday because of deadlines associated with the planned shareholder meeting. All the sales will be canceled if UAL shareholders do not approve the reorganization, which would leave existing shareholders with a minority of the company while providing a cash payout of $84.81 a share.
The decision by the company to dip into its bank account to make up the shortfall was applauded by institutional investors who plan to vote for the deal. In recent months, they have increasingly signaled their displeasure over the prospect of being given debt securities of uncertain value in exchange for surrendering majority control.
"Cash is king, always," said Tim Pettee, a transportation analyst at Alliance Capital Management, which owns about 17 percent of UAL's stock.
UAL currently has about $2 billion in cash, which would be reduced to $1.07 billion if the employee buyout succeeds. Philip Baggaley, transportation analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said he was "not overjoyed" at the prospect of the additional drain on cash. But considering that the company has about $16 billion in debt and leases -- much of it carried off its balance sheet -- switching debt securities to cash "doesn't make much difference," he said.
Mr. Baggaley speculated that UAL had trouble selling preferred stock because such securities were typically bought by corporations for tax advantages, but they generally preferred securities with lower risk than the UAL offering.
UAL's shares closed at $127, down 25 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 6, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Friday about a bond and preferred stock sale by the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, included an erroneous figure supplied by the company for the cash that would remain on its balance sheet if shareholders approve an employee buyout on July 12. UAL's cash would total $1.5 billion, not $1.07 billion.

HEADLINE: ALBANY IN ACCORD ON SCHOOL DISTRICT FOR HASIDIC GROUP

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 1

 BODY:
Just four days after the United States Supreme Court ruled that a public school district created specially for ultra-Orthodox Jews was unconstitutional, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders reached agreement today on a bill that would allow the district to continue operating.
The legislation is intended to address constitutional issues raised by the high court when it struck down the Kiryas Joel Village School District in Orange County, which was created by the Governor and Legislature in 1989 to serve about 200 Satmar Hasidic children with disabilities. 
 The Hasidic parents did not want to send their children to the local public schools but wanted to receive Federal and state aid to pay for special education.
Critics of the arrangement contend that it fragments education at a time when the state is trying to consolidate school districts. They argue that the Legislature is responding to the political power of the Hasidim, a charge that lawmakers deny.
The Supreme Court majority had ruled that establishing the district amounted to improper favoritism toward religion in general and one sect in particular. But in drafting their bill, the Legislators seized on an opening they believed was supplied by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who said in a concurring opinion that the district might have been permissible if it had been created through legislation applicable to any municipality, not just Kiryas Joel, a village about 50 miles northwest of Manhattan whose residents are all Satmar Hasidim.
The lawmakers said their new bill would meet that standard by allowing all municipalities that fit specific criteria to establish new school districts. Currently, only state education officials can create new districts, something that rarely happens.
Legislative aides said that between 20 and 60 towns in addition to the village of Kiryas Joel, could create new school districts under the new bill.
"It's right on point with Justice O'Connor's decision," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who sponsored the bill. "It's mentioned in the ruling that if it's done this way, it would be fine."
But critics of the legislation said it addressed the concerns of only one justice and not necessarily the court's majority. And they charged that the Governor and Legislature had rushed to help the 12,000-resident Satmar community because they are thought to vote and give political contributions in a bloc.
"I'm personally disappointed in the utter disrespect and disregard the Governor and Legislature have for the Supreme Court," said Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association. "This law would encourage the very balkanization I thought everyone was moving against."
Mr. Grumet, who brought the original court challenge against the Kiryas Joel district, said the School Boards Association as a group and he as an individual taxpayer would challenge the new legislation in court.
 
Intent to Move Quickly
 But supporters of the bill said they had to act quickly because the legislative session is scheduled to end this week. And they said there is little evidence that the Satmars have the political clout to make an entire Legislature act.
"It is offensive to say we are helping the Jewish community because they vote and participate in the political process," said Assembly Jules Polonetsky, a Brooklyn Democrat who co-sponsored the bill.
Mr. Grumet and other critics also contended that Mr. Cuomo, who has spoken passionately about the importance of keeping church and state separate, had used legal technicalities to sidestep a Supreme Court ruling on that very issue.
 
'A Duty to Protect'
 Mr. Cuomo could not be reached for comment this afternoon. But earlier this week he said he had signed the Kiryas Joel legislation in 1989 because "I believe government has a duty to protect and serve all its citizens, regardless of their religious beliefs."
He added, "I believe that while the Constitution, thankfully, bars government from forcing anyone to be religious, it does not mandate that we punish people for being religious."
The Legislature was expected to pass two bills that would deal with Kiryas Joel. The first would abolish the existing school district, but allow existing educational services to continue until a new school district is formed, possibly this summer.
The second would establish criteria for creating new districts: Municipalities must have at least 2,000 students and come from established districts with at least 4,000 students. New districts would have to be at or above the state average in wealth and leave behind districts whose wealth would be essentially unchanged.
Those measures were designed to prevent small towns from creating new districts and to insure that wealthy villages could not secede from school districts that include poor areas.
 
A Three-Step Process
 A new district would require three steps of approval: first from the municipal council, then from the local electorate and finally from two-thirds of the existing school district's board of education.
When told of the legislative agreement, residents of Kiryas Joel responded ecstatically. "For my child, it means the difference between a nice life and nothing, barrenness," said Judith Gluck, whose six-year-old son attends the school district. "Every time I talk about it, my tears well up."
 
'Motor Voter' Bill Advances
 In other action, the Governor and legislative leaders also reached agreement early today on how to comply with a 1993 Federal law that requires states to distribute voter registration applications in an array of state and local offices.
Under the so-called "motor voter" bill, the state would make voter registration materials available at offices of the Department of Motor Vehicles and the Department of Social Services, including all local human services offices. Forms also would have to be distributed at agencies that serve people with disabilities, armed forces recruitment offices, and worker's compensation offices. All State University of New York and City University of New York schools would have to provide registration forms to students once a year, and twice a year in Presidential election years.
At motor vehicle offices, applicants would simply have to complete a section of their driver's license registration form. At social services offices, a tear-off voter registration application would be attached applications for benefits.
The Federal law allowed the states a certain amount of discretion. The Republican-controlled Senate wanted to limit distribution of the forms to motor vehicles and social services offices, the minimum requirement of the Federal law.
That is because in New York City, where 69 percent of all registered voters are Democrats, only about half of the voting-age population has a driver's license, compared to three-fourths of the voting-age population statewide.
The Assembly Democrats succeeded in expanding the distribution of registration forms somewhat, but failed to win an agreement that the forms be made available in housing agencies, unemployment offices and high schools.
Nonetheless, voting-rights advocates said the bill should generate a significant increase in voter registration. Sixty-four percent of the state's voting-age population is registered now, making New York 37th among states, according to Board of Elections figures.
 
Accord on Teacher Discipline
 The process for disciplining teachers accused of wrongdoing would be simplified and speeded up under an agreement reached among Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders that would also bolster the rights of accused teachers.
The bill tightens a loophole that currently allows teachers convicted of a crime to continue receiving pay until a disciplinary hearing is complete. Under legislation proposed by Mr. Cuomo the teacher could be fired upon conviction for several drug and sex crimes, but they would be paid back if the conviction was overturned.

HEADLINE: Bland but Tough, Gov. Wilson Uses Lessons of Nixon

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The words rolled soberly off Gov. Pete Wilson's tongue in his eulogy for Richard M. Nixon: "It was his heart that taught us the great lesson of Richard Nixon's life. Never give up. Never give up. Never, ever, give up."
Mr. Wilson, an advance man for Mr. Nixon's unsuccessful campaign for governor of California in 1962, was talking as much about himself that afternoon last April. The eulogy was sprinkled with passages that suited both men, down to the Governor's description of Mr. Nixon's "iron will." It was not lost on followers of his career that Mr. Wilson had been given the less-refined accolade of "iron butt" for his political durability -- a durability evidenced by his improving ratings in the polls. 
 Pete Wilson is rarely inspiring, is hardly charismatic and, after three decades in public life as Mayor of San Diego, a United States Senator and Governor of the most populous state, he still looks far more comfortable behind the scenes plotting campaign tactics than out on center stage.
But like his mentor, the 60-year-old Mr. Wilson has succeeded not because voters have deep affection for him (they do not), but because he is smart, reaches out to moderates, thrives on the game of politics and is relentless in practicing it.
That helps explain why, having presided over the biggest recession in California since the Depression and after being 20 points down in some opinion polls last summer, Mr. Wilson is rebounding in his race for a second term. He is helped by an economy that is beginning to emerge from a recession, but also by his own acumen in shifting the debate to crime and immigration. The latest polls show that in the most important governor's race of the year, one that could signal President Clinton's prospects here in 1996, Mr. Wilson is edging out his Democratic opponent, State Treasurer Kathleen Brown. She had practically been anointed by the pundits as the next governor.
This would have been no surprise to Mr. Nixon, who staged the most successful political comeback of his generation and recognized that Mr. Wilson had a similar capacity. In one of his final political prognostications before his death, the former President told friends that if Mr. Wilson was re-elected, as Mr. Nixon expected, he would be the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996. (Few analysts believe Mr. Wilson's protestations that he will not run for President in 1996.)
"Pete and the President are very much the same," said Ken Khachigian, a Nixon speech writer who helped Mr. Wilson polish the eulogy, along with Ronald Reagan's speech writer, Peggy Noonan. "They both have this great love of the ins and outs of politics. They're devoted to it. Married to it, in a way."
 
Pupil of Nixon
 Mr. Khachigian recalled that when the three met last year over soft drinks and Mr. Nixon offered his thoughts about the race, "Pete was not awed, but he was very much the pupil to the teacher, eager to listen."
In a recent interview, Mr. Wilson brightened when asked about the comparisons to Mr. Nixon. "I hear that from friends and foes," he said.
Although Mr. Wilson speaks in a monotone, his words are those of the Marine infantry officer he once was when he describes his Nixonesque win-at-all-costs mentality. "I don't go looking for fights," he said. "I don't shrink from combat either. There are people who think that I particularly enjoy it. The fact of the matter is that I would be perfectly happy dealing with responsible people honestly and functioning in a largely nonadversarial setting. That isn't my fate in life."
An important reason Mr. Wilson has quashed all but one of his opponents over the years (he lost the 1978 primary for governor) is that his tenacity is well honed. The strategy of Mr. Wilson, who has long surrounded himself with the same close aides, is simple: set the agenda by seizing on highly emotional issues, and never let a rival get the upper hand.
Darry Sragow, a Democrat strategist who has managed two losing statewide campaigns against Mr. Wilson, described it from the other side: "I always picture the Wilson operation stepping out in the path of the opponent and throwing a bag of marbles in the opponent's path. The opponent has to dance on the marbles and invariably slips, falls and is immediately set upon by a host of Wilson operatives who emerge from the woods. They just sit on the opponent until the end of the campaign."
George Gorton, Mr. Wilson's campaign manager and adviser for 24 years, described Mr. Wilson's "trademark move" as "letting his opponents go too far and coming back and blowing them away."
Take Ms. Brown's accusation last March that Mr. Wilson was responsible for the release of Melvin Carter, a serial rapist, from a state prison. Mr. Wilson counterattacked immediately. Saying that he had tried to change the sentencing laws that had allowed for Mr. Carter's release, he accused Ms. Brown of "the most outrageous, deliberate deception."
Characteristic of an attention to detail that many politicians would leave to their handlers, the workaholic Governor stayed up well past midnight drafting a 13-page statement to his aides, plus attachments, for a news conference at which he attacked Ms. Brown. The meticulously hand-printed memorandum was so detailed that it even included citations to the penal code. A week later, Mr. Wilson wrote the script for his first commercial attacking Ms. Brown as soft on crime. He specified that it be shot in black and white for a stark image and with a female narrator.
"I saw an opportunity, frankly, to reveal her for what she was -- and do some damage," Mr. Wilson said. Calling the commercial "dramatically successful," he boasted that it brought Ms. Brown's opponent in the Democratic primary, John Garamendi, up about 10 points in the polls temporarily. Mr. Garamendi was defeated by Ms. Brown last month, 48 percent to 33 percent.
Mr. Wilson seized on another opportunity in April when he called a news conference to announce the early reopening of the Santa Monica Freeway, which had been damaged by the 1993 earthquake. The move infuriated Clinton Administration officials, who were caught off guard and unable to take credit before the television cameras.
Mr. Wilson is also a formidable fund raiser. He and Ms. Brown are expected to raise at least $15 million apiece for the November election.
It takes more than political acumen, though, to be a popular Governor, and Californians rate Mr. Wilson relatively poorly. In a poll in the primary conducted by The Los Angeles Times, only 39 percent of voters approved of the job he was doing, and 61 percent disapproved. Two out of five Republican voters said they were unhappy with his performance.
An even more telling sign was that Ron Unz, a computer industry millionaire and political unknown who challenged Mr. Wilson in the Republican primary, got 34 percent of the vote. And at the Rose Bowl late last month, the Governor was drowned out by boos as he tried to address opening ceremonies of the World Cup soccer tournament.
Mr. Wilson argued that the lackluster showing was a result of sour economic conditions in the state and not because of him personally. "The negatives arise from the deepest, longest recession since the Great Depression," he said.
But the Governor's conduct did not always endear him to voters. Early in his term, he alienated conservatives by allying himself with Democratic legislators to close a budget gap by raising $7.3 billion in new taxes; then he offended Democrats for many positions, from his support of a successful term-limit referendum to his oratory against illegal immigrants, which many view as offensive.
He tried to counter the notion that people did not like him by first saying that many voters did not really know him -- a telling admission for someone who has been in public life so long. Then, he offered anecdotal evidence to make his case.
"The other day I was in Sacramento," he said. "I was waiting for the light to cross the street and a good-looking black guy had the windows rolled down and he was waiting there at the light. He looked over and he saw me and he did a double take. And he said, 'Hey! Go get 'em, Pete!' I get a lot of that. So I am not feeling unloved."
Mr. Wilson has been helped as much by his political skills as by Ms. Brown's lack of them. She is more personally engaging and comes across as far more compassionate. But her campaign has had trouble settling on a theme for her candidacy, and improvements in the economy have hampered her effort to make the campaign a referendum on a failed economy.
Mr. Wilson and his advisers speak dismissively of Ms. Brown, and revel in describing her gaffes on the campaign trail. The Governor went as far as to say that there was nothing that worried him about Ms. Brown as a candidate -- and that only factors beyond his control could cost him the election, like the economy and an inclination for women to vote for her.
Mr. Nixon, he said, told him as much. "He said, 'I think you can win this thing very credibly,' " Mr. Wilson recalled. "He said, 'My sole concern is circumstances beyond your control, meaning international recession.' "
The Governor should be mindful, of course, of the lesson of former Gov. Jim Florio, a New Jersey Democrat. Mr. Florio thought he had recovered from presiding over huge tax increases early in his term and a soured economy, only to lose last November to Christine Todd Whitman.
Mr. Wilson offered much higher praise for the political ability of Senator Dianne Feinstein, whom he defeated when he was elected Governor four years ago. "I don't think she's as nearly as good a candidate," the Governor said of Ms. Brown.
Mr. Wilson's stewardship has been defined largely by events that he could not control, from the state's economic crisis, to calamities worthy of the biblical plagues, including two major earthquakes, fires, floods and droughts. But those disasters may also be what saves Mr. Wilson because they have showcased before the television cameras his steady, yet bland, ability to take charge.
His strength as Governor is his command of the intricacies of policy, a trait that critics say prevents him from standing back and sketching grand themes for his Administration to follow. Mr. Wilson is so taken by the pabulum of policy that his aides cautioned that unless a reporter repeatedly reminded him that the article was not about facts and figures, that would be all he would talk about.
But at the start of the interview, Mr. Wilson made clear that he would stray only so far into his personal side. "No pop psychology," he said.
In addition to his seemingly obsessive drive to win, there is a more personal reason why a victory over Ms. Brown would be sweet for Mr. Wilson. It was Ms. Brown's father, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown, who handed Mr. Nixon a humiliating defeat in the 1962 Governor's race. Now, the advance man in that race has a chance to take his own shot at a Brown.
"I think it's going to be one of the dirtiest campaigns, if not the worst, that I have ever been exposed to," Mr. Wilson said. Would he enjoy it? Without skipping a beat, he said: "Yeah, I think it'll be fun."

With him was Lawrence Ellison, the chief executive of the computer-program company, which is in Redwood Shores, south of San Francisco. (Susan Spann for The New York Times)(pg. 8)

HEADLINE: Tents for Haitians Rise Again at Guantanamo

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 1

 BODY:
For the last two days, 1,700 American troops have been working around the clock, once again, to raise a tent city here for thousands of Haitian refugees. But the boat people are flowing in faster than the soldiers can pitch tents.
Coast Guard cutters delivered 500 more Haitians today, bringing the total to 1,956 since the camps opened on Wednesday. Hundreds more remain on United States ships offshore. 
 "I've got to expect that the flow out of Haiti will remain fairly constant," said Col. Mike Pearson, an army officer in command of the task force at this United States Navy outpost in southeastern Cuba. "I'm ramping up to take my maximum."
Colonel Pearson could reach his limit of 12,500 within days, forcing the Administration to plead even louder with its Caribbean neighbors for help in sheltering the refugees. An American hospital ship at Kingston, Jamaica, the Comfort, has 1,000 Haitians aboard; the Turks and Caicos Islands have agreed to take up to 2,000 refugees later this month.
But Haitians here say tighter economic sanctions against Haiti's military Government, heightened oppression by security forces and a United States immigration policy that seems more lenient will send even larger numbers to sea in rickety boats.
Seeking additional sites was the focus of urgent meetings today in Washington.
Asmime Pierre, a 25-year-old sales clerk, said she and her husband, Jeudy, fled after he was arrested for belonging to the party of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. But the administration's new policy was the catalyst, she said.
"We noticed everyone was leaving on boats, so we decided to leave as well," Ms. Pierre said through a Creole-speaking interpreter.
Jasdrem Codoue, a 48-year-old construction worker, said he left Haiti a week ago with his 11-year-old son, Erkuil, out of fear.
Mr. Codoue said that when he intervened to help a woman arguing with some soldiers at a market, they arrested him.
"They know my face now," said Mr. Codoue. "I can never go back."
Reporters were allowed to interview and photograph only those Haitians already granted asylum, who account for 215 of the nearly 2,000 Haitians here. The rest have arrived in the last 48 hours.
Scores of Haitians trooped down the gangplank of the cutter Durable this morning, carrying only small bundles of clothes, and climbed onto a waiting blue school bus to be taken to a processing center.
The camps echoed with the pounding of hammers and the grinding of forklifts. Marines and Navy Seabees rolled in portable toilets and pitched rows of khaki tents that hold 20 cots each. Double rolls of barbed wire encircle the camp.
The officers have learned several lessons from the time when the Bush Administration housed Haitian refugees here in 1991 and 1992. Then some were held up to 22 months, raising tensions and even causing small riots, Colonel Pearson said. The poor conditions and assertions by human rights groups that the Haitians were not being treated fairly led the Bush Administration to close the camp.
"If any lesson was learned, it was you have to give people some flow-through quickly, either repatriating them or granting them asylum" Colonel Pearson said.
About 80 interviewers from the Immigration and Naturalization Service are to begin arriving on Saturday to hear the Haitians' appeals and judge whether "they have a well-founded fear of persecution," said Seth Libby, a senior immigration officer.
If asylum is granted, the Government looks for a sponsor in the United States, which takes about two weeks. If not, the refugees will be sent back to Haiti.
The Haitians fill their days playing soccer, checkers, cards and dominoes. The camps serve three meals a day, mostly rice and beans served with meat. The American troops are trying to soften the spartan conditions at the tent city and at a second site, Camp Bulkeley, where Haitians granted asylum live in cinder-block barracks.
Each Haitian gets a "comfort package" of a tooth brush, tooth paste, shirt, plastic sandals and towel, and a bucket to put it all in. Soldiers have bought dolls for some of the little girls.
Colonel Pearson said he is ordering camouflage netting to drape over the rolls of barbed wire that give Camp Bulkeley the appearance of a prison. The wire is for crowd control, but he acknowledged that "it looks pretty intimidating."
The officer also noted that graffiti scrawled on the barrack's cinder blocks -- "This Place Is for Animals" -- was left over from the last group of refugees two years ago, and was not the handiwork of the new arrivals.

Attack Under Investigation
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 1 (Special to The New York Times) -- United States Embassy officials said today that they were investigating reports that Haitian soldiers had fired on boat people, leading to a panic in which at least 30 refugees drowned.
The incident was first reported on Thursday by two foreign journalists who quoted witnesses who said they saw the police fire three shots as the refugees were waiting to board a boat in Nan L'Etat, a hamlet 15 miles east of Les Cayes, on the southern coast.
The journalists, Edward J. Barnes of Time magazine and Simon Dring of the BBC, who arrived at the scene on Wednesday afternoon, several hours after the incident, said witnesses told them that most of the victims had been women and children.
Haitian military spokesmen would not comment on the report.
"If it's true, then it's typical of the repressive nature of the de facto Government," said Stanley Schrager, an Embassy spokesman.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise With Dollar On a Light Trading Day

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The dollar paused yesterday and stock traders, or at least the few that were left on Wall Street, were relieved.
After five consecutive sessions of declines, the dollar rallied against both the Japanese yen and the German mark. And in light trading, the stock market rallied moderately as traders began the long Fourth of July weekend. 
 Stocks generally followed the course of bonds, whose yields were again close to the highest levels of the year, but whose prices were virtually unchanged. Commodities prices fell slightly, but not enough to calm traders' inflation concerns.
 
Below-Normal Volume
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 21.69 points, to 3,646.65, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.93 points, to 446.20. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 0.89 point, to 706.85.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was far below normal, with about 199 million shares changing hands, about 32 percent below this year's average daily volume of 293 million shares.
Blue-chip stocks rose, including the Aluminum Company of America and International Paper, as well as oil producers like Exxon and soft-drink companies like Coca-Cola. Also rising were over-the-counter stocks like Intel and MCI Communications.
The share price of CBS, which confirmed on Thursday that it was in negotiations to merge with QVC, fell 6 points, to 307, after generally positive assessments of the proposed deal by Wall Street analysts and a sharp run-up on Thursday.
 
Dollar Rebounds a Bit
 The dollar stopped its fall, for now. After more than a week of establishing post-World War II lows, it rose slightly against leading currencies. It moved up to 98.75 yen, from 98.49 yen on Thursday. Against the German mark, the dollar rose to 1.5995 marks, from 1.5875 marks.
While the dollar has receded somewhat from traders' concerns, in part because of the truncated holiday week next week, the political turmoil in Japan and what is seen as the short-term intractability of the United States' trade deficit with Japan, the issue remains important.
A declining dollar makes assets in dollars, including stocks, less attractive, particularly to foreign investors. Thus, it puts pressure on the Federal Reserve, whose policy-making committee is to meet on Tuesday, to raise interest rates a fifth time this year.
 But not all foreign investors are equally disadvantaged by a weak dollar. For instance, if Spanish investors had bought the Dow industrial stocks 12 months ago, they would have had a modest return of 3.88 percent in dollars for the last 12 months. But when converted to Spanish pesetas, that return would improve to 5.6 percent.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 1.18 points, to 246.34, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining issues by 1,282 to 810. The American Stock Exchange market value index moved up 0.64 point, to 424.72.
The most active stock was Microsoft, with 4.2 million shares traded. It fell 1 1/4, to 50 1/4, as technology stocks retreated. There have been reports that the Justice Department is in the final stages of an antitrust examination of the company.

HEADLINE: THE SIMPSON CASE: THE COURTHOUSE;
The Crowd Consensus: 'Turn the Juice Loose'

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 1

 BODY:
Two weeks ago Denise Brown buried her sister, Nicole Brown Simpson. Today, again dressed in black, she walked past the vendors selling 10 T-shirt styles all proclaiming O. J. Simpson's innocence -- "Save O. J.," "Turn the Juice Loose" -- past bystanders yelling that O. J. was framed, past the lone man with the megaphone trying to talk about the victim, past the ubiquitous television cameras.
Ms. Brown, who once modeled for Vogue magazine, looked straight ahead as she went through a metal detector, rode the elevator to the ninth floor, passed through a second metal detector and entered the small courtroom. The television commentators keep telling viewers that Nicole Brown's two sisters, Denise and Dominique, and her mother, Judy Brown, are there, while Mr. Simpson, they say, has no family members in the courtroom. 
 It is as if they are declaring that the man charged with slashing to death his former wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, could not possibly be related to the Browns. The last time they were all together was at the funeral. For two days now, they have been together in Room 9-311. The parents of the other victim, Ronald L. Goldman, have also been there.
 
Brown Family Noncommittal
 Denise Brown has said she does not want to discuss the case, adding that the Brown family will not criticize the father of Nicole's children. Denise's father, Lou Brown, has made only one comment to reporters this week, saying that the last phone call his wife had with Nicole was at 10 P.M., a statement that seemed to undercut Mr. Simpson's alibi.
There are only 65 seats, and there is a seating chart. In one way it is like a wedding, with a section designated for Mrs. Simpson's family -- as well as Mr. Goldman's -- and another for Mr. Simpson's. In Mr. Simpson's section were friends and lawyers.
There are 25 seats for news reporters, and 10 for the public. To get one of those 10 seats for today's hearing, Sharon Rogers left her 2-year-old son with a baby sitter and staked out a position in front of the courthouse at 7:30 Thursday night.
This is a city obsessed by sensational trials and lawsuits. People here name them as if they were earthquakes, or hurricanes: McMartin, Rodney King (two separate trials), Damian Williams, Michael Jackson, Heidi Fleiss, the Menendez brothers. Ms. Rogers was in the courtroom when Damian Williams and his co-defendants were acquitted of many of the charges in the beating of Reginald Denny, a truck driver, at the start of the Los Angeles riots in April 1992.
Unlike most of the people in the crowd today, Ms. Rogers said she is waiting to hear all the evidence before making a judgment about Mr. Simpson. "Everyone loves him," she said. "It's hard to imagine he did this."
Richard Burns, who arrived at the courthouse 11:30 Thursday night, also got a seat. But this morning Mr. Burns, an unemployed aerospace worker, was disappointed: He didn't get a look at the enlarged police photographs of the victims, which the prosecutor, Marcia Clark, had displayed before one witness.
"I wanted to see what they looked like," Mr. Burns said during a break. "I wanted to see how badly they were stabbed. The reports have said it was pretty bad."
In front of the courthouse, Josie Scieneaux, a vacationing loan officer at a bank, announced the consensus of the crowd, saying, "We think O. J. was framed."
Anthony Bryant, a hotel custodian on his morning off, agreed. "He could've received a phone call saying something had happened at his ex-wife's house," he said. "He saw the body and then ran into the house to check on his kids."
Ms. Scieneaux nodded. "Thank you!" she said. "He ran upstairs to check on his kids. He could've gotten blood on himself when he hugged the body. He saw his ex-wife -- you still love this person -- and he hugged her."
Mr. Bryant said: "Then he panicked. He said: 'What am I going to do now?' "
Ms. Scieneaux: "Thank you! He panicked."
 
'Couldn't Leave Him Alone'
 Ms. Scieneaux brushed off the 1989 police report describing Mr. Simpson's spousal abuse. "I think they had a fight, like any husband and wife," she said. "My husband used to hit me. I left Louisiana to get away from him. O. J. must not have been so bad. This woman couldn't leave him alone."
Rory Felix has sold T-shirts for the Rodney King trial, the Northridge earthquake and the Malibu fire. Today he was selling an O. J. Simpson T-shirt. The slogan: "Media -- Can I Get an Ounce of Truth? Not a Shred of Evidence."
"O. J.'s going to be the biggest seller," Mr. Felix said.
He added that he believed in his product. "I grew up in L.A.," he said. "I idolize O. J. He didn't do it."
Another vendor, Perris Clark, said his T-shirt -- "Let the Juice Loose" -- was inspired by Mr. Simpson's televised drive down the freeway.
"I'm not going to say who did it," Mr. Clark said. "But O. J. didn't do it. Did you look in his face? Look in his face. He didn't do it. If he did it, why would he have gone to the funeral? You have to be a strong person to do that."
 
Dismissing the Competition
 Nearby were nine competitors, all selling T-shirts for $10. Then two newcomers appeared with a new T-shirt -- "Say It Ain't So, O. J." -- for a bargain $8. Mr. Clark eyed them suspiciously. "They're capitalists," he said. "They're just here for the money. I'm trying to uplift my community."
For two days now, the prosecutors have been laying out the evidence that they hope will bring O. J. Simpson to trial. With all the attention focused on what is happening inside Courtroom 9-311, it is as if there is only one case in all of Los Angeles.
But there are more than 60 courtrooms in the Los Angeles Criminal Courts Building. Dana Rannels, 24, emerged from one this morning after testifying in a preliminary hearing involving accusations that her boyfriend assaulted her.
Ms. Rannels said she was testifying on behalf of her boyfriend, whom she declined to name. She attacked him first, she said. They struggled with an iron, she said, which ended up pressed against her face, chipping a tooth.
Leaving the courthouse, Ms. Rannels bought a "Save O. J." T-shirt. "I'm going to stand by him," she said. "I don't believe he did it."
Mr. Simpson's history of spousal abuse did not matter, she said. "I know how it happens," she added. "Why bring it back up now?"
Ozell Roberson, a 59-year-old chauffeur, was there today for Nicole Brown Simpson. He said he had made four trips to the town house where she died to leave flowers.
"Let's not forget the victims," he said.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Watches Its New-Issues Business Tumble

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The volume of new stock and bond issues tumbled in the second quarter to the lowest level since the third quarter of 1991 amid volatile financial markets and rising interest rates.
The decline was bad news for Wall Street, which saw quarterly underwriting fees fall to the lowest level in nearly three years. 
 The falloff in business during the second quarter continued a slide that began in early February, when the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time since 1989.
For the first half of 1994, the total volume of new stock and bonds sold domestically fell to $437.8 billion, according to the Securities Data Corporation, a Manhattan research firm, down 18 percent from the first six months of 1993. If not for a busy January, the numbers for the first half of the year would have looked even worse.
That point was underscored by what happened in the second quarter.
 
40% Drop From '93
 During the last three months, companies issued a total of $159.9 billion of new stocks and bonds, a drop of almost 40 percent from the comparable period a year ago, when $264.4 billion in new debt and equity was sold. Largely because of a strong January, new-issue volume in the first quarter totaled $262.1 billion. In the third quarter of 1991, domestic issuance of new stocks and bonds totaled $149.3 billion, Securities Data said. The second quarter was the worst since then.
As the year began, Wall Street executives were resigned to a business slowdown, if only because so much financing was done during the early 1990's, when interest rates were falling and stock prices were rising. But the magnitude of the decline, caused mainly by the sharp rise in interest rates since early February, caught everyone by surprise.
"Since the beginning of the year, yields on 10-year Treasury notes have risen by more than 1.50 percentage points," said Richard B. Dubusc, a managing director in the syndicated loan department at CS First Boston.
"Nobody expected that kind of a wrenching rise, and when you see something like that you sort of suspend your belief in hopes it will get better," he added. "In this sort of environment, people are funding themselves defensively, either in the commercial paper market, or through the issuance of floating rate notes."
According to Securities Data, the volume of new debt issued fell by nearly 39 percent, to $141.2 billion, from the second quarter of 1993.
But to many on Wall Street, the comparisons with what went on in 1993 are irrelevant.
"People have to keep in mind that 1993 was an aberration," said Thomas W. Davis, head of stock-capital markets at Merrill Lynch & Company.
"Virtually every month of last year was good," Mr. Davis added. "Even in 1991 and 1992, which were record years, there were tough periods. Right now we are in a tough period."
Rising interest rates and a drop in the value of the dollar also hampered new equity issues, even though the stock market spent much of the quarter moving nervously sideways.
Common stock volume totaled $14.3 billion during the quarter, down more than 30 percent from the $20.6 billion issued in the second three months of 1993.
The stock market's twists and turns were particularly frightening for companies coming to market for the first time.
During the quarter, companies raised $8.5 billion through initial public offerings, down more than 21 percent from $10.7 billion in the second quarter last year.
Not surprisingly, the steep drop in underwriting activity has had a negative impact on Wall Street's bottom line.
Underwriting fees last quarter were $1.3 billion, Securities Data said, the worst three-month period since the third quarter of 1991, when fees totaled $1 billion. In the second quarter of last year, underwriting fees were $2.2 billion.
 
Merrill Lynch Leads Again
 Merrill Lynch, the perennial underwriting leader since 1988, held on to the top spot last quarter. The company issued $26.9 billion of securities, 16.8 percent of the market, but down from its market-leading 18 percent share during the second quarter of 1993.
Kidder, Peabody, which surprised many on Wall Street when it vaulted into second place in underwritings in the first quarter on the strength of its dominance in issuing collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s, fell back to seventh place in the second quarter.
During the last three months, the firm has been besieged by an array of problems that in June prompted the General Electric Company, its parent, to make changes in its top management.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: BEHIND THE SCENES;
For Once, Powerhouse Can't Produce the Votes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
For years, Representative John D. Dingell has been one of the most intrepid investigators and dominant committee chairmen in Congress.
He has taken on the Pentagon, the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Institutes of Health. He has exposed unsafe blood banks, bottled water and pacemakers. He has championed civil rights bills and blocked gun control measures. His fingerprints are on every piece of energy and environmental legislation that has been enacted in a generation. 
 And this week, after 39 years in Congress, years in which he has made more friends and more enemies than most members of Congress have constituents, Mr. Dingell, a 67-year-old Democrat from the outskirts of Detroit, suffered the biggest disappointment of his career. He sent a letter on Tuesday to the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, saying he would be unable to muster enough votes in his Energy and Commerce Committee to approve a health care bill.
"I tried; damn, I tried," Mr. Dingell said in an interview in his office afterward. "It was simply not possible to do."
He had been unable to find a way to finance guaranteed medical insurance for all Americans that was acceptable to a majority of the 44 members of his committee, and he had refused to put out a bill that fell short of universal coverage.
 
A Monument to His Father
 Passing a universal health insurance bill with his name on it has been Mr. Dingell's goal since he entered the House in 1955 to fill a seat left vacant by the death of his father, John David Dingell Sr., to whom the bill was supposed to be a monument.
The elder Mr. Dingell survived tuberculosis as a young man and became a union leader and then a New Deal Congressman. In 1943, he sponsored the first national health insurance bill to be introduced in the House.
At the beginning of every session since the son entered Congress, he has introduced national health insurance legislation and has arranged to have it numbered H.R. 16, the number of his and his father's Congressional district.
"My dad believed, and I have always believed, that from a humanitarian standpoint it was the most important thing we could do for the country," Mr. Dingell said.
"And now," he continued, "it has ceased to be just a question of humanitarian concern. It has become an economic concern. Health care costs are going to break the country."
 
A Non-Negotiable Issue
 Mr. Dingell could have shepherded through his committee a watered-down bill that would not have guaranteed medical insurance for every American, but he refused. "Almost anything else is negotiable," he said. "Universal coverage is not."
So rather than produce a bill that would compete with those promising universal coverage that have come out of the Ways and Means Committee and the Education and Labor Committee, he swallowed his disappointment, folded his cards and cashed in his chips.
"I'm not going to dilute the currency of the President and the other committees by putting out bad coinage," he said.
Mr. Dingell blames Republicans for his failure and particularly "the religious right, the far right, who are committed to one principle alone, and that's rule or ruin."
"This is the most bitterly partisan, angry, divided Congress I have ever seen," he said.
 
A Problem of His Making
 All 17 Republicans on his committee were committed to voting against a health bill that bore even the slightest resemblance to what President Clinton proposed.
But Mr. Dingell had an additional problem, and it was largely of his own making. Five of the 27 Democrats on the committee were also prepared to vote against him: Jim Cooper of Tennessee, Ralph M. Hall of Texas, J. Roy Rowland of Georgia, Jim Slattery of Kansas and W. J. (Billy) Tauzin of Louisiana.
That was enough to deny him a majority. It was also a result of Mr. Dingell's own scheming. In the 1980's, Speakers Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Jim Wright more or less let Mr. Dingell choose the Democrats who would be on his committee. Most, if not all, of the five recalcitrant ones this year were picked by Mr. Dingell because he could count on them to vote against pollution legislation being fought by the automobile industry.
Mr. Foley does not give Mr. Dingell such free rein. But the chairman conceded that "some of those I didn't want are standing with me now better than some of those I did want."
 
The Battle Yet to Fight
 Mr. Dingell said he expected the House, after a ferocious fight and with few if any Republican votes, to pass a health bill that would guarantee insurance for all. But he said he had much less confidence that a bill acceptable to him could be passed by the Senate and clear a House-Senate conference committee.
He said he expected to be a member of the conference committee and to have a chance to work on writing the final legislation, and he is determined to block those who opposed him from having that opportunity. He is especially furious with Mr. Cooper, who is sponsoring an alternative to the President's plan.
He also plans an intense investigation of the health insurance industry, which he says is greedy, corrupt and partly responsible for the difficulty in attaining a national health bill.
And what would his father say about all this?
Mr. Dingell turned in his chair and looked at the photograph of his father, a small man with a mustache, on the cabinet behind his desk.
"He'd say, 'Son, you did right,' " the Congressman responded. "Dad was above all things else a practical politician."

He is shown in his office on Thursday. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
