HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Seesaw In Pre-Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities seesawed yesterday in an abbreviated and thinly traded pre-holiday session after a series of conflicting economic reports that failed to generate more concern about inflation and higher interest rates.
Victoria M. Schwatka, a senior vice president for Legg Mason Capital Management in Baltimore, said there was so little trading activity that she wondered whether anyone had bothered to go to work. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 848/32 , to yield 7.60 percent, down from 7.61 percent on Thursday. Shorter-maturity bills were higher, with the rate of a three-month issue up 6 basis points, to 4.18 percent, and a six-month issue up a basis point, to 4.64 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The dollar, which the market has tracked closely during the last few sessions, was mixed against most leading currencies yesterday. Mrs. Schwatka said she thought it was a good sign that the dollar was not down against all the currencies.
 
Commodity Prices Slip
 Commodity prices, another recent market irritant, were subdued yesterday, as the Commodity Research Bureau index of prices slipped 0.40 point, to 229.99.
The Government's gauge of future economic growth, the index of leading economic indicators, was unchanged in May, the Commerce Department said. "I was a little surprised, " Mrs. Schwatka said of the data. "If I had made a prediction, it may have been for a touch lower, and that would have been a long-term trend."
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its June index of manufacturing was 57.5, down from 57.7 in May, in line with expectations.
The prices-paid component index rose to 75.5, from 71.5 in May, and the highest since August 1988. Analysts said that while the gain was not surprising, it was disconcerting for the market, which is already sensitized to price increases. "That component made people uncomfortable," Mrs. Schwatka said.
Analysts said the purchasing management group's June report affirmed the continued strength in the manufacturing sector. The new orders index remained strong, rising to 62.6 percent, from 59.8 percent, as production edged back slightly to 57.5 percent. Similarly, the order backlog component eased to 60 percent. Employment slipped to 49.1 percent, from 52 percent, with the 73.5 reading on the price index the highest since August 1988.
 
Consumer Sentiment Index
 The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for June declined to 91.2 from a preliminary reading of 94.5 and from 92.8 in May. Construction spending rose nine-tenths of a percent, and was in line with expectations.
The rise in the purchasing management group's price component caused a brief dip in Treasuries, though the decline in the University of Michigan's sentiment index may have tempered the impact.
Market participants appeared to be apprehensive ahead of the Federal Open Market Committee's meetings on Tuesday and Wednesday, and next week's monthly employment report scheduled for release on Friday.
The expectations are increasing that the Fed will make a move on interest rates. "I've heard that the Federal Reserve is looking to string any kind of numbers together as an excuse to raise interest rates," Mrs. Schwatka said. She added that there was speculation that the committee might give the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, "the green light to raise rates for the fifth time this year, when he sees fit."
Rising confidence in the European bond market that the Fed will raise rates may have allowed the dollar to rebound against some European currencies, and in turn may have given some support to bond prices.

HEADLINE: New Data Suggest Slow Economic Growth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
More statistical evidence emerged today that the economy is advancing at a moderate pace, though a June survey of factory purchasing managers suggested that inflation may be set to rise.
The Government said its chief forecasting gauge of economic activity, the index of leading economic indicators, was unchanged again in May, while construction spending rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, the third consecutive monthly increase. 
 The Commerce Department said the index of leading indicators remained at 101.2 in May, matching its record high but showing no movement since March. The Government began the index in 1948.
 Analysts said the trend was further confirmation that the economy was cooling but was still in good shape. Most had expected the index to rise slightly in May.
"It should give some comfort to the financial markets, which were beginning to get another case of the 'we're growing too fast' blues," said Martin A. Regalia of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
David Orr, an economist with the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said: "My perception is we're having a mini-slowdown. It's the ebb and flow of consumer cash flow. The rate of growth has slowed, but the level of activity is fine."
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, has shown signs of slowing from the pace that fueled the surge in growth at the end of last year.
Some of the slack caused by leveling consumer demand, particularly for cars, new houses and other expensive items, is taken up by increased spending by businesses for factories and equipment, economists say.
Still, there were signs that consumers could be paying higher prices in the coming months for manufactured goods. A June survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed that more factories were paying higher prices in June than at any time in nearly six years.
The survey's broader barometer of manufacturing growth showed a mild decline in the rate of industrial expansion. But the results showed that manufacturing continued to expand, for the 10th consecutive month.
The Government's index of 11 forward-looking statistics is intended to predict economic activity six to nine months in the future. Three consecutive moves by the index in the same direction are considered a good gauge of the economy's direction.
The index had a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, its eighth consecutive increase before the current flat period.
 
Building Activity Is Up
 The construction spending reports showed increases for all leading sectors, including houses, businesses and schools. The Commerce Department said spending for all categories totaled $504.2 billion, up from a revised $499.5 billion in April, when spending increased seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for June declined to 91.2, from 92.8 in May, an indication that the outlook for the economy had soured slightly.
Economic growth is expected to be more subdued in the next six months as the full effects of rising interest rates are felt.

HEADLINE: Boston Journal;
48 Years Devoted To J.F.K. Are Over

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 1

 BODY:
Dave Powers began working for John F. Kennedy in 1946 and did not stop until today, when he retired as curator of the John F. Kennedy Library.
He heard Kennedy's first political speech in Boston and his last in Fort Worth. He was one of the President's closest aides, more of a First Friend than a policy maker. And after the assassination in Dallas -- where he helped carry the President from the Lincoln convertible into Parkland Memorial Hospital -- he devoted the rest of his life to preserving the Kennedy legacy. 
 It was more than 48 years ago that a young man showed up on Mr. Powers's doorstep and introduced himself as Jack Kennedy. Mr. Powers was an unemployed veteran living with his widowed sister and her eight children on the top floor of a three-decker tenement in Charlestown, the working-class Irish neighborhood surrounding Bunker Hill. Mr. Kennedy, an ambassador's son with a Harvard education, was mounting his first campaign for Congress. A Democratic worker had directed him to Mr. Powers as someone who knew the neighborhood, someone with political savvy who could help him.
The two men went over to the American Legion Hall, where Mr. Kennedy spoke to a group of women who had lost their sons in the war, telling them about the death of his brother Joseph. "He wasn't a great speaker, but he was an honest, sincere speaker," Mr. Powers remembered. "He looked out at these Gold Star Mothers and he said, 'I think I know how you feel, because my mother is a Gold Star Mother.' It was amazing. The women all said that he reminded them of their boys."
Their friendship began when the speech ended. During the next 18 years the two men went from house parties during the Congressional campaign to ladies' teas during the Senate race to state dinners at the White House.
Mr. Powers, now 82, was known for his sense of humor. Pierre Salinger, Kennedy's press secretary, said he was "the most gregarious and popular member of the staff."
People who served in the Administration still talk about the time the deputy premier of the Soviet Union, Anastas Mikoyan, arrived to see the President. "Are you the real Mikoyan?" Mr. Powers asked him. Then there was the state dinner that President Kennedy gave for the Shah of Iran. "You're my kind of Shah," Mr. Powers told the guest of honor.
After the assassination, Robert F. Kennedy asked Mr. Powers to catalogue the gifts that the President had received in office. "We had 16,657 three-dimensional objects," Mr. Powers said, displaying the prodigious memory that enabled him to recite the tallies of every one of his boss's elections.
And he has spent the last 30 years caring for those objects and more. In 1965 he moved them to the National Archives Federal Record Center in Waltham, Mass., where he and a staff of archivists spent the next 14 years assembling the Kennedy collection. In 1979 the collection was moved into the John F. Kennedy Library and Museum, which is housed in a large white I. M. Pei building overlooking Boston Harbor.
When the museum was refurbished last October, Mr. Powers gave the first official tour to President Clinton, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and the rest of the Kennedy family.
The museum has a director, who is in charge of the administration and the archives. As curator, Mr. Powers was responsible for the objects.
"Dave Powers is a great repository of lore about the Kennedy years," said Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian and former Kennedy aide. "He is filled with Irish stories, with political stories." Many of those stories are collected in a reminiscence, "Johnny, We Hardly Knew Ye" (Little, Brown & Company, 1970), which Mr. Powers wrote with Kenneth P. O'Donnell and Joe McCarthy.
The walls of Mr. Powers's office are covered with photographs and mementos, like the 50th birthday plaque he received from President Kennedy. "In recognition of your athletic ability in hiking to my icebox to drink my Heinekens," it says.
And ever since the Wisconsin primary he has worn the same "Kennedy in '60" tie clip in the shape of the PT-109, the vessel Kennedy made famous after World War II. As he spoke, Mr. Powers packed a Waterford crystal football -- a retirement gift from Senator Edward M. Kennedy -- into a plastic blue shoulder bag with fading white letters spelling out "White House Press."

(Associated Press); Mr. Powers, who went to work for Kennedy in his first campaign for office, in 1946, attended a baseball game with the President in 1962, above.

HEADLINE: Q&A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Withdrawing From I.R.A.
Q. When you choose the "term certain" method for withdrawing I.R.A. money, what percentage of the total holdings is withdrawn at age 70 1/2?
E. ALBRECHT, Flushing, Queens
 
A. Term certain is one of two primary ways that minimum distributions can be made from an individual retirement account. Distributions must begin by April 1 after the year in which you become 70 1/2. If you are 70 1/2 and base withdrawals on your own life expectancy, you must withdraw at least 6.25 percent in the first year under the term certain method. If you and your spouse are 70 1/2 and use joint life expectancy, you must withdraw at least 4.85 percent in the first year.
"The payment would change each year because both factors used in the calculation -- the I.R.A. balance and the life expectancy -- change each year," said Joseph J. Seymour, director of retirement services of the Quest For Value mutual funds. "The term certain method means the length of time over which the account to be distributed is certain. It does not mean that the amount of payment is certain." 
 The rate at which distributions are made if the account holder dies after starting withdrawals depends on whether the beneficiary is a spouse. Spouses can roll over the money into retirement accounts. Distribution rules are listed in Section 401(a)(9) of the Tax Code and summarized in Internal Revenue Service Publication 590.
 
Withholding From 401(k)
Q. When I roll over my 401(k) into an I.R.A., is my employer required to withhold 20 percent from my 401(k)?
PERRY M. STEWART, Yellow Springs, Ohio
 
A. It depends on whether you roll over the account directly or take a distribution and then roll it over yourself. If you ask your employer to transfer the funds directly, withholding is not required.
But when you take the distribution, your employer must withhold 20 percent of the amount received, even if you intend to put it into an individual retirement account within 60 days. When you file your tax return for the year, you can ask that the amount be refunded.
A complication may arise for people who have borrowed money from their accounts. "Be careful," said Melvin W. Borleis, managing director of William M. Mercer Inc., a benefits consulting firm. "If you have borrowed against your 401(k) account and that loan is paid off by using a portion of your account, then you may owe taxes later."

Cyclical Stocks Defined
Q. What are "cyclical" or "economically sensitive" stocks?
BEATRICE WEBER, West Palm Beach, Fla.
 
A. Such stocks belong to companies whose performances are closely linked to the economy, and their prices tend to rise and fall with the economic cycle. Auto, steel and machinery companies are considered cyclical because their products are in greater demand when the economy is expanding. .
"The converse of cyclical stocks are those that supply necessities -- the purchase of which cannot be easily postponed until the next economic upturn," said Robert N. Gordon, president of Twenty-First Securities. "These include companies such as food and drug manufacturers."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Some Gains After a Week of Declines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen yesterday for the first time in a week and gained against other currencies in light trading. But the market remained bearish about prospects for the dollar.
Dealers avoided making big trades ahead of next week's summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations and a meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making board. Either meeting could have a large impact on interest rates and international currency policies. 
 "Everyone is sitting tight; we have a big week coming up," said Win Thin, an economist at MCM Currencywatch Inc. "People are not being too aggressive either way."
Speculative pressure on the dollar eased in advance of the three-day holiday weekend in the United States. Although European and Asian markets will be open on Monday, American financial markets will be closed in observance of the Fourth of July.
The dollar started the day by falling to yet another record low in Tokyo, hitting 97.73 yen, but the Bank of Japan reportedly then intervened. Later in Europe, the dollar rallied strongly, rising close to the 100-yen level.
But the dollar began to retreat when the American financial markets opened. In late New York trading, it was quoted at 98.75 yen, up from 98.49 yen on Thursday.
It also rose in New York to 1.5955 German marks, from 1.5875 marks on Thursday.
Traders cited weakening bond prices for the dollar's erosion in New York yesterday. They expect further declines unless Washington and other governments take stronger action to support the dollar against the yen.
"You can talk about technical factors and a lot of other things people look at," said Cyrus Whitney, chief trader for Commerzbank in New York. "There's a confidence crisis, and that's not going to change for a while."
That is why traders are focusing on the Federal Open Market Committee's meeting on Tuesday and Wednesday and the Group of Seven summit meeting on Friday.
"The market is waiting to see what action the central banks and the G-7 nations take," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange for the Bank of Montreal in New York. "If there's no concrete action, it will be a green light to sell dollars."
An increase in American interest rates would probably push up the dollar by making dollar-denominated assets more attractive. But economists say the Fed is unlikely to act simply to support the dollar against the Japanese yen.
More likely is coordinated action by the Group of Seven to prevent a further weakening of the dollar. More declines in the dollar could hamper economic recoveries in Europe and Japan by depressing their exports to the United States.

HEADLINE: Six Major-Party Candidates Compete in an Open Race to Succeed Weicker

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1

 BODY:
The issues in Connecticut's race for governor have already been decided. Among the six Democrats and Republicans campaigning to succeed Lowell P. Weicker Jr., everyone agrees that the state needs more jobs and less crime.
But as the Weicker era comes to a close, neither major party is agreed on who will represent its cause on the ballot come November. At this stage, the public barely knows who is running. 
 One result is an unusually open race in a state once noted for strong party leadership, especially among the generation of Democrats raised in the ways of John M. Bailey, the powerful state and national chairman in John F. Kennedy's day.
Both parties say this election is critical. A united party could return the Democrats, who finished third in 1990, to the office they have lost only twice in 40 years. Unity could elevate the Republicans to a chair they have not captured since 1972.
Still, some of the strongest potential candidates have opted not to run. Attorney General Richard Blumenthal and United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, both Democrats, announced that they would not run for governor. So did United States Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican.
Four Democrats -- State Senator John B. Larson of East Hartford, State Senator Richard J. Balducci of Newington, State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr. and Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport -- are going to their party's convention on July 16, and a September primary is expected.
 
'Going to Give You a Choice'
 Among Republicans, Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer is intent on waging a primary, even though the party's 1990 candidate, John G. Rowland, has a large majority of delegates to its July 23 convention.
"I'm going to give you a choice on who to select for governor," Mrs. Kezer, the only Republican elected to a statewide office in 20 years, told the Greenwich Republican Town Committee last week as they met over veal parmigiana and surf and turf at a steakhouse here.
"In 1990 I won my race," she said. "John Rowland did not. Republicans need other voters, and I can appeal to them."
With the nominating conventions weeks away, the candidates are conducting several campaigns at once: courting delegates; reaching out to the voters who will take over once the conventions end, and trying to raise the money that makes it all possible.
Polls show that only Mr. Rowland, a former United States Representative from Waterbury who spent $3 million in 1990, is widely known to voters. The polls also show him with wide leads over Mrs. Kezer, all of the Democrats and Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, Mr. Weicker's successor in A Connecticut Party, a party the Governor created in 1990.
Mr. Rowland moved this week to solidify his position at the convention by announcing his choice for a running mate as lieutenant governor, State Representative M. Jodi Rell, who has represented the town of Brookfield in Fairfield County since 1984.
 
From Town to Town
 But the polls also show that people are not paying attention yet. Given all the possible match-ups among candidates, a large majority of those surveyed had no preference in nearly every pairing. And so the candidates see no doors closed yet as they speed from town to town, from party meeting to union picnic, from talk show to television taping, their stump speeches already honed, their identities ready to emerge.
"After the convention, the delegate counts don't matter," said Jane Ciarleglio, the campaign manager for Mr. Balducci, a former House Speaker, who she says is on the threshold of qualifying for a primary with 15 percent of his convention's 1,476 delegates.
In the Groton Public Library, signs of southeastern Connecticut's economic distress are everywhere. People study relocation information at the Job Search Center. A notice on a newspaper rack says the Sunday help-wanted sections from Boston, New York and Washington are held at the reference desk.
 
A Brief Appearance
 In a meeting room, the Democratic Town Committee is waiting for Senator Larson. An aide, Thomas Moukawsher, fills the time with a plea for party unity.
Mr. Larson, the Senate president and his party's best known hopeful, has the record of a classic Connecticut Democrat, progressive on social issues (an early advocate of family-leave legislation), fiscally conservative (he resisted the income tax). A 45-year-old Irish Catholic, he carries a bit of the Kennedys in his voice and manner.
As his aides are quick to point out, he also carries the support of party leaders, he is raising the most money and he has advertised on television. As the convention approaches, he is laboring to set himself apart as the Democrat who can win.
Mr. Larson, arriving late from halfway across the state, has time to thank the Groton delegation for its support -- he has been a strong advocate for the region's submarine-based industries -- and to answer one question before the library closes for the night, ending the meeting.
At Quassy Amusement Park in Middlebury, Mr. Curry stands on a picnic table to address state maintenance workers eating hot dogs and drinking beer at their union's annual picnic. As Comptroller, he has had the luxury of being a critic in residence the last four years, commenting on the state budget without having to vote on it or, like Senator Larson, to reject arbitrated pay raises for unions like the one he is addressing. He is counting on strong union support in a primary.
At 42, Mr. Curry also eerily echoes the Kennedys, especially in a knack for relaxed humor. On WATR, a Waterbury radio station, a caller asks if he is a liberal, and Mr. Curry states a familiar Connecticut creed: "I was born in a family that believed if you didn't vote Democratic, you couldn't be buried in the Catholic Church."
His fuller answer: yes, if liberal means believing that government can help people; no, if it means tax and spend.
 
'It Could Be a Lot Better'
 Mr. Curry is in a close race with Mr. Larson for delegates, but he has counted on a primary all along because his support is with the grass-roots organizations he has long worked with. With the perspective of an outsider, he disarms talk-show callers who gripe about the state government.
"It's never going to be perfect," he told one. "It's never going to be like a business. But it could be a lot better."
Senator Balducci and Mayor Ganim, with the fewest delegates, are under the most pressure to step aside for party unity. Mr. Balducci, praised for his leadership as House speaker in the state's 1991 fiscal crisis, has rejected overtures from Mr. Larson, Mr. Curry and state officials to run for lieutenant governor.
Mr. Ganim, his support limited to Bridgeport, has annoyed legislators in both Hartford and Bridgeport with television advertisements that take credit for reversing Bridgeport's fortunes while criticizing the Legislature for inaction this year.
Among the Republicans, Mr. Rowland is concentrating on raising money and trying to pry delegates from Mrs. Kezer to block a primary. At the Greenwich Town Committee, he attacked the state's new prisons as "Club Meds," vowed to eliminate the income tax, and cited his lead in the polls.
Talking about crime, he said, "You may think that here in Greenwich we're safe, but we're not."
Mrs. Kezer must make the case that a Republican primary is worthwhile, and her case is that Connecticut voters are more moderate than Mr. Rowland. She promised a voice for all voters, referendums and initiatives, term limits on state offices.
A town committee member asked grumpily how she would get state employees to work more than 35 hours a week. She replied, "They are paid for 35 hours, and the state can't afford to pay for more."
The answer, she said, was better management. "You'll never, ever be able to change state government if you go in and try to bash people over the head," she said. A handful of people applauded.

Curry Jr., talking with voters at a park in Middlebury, are in a tight race for delegates in their pursuit of the Democratic Party's nomination for governor of Connecticut. There are two other Democratic candidates and two Republican hopefuls in the primary races. (Photographs by Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tire Recycling Works, And It's Also the Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The National Association of Counties has listed waste tires as its No. 1 solid-waste problem. Unfortunately, a well-financed special interest campaign is distorting the benefits associated with implementing a section of United States transportation law that requires federally supported highways to use a small percentage of discarded tires in highway asphalt (Section 1038 of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act). 
 The use of asphalt containing "crumb rubber" is commercially viable, environmentally superior and cost-effective, and was wisely endorsed by both houses of Congress and signed into law by President Bush in 1990. It will reduce the long-term costs of highway maintenance and help improve our management of resources and waste materials.
Delay in putting this provision into practice would not only undermine the enormous efforts of cities and counties throughout the country to deal with waste tires economically and in an environmentally suitable way, but would also inflict great damage on enlightened investors who have put millions of dollars into this environmentally oriented market opportunity.
 
ALLEN HERSHKOWITZ
Senior Scientist
Natural Resources Defense Council
New York, June 23, 1994

HEADLINE: Dedicated Lawyers for Indigent Are a Bargain;
Anti-Taxpayer Verdicts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jury awards against public entities in personal-injury lawsuits have grown ominously. New York City's payout alone has gone up every year since 1986 -- the last time the State Legislature attempted tort reform -- from $103.7 million to nearly $260 million in this fiscal year. 
 Many claims are exaggerated, and some are downright fraudulent. Equally troubling, approximately one-third of every dollar paid goes into the pockets of a few hundred personal-injury lawyers. Nationwide, such lawyers collect more than $15 billion a year in contingency fees!
Yet a June 17 front-page article asks readers to believe there is no problem. Unfortunately, we are not told about the sampling methods your sources used. Moreover, the conclusion that jury verdicts have come out of the stratosphere is contradicted by the president of the local plaintiffs' bar association whom you quote.
In many cases that go to trial, the plaintiff has a significant injury but a weak liability claim. Such cases are more likely to wind up in a so-called defendant's verdict, but often they result in "sympathy" verdicts. When plaintiffs with essentially meritless claims read of a subway mugger who recovers millions, it encourages them to spurn nuisance-value settlements. Often in such cases the jury awards less than if the plaintiff were blameless. Any alleged falloff in the average award may have as much to do with an increase in frivolous litigation as with changing juror attitudes.
Even if we accept that verdicts in other states are holding steady, New York's have skyrocketed. Last year saw verdicts in successive weeks of $104 million (against the city) and $196 million (against private defendants). This fiscal year, New York City and its Health and Hospitals Corporation have been hit for five awards of more than $40 million, as against only three such awards ever before.
The Mayor has submitted measures to the State Legislature to tame runaway juries, especially in "noneconomic loss." The bills would limit the amount of pain and suffering-type awards to $250,000, and bar any such recovery unless a plaintiff can show that he or she incurred medical expenses of at least $5,000.
These measures would bring us in line with 39 states that have established reasonable limits to protect taxpayers, while giving the injured full economic recovery (medical expenses, lost pay) and a substantial recovery for noneconomic injuries.
The city is also supporting a measure submitted by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that would result in having cases against the city tried by a judge sitting without a jury, exactly as against the state itself. Together, these reforms mean the taxpayers save money.
 
PAUL A. CROTTY
Corporation Counsel
New York, June 21, 1994

HEADLINE: 137 Cubans Land in Florida; Largest Boatload Since 1980

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 1

 BODY:
The largest single boatload of Cuban refugees to land in Florida since the Mariel boatlift in 1980 docked here today, joining a wave of Cubans fleeing their homeland that is the greatest since the 1980 influx, when 125,000 landed in Florida.
The 137 men, women and children who made the 90-mile journey from Cuba in a 75-foot steel-hulled freighter pushed this year's total to 3,854; of that total, 1,173 arrived in June. With the year now at the halfway mark, the number of Cuban refugees arriving by raft or boat has surpassed the total of 3,656 who fled here in all of 1993, immigration officials say. 
 "It's by far the busiest month and year since the Mariel boatlift of 1980," said Petty Officer Rob Wyman, a Coast Guard spokesman here.
The vessel was monitored by the Coast Guard for several days as it made its way near the Bahamas, Mr. Wyman said, and was escorted to shore by a Coast Guard patrol boat when it arrived off Miami Beach.
 
More Haitians, Too
 Agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service interviewed the Cubans and turned them over to Church World Services, an organization that helps refugees settle in the United States.
Along with the new influx of Cubans, the Coast Guard halted 1,667 Haitians in June, the highest monthly total since 1992, when President George Bush ordered the return of all Haitians found at sea.
Russ Bergeron, a spokesman for the immigration agency, said the refugees were leaving their homelands for different reasons.
The main reason for the influx of Cubans, Mr. Bergeron said, is a deteriorating economy at home. In addition, he said, the weather this year has been more favorable than usual for crossing the Straits of Florida in inner-tube rafts or small boats.
As for the Haitians, he said, many have fled partly because of President Clinton's announcement in May that those found at sea would be interviewed for possible political asylum, creating a heightened "anticipation of the opportunity of gaining some sort of relief."
 
Fear of Oppression
 Although both Cuba and Haiti are undergoing economic difficulties, some of the refugees say they have fled because they fear political oppression or violence.
Rolando Mora, a 30-year-old music instructor from a town near Havana, arrived in Key West this morning after a Coast Guard cutter rescued him and two friends from a raft made from gas cans and wooden planks. Mr. Mora said he had been jailed in Cuba for a year for speaking against the Government of Fidel Castro.
"I wrote a song about the Commandant," Mr. Mora said, referring to Mr. Castro. "It explains everything that is happening" in Cuba, he added, saying the the last verse ends with a vow to leave Cuba on a raft.
Since the breakup of the Soviet Union in 1991 and the subsequent loss of Soviet subsidies, Mr. Castro has resorted to tight rationing measures. In Haiti, where military officers have ruled since September 1991 after ousting the nation's democratically elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, sanctions imposed by the United States have squeezed the Haitian economy.
Concerned about the possibility of another large influx of refugees, the Coast Guard has stepped up its patrols off Florida. Last weekend, Coast Guard officials said, 786 Haitians in 25 boats were intercepted.
Starting June 15, the Coast Guard has been taking any Haitians found at sea to a Navy medical ship off Jamaica, where they are interviewed to determine if they should be given a hearing for asylum. Those who are not granted hearings are returned to Haiti.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 4, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about 137 Cuban refugees landing in Florida misstated the number of Haitians who were halted by the Coast Guard in June. It was 5,603, not 1,667.

Companies
Top executives of Federated Department Stores presented their plan to board members of R. H. Macy & Company for merging the two retail companies amid increasing signs that Federated's turbulent courtship of Macy may finally pay off. [Page 33.] 
 Competition has forced big food wholesalers like the Fleming Companies of Oklahoma City to move beyond their original roles, crossing into the retail food business and blurring the line between the grocer and the middleman. [33.]
 A unit of Pfizer has agreed to pay $10.75 million to settle Justice Department claims that the company lied to gain Federal approval for a mechanical heart valve that has fractured, killing hundreds of patients worldwide. [33.]
 Three banking companies announced merger deals, a sign of what analysts say is an increase in the pace of financial mergers. Banks, they say, are benefiting from rising stock prices and are acquiring other institutions to expand into key markets in advance of Congress's passing a nationwide interstate banking law. [33.]
 A merged CBS and QVC probably would not see a decrease in its earnings per share, analysts say, even after paying CBS shareholders about $2.9 billion in cash. [34.]
 First Brands plans to sell its Prestone antifreeze business to the unit's managers and Vestar Capital Partners, a New York investment firm. The terms were not disclosed. [35.]
Bally Entertainment has filed with the Federal Trade Commission for clearance to buy as much as 25 percent of Circus Circus Enterprises. But analysts said Bally would have difficulty raising the money for such a transaction. [35.]
 Nippon Telegraph and Telephone plans to list its shares on the London and New York stock exchanges to improve its profile abroad and help it raise funds more easily. [35.] ITT Hartford Insurance created a new type of corporate retreat with a social payoff when 60 of its employees painted a shelter for the homeless. [21.]
 
Markets
 The volume of new stock and bond issues tumbled in the second quarter to the lowest level since the third quarter of 1991 amid volatile financial markets and rising interest rates. [33.]
 Stocks rose in light trading as the dollar rallied against some leading currencies. The Dow rose 21.69 points, to 3,646.65. [34.]
 The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen for the first time in a week and gained against other currencies. [41.]
 Copper prices climbed for a third consecutive session. Crude oil prices rose, but the Commodity Research Bureau's index slipped 0.36 point, to 230.03. [41.]
 Prices of Treasury securities seesawed in an abbreviated and thinly traded pre-holiday session. The yield on the long bond fell to 7.60 percent, from 7.61 percent on Thursday. [42.]
 
The Economy
 The chief gauge of economic activity was unchanged in May, the Government said, while construction spending rose slightly, providing more statistical evidence that the economy is advancing at a moderate pace. But a June survey of factory purchasing managers suggested that inflation may be set to rise. [42.]
 
Your Money
 Some companies and benefits consultants are creating extensive retirement plans that suggest just how diverse workers' investment options may be in the future. [31.]
 A low-risk variation of arbitrage can be played by individual investors who become shareholders in companies that sell their stock to the public at a discount. [31.]
 Ford is offering home equity loans that come with rebates on the purchase or lease of the auto makers' cars and trucks. But many lenders are offering more attractive deals. [31.]

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
CALLED OUT, by A.G. Mojtabai. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.) An abstract, intelligent novel, ostensibly about a jet crash in a small town, that renders the reactions of the witnesses to a random disaster in beautiful, somber prose.
 
CIGARETTES ARE SUBLIME, by Richard Klein. (Duke University, $21.95.) People smoke them because they are dangerous, and for a lot of other reasons as well, according to this polemical, analytical, lit-critical, theoretical, political ode to deathweed by an up-to-date professor of French.
 
COLORED PEOPLE: A Memoir, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. (Knopf, $22.) A distinguished American scholar's intricate, captivating account of the rich family and community life of black people in Piedmont, W.Va., on the eve of desegregation.
 
GAY NEW YORK: Gender, Urban Culture, and the Making of the Gay Male World, 1890-1940, by George Chauncey. (Basic Books, $25.) A historian's enormously informative study of 50 years during which a flourishing gay culture carved out public and private space for itself.
 
IN TOUCH: The Letters of Paul Bowles, edited by Jeffrey Miller. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) Selections from the "out" box of the enigmatic writer, composer and Tangerine; often forthright and withdrawn at once, some of them contain passages as brilliant as any in his printed work.
 
A JOURNEY THROUGH ECONOMIC TIME: A Firsthand View, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Born in 1908, the preternaturally lucid and articulate Mr. Galbraith has kept his eyes open ever since and seen a great deal he didn't care for.
 
JUSTICE LEWIS F. POWELL JR., by John C. Jeffries Jr. (Scribners, $30.) An illuminating biography of a pivotal Justice of the Supreme Court whose instinctive conservatism was always tempered by his respect for the rule of law and his willingness to listen hard.
 
MOSES SUPPOSES, by Ellen Currie. (Simon & Schuster, $20.) A welcome first collection of Ms. Currie's short stories, new and old; in relationships gone wrong, in everyday objects, she discerns hints of large meanings and glimmers of submerged mysteries.
 
ROOMMATES: My Grandfather's Story, by Max Apple. (Warner, $19.95.) An enthralling novelistic memoir of the infinitely durable Herman (Rocky) Goodstein, who at 93 accompanied Mr. Apple to college and proved, in the long run, to be worth all the trouble he caused.
 
SHOT IN THE HEART, by Mikal Gilmore. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Fifteen years after Norman Mailer's "Executioner's Song," Gary Gilmore's youngest brother reclaims his own life in this highly personal account of his family.
 
THE WAGES OF GUILT: Memories of War in Germany and Japan, by Ian Buruma. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) An examination, by an impressively informed and empathetic journalist, of the ways in which the cataclysms of our century have shaped national identity.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 14; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3044 words

HEADLINE: SPECTATOR SPORT;
R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr.

BYLINE: By Dinitia Smith; Dinitia Smith is a novelist and journalist in New York City.

 BODY:
DAVE GERGEN CALLED ME on Thursday," says R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr., editor in chief of The American Spectator, the conservative monthly. David Gergen is the White House Counselor.
Tyrrell -- "Bob," as he is known -- is telling me about the call as we drive in his Mercedes through suburban Virginia to the supermarket to buy a pie. 
 "Gergen said, 'How ya' doing?' "
" 'Better 'n you, Dave!' I say.
" 'Why's that, Bob?' he asks.
" 'It's great to be a free man!' I say."
What Gergen wanted, Tyrrell says, was an advance look at the April-May issue of The American Spectator. In January, The Spectator had published "His Cheatin' Heart," by David Brock, an investigative writer alleging that four Arkansas state troopers arranged sexual encounters for then-Governor Clinton. Now there was to be a second installment of Troopergate.
Another trooper had come forward to say he had solicited sexual partners for Clinton and seized upon "residual" opportunities for himself. The article maintained that a trooper loyal to Clinton had had his state car repaired at a body shop he himself owned. And the list of malfeasance continued. Attempted seduction at the state fair, during a trip to the Arkansas-S.M.U. football game, at an Oriental barbecue restaurant in Little Rock. The energies of the Governor and his troopers seemed limitless.
"Boy Clinton!" Tyrrell nearly spits it out. "He's abused his power with these women! He's corrupted the entire State Police! He's involved in deception!
"Do you know what he did to Paula Corbin Jones?" Tyrrell asks. Jones is the Arkansas woman who sued the President for supposedly making a sexual advance to her. A secondhand version of Jones's story, one she disputes, first appeared in The Spectator in January. Clinton "had a trooper summon her," Tyrrell says, going on with a lurid description of the sex act that ensued, or didn't.
Bob Tyrrell talks like a man obsessed -- with the Clintons' sex life, with their tax returns, with their investments. During the 1992 Presidential campaign, The Spectator published a scathing piece on Hillary, "The Lady Macbeth of Little Rock." Another said Mrs. Clinton had asked state troopers to get sanitary napkins for her. Last year The Spectator published "The Real Anita Hill," by David Brock, who referred to Hill as "a bit nutty and a bit slutty" and said she returned exam papers to students with pubic hairs on them. To Tyrrell, feminists are bed wetters. And as for homosexuals, they're bringing about "an end to community," says Tyrrell. Plus, they have heads shaped like "butternut squash," The American Spectator once said.
All this annoys the White House. George Stephanopoulos, a White House adviser, says: "The American Spectator's journalistic standards are on a par with The National Enquirer's. It's pulp fiction! Trash! Tabloid! It's not journalism."
Maybe that's why, in just two years, the circulation of The Spectator has increased tenfold, from 30,000 to 300,000. The circulation of journals of opinion generally rises when the opposition is in power; today The Spectator's exceeds both The Nation's (around 90,000) and the New Republic's (around 100,000). The Spectator, redesigned with a glossy cover and now advertised on Rush Limbaugh's shows, has inched past the more sedate National Review, long the dominant conservative journal. "I think The Spectator is terrific," says William F. Buckley Jr., editor in chief of The National Review and a friend and hero of Tyrrell's. "That zany stuff up front," -- Tyrrell's column, "The Continuing Crisis" -- "the investigative stuff, is attracting a lot of attention," he adds.
"The image of conservatives has always been somewhat nerdy, 90-pound weakling types," says Wladyslaw Pleszczynski, managing editor of The Spectator. "Bob's is an athletic, vigorous conservatism. He has made it possible to think of conservatives as stylish and witty. He encouraged the neo-cons to come into the magazine's pages. He was instrumental in forming the Reagan coalition." Indeed, at The Spectator's 25th anniversary dinner, in 1992, virtually every important figure in the conservative movement showed up -- Irving Kristol, Jeane Kirkpatrick, John Sununu, Gen. William Westmoreland, Judge Robert Bork, Jack Kemp. The magazine, with its office on a quiet street in Arlington, Va., and 22 employees, is liberally financed by conservative groups like the Sarah Scaife Foundation and the Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation, and contributions from its affluent, well-educated and mostly male readers.
THE AMERICAN SPECTATOR IS BOB Tyrrell's creation. He assigns its big investigative pieces and plans its grand strategy. Along with the magazine's Swiftian satire is some serious reporting built on a consistent conservative philosophy: in February, a long piece by John Corry on M.I.A.'s; regular reports from Russia on its burgeoning democracy; continuing coverage of health care reform. (The Spectator says the Clinton health plan will fail because of an overburdened bureaucracy.) On foreign policy, The Spectator is pro-Israel and believes that the United States should defend democracies everywhere.
Each month Tyrrell invests his column with observations on everything from the death of former President Richard Nixon -- "he aged gracefully and died in the spring" -- to the Clinton Administration's failed Bosnian policy to sculptures at Evergreen State College, in Washington, that celebrate the power of women. One word that appears often is "Kultursmog," Tyrrell's term for "a politicized culture whose values, discourse and anxieties are polluted by the left's many contending interests."
Tyrrell is a small, compressed, bristling man of 50, with pale blue eyes, long eyebrows and a surprisingly high-pitched voice. "He has this Midwestern twang," says his friend Taki Theodoracopulos, a contributor to The Spectator. "I tell him, 'You've got to stay away from public speaking because of your terrible accent!' "
Tyrrell resembles the Irish cops who were his forebears on his father's side; he claims his great-great-grandfather, P. D. Tyrrell, a Secret Service agent, prevented a man from stealing President Lincoln's body from his grave. These days, Tyrrell disdains the Treasury Department because it houses the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. "Those people are against everything we believe in!" he says. The pages of The Spectator are filled with Tyrrell's essays in favor of alcohol, tobacco -- and fatty foods.
Tyrrell stops his car in front of his house, in a prosperous development near the Beltway. An American flag flies out front. "Just a stone's throw from Teddy Kennedy," Tyrrell says. "And I supply the stones!"
Inside hang autographed pictures of Presidents Bush, Reagan and Nixon. Tyrrell lives alone, though his three children, P. D. (Patrick), 20, Katy, 18, and Annie, 13, often stay over. Tyrrell has been divorced from Judy Matthews Tyrrell for almost five years. "He's very difficult to live with," says Taki Theodoracopulos. "He expects every woman to 'do her duty.' I think there was some tension there because she wanted to be independent." Tyrrell's book of observations and reminiscences, "The Conservative Crack-Up," contains a rather sour account of his marriage: "She resorted to tennis, then religion and then psychotherapy. Finally she tried divorce -- all common American coping mechanisms for navigating middle age." Ms. Tyrrell is now a divorce lawyer with Sandground, Barondess and West in McLean, Va., a firm known for its aggressive style. Bob Tyrrell boasts about his nights out at Annabelle's, in London, and his fondness for "physiologically well-appointed women."
Tyrrell's humor has a manic, compulsive quality. When he wants to say something, especially after he has had a couple of drinks, it's hard to stop him. "I like him except when he gets drunk," Theodoracopulos says. "When he gets drunk he speaks about The Spectator nonstop."
Tyrrell does most of his work from home, writing his column and his books, six to date. (Unlike many political columnists', Tyrrell's books are not simply recycled writings.) From his library, Tyrrell calls Wlady Pleszczynski, the 44-year-old son of Polish concentration camp survivors who runs the magazine on a daily basis. "Editor-in-chief-for-life here!" Tyrrell barks into the phone. "Wlady, is there anything I should know?" Pause. "The Ten Commandments? Ye-es." Another pause. "The Lord's Prayer? I'm being serious, for Chrissakes."
Tyrrell is a practicing Catholic -- "Practice makes perfect," he says. What influenced his political ideas? He responds oddly. "Yeats's absorption in magic was as inexplicable to me as some people's absorption in Chinese cuisine." Yeats is one of Tyrrell's intellectual heroes, along with Mencken and Luigi Barzini.
He was raised in River Forest-Oak Park, Ill. His mother came from a prosperous Chicago family, which has given Tyrrell financial independence. Tyrrell is vague about his father. Some accounts say he was a Pabst brewery worker. "I think he may have represented Pabst in some way," Tyrrell says. "My father was the most successful man I ever knew -- he never wanted to do anything in his life. And he never did anything." Tyrrell was educated by Dominican friars in high school and traces his love of language to them. He went to Indiana University because of its fine swim team, whose coach, James E. Counsilman, he counts as a major intellectual influence. During workouts, Counsilman would lecture on art and politics. "Mozart or Puccini might lilt over the public-address system," Tyrrell wrote in "The Conservative Crack-Up," "instilling a fear in many of the nearby students of physical education that homosexuals had taken the place over."
At Indiana, Tyrrell was in Phi Kappa Psi with Steve Tesich. "We were antifraternity people in a fraternity," Tesich remembers. Later, Tesich wrote the screenplay for "Breaking Away," a film about a group of Indiana students with intellectual pretensions, not unlike Tyrrell himself. Tyrrell went on to get his master's in diplomatic history. While a graduate student, he joined a conservative supper club, the "Beer and Pizza Marching Society," where he met a young law student, Dan Quayle. "We'd sit around and have little conspiracy meetings on how we could reduce government -- and put ourselves out of a job." says Quayle. "Tyrrell would pontificate about the virtues of less government. Of course, I needed a job!" (Despite their friendship, Quayle once told a reporter he had trouble getting through The American Spectator. Tyrrell took revenge by ridiculing Quayle in a cover story, "Why Danny Can't Read." "He's an engaging person," Quayle says now, "and his opinions come from a solid intellectual foundation.")
When Quayle and Tyrrell were students, the campus was in the throes of rebellion from the left. "It bothered him there wasn't the other side of the political spectrum being expressed by students," Tesich says. So in 1967 Tyrrell founded The Alternative (which became The American Spectator in 1977), publishing it from "a right-wing libertarian commune" in a farmhouse near Bloomington, Ind. Later, the paper was fortified with a grant from the Eli Lilly Foundation, established by the Indiana pharmaceuticals family.
In 1986 the Tyrrells moved to Washington to be near "the center of the political circus," he says. But Bob Tyrrell retains a kind of nostalgia for the good old days, when sex was "an extremely serious engagement, a mystery," when people could hurl racial slurs at one another without necessarily getting killed. In the old days, says Tyrrell, "there was far more ethnic and racial and religious integration in cities like Chicago. Men would refer to 'The Micks,' 'The Papists,' 'The Yids'! These were rich, flavorous terms -- though sometimes they would betray real enmity," he admits as we sit down to dinner at his house.
The dinner, veal and braised fennel, has been cooked by his Grenadian housekeeper, Doreen Gibbs. "In the Caribbean they don't talk about racism!" Tyrrell says, watching Gibbs serve. "I don't believe black people are less intelligent. Black people from the Caribbean are extremely well educated. What really hurt them isn't the color of their skin. They were impoverished people who came into American society when the welfare state was in place. Thank God it's not happened to Caribbean people who came into my kitchen! I love the lilt of their voices and the cheer they bring."
As Tyrrell speaks, Gibbs smiles -- mockingly, I think -- puts a dish on her head and marches back into the kitchen.
Tyrrell tells me about a PEN benefit where he was a guest of Ted Forstmann of the investment bank Forstmann Little. "A bore beyond belief!" Tyrrell says. "There was some moron from South Africa, then Peter Jennings talking about Reaganism as if it were Stalinism -- as though the Reagan years were not the longest period of economic growth in peacetime! I spent the rest of the evening blowing up a condom. Repeatedly, I'm proud to say. And let the air out so it sounded like a Bronx cheer. Somebody told me Barry Diller was appalled!"
Forstmann has contributed money to The Spectator. "Bob is a very bright guy, extremely well read," he says. "At times he's extremely witty. I don't think the PEN dinner is a good example of that wit. He was very unwitty at the PEN dinner. His behavior was unlike anything I ever saw."
The playwright Tony Kushner also spoke at the dinner. Tyrrell says, "His technique is superb; his message is idiotic." Two years ago The Spectator ran a piece by Michael Fumento, author of "The Myth of Heterosexual AIDS," saying reports of AIDS among women and heterosexuals are greatly exaggerated. "AIDS is lethal," Tyrrell says. "But they're forever trying to magnify a sensible point out of proportion. Heterosexual cases are practically nonexistent. The latest studies show that only 2 to 3 percent of Americans are homosexuals. Kinsey was wrong in saying it was 10 percent. There are thousands of years of moral teaching suggesting homosexuality is wrong."
The Spectator has written pieces disapproving of homosexuality, I point out, yet one of its star writers, David Brock, is openly gay. "He hasn't made it a goddamned issue!" Tyrrell says. "He hasn't bored me to death with discussions of his sex life."
It is getting late, but Tyrrell still has energy. He takes out a Montecristo No. 1, appraises it. "They're so whipped in that country," he says of Cuba, "they can't even make cigars."
THE NEXT DAY, I HAVE LUNCH with David Brock. It is an awkward conversation. Even Brock's mother was upset when he wrote his article criticizing Anita Hill. Then there had been a debate in the press about whether Brock's being gay made him a misogynist and affected his reporting.
As for his article on Hill, Brock says, "That was not misogynist," though "it may have been an exaggeration." His reporting of the Troopergate piece was criticized, I point out; some of the troopers had been accused of drunken driving and insurance fraud. "Any private citizen is going to have something in his background -- a broken marriage, a parking ticket," Brock says.
Does he have a problem as a gay man writing for a magazine, and an editor, critical of homosexuals? "The American Spectator has always been unlike other conservative magazines. I don't feel hypocritical that it publishes pieces critical of the gay life style; I find the people who edit the magazine quite tolerant."
That night, Brock, Tyrrell and I have dinner at the Jockey Club with Andy Ferguson, former assistant managing editor of The Spectator, and Tyrrell's son, P. D., a student at Loyola University.
Tyrrell mentions AIDS again. "Militant homosexuals have tried to keep up the hysteria about AIDS. AIDS is spread by promiscuous homosexual sex. Homosexuals, responsible and restrained, have been less of a problem."
"I'm in the responsible-and-restrained category," Brock interjects.
Tyrrell takes a party favor -- a hazelnut -- out of his pocket and bangs it against the table. A condom pops out. P. D. Tyrrell watches his father but doesn't smile.
To distract Tyrrell, I ask, "What are the major concerns of The American Spectator?" "Our major concern is freedom in America!" he cries.
The next morning Tyrrell and I have a last conversation on the deck of his house. His allergies are bothering him. The roar of planes from Andrews Air Force Base mixes with the noise of traffic on the Beltway.
I ask Tyrrell about a comment from Victor Navasky, on leave as editor of The Nation, that The American Spectator has become "part of the tabloidization of the press." "They appear to have bought into the same thing as the TV news magazines, in a lurid and irresponsible way," Navasky says.
Tyrrell replies, "When you have a President leading a tabloid life, those who report on him are going to sound like a tabloid."
I also ask Tyrrell about his views on feminists. In "The Liberal Crack-Up" he wrote: "The vast majority of feminists were disagreeable misanthropes, horrible to behold, uncouth and unlovely . . . burdened by a splitting headache, halitosis, body odor and other ailments too terrible and obscure to mention."
Tyrrell now says: "There was an element of exaggeration. It was there for poetic effect. Betty Friedan was the worst -- that charlatan!" He stops, glances at me for my reaction.
"You're embarrassed?" I ask.
"I am not!" Tyrrell says stoutly.
I turn to something less provocative: his predictions for the Clinton Presidency.
"The economy is going to get worse," says Tyrrell. "There are going to be more revelations about financial chicanery and political corruption in Clinton's personal life. I think it's entirely possible he'll be challenged for the 1996 nomination." Tyrrell says he believes that Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska might even take the Democratic nomination -- and that Senator Robert Dole of Kansas will be the Republican challenger.
Tyrrell and I say goodbye, and I pay Tyrrell's occasional driver, Jim Vetter, to take me to the airport. "He's really having a ball with this Clinton thing," Vetter tells me. "I guess a lot of liberals don't like it. But -- what the hell! This is America!"

LENGTH: 712 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
American Center Finally Open in Paris

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THERE may be a glimmer at the end of the tunnel, but you couldn't yet call it light. Bruised feelings abound and question marks remain. Still, after two years of crisis and nine months past its projected unveiling last September, the new American Center in Paris is open at last.
The opening party, with American and French V.I.P.'s prowling about Frank Gehry's playful, commanding new building on the Rue de Bercy and the adjacent new park, was on June 7; the public was admitted the next day. The June 7 date was chosen to connect with the June 6 D-Day celebrations, and perhaps initially in the hope that a Clinton or two might grace the center. In the end, center officials had to go over to the American Embassy in Paris for Hillary Rodham Clinton to proclaim the facility open. 
 But open it is, and physically, at least, it's a beauty. Mr. Gehry's design was criticized in some French quarters as not wild and crazy enough, as if the Los Angeles architect had pulled his punches for genteel, ladylike Paris. But Mr. Gehry deftly explained how his building had been inspired by Paris itself, and most of the post-opening articles in the French press positively purred with pleasure. In fact, the new center does blend Mr. Gehry's Krazy Kat deconstruction with functionality and homages to Paris, in its limestone surface and swooping mansard roofs.
Functional the building may be, but for what functions? The center dates back to 1931, and for decades it puttered along happily on the Boulevard Raspail in Left Bank Paris, offering English language courses and a lively array of then not-so-well-known American vanguard artists. In 1987, with their building decaying, center officials cut a deal with the City of Paris, which was seeking to develop its rundown Bercy district in the 12th arrondissement. The new center was built using nearly all the money from the sale of the old one, some $40 million. (The old site is now occupied by Jean Nouvel's spiffy new headquarters for the Cartier Foundation.)
But then the recession hit, fund-raising dried up and the second-guessing began. The old team -- meaning Judith Pisar, the board chairman, and Henry Pillsbury, the executive director -- was blamed for not holding back any of the Raspail money and for isolating their new building on the eastern outskirts of Paris. The newly hired programming staff was messily fired in 1992. The opening was delayed, and a board transition team, headed by Frederick B. Henry of the Bohen Foundation and Rachel Newton Bellow of the Mellon Foundation, organized the first year's programs.
Nearly everyone's feelings were hurt. Mrs. Pisar felt undervalued, and what appears to be an industrious public-relations campaign has burnished her image. Although Mr. Henry and Ms. Bellow kept a low profile at the opening party, both Mrs. Pisar and Mr. Pillsbury are still scheduled to relinquish their current titles at a September board meeting, and the search is on for a new executive director. The old programming staff is still bitter. Artists with postponed or canceled projects are disgruntled, as are a few younger artists who won fellowships for study in Paris and then complained the center let them down. (Mr. Pillsbury insisted there was only one real complainer and that the center had fulfilled all its obligations.)
Starving artists or no, the June 7 party was a corker, mostly paid for by Philip Morris, with lavish food and music by the Cajun band Loup Garou and David Byrne. Maybe this show of flashy bravado will convince enough donors that the center is a going operation worthy of support. Already, several million dollars for both the projected $25 million endowment and the $5 million annual operating budget are in hand, and vanguard events of one sort or another will partly fill the center to year's end.
With luck, Mr. Gehry's fabulous shell will slowly fill with life. That means not only its gallery spaces and black-box theaters and 400-seat legitimate theater and 100-seat film theater, but also its library and apartments and lobbies and foyers and concessions and restaurants. Mr. Gehry has said he wanted to build a self-contained city, teeming with life. So far, he's got a gorgeous monument to an as-yet unrealized cultural ambition.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new center, 51 Rue de Bercy. (Erich Koyama)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet Impala SS;
Heavy Metal Act Gets an Encore With a 60's Hit

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
"IT'S a funny thing," a colleague once said to me in Detroit. "You want to talk cars, you go to the Ford guys. They like cars. But if you want to buy a car, you go to G.M. The company is huge and gray and all that, but those guys turn out some really neat stuff."
True, even if it is a bit unfair to Ford and the rest, which have had their moments. 
 But consider this: the 1959 Cadillac, immense and drenched in chrome, with torpedo taillights and giant fins, was Detroit's most outrageous foray into conspicuous consumption. G.M., right?
Then there is the Corvette, a pure-zoom sledgehammer of a sports car that has been in steady production for 41 years and is as good as anything in the world. G.M., of course.
And G.M. has come up with such pleasant oddities as Pontiac's innovative plastic-body Fiero and Chevrolet's rear-engine Corvair -- which was terrific and could have become even better if G.M. had continued to develop it instead of caving in to attacks on the car by Ralph Nader.
All the same, none of these products were what one would expect from a corporation of bean counters and committees, committees, committees.
My friend was right. And that's why we shouldn't be surprised at the likes of the latest anomaly, the 1994 Chevrolet Impala SS.
 The Impala is, of course, a Caprice in drag, and it moves away from a stoplight faster than anything else its size. We'll get to that.
First, consider the basic Caprice, a full-size four-door sedan that is America's favorite taxi.
I first drove the Caprice in its cab-stand mode three years ago. That test car was New York City's first '91 yellow Caprice, with a light on its roof and a meter on the dashboard. If I'd taken money out of one pocket and put it into the other, it would have cost me $45.10 to get from Manhattan to my home on Long Island.
Such a fare might, in fact, have been justified, because the standard Caprice has a 5-liter V8 engine and it weighs 4,000 pounds, so the fuel economy is not quite a match for the small stuff from Honda and Toyota and Saturn. But that hasn't mattered to a certain segment of the population, even though Caprice sales have disappointed G.M.
In mufti, painted a more sensible color and wearing whitewalls, the Caprice has a base price of $19,570, and it sells 90,000 copies a year to taxi and government fleets and people like me who love old-fashioned iron.
The car is big. It has room in front, room in back. An automatic transmission makes it civil in town, but its true worth is out on the highway, and it glides effortlessly over America's concrete.
Now, though, General Motors has dressed its whale in muscles, creating the first Impala SS -- for Super Sport -- since 1969. The car elicited raves when it was introduced as a concept vehicle at the 1993 New York Auto Show, and this year's production model drew 9,000 orders. About 3,000 of those went unfilled because of a lack of production capacity. Next year, though, G.M. plans to make 15,000 Impalas.
It might have been even more attractive if G.M. had offered it as a two-door hardtop, and Chevrolet Engineering did produce two such cars at an early introduction, but they were simply toys for the designers. So what we have -- and what you can buy for $22,495 -- is a black (only black) version of the Caprice-as-muscle-car.
Instead of the standard Caprice's 170-horsepower engine, the Impala SS carries a 5.7-liter Corvette engine that produces 260 horsepower. The juice goes to the road through an electronically controlled four-speed automatic, and four-wheel anti-lock disk brakes are standard.
The low hood rises on dual gas struts, and the engine sits way back from the nose, mounted fore to aft and driving the rear wheels, as with other Caprices. When you're feeling mellow the engine drives the car with quiet aplomb. The Impala is basically docile, smooth and slick. But when you stamp on the accelerator, the SS becomes its namesake.
As might be expected, the car is f-a-a-s-t, and the engine screams. Zero-to-60 acceleration takes only 7 seconds, and the top speed is 158 miles an hour. On the road, the Impala handles well, behaving unlike most of its large domestic brethren. It is comfortable and has European manners, which is to say there is no wallow.
Standing still, you are struck by its sleek and swoopy body, with bumpers that sweep into the profile and aggressive molded wheels with wide openings that reveal the huge disk brakes. Modern as the body is, though, it harks to the past by sitting on an old-fashioned frame, unlike most of today's cars, whose unit-construction dispenses with a separate chassis.
 
A Chevy bow-tie emblem graces the mesh grille, and an Impala SS logo stretches for two feet along the rear fenders, just ahead of the wraparound taillights. Outrageous as the label is, it is subtle, too, because it is black and blends into the body. Chrome Impala emblems also dress up the rear-window pillars and the trunk, which has a small spoiler on its trailing edge.
Under the lid, the felt-wrapped spare -- smaller than the Impala's fat tires but still full size -- takes up a lot of space. The liftover for luggage is also fairly high, and the taillights intrude into the trunk, meaning there is less space there than might be expected.
Inside the car, though, there is room aplenty. The upholstery is done in gray leather, nicely finished and very comfortable. The driver's view is no different from that in other Caprices, with a soft plastic dash, dual air bags and the usual four-spoke steering wheel, the entire hub of which serves as a horn.
Like many G.M. cars, the Impala has a remote release button in the glove box that opens the luggage compartment. Unlike earlier cars, though, the button works with the ignition off, which makes it useful when you pocket the key and then remember that you needed something in the trunk.
Other remote buttons reside in the key fob, allowing you to open the trunk or lock or unlock the doors from afar. That feature is particularly useful when you want to get inside quickly and safely on a dark night in the city.
Power equipment is standard, and it includes things like an electrochromatic rear-view mirror to deal with those insensitive sons who barrel up from behind with high beams ablaze. The mirror, which automatically dims that glare, incorporates dual reading lights, and there are other nice touches as well, such as twin cup holders in the console that divides the front bucket seats and offers storage under a padded armrest.
All in all, I have to say it: I know that giant cars with huge V8's are not sensible or politically correct, but I love the Impala SS. And, yes, those corporate committees at G.M. have pleased me once again.
 
INSIDE TRACK: You might wish it were the classic '57 Bel Air convertible. It's not, but the born-again Impala SS is a latter-day muscle car worthy of the name.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1353 words

HEADLINE: As a Tax Break for Some Condos Ebbs, Costs Soar

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
AS the 10-year tax abatements run out on condominiums built under the city's Section 421a program in the mid-80's, monthly carrying costs in these buildings are soaring -- in some cases equaling the once higher monthly costs of nearby co-ops.
This rise in what brokers call "out-of-pocket" charges in these condominiums has made the apartments generally harder to sell, according to many real estate agents. Some buildings, however, because of their location, size of apartments or cachet, may not have been hit as hard as others. 
 In Manhattan, the rise in monthly carrying costs for condominiums as taxes are phased in "certainly has had an effect in an already weak market," said Joan Ambrose, co-owner of Ambrose-Mar Elia Real Estate. "With the exception of the top-of-the-market buyer, out-of-pocket expenses are a big factor in decision making."
New multifamily construction in the 80's commonly took the form of condominiums, in which each apartment is independently financed and there is no underlying mortgage on the building. In Manhattan there were more than 21,000 condos built with Section 421a abatements, compared with about 900 co-op units, according to the City Finance Department.
Alan Nickman, a broker in Bellmarc Realty's Upper West Side office, pointed to the increasing trend toward parity of monthly carrying charges between comparable condominiums and co-ops as one of the most intriguing trends in the Manhattan market. Nevertheless, he said there would always be people who preferred condominiums.
"They like the more liberal attitude toward renting and selling, or for one reason or another, they can't pass a co-op board's scrutiny," he said.
Tax abatements, or the lack of them, can make a big difference in monthly carrying costs. At 60 East 88th Street, a posh 14-unit mid-block condominium between Madison and Park Avenues, one five-room apartment on the seventh floor that started with taxes of $106 a month in 1988 was up to $791 a month in 1994. In a 9 1/2-room apartment in the same building, taxes went from $252 in 1989 to $2,263 in 1994, according to the building's prospectus and recent sales listings. Nevertheless, brokers say apartments in this building are eminently salable because of its handsome post-modern-influenced design, its location and its small size.
The 40-story, 210-unit Kingsley, at 400 East 72d Street at York Avenue, is more typical. Built in 1984, its apartments range from studios to three-bedrooms. Real estate taxes for a typical mid-tower two-bedroom went from $191 in 1985 to $763 in 1994.
On the Upper West Side, the decade-long tax abatement program will expire in 1997 at the Park Belvedere, a condominium at 101 West 79th Street, at Columbus Avenue. There, real estate taxes on an average two-bedroom rose from 6 percent of the total carrying cost in 1987 to a current 41 percent. Carrying costs in condominiums also pay for building operations, as they do in co-ops. But in co-ops they also cover mortgage debt on the building.
The Section 421a tax abatement program was authorized by the state Legislature at New York City's behest in 1972 in an effort to stimulate residential construction at a time of recession. It was used in the construction of more than 67,000 apartments in the city -- the total includes condominiums, co-ops and rental buildings -- over 37,000 of them in Manhattan.
Under the 421a program taxes on new construction are phased in over 10 years, rising 20 percent every other year. At the beginning of the abatement period taxes are payable on the land only, or any property that had existed on the land within the preceding year.
The program was citywide and "as of right" until 1985; after that, builders in Manhattan between 96th and 14th Street had to provide a certain amount of low-income housing to get the Section 421a benefit. The expiration of the 421a benefit as an "as-of-right" program led developers to rush to get foundations in before 1986, said Douglas Lane, chief review assessor at the city's Department of Finance.
Fiscal 1986, covering November 1985, marked a peak in Section 421a applications. There were 61 for Manhattan, compared with 30 in fiscal 1985 and 30 in fiscal 1987. In fiscal 1994 there were four applications. The city's fiscal year ends on June 30.
Many buyers may not have understood that they would eventually have significant tax increases when the abatement expired, real estate lawyers said, despite requirements by the Attorney General's office that the workings of the program be spelled out clearly to prospective buyers.
"Were they fully warned by the Attorney General?" asked Kevin B. McGrath, a partner at Graubard and Mollen. "Were they told by their lawyer? Yes and probably yes."
"Did they understand it? Probably not," he concluded, adding that "human nature precluded their understanding it."
Shelly Friedman, a partner at Brown and Wood, said that the tax abatement "wasn't designed for buyers and it wasn't designed for sellers; it was front-loaded to create an incentive to build."
"Nobody was left holding the bag," he said. "People hear what they want to hear; they read what they want to read."
Prospective buyers of condominiums were warned of tax increases in offering plans. For example, the plan for Zeckendorf Towers, at 1 Irving Place, issued in 1986, could not be clearer. On the first page, the plan advises potential buyers that "this plan contains special risks to purchasers."
On the fourth page, the document warns in capital letters that "Application has been made by the sponsor for partial exemption from real estate taxes attributable to residential units pursuant to Section 421a of the New York Real Property Tax Law."
"Such exemption, if granted," it continues, "will be for a limited period of 10 years and will decrease progressively during such period."
"PEOPLE are entitled to feel they passed under a dark cloud," said Mr. Friedman, "but there's really no remedy."
At the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Mara Neville, a spokeswoman, said the 421a program was"alive and well." The housing agency is primarily responsible for administering both the 421a and J-51 tax abatements. The J-51 program, which is also ongoing, covers rehabilitation of existing buildings; Section 421a programs cover new construction of all types of multifamily buildings, although 65 percent of buildings constructed under the program are condominiums, with 25 percent rentals, according to the Finance Department.
Jeff Levine, head of J.E. Levine Builders in Queens and president of the Queens County Builders and Contractors Association, says that 421a is only alive and well outside Manhattan.
"Right now I'm working on a project in Riverdale in the Bronx," he said. "I'm getting the 421a as of right -- I don't have to include 20 percent low-income housing, which some neighborhoods don't exactly love."
According to the city's housing agency, 154 units of low- or moderate-income housing have been built in the area between 96th and 14th Streets in Manhattan since the restriction went into effect a decade ago. A total of 1,140 have been built citywide since the original 421a program ended.
While the requirements of the Section 421a subsidy program have changed over the years, the full effects of the program's tax-abatement mechanisms are now being felt in many of the units built in the 80s. To some real-estate experts, the long-term effects are beneficial. Steven Spinola, president of the Real Esate Board of New York, called the abatement phase-out "positive," saying it has had the affect of putting co-ops and condos "on an equal basis" in the market.
"People ought to realize that co-ops are just as valuable as condos," he added.
To Frank Braconi, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, whose members include many in the for-profit and nonprofit development fields, the question of fairness is clear. "Sure, we've had complaints from people," he said. "But we believe the city should keep its bargains -- the city made a deal and the time is up."

HEADLINE: Peddlers Called Bane of Downtown

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your "An Engine for Economic Improvement Downtown" on May 29 some industry leaders suggested measures for uplifting the area. However, not one mentioned the continued failure of the vaious city agencies in dealing with peddlers. Recently I visited a client in lower Manhattan. At 12:30 P.M., lower Broadway from Wall Street to the tip of Manhattan looked more like a market area for peddlers than the site of the New York Stock Exchange. 
 It is beyond me that we continue to permit a stream of peddlers selling everything from baseball cards to apparel with their vans illegally parked along the curbs, virtually eliminating one lane of traffic. For the life of me, I cannot conceive of anyone looking for office space in lower Manhattan if this condition continues to persist.
 
ABRAM BARKAN
Manhattan
 
The writer is chairman of Douglas Elliman's appraisal and consulting division.
