HEADLINE: In a Mexican Border Town, Dog Days Just Won't Quit

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: OJINAGA, Mexico, June 26

 BODY:
It's 119 degrees. The grim gray mountains shimmer. The asphalt of Free Trade Boulevard looks like black slush spilling toward the border. The only people in sight are Miguel Zaragoza and his brother Carmelo lazily crossing the boulevard on their chestnut mare. They've got a few dozen head of cattle to drive to the Ojinaga pens.
This is not quite the dynamic scene envisioned by city officials two years ago when they changed the name of their central street to Free Trade Boulevard from Chihuahua Avenue. The hope was that by rolling out a municipal red carpet they could insure that the benefits of the free trade agreement arrived in this sun-baked town of 40,000. 
 Six months after the trade pact took effect, there's no sign that anything has changed for better or for worse. Border officials say commercial traffic is about the same as it was before. Free Trade Boulevard, the first thing seen by travelers arriving from Presidio, Tex., remains a sorry sight, with empty lots and boarded-up stores. Among the few viable enterprises are a liquor warehouse and a shop that makes gravestones.
 
Nafta Stirs False Hopes

The North American Free Trade Agreement, which lowered tariffs on goods crossing the border, was expected to have an immediate impact on busy ports of entry like Tijuana and Ciudad Juarez that already had lots of commercial traffic. In nearly forgotten places like Ojinaga, 200 miles southeast of El Paso, changing the name of the main street seems to have stirred false hopes, and ultimately, deep disappointment.
"It's only for the rich," said Juan Francisco Reyes Campos, who is unemployed and not very thrilled about the future.
"We'll wait until December to see if there are any results," said Jose Isaac Uribe Alanis, the new opposition party Mayor, who thinks the previous administration probably erred when it raised people's expectations. "If not, we'll change the name."
A new name has already been picked: Peguis Highway, after a nearby mountain. It may not say much, but at least the mountain is already there.
O.J., as the locals refer to Ojinaga (named for a Mexican general, the town's full name is pronounced oh-hee-NA-gah), may be the town that Nafta forgot, but in truth it never had much going for it. The first Franciscan friars who tried to settle here in 1715 were run off by the Indians. Pancho Villa took the town in 1913 and reduced much of it to rubble. For the last 30 years Ojinaga's most successful businessmen have been drug smugglers.
In 1978, when border factories known as maquiladoras were sprouting up in every other border city with a highway and a 24-hour-a-day crossing to the United States, one of Ojinaga's loyal sons, Arturo Baeza Pantoja, came back to the city where he had spent the first 11 years of his life. He built a cinder-block factory, started sewing together shirts with material from the United States and planned to lease out the rest of the space to another maquiladora. Build and they'll come, he reasoned.
He waited 16 years.
A small maquiladora now finally makes wooden tables for vans. And in a few months a new factory should start turning out dog toys.
Ojinaga has been so dispirited the last few months that even the "dog factory," as it is referred to here, is seized upon as proof of progress. Otherwise, the scene is bleak. Near Mr. Baeza's factory, Ojinaga's adobe bullfight stadium is deteriorating, unused for at least 15 years. The city's zona rosa of stifling adobe backrooms and gaudy dance floors is as mean as the dogs in the city's junkyards.
Unlike border towns that have evolved into Mexican-American amusement parks, downtown Ojinaga remains down country. A hot spot is a 24-hour restaurant that specializes in menudo, a local tripe stew. A tourist brochure can list so few reasons to visit that it encourages Americans to take advantage of lower dentists' rates and "Come have your teeth cleaned!"
There is a small museum devoted to Pancho Villa, and an almost treeless little plaza.
And then there's the ball of fury.
 
A Mysterious Landmark
 On a downtown corner, near the public library, a metal ball measuring three feet in diameter is inexplicably cemented into the ground. No one can say for sure where it came from, just as no one can say where Ojinaga is going. One local legend says the ball is a meteorite.
"They uncovered it when they built the library," said Martin Pompa, who has lived in Ojinaga for all his 31 years and spends many unemployed hours in the shade of an abandoned building near the ball.
"Generally," said Mayor Uribe, "it's believed that the Spaniards brought it to mill wheat."
The relentless heat makes bars some of the most profitable businesses in Ojinaga. The Bikini Bar, on the central plaza, stays open till 2 A.M. and does steady business with Mexican-Americans crossing the border from Texas for a night out. Musical trios, like the one Marcos Chavez runs with his son Mario and another friend, spend the day hauling their instruments from one bar to another, playing for two pesos -- about 65 cents -- a tune.
"Seems to me they're washing the streets a little more often since January," Mr. Chavez said after belting out "Que Bonito es Chihuahua," a popular song in these parts. "But besides that, everything now is about the same as before."
The owner of the Bikini Bar, Hector Moreno Alonso, didn't have much to say about free trade, but he did offer an explanation for the ball of fury.
"It's part of a machine they used to use around here to break rocks," he said.
 
Even Here, Some Optimists

Even in a place as bleak as post-Nafta O.J., there are optimists. "Yes, we have a future," said Jose Santos Armendariz, head of the Ojinaga Chamber of Commerce. Mr. Santos, a pharmacist, mentioned plans for a new luxury train from Dallas, an improved airport and an interstate highway spur on the Texas side. He admitted the city's future was uncertain, as uncertain as had been its past.
"Ah, the ball," he said animatedly. "Well, we don't know for sure, but I think it was part of an anchor, a big one."
Ojinaga is, and was, at least 517 miles from the ocean.

HEADLINE: Political Notes;
Asked to Find a Winner, A Judge Declares a Tie

 BODY:
After a divisive campaign, a confusing election, three recounts, four lead changes and a month of accusations and recriminations, the race for the Democratic nomination for county executive in New Jersey's second most populous county, Essex, is officially a tie.
Judge Burrell Ives Humphreys of State Superior Court last week certified the results of a court-ordered recount of the June 7 primary between Thomas Giblin, the chairman of the county's Democratic Party, and Cardell Cooper, the Mayor of East Orange, that showed each candidate with 22,907 votes. 
 That has left the candidates frustrated, election officials bewildered and many observers flabbergasted.
"Statistically, the odds of a tie in a countywide race are as great as the United States winning the World Cup," said Walter L. Fields Jr., the state political director for the New Jersey State Conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "You would have better odds at winning the New Jersey Lottery."
Mr. Cooper, who is seeking to become the state's first black county executive, and Mr. Giblin are trying to win the right to face Mayor James Trefinnger of Verona, a Republican and a county Freeholder, this fall. In Essex County, capturing the Democratic Party primary has been tantamount to a general election victory.
Mr. Giblin's camp has called for a new primary election. Mr. Cooper is sticking to his claim of an outright victory based on 38 emergency ballots that the election board disqualified, and he said his lawyer would be in court this week to force the issue.
 
New York's Bond Ratings Languish at A, as in Abysmal
 An increase in New York's bond rating this year would have provided Gov. Mario M. Cuomo with a campaign emblem of his efforts to bring New York out of the recession. But both major Wall Street credit-rating agencies announced last week that they would leave New York's ratings where they were, at rock bottom.
In doing so, they weighed in on the recurring Albany debate about whether it really matters that the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo fail so persistently in passing a budget by April 1, the start of the state's fiscal year.
Before April 1, Mr. Cuomo typically lectures the Legislature about the importance of a timely budget. Once the deadline has been missed, he tends to downplay the significance. Lawmakers, meanwhile, argue privately that an on-time budget is less important than a budget that satisfies their needs.
The budget was not approved this year until June 8, the second latest date ever.
In their reports, the two credit-rating agencies made it clear that timeliness mattered to them, and that it contributed to an overall impression that New York's government did not work.
Moody's Investors Service kept the state's general obligation bond rating at A, the second lowest of all states. "While not an uncommon event, since the last budget enacted by April 1 was in 1984, the delay this year has been excessive," said the report. "The inability of the Governor and the two houses of the Legislature to reach budget accord is indicative of the partisan nature of the budget process and the divergence of priorities among participants in achieving ongoing budget balance."
Standard & Poor's echoed that sentiment, keeping the state's rating at A-, the lowest of any state.
 
Using a Campaign War Chest For Another Kind of Battle
 When Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn lost his seat in Congress to redistricting and defeat in a crowded Democratic primary in 1992 -- despite a war chest of more than $2 million -- some New York politicians shook their heads and said he would have been better off to have simply taken his money and retired, instead of spending it in vain on costly TV commercials.
He qualified to keep the money under a provision that has since been abolished.
Now it turns out that Mr. Solarz did put at least some of the money to private use after his defeat. A study released last week by the Center for Public Integrity in Washington showed that Mr. Solarz spent $197,376 for legal fees. For much of last year, Mr. Solarz was facing a Federal inquiry into his dealings with a Hong Kong businessman with reputed ties to organized crime. The investigation ended without charges this winter, but it scuttled Mr. Solarz's nomination as President Clinton's Ambassador to India.
The study found that since 1979, when the House passed an amendment allowing members in office before 1980 to convert campaign funds to non-election purposes, 112 former members of Congress have done so. About $6 million went directly to personal use, or to the members' heirs, the study found. The other $4.5 million went to cover travel, entertainment or other expenses, or to pay legal fees. Twenty-three members who left office in 1992 converted about $2.4 million to such uses.
 
Rushing to Block a Veto, Council Trips Over Procedure
 The New York City Council got a lot of attention last month when it stood up to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on the question of contracting out city services, overriding his veto of a bill that would give the Council some say over privatization.
But it turns out that the Council must vote on the override measure again because of a technical mistake.
The Council received the Mayor's veto message on June 13 and, riding a wave of Democratic resentment, promptly overturned the veto the next day by a vote of 43 to 7. (The seven Republicans stood by the Mayor.) Part of the rush was a fear among some members that the Mayor would use budget negotiations to discourage members from supporting the override.
The meeting on June 14, however, was technically the continuation of a meeting that began on June 9. That's because Council leaders had never adjourned the first meeting, preferring an indefinite recess so they could vote at a moment's notice on a budget agreement if one emerged.
But the charter says the Council can vote on a veto only at the next regularly scheduled meeting after it receives the message from the Mayor.
The Mayor's office, which is considering challenging the law in court, gleefully informed the Council of its mistake earlier this week and now a second vote must be taken. The vote has not been scheduled yet.
"I don't expect the result to be materially different," said Richard Riley, a spokesman for the Speaker, Peter F. Vallone.

HEADLINE: As Haiti Embargo Tightens, Poor Children Get Hungrier

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GONAIVES, Haiti, July 2

 BODY:
Minerva Guillaume, bright-eyed and alert, rushed past hundreds of other children to the front of the food line. She was caught and whisked to the back. She flashed an impish smile.
"I am hungry," said Minerva, a wisp of a 7-year old, who wanted to get her share of the day's fare, gruel mixed with okra. "I want to eat." 
 Less than a mile away at a hospital, Dieulafanne Francen cuddled her 9-month-old baby, Donlegel Miton, his eyes sunken, his face gaunt, and his shriveled skin barely clinging to his bones.
"He is sick," said the mother, unsure of the cause of her son's misery."He cries all the time."
Every day tens of thousands of children holding plastic or aluminum plates line up in mud schoolhouses under thatched roofs, awaiting what will perhaps be their only meal of the day.
 
Malnutrition Widespread
 At nearby hospitals and clinics, hundreds of less fortunate children like Donlegel sit listless and hold on to dear life, suffering from kwashiorkor, a severe form of nutritional deficiency characterized by changes in pigmentation of hair and skin, bloated belly and stunted growth.
Haiti's children have borne the worst of the political and economic chaos that has gripped the country since its President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, was ousted in a military coup in September 1991 and economic sanctions were imposed on the country. The infant mortality rate hovers at about 111 per 1,000 births.
The statistics tell only a fraction of the story. Aid officials say that complete numbers are not available, partly because they have been unable to undertake comprehensive studies since the coup. But a May 1994 U.S.A.I.D. Monitoring Report showed a 3.3 percent increase in the rate of the most severe malnutrition in Haiti.
And if the crisis persists, aid workers warn that the malnutrition rate, already one of the highest in the hemisphere, will reel out of control and that it may take years to reverse the health damage caused by the lack of food, if it can be reversed at all.
 
Feeding Programs Boosted
 In the last few months, aid workers have increased their emergency feeding programs from about 350,000 people to nearly 1 million a day and plan to expand to about 1.7 million people, or roughly 1 in 4 Haitians. Their main target is those most susceptible to malnutrition, children up to the age of 12 and pregnant or lactating women.
"This is a critical moment we're living through now," said Cothias Jean Martel, assistant administrator for CARE's Food Aid Project in Gonaives, 180 miles northwest of Port-au-Prince, the capital. "The Haitian people have a strong will to survive. That's why we're alive, but we're barely doing that."
As the malnutrition rate among children continues to soar, it will present yet another difficulty for the Clinton Administration, which has pressed for and won a tougher embargo against Haiti.
In an effort to isolate the country to force recalcitrant military officers to cede power and allow Father Aristide, the country's first democratically elected President, to return, the trade sanctions against Haiti have been tightened to the point of almost a total embargo.
Direct commercial flights to the United States have been suspended, visas to enter the United States have been revoked, and the foreign assets of Haitians living in Haiti have been frozen. Although the sanctions exempt food and medicine and are not aimed at the poor, there is no way protect them from some of the effects of the embargo.
 
Farm Fields Abandoned
 While famine is widespread in Haiti, it is more acute here in the northwest, in the poorest province of the hemisphere's poorest country, which is suffering the effects of a seven-year drought.
Farmers have abandoned their fields and are reverting to chopping down trees to make charcoal. Corn and millet stalks lie withered on baked soil.
Over the last three years, as countries cut off trade with Haiti, food has remained available, but the prices of staples like rice, beans and cornmeal have increased fivefold.
Moreover, about 10,000 people are expected to be squeezed because they cannot export mangos, their main source of income.
While CARE and other development organizations run more than 600 feeding centers throughout the country, the centers are out of the reach of many people.
 
Needy Far From Help
 Yolande Clovis, the mother of a 3-month-old girl, walked for more than an hour to get a large bowl of gruel and peas at a feeding center in Canal Bois, a village on the outskirts of Gonaives.
"I heard they were giving food here, so I came," she said. "It's food, and I thank God that I will have something to eat."
Dieudonne Altidor, 25, stood quietly in line with her son, Aliencin, as she waited her turn.
"I can't complain about the food," she said matter-of-factly. "I am a poor person. I am just happy for it."
At another feeding center in the Raboteau section of this city, hundreds of children waited silently in the scorching sun near an outdoor kitchen where cooks prepared large pots of food.
While relief workers hand out a 15-day supply of uncooked wheat, oil and peas to some families, they continue to cook for children to insure that they get at least one meal a day.
But as the tougher and less porous embargo takes hold, relief efforts are being hampered by a lack of spare parts for cars and motorcycles to transport the food from the docks of Port-au-Prince to the provinces, aid officials said.
"If we cannot get the food, it will be a catastrophe," said Antoine Jean-Baptiste, who runs a feeding center in Gonaives. "Many of the children will die. I have seen that happen."

HEADLINE: Rebels Have Little to Show for Efforts to Topple Saddam Hussein

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SALAHUDDIN, Iraq

 BODY:
In a small, nondescript house, with armed guards out front and the windows bricked shut, the men and women who would seize power from President Saddam Hussein plot their way to Baghdad.
In cramped, dimly lighted rooms they stuff miniature copies of their opposition newspaper into matchboxes to smuggle past Iraqi lines into the capital. They record blistering attacks against the Government to be broadcast on their radio and television stations. They pound new information into computers in an effort to flesh out profiles of officers who might be willing to stand with them against the Iraqi leader. And in a camp just outside town, 500 militiamen train with former Iraqi officers. 
 But three years after the Persian Gulf war, the Iraqi National Congress, the umbrella organization for Kurdish, Shiite Muslim and Sunni Muslim opposition groups, has little to show for its efforts.
 
Hussein Remains in Power
 Mr. Hussein not only remains in power, but with Iraq increasingly in compliance with the United Nations cease-fire resolution, it seems only a matter of time before sanctions are lifted.
The few coup attempts, only one of which, in June 1992, seriously threatened Mr. Hussein, were all swiftly crushed. The Clinton Administration last year scaled down a covert $40 million Central Intelligence Agency program to overthrow him. Administration officials said much of the aid had been distributed to groups and officers with no real following. Too much money, they said, went into the production of leaflets and propaganda that had little impact.
"The Americans always held out this hope that some mysterious officer would come along and rid the world of Saddam Hussein," said a senior Iraqi National Congress official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "This hasn't happened, and isn't likely to happen."
Several million dollars is still given to opposition groups by the C.I.A. to finance broadcasts and other propaganda efforts. Iraqi congress officials refused to say whether they were included in the covert financing.
The group set up its operations a year ago in the northern "security zone" controlled by Kurdish rebels and protected by the United States and its allies, but much of its recent efforts have been devoted to separating warring Kurdish guerrilla factions.
In a sweltering television studio, Sermat Ilias, a political commentator dressed in a coat and tie, glanced at his script as the strains of Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" faded away. His recorded commentary would be broadcast on the group's television channel in the north that night after the evening news.
The news program, filled with scenes pirated from various satellite broadcasts, including those of CNN and the BBC, is beamed south each evening to Iraqis living below the Kurdish-held security zone.
The television and radio stations, frequently attacked by the Government-run press in Baghdad for spreading foreign propaganda, are often jammed. The dissidents insist, nevertheless, that their efforts are slowly eroding Mr. Hussein's authority.
"We do not put our faith in a magical coup," said Ahmed Chalabi, effectively the head of the Iraqi National Congress. "We are trying to mobilize support inside Iraq and spread the word to let people know we are here and offer an alternative."
 
Hussein Heads 'Wanted' List
 The dissidents demand that Mr. Hussein, 7 of his relatives, 5 of his top advisers and 27 army officers and officials of the governing Baath Party stand before an international tribunal for war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide. Mug shots of the Iraqi leaders to be brought to justice are tacked to the walls of the safe houses in this mountain town.
However quixotic such a demand seems, it is also meant to reassure Iraqi officials that any such measures will be limited to the top echelon.
"We want the army to know we can work with them," Mr. Chalabi said. "We do not reject all elements of the regime."
Despite all the pamphlets, newspapers, leaflets and broadcasts, it is hard to tell how widely the propaganda is spread and how effective it is.
"They have nice facilities and a lot of money," one senior Kurdish guerrilla leader said, "but I doubt many Iraqis even know they exist."

HEADLINE: New Proposal For Shutdown At Chernobyl

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VIENNA, July 2

 BODY:
The United States and its allies are developing a strategy for closing the Chernobyl nuclear reactors permanently and helping to make Russian-designed nuclear reactors safer, officials at the International Atomic Energy Agency here say.
The immediate centerpiece is a substantial package of Western aid that is expected to be approved, at least in part, after the meeting of the seven biggest industrial nations in Naples next week. The money would enable Ukraine to close all four reactors at the Chernobyl site and complete construction of up to five new, safer nuclear power plants. 
 There was an agreement in principle by the 12 European Union countries in Corfu last week to supply up to $600 million for nuclear safety in Ukraine. And to provide the Group of Seven participants with specific examples of projects, energy officials from the United States and Ukraine released a report on Friday identifying new energy sources and conservation measures as alternatives to the electricity supplied by Chernobyl.
 
Common Standards for East
 The emerging strategy also involves two new international agreements intended to make Russian reactors safer.
One would encourage Western nuclear companies to upgrade Russian reactors by limiting the companies' liability for future accidents. A second, to be completed in September, sets common standards for reactor safety codes.
"All three developments fit together," said Morris Rosen, the American physicist who is the International Atomic Energy Agency's assistant director general for reactor safety. "We are finally getting somewhere."
After first agreeing to close down the whole Chernobyl plant in 1991, five years after the disaster there, the Ukrainian Parliament dismayed the West by deciding last October that energy needs required the country to retain the two functioning reactors and repair a third shut down after a fire in 1991.
 
Decision Is Protested
 In March, Hans Blix, director general of the international agency, protested the decision, telling President Leonid Kravchuk that "international levels of safety are not being met at Chernobyl."
A mission sent to Chernobyl by the agency said the sarcophagus encasing the burned-out No. 4 reactor, which exploded in 1986, spewing radioactive debris across much of Europe, was in danger of collapsing, posing a new radiation hazard.
It also found a serious shortage of spare parts and trained staff at the two functioning reactors. Some 40 percent of Chernobyl's top technicians have left in recent years, mainly because of falling living standards.
Experts from a dozen countries met in April to discuss the report, and a clear majority called for Chernobyl to be shut down as soon as possible, warning that it remained a threat to the rest of Europe.
But the Ukrainian delegation said it could not afford to close the plant until five new, safer nuclear reactors, currently under construction, have been completed.
The Ukrainians also said they would need some $196 million in foreign assistance to complete the first three on schedule by 1996, while finishing the two other units by 1999 would bring the bill to some $1.2 billion.
While Eastern countries are asking for foreign help in making their power reactors safer, many Western nuclear companies are reluctant to become involved until their legal liability for future accidents is clarified.
The World Bank has estimated they could earn up to $24 billion upgrading the 59 Russian-designed reactors currently in operation and 10 more under construction when demand for new reactors in the West is almost nonexistent.
 
New Guidelines Sought
 In an effort to overcome this obstacle to nuclear trade, officials here say the Clinton Administration will press for an agreement by next spring on a new convention that would shield nuclear construction companies from accident damage suits by putting primary responsibility for safety on the reactor operator.
In a paper circulated to International Atomic Energy Agency members recently, the Clinton Administration says it wants wide participation "in an international liability system providing for both prompt and adequate compensation for victims of nuclear accidents and for legal protection of nuclear suppliers."
More than 80 countries are expected to sign a new international convention on nuclear reactor safety.

HEADLINE: U.S. View of Sanctions: Turn Up Heat Half Way

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
It should come as no surprise that in his foreign policy showdowns, President Clinton has made economic sanctions his weapon of choice, even though such measures have, at best, had a middling record of success.
The reason sanctions appeal to Mr. Clinton, who is well aware that Congress and the public are uneasy with the use of force, is clear: They go beyond talk, but stop short of war. They send a message of toughness, they usually hurt their target and they cause little pain at home. 
 With these advantages in mind, Mr. Clinton has turned to sanctions, often working closely with other nations, in the diplomatic crises he has faced: Bosnia, Haiti and North Korea.
"We use sanctions because they can be effective," said an Administration official. "There is a lot of pressure to do something, and we're in an era when there's great concern about loss of life. Somalia showed there is very little tolerance for combat deaths these days."
 
Not Entirely Successful
 The problem is that the most exhaustive academic study of the subject concluded that since 1973, sanctions achieved their goals only a quarter of the time they were used.
They failed to persuade the Soviet Union to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan, they have not gotten Saddam Hussein to change his ways in Iraq and they have not toppled Fidel Castro. Nor has a trade embargo against Serbia stopped its support of the Bosnian Serbs, who have occupied almost three-fourths of Bosnia.
At the moment, the Clinton Administration is carrying out sanctions -- in some cases under United Nations auspices -- against more than a half dozen countries, including Cuba, Haiti, Iraq, Iran, Libya, the Sudan, and the Yugoslav Federation of Serbia and Montenegro. And that list does not include the sanctions threatened against North Korea.
To be sure, previous presidents embraced sanctions as a weapon, but experts say sanctions are being used more frequently in recent years because the end of the cold war has made it easier to obtain international solidarity behind them.
 
U.S. Seeks Partners
 It was not long ago that the United States seemed content to go it alone in imposing sanctions, but increasingly it scours the globe for international support.
"Cooperation has become important because the United States is no longer the pre-eminent economic power that it was right after World War II," said Gary Hufbauer, an expert on sanctions at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
But in spearheading efforts to put together sanctions against different countries, Mr. Clinton has shunned the advice of most longtime students of the subject: Turn up the heat all the way, and turn it up fast. In this way, not only do adversaries see that you mean business, but they do not have time to prepare ways to make an end run around the sanctions.
 
Go-Slow Approach
 Instead, President Clinton has chosen a one-step-at-a-time approach to sanctions, partly because of his tentativeness on foreign policy and partly because some nations whose support Washington badly wants insist on a go-slow approach. Administration officials caution that if they use every weapon in their sanctions arsenal from day one, the only option left if sanctions fail is force.
The Administration boasts that its threat of sanctions pushed North Korea to agree, at least for now, to freeze its nuclear program. The phased sanctions that Washington proposed were to start with a ban on North Korea's arms exports and a cutoff of $15 million in United Nations aid.
Those were to be followed by a prohibition on all financial transactions. That would hardly affect the United States, but would have significant repercussions in Japan -- and could create tensions there -- because Koreans living in Japan send hundreds of millions of dollars to North Korea.
In the case of Haiti, the United Nations, with Washington's backing, imposed a trade embargo more than a year ago. But it was not until June that the Administration slapped on sanctions intended to hurt Haiti's economic elite, who have lent crucial support to the military leaders. These measures, taken in conjunction with Canada and other countries that have major business dealings with Haiti, include banning commercial flights with Haiti and freezing Haitian assets in the United States.
 
Approach Is Criticized
 Many experts say the Administration has taken a sloppy approach in targeting the sanctions on Haiti because these measures have squeezed the poor but have left the rich untouched, until recently.
"In commercial disputes, Administrations usually do a terrific job targeting sanctions, for instance, slapping tariffs on French wine because they know winegrowers have a huge amount of political clout in France," said Lisa Martin, a Harvard political science professor who has written extensively about sanctions. "But when we use sanctions for political purposes, we for some reason haven't paid much attention to targeting."
William H. Gray 3d, the President's special adviser on Haiti, all but admits that the Administration should have stepped up sanctions on Haiti faster and focused them better.
"Even though there have been a series of sanctions over the last couple of years, they really have not been very significant," he said. "These are the first sanctions that you've had that have had real teeth in them."
 
Easier on the Elite
 But even well-designed sanctions usually punish the masses more than the elite. When sanctions are directed at dictators like Saddam Hussein or Haiti's military rulers, these leaders can take the nation's wealth and divert it to groups like the military and presidential guard that are needed to keep them in power.
Another problem with sanctions is that they sometimes backfire. In the view of many experts, sanctions against Cuba have allowed Fidel Castro to claim that the United States trade embargo, not Communist economics, have wrecked his economy.
But the Administration recognizes that sanctions can kill several birds with one stone. While one official said diplomatic demarches amount to little more than words over tea and cookies, sanctions make leaders look tough at home and abroad. Rallying other nations around a sanctions program is a visible way of claiming world leadership. In addition, sanctions let other countries know they will pay an economic price if they choose to become international outlaws.
Last but not least, sanctions just might cause the targeted nation to stop its objectionable behavior.
"Sanctions are not a precision-guided instrument that can bring a solution to every problem," said a senior Administration official. "But they are effective at their fundamental purpose of exacting a cost for behavior that's repugnant, dangerous and destabilizing."
 
South Africa Cited
 Administration officials argue that too little attention is paid to the times sanctions succeed. Exhibit No. 1, they say, is South Africa, where a ban on loans, investments and many imports helped pressure the Government to end apartheid. According to many experts, what pushed white South Africans to abandon apartheid was not the economic pain from the sanctions, but the international opprobrium contained in those measures.
Administration officials point to other limited successes. The ban on flights and arm sales to Libya have pressured Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi to cut back on his support for terrorist activities.
The worldwide trade embargo against Iraq has gotten President Hussein to take some steps toward destroying his weapons of mass destruction, although not as much as Washington wants. Nonetheless, the sanctions have failed to get the Iraqi leader to recognize Kuwait's borders and stop harassing Iraq's Kurdish population.
 
Serbia Is a Question
 There is a debate raging about how well the embargo against Serbia has worked. Some officials say Serbia has been bitten so hard that it has pressured Bosnia's Serbs to agree to a cease-fire and engage in peace talks.
But many experts counter that the embargo has failed badly and that the Bosnian Serbs have agreed to peace talks only because they have conquered all the land they want. Under this view, the embargo has proved ineffective because of smuggling through Bulgaria, Greece, Hungary, Romania and other countries in the region.
"This is an example of a disastrous program," said Michael Malloy, a sanctions expert who is director of graduate studies at Fordham University. "The reason is it's been hard to get broad international and regional cooperation."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 25; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1272 words

HEADLINE: For Student Debaters, Success on Their Terms

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 1

 BODY:
There are places in the land where the passion of high school debate nearly rivals that of high school football. New Jersey is not one of those places.
But New Jersey -- specifically, Newark -- is home to a nationally prominent debate team. In 12 years, the Science High School debate team has won 12 varsity state championships. This team has taken part in the National Forensic League finals for 10 years in a row and last month traveled to Kansas City to do so again. It is one of only 90 high schools in the country to hold a chair at the Barkley Forum, a debating honor society at Emory University. 
 If this is a surprise to many people, the debate team members no longer care.
"Some people think our economic situation has some bearing on our ability to be logical or persuasive," said Melissa Cooper, a graduating senior and member of the team. Sitting in a computer lab, surrounded by her teammates, Ms. Cooper laughed and shook her head in exasperation.
"We have the same mind as anybody else. They didn't have to do anything special to start a debate team in Newark. All they had to do for us was give us money."
 
The Coach's Import
 Money is important -- traveling to tournaments and camps for research is costly. But for a debate program to thrive, it needs a coach willing to dedicate 20 hours a week after school, willing to attend the weekend tournaments, willing to travel about the country supporting and encouraging his team. Science High School has Brent Farrand, a 42-year-old math teacher who has been the bedrock of the program since he created it 14 years ago. Mr. Farrand said he has loved debate since he first stood before a judge during his own high school days in Liberty, N.Y.
"It taught me a whole different way of looking at the world," he said. "It taught me that problems are caused by human beings, so human beings can solve them."
Science High School, one of Newark's three magnet schools, draws accomplished students from throughout the city. But Mr. Farrand said the best students do not necessarily make the best debaters.
"The speaking skills, the research skills, all those we can teach," he said. "But it's very difficult by the ninth or tenth grade to teach the rudiments of thinking. It's possible, but it's very difficult."
 
Two Types of Debate
 In comprehensive debate programs such as the one at Science High, students compete in both policy and Lincoln-Douglas debates. In policy debate, two teams of two debaters square off on a single, nationally assigned issue that they have studied and researched. The debaters must be prepared to attack or defend all aspects of the issue. There are proposals and attacks, cross-examinations and rebuttals, all conducted in intense, rapid-fire exchanges that can leave observers gasping for air.
By contrast, in Lincoln-Douglas debates a pair of students speak on a single moral or ethical question, seeking to persuade judges with their knowledge of history, philosophy and the social contract by which we live.
This year, policy debaters had to devise a national health care plan. Hassan Ceaser said that after hours of research, he and his partner argued that President Clinton's health care plan should be adopted as originally proposed, with the addition of comprehensive psychiatric and mental health care coverage.
"We argued that the mentally ill are very dehumanized in the present system," he said. "There's a very small number of symptoms you can show before you're just automatically put into an asylum. We increased outpatient services so people's families can take care of them.
"On the negative side, we said the proposal was really vague. We debated what 'comprehensive' meant, what 'all' meant, what 'American citizen' meant. We debated how doing this here would affect the rest of the world, since we're a superpower."
 
Repairing an Image
 The team's success is a balm for officials scarred by harsh criticism of the deeply troubled Newark district. For two decades, the 48,000-student system has been repeatedly cited for dismal student performance, high truancy rates and mismanagement. Its students routinely fall far behind state standards in reading and math. Last year, the state began steps toward a possible takeover of the district, despite bitter opposition from system officials.
But more than 92 percent of Science High's ninth-grade students passed all the 1993 state High School Proficiency Test. The state average was 82 percent, and Newark's nonmagnet high schools scored between 12.5 and 49.5 percent.
Five other Newark high schools have speech teams operating at various levels. But none has been able to recreate the full-fledged program at Science. "They get a lot of attention," said the principal, Christine Taylor. "Some other students who do things wish they were given as much attention as the debate team. But, generally, their fellow classmates are very proud of them."
These students feel keenly the pressure of representing their school, their city and sometimes their race. They are one of the few urban public schools on the national debate circuit and the only one, they say, whose members are all either black or Hispanic. Only the youngest has not been the sole Hispanic or black debater at a tournament, and felt a heart-stopping moment of profound alienation.
"Once in Washington, D.C., I was the only Puerto Rican, the only minority, in about 300 people or so," said Jose Caceres. "They didn't ask me about the program or the education system. They ask, 'How do you live over there? How do you get through the day?' "
What does he tell them? "I tell them it's normal."
 
Dealing With Racism
 Sometimes there is overt racism, the students said. But often the judges are fair and the competitors open and friendly. The struggle, they said, is to overcome prejudice where it exists, and to avoid seeing its specter where it does not.
"You definitely have to be self-confident," said David Murray, 16. "You know that other person isn't going to lose because of his race. You have to say, 'This judge is going to vote for me because I'm good.' "
"And you don't want someone to vote for you because they feel sorry for you," Ms. Cooper said. "You don't want them to say, 'Oh look, that's so cute. She's from the inner city and she can talk.' "
Their assistant coach, Diana Dunker, tells them the story of her own senior year, when she and her partner, both black, faced the pressure of competing in what was a predominantly white activity. At an important tournament, her partner became ill but resisted going to a hospital before the final round.
"She told me we had to debate them or else people were going to think we were scared of them," Ms. Dunker said. "That made me realize how much pressure we were under, that she would sit here and risk her life to debate this last round so people wouldn't think we weren't up to par."
These students said any problems they have faced dissolve in the honey of what they have gained: responsibility, an awareness of people and places and issues beyond Newark and the process of critical thinking.
Most precious of all, said Christiane Gabriel, 17, is confidence. Ms. Gabriel, who will attend Rutgers this fall, smiled as she recalled how easily intimidated she used to be.
"I agreed with anybody who told me something," she said. "It wasn't until I joined debate that I realized I have to have confidence in myself. Just because somebody else says something, if I don't agree with them, that doesn't mean I'm wrong.
"I learned that I am a strong person," Ms. Gabriel said. "I am intellectually smart."

HEADLINE: WORLD CUP '94;
Being Brazil's Coach Includes Ignoring 150 Million Opinions

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS GATOS, Calif., July 2

 BODY:
Ana Paula Olsen was explaining the fanaticism of soccer in Brazil. Every fan has a favorite player. And every fan has a favorite player's favorite body part.
"The television cameras will stop people on the street, and they will say, 'I like Dunga's legs and Rai's butt,' " said Olsen, a native of Brazil who owns a bikini shop in this Silicon Valley town, where Brazil's World Cup team is lodging. "It's always the legs and the butt." 
 Given this consuming passion, what would happen to the coach, Carlos Alberto Parreira, if Brazil somehow lost to the upstart Americans on the Fourth of July?
"If they lose, he should stay here, move to Utah," Olsen said. "Or maybe to Nepal."
 
Every Advantage, but . . .
 Brazil should not lose to the Americans on Monday at Stanford Stadium. Brazil has won three World Cup titles; until they beat Colombia, the Americans had won three World Cup games. Brazil has every advantage: speed, skill, experience, technical superiority. Brazil versus the United States in soccer should be the same as the United States versus Albania in basketball. A runaway.
Except for one thing.
Brazil has not won the World Cup in 24 years. People are getting edgy. A 1-1 draw on Wednesday with Sweden was denounced as a "tragedy" by the Brazilian news media. Anxiety has broken out like a national rash. It's not because the Brazilians are afraid of the Americans. It is just that, in Brazil, there are only two results: stylish victory and panic.
"We have not won in five World Cups; the sixth we have to," said Zetti, the reserve goalkeeper. "But when you have that much pressure and expectation, it can be a minus instead of a plus."
It is said that there are 150 million coaches in Brazil, each certain of what is best for the national soccer team. All 150 million are giving Parreira advice, whether he wants it or not. President Itamar Franco has offered suggested lineup changes. Even Parreiera's own mother said she would like to see Ronaldo, the 17-year-old sensation.
The most famous Brazilian of them all, Pele, is writing a newspaper column for USA Today, pointing out Parreira's mistakes, calling for replacements at forward, defense and midfield.
"Brazil cannot play any worse," Pele wrote on Friday.
And this is a team that has yet to lose.
Pele recommended six lineup changes for Monday's game. At least, Parreira's mother recommended only one.
"One is enough," Parreira said.
At a news conference on Thursday, more than 100 reporters grilled Parreira on the sad state of his team after the 1-1 draw with Sweden. But they didn't so much ask questions as levy their own harsh opinions.
"The Brazilian national coach has a job tougher than the director of NASA," said Ney Bianchi, a reporter for Brazil's Manchete magazine who has covered every World Cup but one since 1958. "At NASA, you lose your job only if a rocket explodes. In Brazil, all you have to do is lose a game. Or maybe get a tie."
It is estimated that 93 percent of all Brazilians will watch some portion of the World Cup. Soccer is a galvanizing diversion for a country rent in recent years by the impeachment of its president, galloping inflation, the killing of street children and the yawning gulf in income distribution between the richest and poorest citizens. Brazil's most charismatic sports hero, the champion race driver Ayrton Senna, died in a crash two months ago. Now the entire country looks to soccer for reassurance and regeneration.
 
No Second Place
 "Second place is a national tragedy," said Bianchi, the magazine journalist.
Certainly not of the magnitude that occurred in Colombia early this morning, when Andres Escobar, the man who inadvertently scored for the Americans, was gunned down. But such is the urgency of another World Cup title that segments of Brazil's daily practices are broadcast live on television; newspapers carry arcane diagrams showing every pass, every shot, every player movement. Broadcast journalists swarm around the coach and players, pressing cellular phones into their faces, sending their responses home live and unfiltered.
Parreira, to his credit, always makes himself available and remains cheery.
"Brazilian public opinion is more critical than any place in the world," Parreira told a group of English-speaking reporters on Thursday. "If we were 30 percent as good as the fans and the media expect us to be, we would be unbeatable."
"From now on, I do believe that FIFA has to find a special way for Brazil to participate in the World Cup," Parreira mused, referring to soccer's world governing body. "At least allow Brazil to play in the World Cup with six national teams. That might please half of the people. One team will just play attack football. Another national team will just play defense. The third will play creative football, the fourth will play fantasy football, the fifth will play competitive football. To please everybody with one national team is a big task."
That, in essence, is the key to Parreira's success and his sanity. It is impossible to please everyone, so he doesn't try. He ignores the suggestion that his team is too cautious, dismisses those who pine for the days of Pele and three forwards in attack, disregards the opinions that Rai is unfit for his role as playmaker and that Dunga and Mauro Silva lack the speed to play in tandem in the midfield. He even ignores his own mother.
 
Win or Lose, Parreira Will Leave
 "You have to have your own way; otherwise you are lost," Parreira said.
At 51, he and Bora Milutinovic, the Serb who coaches the Americans, are the only coaches to have led three different countries into the World Cup. Parreira coached Kuwait in 1982 and the United Arab Emirates in 1990. His first stint as coach of Brazil's national team ended with his firing in 1987. This time, win or lose, Parreira is leaving on his own terms after the World Cup, likely to land as coach of Valencia in the Spanish League.
He has scrapped the European-influenced sweeper defense that Brazil used futilely at the 1990 World Cup and imposed his own system and will. Instead of three forwards, Parreira employs two central midfielders and a pair of outside backs in Leonardo and Jorginho who charge forward voraciously on attack.
When the mercurial forward Romario presented disciplinary problems, Parreira left him off the national team until a victory over Uruguay was necessary during World Cup qualifying. But Parreira also knows his players must be allowed their freedom and creativity. Romario has responded with three goals in three games.
"This is the Brazilian way," Parreira said. "The only thing we stress is discipline to be well-organized without the ball. That's the only concern I have."
 
More Coaching Advice
 Millions are more than happy to worry about everything else. Olsen, the shop owner, called Rio on Thursday to place an order on bikinis. The woman on the other end wanted to talk soccer.
"Tell Parreira to bench Rai," the woman instructed Olsen.
Monday's game against the Americans is anticipated with hope and dread. Something unlucky has always happened to Brazil in recent World Cups.
If there is a satisfying victory, 20,000 Brazilians and Brazilian wannabes are expected to parade again through downtown Los Gatos as they did after a 3-0 shutout of Cameroon.
And advice for Parreira will flow like celebratory beer.
"He has a system and he believes in it," said Gerson Nunes, a midfielder on the 1970 championship team. "He doesn't want to change, although if he listened to a few suggestions, he'd probably win more easily."

HEADLINE: Gambling: Who Wins, Who Loses?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"False Promise of Development by Casino," (June 12) suggested that legalized gaming in regional markets negatively affects local economies. This is not an accurate picture, however, in markets where casinos are operating. 
 In Mississippi, the growth of the gaming industry is responsible for creating an estimated 40,000 jobs since 1992, and the reduction of unemployment figures from 10.8 to 5.4 percent. State records show that casinos have taken in $1 billion in gross revenue, of which the state has received $81.1 million from taxes and fees. A November 1993 study of United States economic recovery by U.S. News & World Report placed Mississippi first among the states in improved economic health.
Harrison County, which encompasses Biloxi and Gulfport, Miss., and is home to 11 of the state's 25 casinos, has shown tremendous growth in the last two years, including a 26 percent increase in the number of passengers arriving in local airports, a 17 percent increase in retail sales and a 60 percent increase in hotel sales tax collections.
Sixty-four percent of Mississippi's casino customers live outside the state, according to the state Center for Policy Research and Planning. The gaming industry has energized tourism in Mississippi, nearly doubling its income from $1.6 billion in 1990 to an estimated $3.3 billion for 1993. In a state where casinos are the largest employers, where management is hired regionally and casino companies are investing millions in their operations and community development, the success of gaming has been in the best interest of Mississippi.
 
WILLIAM SITTMANN
Las Vegas, Nev., June 15
 
The writer is vice president for corporate affairs at the Lady Luck Gaming Corporation, which operates three casinos in Mississippi.

HEADLINE: Wage a Cold War Against Serbia

BYLINE: By David Gompert; David Gompert, a Rand vice president, was a senior director on the Bush Administration's National Security Council staff. This is adapted from a longer article in the current issue of Foreign Affairs.

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has reluctantly decided to join our European partners in an attempt to end the war in Bosnia as soon as possible by giving half that country to Serbia. We are thus a step closer to blessing Serbia's victory and just a step away from pardoning this conquest by lifting the economic embargo on Serbia.
In Geneva on Tuesday, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev of Russia and their Western European counterparts are expected to approve a plan to divide Bosnia. The Bosnian Government and the Serbian side will then be asked to accept the plan before the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial countries in Naples three days later. 
 If the Serbs balk at returning much of the land they have taken from Bosnia's Muslims, we can depend on our allies and Russia to ask the U.S. to press the victims of aggression to capitulate.
 The Clinton Administration did not bring us to this sorry state of affairs singlehandedly. It took four years of failed Western policies to get here -- four years of trying to shift responsibility and blame across the Atlantic and back, of toothless United Nations Security Council resolutions, of explaining away the savage destruction of a multi-ethnic European state as a hopelessly complicated civil war with all parties at fault.
Indeed, by being willing to use force, the Administration broke, temporarily, with the West's willingness to tolerate the intolerable in Bosnia.
But now it sees no way out. We cannot get a U.N. agreement to permit the victims of aggression to defend themselves. We cannot count on our allies to remain in Bosnia to protect humanitarian operations. We cannot count on Serbia's neighbors to abide by the trade embargo. There is no stomach in the U.S. or Europe for the heavy bombing that would produce a just peace.
 The Western position is now fundamentally indistinguishable from that of the Serbian strongman, Slobodan Milosevic: end the fighting, partition Bosnia, lift the sanctions. (Will clemency for war crimes also become negotiable?)
In its eagerness to stop the fighting, the West is presenting President Milosevic with the opportunity to become victor, peacemaker and father of Greater Serbia.
Weary of Secretary Christopher's "problem from hell," the U.S. may now have to send American troops to police the results of ethnic cleansing. Should we not pause to consider whether there may be some better, if imperfect, alternative?
There is -- if the West can summon the will to wage a cold war against Serbia until a democratic revolution discards its criminal regime. Economic sanctions and information warfare may take years to reform Serbia, but the outcome is certain.
Those who dismiss the eventual demise of Milosevic Inc. as unrealistic will be hard-pressed to explain the more remarkable results of Western steadfastness in defeating Soviet Communism and South African apartheid.
 In any case, ending Serbia's punishment and isolation now, in return for a flawed and unstable peace, would extend the life of this Balkan bully for years, bringing new crises and more atrocities.
 Would our allies see it through? In fact, the Europeans have proved quite firm in sanctions against South Africa, Libya and Iraq. In the case of Serbia, they can easily endure the limited damage to themselves. At any rate, if the allies believe sanctions cannot be sustained, why do they believe the Serbs will concede hard-won territory to get them removed?
 A more legitimate concern is with the harmful effect of the embargo on the frail new democracies of south-eastern Europe: Albania, Macedonia, Bulgaria and Romania. The West cannot treat them as expendable.
Instead, the European Union and the United States should expand and sustain economic support so that these frontline states can survive even as Serbia falters.
 A quarantine of Serbia is more likely to succeed if accompanied by a campaign to inform the Serbs why they are being treated as lepers. To date, the Serbs may be miserable, but they believe they are right, and they blame the West, not Mr. Milosevic, for their plight.
But most Serbs only know what they see on the television station he controls. With Western help, television and fax networks -- the technology that riddled and helped wreck the Soviet system -- could break Mr. Milosevic's information monopoly. Serbs need to know the truth about their rulers, the atrocities in Bosnia, the reasons for their hardship and their options.
 During a cold war against Serbia, scattered fighting would be likely to persist in Bosnia. But now that the threat of NATO air strikes exists, the Serbs could be deterred from attacking the half-dozen Muslim enclaves in Bosnia's Serbian-controlled area, and even if the Muslims attempted limited counteroffensives there is little reason to think the fighting would spread or that the main battle lines would shift.
 The West cannot resolve this conflict on acceptable terms with limited air power. But it should leave no doubt that air strikes would be used to uphold U.N. decisions and protect peacekeeping troops. Humanitarian relief convoys would get through to affected populations if they had adequate ground and air escorts who were ordered to use all necessary force. Those who interfered with such efforts or harm U.N. personnel should be exposed to air attack and charged with war crimes.
To the French and British, who say they might pull out of Bosnia if there is not a quick deal with the Serbs, the U.S. should offer air cover and make the case publicly that the right stance toward Serbia is steadiness, not retreat.
 Even if sanctions did not produce sweeping change in Belgrade, a crippled Serbia is preferable to one that is given the chance to rebound.
Moreover, economic war in perpetuity against an unrepentant Serbia would send a strong signal to other tyrants that international aggression, whether it succeeded or not, would result in unforgiving punishment.
 There never was an easy solution to the Yugoslav problem. Although the West is not prepared to defeat Mr. Milosevic militarily, it is not obligated to cut a deal with him.
We can reach a more acceptable outcome in time with an acceptable Serbian leadership by showing the same steadfastness we did in the larger cold war.
Unless we hand him victory now, Mr. Milosevic will lose a cold war, and real peace can then come to the Balkans.

HEADLINE: John Dyson, Upstart From Upstate, Speaks Up (Again)

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
It was a John S. Dyson kind of moment.
Gov. Hugh L. Carey was in office and Republican state legislators were complaining about the appearance of Mr. Dyson, the 34-year-old Democratic Commerce Commissioner in "I Love New York" ads promoting New York State. 
 Suspicious that Mr. Dyson was promoting himself as well as the state, the lawmakers were considering legislation to bar the appearance of state officials in publicly financed ads. And Mr. Dyson, mocking it all, showed up to be questioned at a legislative hearing in a black Lone Ranger mask, prompting a Republican walkout.
It was the gesture of a man who never wanted to be a faceless bureaucrat, a commissioner with such a penchant for the flamboyant gesture or outrageous quote that even admiring former colleagues still groan that if there is a propeller he will walk into it, if there is no controversy he will create one.
And last week, Mr. Dyson, now 51 and a deputy mayor to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, struck again, in a dispute with City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi over whether a company owned by a black woman should be rehired to market New York City bonds. "The Comptroller ought to know the difference between a bid and a watermelon," he said to The Bond Buyer, in a remark that was denounced by many Democratic officials as racist or offensive and revived questions about whether Mr. Giuliani's administration is insensitive to blacks.
Mr. Dyson apologized, saying he had not intended to be offensive, but was trying to compare something "fixed and firm like a bid" to something he considered "soft and mushy" -- Mr. Hevesi's contention that two financial advisers could be used to market city bonds for the same price as one.
"Upstate we say about someone whose head is mushy, that he has a watermelon for a brain," he said. "It is not a racial remark in upstate New York. I didn't realize, in fact, how intensely it had become such a thing in New York City."
But that, Mr. Dyson's critics say, is just the problem: that he shows a lack of appreciation for the care needed by public officials in a racially divided city. State Comptroller H. Carl McCall was highly critical of the remark said he couldn't judge whether Mr. Dyson had intended to use bigoted language. "But in a city like New York one should understand that a remark like that will be perceived that way and you should avoid making them," said Mr. McCall, the lone black official holding statewide office. "If you don't understand that, you are out of your element."
 
'Enjoys Being Outspoken'
 Yet controversy has always been Mr. Dyson's way, across a decade of public life that saw him serve as State Agriculture Commissioner, Commerce Commissioner and then chairman of the State Power Authority, until 1985. One year later, he made a failed bid to win the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, then returned to his Dutchess County home in Millbrook, where he ran his own investment firm and a winery.
"John enjoys being outspoken," said Phil Friedman, a political consultant who ran Mr. Dyson's 1986 campaign. "He is the kind of person who gives himself credit for saying things he believes other people won't say, and even though he apologizes later and retracts, he's managed to continue the pattern."
Mr. Dyson admits that some of his style is attributable to the freedom granted him by wealth. "It comes in part because I can afford to do it, you know, to be honest," he said. His father, Charles H. Dyson, founded an investment firm, now known as Dyson-Kissner-Moran, which has made the elder Mr. Dyson one of the wealthiest men in the country.
"He invented something," Mr. Dyson said of his father. "He invented the friendly version of the leveraged buyout." Forbes magazine estimates Charles H. Dyson's worth at $550 million. The Deputy Mayor indicated on financial disclosure forms required by the city that he earned at least $1 million last year in interest and from partnerships and investments.
But Mr. Dyson chose not to go into the family business, showing a zeal for government and politics. He made his first, unsuccessful bid for public office in 1968, running a close Congressional race against the Republican, Representative Hamilton Fish 3d. The Conservative candidate was the not-yet-notorious G. Gordon Liddy, who withdrew.
After Mr. Dyson served in Vietnam as an Army intelligence officer, he returned to New York and within several years was a member of the Carey administration.
In office, Mr. Dyson's ability to antagonize opponents was not limited to his masked appearance. He feuded publicly with New York City officials when he moved most of the Power Authority's operations from Manhattan to White Plains, because of a rent increase and lack of space at its Columbus Circle headquarters. He complained at the time that the city had made little effort to help him, while city officials said he refused even to consider space outside Manhattan. "Even here, we've had several people killed at Columbus Circle," he said at the time. "It's hard to persuade anyone to come to a place that has the reputation of being less safe than where they are now."
Mr. Carey, now a Washington lobbyist, still praises him as one of the more effective members of his administration. "What we did mainly is turn the city around, and the biggest thing we did is create job opportunities," Mr. Carey said. "John is one of the key three or four people around me who worked on jobs."
It was Mr. Dyson's record as Commerce Commissioner that led the Liberal Party leader, Raymond B. Harding, and the media strategist David Garth to recommend him to Mr. Giuliani as deputy mayor for finance and economic development.
 
'Sheer Ability'
 "When I think of John Dyson I think of sheer ability," Mr. Harding said.
As Deputy Mayor, Mr. Dyson has negotiated for the city in the sale of the Coliseum site to the developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman, and worked out the boundaries of the city's Federal empowerment-zone proposal with Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem. He solicited private donors to help support the city's museums and cultural institutions. And partly because Mr. Giuliani's other deputies are so studiously low-profile, Mr. Dyson has emerged as one of the most visible members of the government.
When he was negotiating the Coliseum deal, Mr. Dyson made public the Giuliani administration's offer to restore $50 million in capital funds to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, owner of the Coliseum site, to persuade it to come to terms with Mr. Zuckerman. Under criticism, Mr. Giuliani backed away from the proposal, saying, "That is John Dyson's proposal, not mine."
 
The 'Do Not Worry' Comment
 Last week was not the first furor for Mr. Dyson over remarks some perceived as insensitive to black New Yorkers. After a newspaper article asked whether Mr. Giuliani and his chief deputy, Peter J. Powers, were capable of governing a diverse city, Mr. Dyson wrote in a memo to Mr. Powers that was intended to remain private: "Do not worry. Two white guys have been running this city of immigrants for over 200 years."
At another point, after the administration held a Cabinet meeting on Staten Island, Mr. Dyson suggested that a similar Cabinet session was unlikely in Harlem, which he said had received "the vast proportion of the attention over the last four years."
But it was Mr. Dyson's reference to watermelon last week at prompted calls from some black and Hispanic lawmakers for his resignation. "There is no way he can come and make an excuse for what he said," said Councilwoman Una Clarke, a Brooklyn Democrat. Mr. Giuliani came strongly to Mr. Dyson's defense, even as others outside the administration questioned whether Mr. Dyson was becoming a liability.
And by 1 A.M. yesterday, Mr. Dyson had come full circle. Nominated for the M.T.A. board by Mr. Giuliani, he was again facing a Senate committee. And while Mr. Dyson ultimately won committee approval, the early morning hearing took on the tones of a morality play.
 
What He's Learned Recently
 "I would really like for you to articulate what you have learned from this very, very painful experience to so many people -- so many people that are not represented around this table or this legislature," said a weary looking Senator Norman J. Levy, a Long Island Republican and chairman of the transportation committee.
Mr. Dyson looked contrite. "I suppose it's hard to describe all the things that have gone on in the last 48 hours or so, but coming from where I come from in upstate New York, I've learned a great deal," he said. "'Will I be more careful in the words I use?" he asked "Yes. Have I made mistakes in what I've said in the past? Yes.
"I've apologized for what I said. I've learned some more about the extreme sensitivities in the city of New York, which is more so than in other parts of the state of New York where I have served before. And I think we all in the city of New York have learned a lesson, which is that we need to come together and stop fighting."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STUYVESANT TOWN;
Cooler Days Are Here. Or Are They?

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
After sweltering every summer for nearly half a century, Stuyvesant Town is finally getting new electrical wiring that will allow the installation of air-conditioning. But now residents face a new frustration: a shortage of air-conditioners.
For years the lack of air-conditioning has been a recurring issue at Stuyvesant Town, which had not upgraded its electrical system since it opened in 1947. Cost has been a major consideration; the rewiring is costing $60 million for the 89 buildings. 
 With the heat wave in June, air-conditioners began selling out everywhere. It became especially difficult to find a model that fits Stuyvesant Town's specifications.
"We ran out of inventory," said Morris Portnoy, owner of a major local supplier, Bloom & Krup, whose crews installed about 300 air-conditioners in Stuyvesant town. Now more than 100 orders are unfilled.
"I could sell 500 to 800 more this summer, easily," he said, adding that, as the rewiring project nears completion, "next year demand will be into the thousands."
Another supplier, The Frenchmen, is still installing air-conditioners but has only about 100 left that fit the specifications. That supply is not likely to last more than a week. William Koniuk, who runs the company, said that while he was seeking other sources, "this is the worst season I've seen with manufacturers."
Hoping to capitalize on the burgeoning Stuyvesant air-conditioner market, both suppliers had advertised heavily in the Town and Village weekly newspaper to sign up customers.
One reason air-conditioners began selling out during the heat wave was a low inventory after strong sales last year. "The economy was uncertain, and manufacturers did not believe we would have two strong seasons in a row," Mr. Portnoy said. "It's a sad situation where people waited 47 years for the wiring, and now we don't have enough air-conditioners."
Also, he said, Stuyvesant Town's specifications have essentially limited buyers' choice to certain models by Friedrich, which he said are in demand everywhere.
Residents lucky enough to get on the top of the list are luxuriating in their comfort. "I loooove it -- it's the best thing that ever happened," said Ann Fink, whose building at 270 First Avenue was the first wired, last year. "We're here 19 years, and every summer we swore we were going to move. We had 10 fans -- ceiling fans, floor fans, wherever. Open the door and you got blown to the other end of the apartment. Now we bought three air-conditioners, for the living room and both bedrooms. I would buy one for the bathroom if they made it."
Not everyone in the 8,756 apartments is hooking up, however. Some object to the cost. The wiring entails a monthly rent increase of $27 per room, plus $20 a month per air-conditioner as a year-round electricity charge. The air-conditioners themselves range upwards from $700 for a living room model and $600 for bedroom models.
"I can't afford it," said Gertrude Petty. "I've been 42 years in this hot apartment -- I'm 86, don't you know -- and I tell myself, you lived here through this hell 42 summers, and you can make it through another." BRUCE LAMBERT

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stuyvesant Town residents are installing air-conditioners now that electrical wiring is being upgraded. (Chang Lee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STUYVESANT TOWN;
Fixing the Popping Windows

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
What do you do with 58,416 newly installed windows after 2,000 of them implode and shatter?
That's the issue in the latest battle over the implosion problem, an unusual mystery that has plagued Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village apartments since late last year. 
 It is an issue that is crucial to both tenants and the owner of the complexes. The state has held up a rent increase until the problem is solved.
The owner, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, has this answer to the problem: drill tiny holes in the double-pane glass to relieve the excess vacuum suspected of causing the breakage.
But tenant leaders question whether the planned repair will work. The windows were designed with argon, a nontoxic gas, between the panes to enhance their insulating effectiveness. Critics in the tenants' association say that holes will allow the argon to escape, defeating its purpose, and could also admit moisture and cause condensation inside the windows. Nancy Peskin, a Met Life spokeswoman, said the holes will be so small as to be virtually invisible, and there is no plan to reseal them after the air pressure is equalized.
"Nobody has any faith in this solution," said Jo-Ann Polise, vice president of the tenants association.
Citing the window problems, the tenants have opposed Met Life's request to the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for permission to impose a $9-per-room rent increase to finance the $30 million project.
Now the tenants have won a preliminary victory. State officials advised Met Life that the window job must be satisfactorily completed before the rent can be raised. Unless Met Life wins a reversal in the state's position, it has lost out on a retroactive increases of hundreds of dollars for each of the 11,251 apartments. Ms. Polise said, "It's a considerable savings to tenants." B.L.

HEADLINE: African Despair, and Hope

 BODY:
Africa was given unaccustomed attention last week as the Clinton Administration held a two-day conference on the economic and political afflictions in 30 countries south of the Sahara. But what the conference unintentionally highlighted was the low priority Mr. Clinton has given to a region whose enormous promise is blighted by declining economies and soaring fertility rates.
The cold war's demise, however welcome elsewhere, has proved a setback for black Africa. Superpower rivalry once gave crucial influence to poor lands with prized real estate for military bases, or a grip on maritime "choke points," or large reserves of strategic minerals. But with the Soviet-American competition now over, the C.I.A. is closing 15 African stations. Actual U.S. development aid to sub-Saharan Africa has tapered to around $800 billion this year, as the industrialized world pumps an increasing share of multilateral development funds into the former Communist countries. 
 As The Times's John Darnton detailed in a recent series, Africa's leverage has markedly weakened during a grim decade when its gross national product declined 2 percent a year. A single figure underscores the disastrous state of the region's economy. Excluding South Africa, the total output in 1991 of all countries below the Sahara, with a combined population of nearly 600 million, was roughly the same as the gross national product of Belgium, home of 10 million people. And as output plunged, the region's foreign debt tripled, to $180 billion. Its population will double in 25 years, further straining resources, if the present fertility rates continue.
None of this justifies passivity or despair. Sub-Saharan Africa boasts far more arable land and mineral riches than other poor regions. And in an unforeseen windfall, South Africa, the region's industrial powerhouse, has ceased to be an economic and political pariah after a peaceful democratic revolution brimming with promise.
South Africa's salutary transformation is the region's most stirring event since the post-colonial surge to independence 30 years ago. Not only has apartheid been revoked, but President Nelson Mandela has shown how to turn bitter adversaries into political allies, providing a model for African states polarized by ethnic and political rivalries. And if Pretoria really opens its own frontiers to freer trade, it could jump-start stalled economies elsewhere.
Given a spell of peace and trade across open frontiers, plus the stimulus of a dozen new stock markets, sub-Saharan Africa's economy could grow by 3.9 percent a year in the coming decade, according to forecasts by the World Bank. But Africa is not a machine that can accelerate by itself; it needs the help of a world that has been too quick to take profits out of Africa and too slow to extend a helping hand.
Africa's immediate needs include debt forgiveness or at least a generous rescheduling of loans it cannot possibly repay; seed money for small-scale development rather than big-ticket prestige projects coveted by dictators, and aggressive diplomacy to help end wars and promote democratic reforms.
The Clinton Administration justifies the relative penury of its African development programs by pointing to competing needs. Maybe so. But that excuse cannot explain the absence of a single high-profile appointee to serve as an advocate and goad to conscience. Africa has fallen into the lap of anonymous bureaucrats and stagers of conferences. It deserves far better.


CORRECTION-DATE: July 6, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on Sunday, "African Despair, and Hope," misstated the annual amount of U.S. development aid to sub-Saharan Africa; it has hovered at about $800 million for the last three years.
