HEADLINE: All the President's Problems

BYLINE: By Andrew Sullivan; Andrew Sullivan is the editor of The New Republic.

 BODY:

THE AGENDA
Inside the Clinton White House.
By Bob Woodward.
Illustrated. 352 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $24. 
 BILL CLINTON'S train wreck of an economic plan is headed for a roll-call in the Senate, and three White House missionaries are in hot pursuit of Senator Bob Kerrey, whose vote could pull the bill through. A rendezvous arranged, the persuaders arrive at the American Cafe in Union Station, only to find they are at the wrong American Cafe. They lurch off again, down Massachusetts Avenue, and finally meet up with the elusive Senator at the right American Cafe.
In one of the piquant moments that make "The Agenda," Bob Woodward's account of the Clinton Administration, such a compulsive, Grisham-like read, "Kerrey asked what was next for the White House. Paster [Howard Paster, President Clinton's Congressional liaison] mentioned something about how they were going to move on to health care. 'No, no, no,' Kerrey said loudly and dismissively, 'I don't mean legislative strategy. I mean, what's this Presidency about?' "
It's page 289, and we still don't know. After listening to the Senator from Nebraska's subsequent demolition of the Clinton Presidency, the President's men simply parrot back that their boss agrees with everything Senator Kerrey says. At this point in the book, this is a credible statement. At this point in the book, Mr. Clinton seems to agree with everything anybody says.
* It's April 1993, and Mr. Clinton is meeting with his health and economic advisers: "Where are all the Democrats? . . . We stand for lower deficits and free trade and the bond market. Isn't that great?" he yells sarcastically -- before going along.
* It's Memorial Day weekend, and Mr. Clinton is talking strategy with Paul Begala, a key political consultant, who argues that the economic plan looks soft on the wealthy: "I know this thing is a turkey," Mr. Clinton says.
* It's July, and Senator David Boren is arguing for an alternative that would cut the deficit stringently: " 'Oh, he's right!' Clinton said at one point soon after. There weren't enough spending cuts, he complained. They had not zeroed anything out completely -- that would have been dramatic. There weren't enough entitlement cutbacks."
* It's autumn, and key Cabinet members and advisers are pressing the President to stand up for the free trade agreement with Mexico: " 'I have to be a President beyond the borders,' Clinton finally said, declaring that he would go ahead. 'It is not an option to drop.' "
I'm assuming, of course, that everything in the book -- from the deepest thoughts of Robert J. Shapiro, an economist and Clinton campaign adviser, to the mood swings of Gene Sperling, the deputy director of the National Economic Council -- is true. It certainly rings true. And no one in the White House has seen fit to rebut. Sure, the book contains no major surprises (despite the publisher's hype) and, like Mr. Woodward's previous books, is animated by no coherent analysis and no guiding idea. But that doesn't make it any the less worthwhile as adumbrated, reliable gossip. Besides, Mr. Woodward has long since graduated from investigative journalism to what might better be called confessional journalism: the sources now come to him. We glean what's beneath from the scattering of arcana on the surface. And what's beneath is often worth considering.
Take the President of the United States.
Some commentators have read the book as showing Mr. Clinton as indecisive; in fact, he makes decisions throughout, sometimes belatedly, often with great difficulty, but always eventually. He makes complex calls on the economic plan, even down to line-item budget matters. He makes health care a priority, and takes a stand on the trade agreement. He is also not merely the passive receptacle of his advisers' agendas. It's clear from the book that Mr. Clinton is admirably adept at listening to a range of people and voices, weighing arguments, measuring responses. This is not the same as weakness (in many ways, it's a strength),
and it's why, in person, Mr. Clinton can be so impressive, why Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, could have been so charmed by his attentiveness and apparent agreement at their first meeting:
"Greenspan tried to evaluate the President-elect's sincerity. Was it possible that Clinton was pulling his leg? That it was all a show? That, Greenspan felt, would be really impressive. He would be disturbed if someone was that skilled at deceiving, but it would be remarkable. Clinton's performance was too straight."
No, the problem with Mr. Clinton is not a practical one -- he's not alone in being an executive who prefers a mixture of advice and takes his time to come to a decision. As Mr. Woodward details his ability to keep track of meetings, to mix politics with policy, to call dozens and dozens of Congressmen, to consult with a staff that stretches from the earringed David Dreyer to the courtly Southerner Thomas F. (Mack) McLarty, it's hard not to be overwhelmed by the sheer range of the President's political and social talent.
The problem is an intellectual one. In this book as in the daily newspaper, Mr. Clinton is not simply, as Mr. Woodward has Mr. Greenspan delicately putting it, "an intellectual pragmatist." He seems to live intellectually in a world where there are simply no contradictions; where nothing comes at the expense of anything else; where traditional big-spending liberalism is compatible with deficit-cutting neoliberalism; where welfare reform never actually hurts people; where deficits can be cut while Government investments in education and infrastructure are increased and entitlements left untouched. This is not a question of cynicism. Bill Clinton is no George Bush: he has not ceded everything to political expediency. And it's not a question of pragmatically splitting differences, which every practical politician has to do. With Bob Woodward's Bill Clinton, it's a question of not believing there are differences to split.
SO when the contradictions finally assert themselves, as they tend to do, Mr. Clinton's response is a mixture of shock, self-pity and rage. The most memorable outburst in "The Agenda" comes when Mr. Clinton is told that his economic package cannot both meet Congress's well-known spending caps and keep its ambitious investment plans. Some of his anger can be attributed to his staff's insufficient warnings. But some of it can't: "The President began to yell and shout questions. How? Why? When? . . . Slamming his fist down on the end of his chair, Clinton let loose a torrent of rage and frustration. He said he felt blindsided. This was totally inconsistent with what he had been told. Why hadn't they ever had a serious discussion about the caps? . . . The President turned red in the face. Why didn't they tell me? he asked."
The psychological origins of this intellectual blindness are not hard to discern. The Bill Clinton Mr. Woodward portrays is pathologically averse to real conflict. "I don't hate anyone," he remarks at one point. "I forget the people I'm supposed to hate." It's notable that throughout the book, Mr. Clinton never blows up at anyone his own size, or even at anyone in particular, but at the world in general, at an unnamed "they," at a minor flunky ("I want him dead, dead. I want him killed. I want him horse-whipped") or, if all else fails, at the long-suffering George Stephanopoulos, his senior policy adviser.
This is not, the book cumulatively reveals, the behavior of a bully so much as that of someone so traumatized by conflict that he will avoid it at any cost, and then abstractly rage at the consequences. At one point in the explosive phone conversation in which Senator Kerrey tells him he is going to vote against the economic plan, Mr. Clinton plaintively wails like a 14-year-old -- " 'Everybody said this is going to be the smart thing to do,' Clinton said, his voice rising with fury and defeat. 'I took this thing on head on and I gave a good-faith effort' " -- once again refusing to take responsibility for the genuine ideological disagreement his difference with Senator Kerrey was rooted in.
MR. WOODWARD'S judgments on the other White House players are less definitive, but often telling. Mr. Clinton's political consultants, Paul Begala, James Carville and Mandy Grunwald, turn out to be spectacularly wrong about almost everything. My favorite example is their "populist" insistence that the people had little desire for deficit reduction, when it was clearly the popular rage of 1993.
Mr. Begala, to his credit, eventually gets it; and Mr. Carville, to his credit, finally swallows the gas tax added to the economic program to help bring down the deficit. Still, they all pitch in (with Hillary Rodham Clinton) against pushing the free trade agreement rather than health care reform in the fall. Wrong again! In fact, wrong about the politics of health care altogether.
Ira Magaziner, the White House health care policy adviser, is a suitably comic figure, doggedly insisting that his enormously cumbersome plan was actually going to save money. And the Administration economic team comes off as remarkably sane and more liberal than Mr. Woodward's ideological rubric (which pits the neoliberal economic appointees against the paleoliberal political consultants) would suggest: Laura Tyson, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, fights a hard battle to soften deficit reduction, and Robert Reich, the Secretary of Labor, maintains constant pressure in defense of more Government spending on long-term investments like education.
Most surprising of all, perhaps, is Vice President Al Gore's political skill. He alone seemed to see the opportunity for Mr. Clinton back in early 1993 to cut a fresh figure as a deficit slayer and clearly establish his New Democrat credentials. He's a team player who doesn't always live up to his nice-guy image: "I want to know if you're going to screw us," Mr. Woodward tells us the Vice President demanded of Senator John Breaux at one point. And a by now often cited moment one day in the Oval Office is indeed wonderful. Mr. Clinton, lamenting "the endless compromises and delays" besetting the economic plan, turns to Mr. Gore: " 'What can I do?' he asked the Vice President. 'You can get with the goddamn program!' Gore answered tersely, his own exasperation boiling over." By the end of this book, the reader is left with the tantalizing thought of what might have been had the ticket been Gore-Clinton and not the other way around.
This is not, however, an account of the Clinton Administration as a whole. Mr. Woodward shares with Mr. Clinton an obsession with economic policy that blinds them to the political context in which economic policy must always be made. There is nothing, for example, about Bosnia in Mr. Woodward's account, and virtually nothing about a defining headache of the first few months of the Administration, the battle over homosexuals in the military. Even vital parts of the economic program such as the expansion of the earned-income tax credit, arguably Mr. Clinton's greatest social policy achievement, are given extremely short shrift because they don't fit into the plot line.
The entire Perot phenomenon is also essentially absent, although it greatly affected the climate in which Mr. Clinton's first year unfolded. Ross Perot's support in his 1992 Presidential race showed that populism in the late 20th century was an essentially antiliberal force; that it stemmed from a distrust of government, not a demand for more of it. Mr. Clinton and his consultants seem blissfully unaware of this fact, blithely talking up class warfare and redistribution of wealth. But if Mr. Clinton is unaware of it, so is Mr. Woodward.
There are other worries. Mr. Woodward elevates Alan Greenspan in a way that helps his plot line and his publisher's belabored hyping but does not exactly ring true. The notion that deficit reduction was actually good for the economy was not an idea that Mr. Clinton needed Mr. Greenspan to tell him; it's conventional wisdom, repeated a thousand times during the campaign and well understood by the neoliberals in the Clinton entourage.
MR. CLINTON adopted it not because of a tutorial with the chairman of the Fed, but because the voters had demanded it in 1992 and Congress insisted on it the following year. From "The Agenda" you might get the impression that 1993 was a year in which a popular President battled an unpopular Congress over how to run the economy.
But Mr. Woodward's broader failings are made up for by the pleasingly breathless style in which the story is told. Occasionally he overreaches: "Panetta looked out the large panels of windows. A summer thunderstorm was brewing. He was awed as it built, black and gray clouds approaching, then the rain and wind, and finally the storm itself passing through. He had watched, from a much greater distance, other Presidents go through similar turmoil." In general, though, Mr. Woodward makes even the ill-fated B.T.U. tax tick along briskly enough.
And with this Administration, Mr. Woodward's deeper flaws -- that he has no ideas to speak of, shows little sense of history and is unable to relate a narrative to a larger argument -- are strangely fitting. With Mr. Woodward and President Clinton, the journalism of mere process has met the politics of mere process. Mr. Woodward has finally found the President he deserves.

HEADLINE: ABOUT BOOKS

BYLINE: By Shirley Horner 

 BODY:

Sights on the Road
 THERE is an image of New Jersey that perhaps should be lost, but not if Peter Genovese, the author of "Roadside New Jersey," can help it. The hordes of writers waxing poetic over the gently rolling hills and wide sandy beaches miss the mark, Mr. Genovese says; what is great about the state is what he found and photographed while driving over hundreds of thousands of miles of roads. 
 "There was another New Jersey out there," writes Mr. Genovese, a Manasquan resident who is a columnist for The Home News, based in East Brunswick.
So get ready for an entertaining, whirlwind tour of the offbeat, beginning with unlikely though not necessarily enviable residences like a windmill in Barnegat, a log in Beach Haven and a castle on Route 57 in Mansfield fronted by this ominous sign: "Harley Parking Only. All Others Will Be Crushed." Published by the Rutgers Univerity Press, "Roadside" sells for $18.95.
The ubiquitous diner is immortalized here -- there are 31 pictures of diners -- as well as motels like the "queer little place, the green-and-white motel on Route 40 in Upper Pittsgrove" that resembles "a 1950's version of a spaceship" and whose owner "can't figure out" why people stop there.
The book's more than 400 photos, in color and black and white, include the street signs of Wit's End, Mount Misery and Sodom Lane along with other reasons to pause while driving: the Dog & Cat Deli for a pet-food store in Ocean Township, the Recessions Family Restaurant in Butler and Hairdresser on Fire in Roxbury.
Call this ideal travel literature, especially appealing for the character sketches of people Mr. Genovese met during his New Jersey travels: like Hubcap Jack, the octogenarian proprietor of Hubcap Pyramid, a 25-foot pile of hubcaps in Weymouth, or Helen Ertl of Vienna, who by tying the message "Help" around 11 maple trees fought the plan of the Department of Transportation to cut down them down -- and managed to save five.
And when the time comes for a thoughtful new state slogan for New Jersey, perhaps Mr. Genovese will submit one from a sign he discovered with the following advice: "Eat peanuts while you have your teeth."
 
Award for Art Essays
 The New Jersey Council for the Humanities recently gave its book award to Dr. Carol Duncan, the author of "The Aesthetics of Power," a somewhat benign title for a book that holds many a fiery message. Dr. Duncan, a professor of art history at Ramapo College in Mahwah, did not, according to the preface, intend that critical art history be perceived any other way.
In her world, as reflected in this collection of her essays, published by the Cambridge University Press ($16.95 paper; $49.95 hard-cover), art is neither neutral nor placid, and so she does battle with "the moral and political meanings that works of art have held in the past."
"The subjugation of the female" -- that is, equating the female sexual experience "with surrender and victimization" -- motivates modern erotic art, the author says. Further, she warns that although the significance of art is believed to be purely esthetic and "never bad for anyone," many so-called masterpieces with an air of authority "affirm the ideals of male domination."
Just who is Cheryl Bernstein, the author of the final essays of this book? In an interview, Dr. Duncan said that in 1970, "wanting to puncture the self-inflated and overly verbose world of art criticism, I invented a parody and called her Cheryl Bernstein."
How Bernstein was accepted in the art world, becoming known as "an astute, theoretically advanced critic" -- until the author voluntarily retired her in 1980 -- carries a message of its own about indistinguishability of parody and art criticism.
The New Jersey Humanities Book Award is presented to nonfiction works by authors linked to the state "by virtue of birth, residence or occupation" and whose work "invites critical reflection and makes scholarly knowledge available and exciting to a general audience." Winners get $1,000, and their publishers get $2,000 for marketing purposes.
 
Electronic Medical Manual
To say that one legendary title published in New Jersey has an enviable sales record worldwide is far from a boast, because The Merck Manual, printed by Merck & Company of Rahway since 1899, sold more than one million copies of its 15th edition. Its 16th edition, issued in 1992, is expected to exceed that figure by 20 percent.
Intended as a reference source for doctors, the $26 book now appeals to the vast variety of health care professionals and that amorphous group usually referred to as the medically curious. The manual provides information about the causes, symptoms, evaluation and treatment of virtually every disorder known to medicine.
What made news at the American Booksellers Convention, held in Los Angeles in May, was what Dr. Robert Berkow, the manual's editor, called abreakthrough: all 2,800 pages were turned -- perhaps "shrunk" describes it better -- into a half-ounce Read-Only Memory (ROM) card, two and one-fourth inches high.
The card fits into a Digital Book System, a hand-held electronic book, 5 inches by 3 inches by 1/2 inch, made by Franklin Electronic Publishers ofMount Holly. A combination of the electronic version of the manual and the digital book reader is being offered for $199.95 by Franklin (800-762-5382). Otherwise, the two items, if purchased separately, would total about $300.
Whether you enter cholesterolosis of the gallbladder or snoring, the speed with which the electronic book finds each reference is fraught with possibilities for even the mildest hypochondriac.

HEADLINE: Early Signs Point to Strong Shore Season

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY 

 BODY:
IF the appearance of dolphins just beyond the breakers in Ocean City is an economic indicator of a good summer ahead, then Virginia Berwick's saltwater taffy and fudge shop on the boardwalk should do a booming business.
"The dolphins were out there just yesterday," Mrs. Berwick said with a smile and an optimistic tone on a recent day. Gazing out the window of her store, she added, "If the weather is good and the beaches stay clean, it will be a great summer." 
 Mrs. Berwick's qualified prediction of the 1994 Jersey Shore tourism season is shared by environmental and tourism officials alike. Other important factors, like the national economy and how much disposable income families think they have, will have a bearing on vacations along New Jersey's 127 miles of ocean beaches. But good weather and the perception of a clean coastal environment are the fragile variables that make all the difference.
"We are still holding our breath," Robert C. Shinn, director of the State Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, said, "but we feel positive about this being a good summer."
Karen Shaffer, a spokeswoman for the state division of travel and tourism, said that "preseason business at the Shore is a barometer of what is coming, and we have received all positive reports from real-estate agencies, hotels and other establishments, which are doing more business than they did this time last year."
Ms. Shaffer said that although an extensive economic survey had never been done, the division's reported tourism revenues for 1993, according to an independent survey, were $18 billion.
Shore tourism accounted for $9.5 billion of that, she said, with about $3 billion of the Shore tourism figure attributable to casino gambling in Atlantic City. So traditional Shore tourism, minus Atlantic City gambling revenue, generated $6.5 billion last year. According to Ms. Shaffer's figures, this was $700 million more than the $5.8 billion reported for 1992, when the total with casino gambling was $8.8 billion.
Although optimistic preseason predictions are usually easy to come by in any area that relies on tourism, real-estate people and other business owners, as well as tourism officials, said in recent interviews that 1994 shows signs of becoming the best summer in years. And that, they say, would mean that the Shore will have recovered from its disastrous economic decline of the last decade.
Starting in 1987, garbage and medical debris on beaches, as well as high bacteria counts in the water from malfunctioning sewage treatment plants, forced some ocean beaches to close occasionally. Widespread news reports exacerbated what was a precipitous decline in Shore tourism through 1990. In 1988 and 1989, for example, that economy was said by officials to have lost $1 billion.
All the bad news coincided with a general downturn in the economy that was particularly severe in the Northeast and what tourism experts said had become in the 1980's a national trend toward shorter, less expensive vacations. The trend continues in New Jersey, with extended weekends and one-week vacations being the most common getaways, real-estate agents say.
But at least some of the problems of the 80's may have ended. "Each year since 1990 has been a little bit better, until last year, when it was substantially better," said Andrea Schlosser Carter, a real-estate agent in Lavallette in Ocean County, who is also a director of the Ocean County Board of Realtors.
Ms. Carter said last year was the best one for rentals since 1985. But rentals this year are up by 20 percent, she said, raising the possibility that the Shore economy has turned the corner. "There seems to be a renewed interest in the Shore," Ms. Carter said.
 
Prospect for Clean Beaches
 Nevertheless, what will allow Mr. Shinn and others to relax and exhale come September are a sunny, dry summer and clean beaches. Big storms or frequent rains can still flush millions of gallons of pollutants from land-based sources like treatment plants and storm sewers into the Atlantic. Along with things like contaminated sediment from rivers and bays that are stirred up by storms, the pollutants can produce the high levels of bacteria that shut down beaches.
At least two beach closings have occurred already, said Barbara Derer, a spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy. One was at Cape May on June 8, the other at Seaside Heights on June 15. In both instances, Ms. Derer said, the closings were due to high bacteria counts and lasted just one day.
Cindy Zipf, director of Clean Ocean Action, a coalition of environmentalists and 300 Shore-related businesses, said much has been accomplished in recent years to improve the monitoring of coastal pollution and to clean up beaches and harbors. For instance, Ms. Zipf asserted, "New Jersey's ocean water quality testing is now second to none."
Federal, state and local environmental and health officials have joined in several programs that more closely monitor pollution and clean up harbors and beaches before Memorial Day and during the summer. Mr. Shinn said in an interview that a state program removed 5,000 tons of debris from harbors and beaches before Memorial Day this year.
 
Losses in Earlier Years
 Exactly how much damage has been done to Shore tourism since the 1980's has never been officially assessed by Trenton. But many individual businesses and municipalities reported losses of 30 percent to 60 percent between 1987 and 1990. Beach resort towns in Monmouth and Ocean Counties reported the heaviest losses for that period, while Atlantic and Cape May Counties suffered somewhat less.
Whatever the precise losses and gains, the declining Shore economy of the 1980's galvanized groups that had long been divided over how to keep the ocean clean and how clean beaches should be.
"The reality is that the Shore economy is directly tied to the quality of the environment," Ms. Zipf said. "It is now an accepted, adopted philosophy that in order for towns and businesses to be successful they need a clean ocean."
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, addressing a recent gathering of some 250 representatives of environmental and Shore-related businesses in Ocean City, said state funds for tourism promotion were being well spent. She said she had approved a coming legislative appropriation, raising the total for statewide tourism promotion in the 1995 fiscal year by $1.1 million to $5.9 million.
While it was not immediately known how much of the total will be spent on the Shore -- most advertising presents the entire state as a single destination -- Mrs. Whitman said it was a rare increase in state spending that would pay off. Each dollar spent on tourism promotion brings $100 in revenue to the state's economy, she said.
The Governor encouraged regional tourism agencies and others to continue "bundling and packaging" recreational, historic and environmental attractions, which has been part of the new marketing strategy since business dropped off several years ago.
 
Help From Private Sector
 Help is coming from the private sector, too. Five utility companies with substantial investments at the Shore announced that they would spend $500,000 to promote Shore tourism. Ron Marano, a spokesman for the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, one of the participants, said in an interview that the utilities were members of the Jersey Shore Partnership, a group of businesses interested in promoting the coastal economy.
Mrs. Whitman also told the gathering in Ocean City, which was called Coastal Alliance '94, that physically protecting the resources of the Shore was another key concern of her administration because "the Shore is a large part of who we are in New Jersey."
 
Shore Protection Fund
 A $15 million Shore Protection Fund, which was originally proposed under her predecessor, Gov. Jim Florio, was passed by the Legislature last year and is now available as the state's first stable source of money for Shore protection projects, the Governor said. The fund is for rebuilding and fortifying beaches and man-made coastal structures damaged by perennial erosion and storms.
James F. Hall, director of the division of natural and historic resources in the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, said the $15 million would allow the state to qualify for matching Federal funds, which often cover 65 percent of the total cost of projects. This formula will see about $40 million generated each year for beach protection in the state, Mr. Hall said.
Mr. Shinn said in the interview that a computerized Geographical Information System, which is being programmed by the department to include data like the locations of stormwater and sewage treatment outfall lines and ecologically sensitive coastal areas, is still being developed. Eventually, he said, it will allow the state to regulate development of the Shore and track pollution more scientifically.
As Mrs. Whitman declared in her address, "We are no longer entrusting the Shore's integrity to pure chance."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 600 words

HEADLINE: Asylum Seekers Need Only a Reasonable Fear

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The concern about the fairness of the procedure and the confusion about the criteria in the screening of Haitian boat people aboard United States ships described in June 17 and 18 articles from Kingston, Jamaica, are symptomatic of a political and not a legal dilemma. The law is well established. The controlling standard was laid down by the Supreme Court in Immigration and Naturalization Service v. Cardoza Fonseca. 
 The essence of this decision was that applicants for asylum in -- or refugee admission to -- the United States are not required to show that they would be singled out for punishment if sent back to the country from which they fled. Nor do applicants have to demonstrate the likelihood, let alone the clear probability, of such punishment. A reasonable possibility of persecution is, or should be, sufficient to support an asylum or admission request.
Since the refugee legislation of 1980 was meant to bring United States law in concordance with the United Nations Convention, the Court felt at ease in adopting criteria developed by the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. It quoted approvingly the refugee agency's explanation that an applicant's fear in general "should be considered well founded if he can establish, to a reasonable degree, that his continued stay in his country of origin has become intolerable for him for the reasons stated in the refugee definition, or would for the same reason be intolerable if he returned there."
And the Court, to make quite clear how it wanted the new standard implemented, stated in a memorable caveat: "There is simply no room . . . for concluding that because an applicant only has a 10 percent chance of being shot, tortured or otherwise persecuted, that he or she has no well-founded fear of the event happening."
Fear is a subjective reaction. And it was this aspect of the Court's decision, delivered by Associate Justice John P. Stevens, that Justice Harry
A. Blackmun addressed in his concurring opinion.
He pointed out that the term "well-founded fear" demanded a particular type of analysis -- "an examination of the subjective feelings of an applicant for asylum, coupled with an inquiry into the objective nature of the articulated reasons for fear," the sort of analysis for which Justice Blackmun commended the "well-reasoned opinions of the courts of appeals that almost uniformly have rejected the I.N.S.'s misreading of statutory language and legislative history." And he ended with a stern admonition:
"The efforts of these courts stand in stark contrast to -- but, it is sad to say, alone cannot make up for -- the years of seemingly purposeful blindness by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which only now begins its task of developing the standard entrusted to its care."
These words were written seven years ago. Alas, they are still apt in the Haitian context. It is as easy to impugn the motives of asylum seekers as basically economic as it is difficult for an outsider to comprehend fully and to untangle the components that lead people to conclude that life in Haiti has become intolerable. But as long as there is a possibility, and be it only a 10 percent possibility, that an individual upon return to Haiti will be exposed to the retaliatory vindictiveness of a murderous regime, that person is protected by a decision of the United States Supreme Court.
 
ROBERT P. DE VECCHI
CHARLES STERNBERG
New York, June 22, 1994
 
The writers are the present and former executive officer of the International Rescue Committee.

ECONOMY IMPROVES IN EUROPE

HEADLINE: Hospitals Learning The Not-Subtle Art Of Self-Promotion

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

 BODY:
Lenox Hill Hospital sends newcomers to the neighborhood a "health kit" that offers would-be patients "free diet and nutritional counseling" and a "free cosmetic surgery screening," along with a "free gift" for those who fill out an enclosed card. (O.K., it's a refrigerator magnet.)
Last summer New York Downtown Hospital offered tourists coupons good for $25 off on a visit to its emergency room. And Elmhurst Hospital Center has hosted tax seminars, classes in English as a second language, even a community dance to coax prospective customers. 
 Under intense new pressure to compete for patients, New York area hospitals have jumped into the business of wooing patients. In the last year to 18 months, hospital administrators say, most local institutions have begun advertising either for the first time or more aggressively than ever before. Many have hired consultants, and some are considering celebrity spokesmen and women.
Hospitals have begun offering prospective customers everything from free key chains to new high-tech services and amenities such as guest accommodations for family members. One even promises superior food, replacing lime gelatin and cottage cheese with low-sodium Chinese food.
Until recently, hospitals generally disdained all but the most discreet marketing efforts -- a lecture series, perhaps, or a health fair -- and most institutions simply waited for referrals from staff physicians.
But with managed care gaining ground and the demand for hospital beds steadily declining, both because of medical advances and fixed reimbursements that encourage shorter stays, hospitals are facing dim prospects. Many experts believe that one in five hospitals in the region will be out of business by the end of the decade. So the competition to stay alive is intense.
"It's insane," said Carol Hauptman, director of public relations at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in Manhasset, L.I., which she said is reluctantly following suit, starting its first major marketing campaign in the coming weeks. "Every five minutes," she said, "we hear another hospital touting another medical program, some of which are not exactly in-depth medical programs at institutions that are not exactly world-renowned, along with the renowned ones, too."
Even New York City's public hospitals recently entered the fray, with a plan for an initial outlay of $1 million on marketing to hold on to Medicaid patients courted by health maintenance organizations aligned with private hospitals.
 
'The Wild West'
 "It's going to be the Wild West for the next few years," said Dr. Bruce Siegel, president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's 11 public hospitals.
Yet even as the competition mounts, local hospital administrators seem torn about what they are doing: How far can the definition of 'public health education' be stretched to apply to sophisticated advertising campaigns? And how far should hospitals go to compete without compromising their central mission of healing the sick?
"It's diverting millions of dollars from the bedside," Dr. Philip Lanzkowski, acting medical director of Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park, said of the current marketing blitz. "I'm not sure about how ethical it is do to that. This is not big business in the sense that we're G.E., and I'm personally very opposed."
Most hospital administrators declined to say how much they are spending on these new efforts, Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said most medical centers still only spend a tiny percentage of their budgets on traditional advertising and marketing -- a maximum of $2 million to $3 million a year. But with the entire definition of what constitutes hospital marketing in flux, he said that dollar amount significantly understates the money being spent to make hospitals more competitive.
And administrators are also debating which ones will prove effective.
The frenzy in the New York area comes about three years after the hospital wars first flared in the rest of the country, because doctors in the Northeast in general and New York in particular have been slow to accept managed care. And some marketing experts say strategies popular in New York, such as direct mail and heavy advertising, have already failed elsewhere. Administrators of several West Coast hospitals said they consider most direct appeals to consumers a waste of money because it is health maintenance organizations, and not individual patients, that ultimately make most decisions about what hospitals to patronize.
"What happens when you spend all of your money promoting cardiovascular doctors and then managed care companies say, 'You may have a big name, but we're not using you,' " says Dr. Paul Keckley, a Nashville-based marketing consultant to hospitals across the country. "Everything will depend on who gets results at the lowest cost."
Meanwhile, local hospitals are simultaneously trying a variety of approaches to see what works.
Small community hospitals, which are the most vulnerable in the industry shakedown, are particularly busy adding services they hope will distinguish them from the pack.
Last year, St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains opened a Beneath the Sea Hyperbaric Medical Center. The center is staffed by "experienced scuba divers," according to a hospital brochure, and is equipped with a hyperbaric chamber to treat divers with the bends and other diving-related maladies. Currently, the hospital is building a guest house for family members of patients receiving bone marrow transplants.
But larger institutions, too, are specializing.
"In the end, not all of us are going to do the same kind of procedures," said Dr. Benjamin K. Chu, vice president for clinical affairs at New York University Medical Center. "In the end, how many of us are going to be able to do state-of-the-art cancer surgery or cardiovascular surgery?"
And more hospitals are using extensive marketing surveys and focus groups to find untapped corners of a shrinking market.
Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center found that many people did not use its services because they did not want to travel to Washington Heights, the upper Manhattan neighborhood where the hospital is located. So last month, it opened a medical center on the Upper East Side, "to capture people who didn't want to come to Washington Heights for their first visit," said Richard Kearns, executive vice president for external relations.
Englewood Hospital and Medical Center in New Jersey built what it calls an exact replica of a Japanese health center after research showed gaps in the service provided the area's 200,000 Japanese-born residents.
For the center, the hospital imported design plans, medical equipment and hired an all-Japanese staff, even stocking it with kimono-style robes and videos of Japanese cartoons for the children.
Under an expanded definition of what constitutes marketing, some New York administrators also said that cost-cutting measures suddenly qualify as smart marketing that makes them more attractive to the ultimate consumer, the managed care company.
Both small and large institutions are affiliating madly, with the smaller hospitals able to offer H.M.O.'s a wider range of services, and the major centers tapping new sources of patient referrals.
Many are also diversifying on their own, opening primary care centers and nursing homes, hoping to provide the "cradle to grave" service that managed care companies favor.
"We're doing a lot of things to position ourselves strategically and operationally," said Barry Freeman, director of Mount Sinai Medical Center, which has links to 13 other hospitals and four nursing homes.
At the same time, Mount Sinai is also using more old-fashioned pitches for name recognition, such as one television ad in which a nurse puts fresh sheets on the hospital bed in a sunny, flower-filled corner room with two commanding views of the New York skyline.
Irma Damhuis, vice president of public affairs and marketing for Mount Sinai, said, "the message is slightly heightened at this point, in part in reaction to the clutter that's out there."
In other examples of current advertising, White Plains Medical Center in Westchester County is running magazine ads that say, "In its search for an ally in the fight against cancer, Johns Hopkins' choice was obvious: White Plains Medical Center."
On the radio, the mother of a child with asthma says using Beth Israel Medical Center's Physician Referral Service is "the smartest move I ever made."
Even Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore has been advertising in New York, with radio ads and small announcements in the Playbill programs passed out to theatergoers.
"But I'd say right now we're somewhat schizophrenic in our approach," said Dr. Toby Gordon, vice president for planning and marketing at Johns Hopkins. "We have invested in some marketing but we haven't fully committed, and with everything happening in health care we're probably going to have schizophrenia for another year."
Among the regional hospitals that have already committed to a single marketing strategy for example, is Danbury Hospital in Connecticut, a hospital that retooled its marketing strategy within the last year.
"I could advertise until I was blue in the face, but if I'm not that managed-care company's panel, then I'm wasting my time," said C. D. Peterson, vice president of planning and marketing at the hospital.
Cost-cutting pitches to H.M.O.'s are probably the most controversial marketing plan of all, because of questions about how economies can compromise the quality of patient care.
 
Cost-Effectiveness
 Mr. Peterson, who insisted that cost-trimming measures at Danbury had actually increased patient satisfaction, said that in an effort to cut the expense of specific medical procedures, the hospital had, for example, reduced the number of available hip replacement prostheses from 9 to 3. Each required specialized training for employees, he said.
After reviews showed that the bulk of one large local employer's health care dollars were being spent on drug treatment for its employees' adolescent children, the hospital developed a shorter-term inpatient treatment program, combined with outpatient services.
Currently, he said, the hospital is working on a more cost-effective way to treat those who suffer from carpal tunnel syndrome. The condition, a repetitive stress injury caused by repeated finger, hand, and wrist motions such as those used in computer typing, has become a leading cause of workplace disability.
Mr. Peterson said hospital officials asked managed care executives, "If we could come up with a product that pulled together doctors, physical therapists, and work site review, would that interest you?"
"The answer was yes, so now we're moving forward in the hope they'll send us many more people" who suffer from the condition, he said.
"That, in my estimation, is what marketing is today. That's the only way you're going to become a winner."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
At 60 M.P.H., Arafat's Progress in Gaza Is a Blur

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GAZA, July 3

 BODY:
If it is the task of presidents to roar along the highway in motorcades, to blow kisses at flower-bearing children, to dedicate factories and to move from one photo opportunity to another, then Yasir Arafat was unquestionably a president today in the country of Palestine that he hopes is aborning.
Anyone remotely aware of the rituals and excesses of American-style Presidential trips would have instantly recognized the patterns in Mr. Arafat's journey across the Gaza Strip on his third day here. Yet it was also a bit like looking at an image in a fun-house mirror. Yes, it was familiar. But somehow it was not quite right. 
 For starters, presidents usually keep to schedules. As best as one can tell, the word "schedule" is not in Mr. Arafat's vocabulary.
Presidents, at least in the United States, usually do not zoom along the road at 60 miles an hour, trucks and cars roaring behind in convoy, each with soldiers leaning out the window with rifles and pistols in the air and doing a good job of looking as though they are just waiting for someone to make their day. Usually, presidential security men do not ride in a stretch Mercedes with its license plates reversed, to hide the fact that the plates are Israeli and the car quite possibly stolen.
Still, the recognizable trappings and symbolism of high office were all there. Mr. Arafat has carefully touched important political bases -- visiting refugee camps as a reminder that the issue of Palestinian refugees is alive, talking with people crippled in the anti-Israeli uprising, touring prison cells where Israel had held Palestinians and meeting with Arabs holding Israeli citizenship.
A highlight today for the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization was a visit to a new factory that processes citrus fruit into juice. Financed by Italy and the United Nations Development Program, the plant exemplified the importance of "reconstruction and development" for impoverished Gaza, Mr. Arafat said.
His was a vintage presidential tour for the electronic age, down to the shoving, swearing mass of cameras and pens that surged through the factory with him. If inane questions and answers are also a part of being president, then Mr. Arafat has arrived.
"Do you like orange juice?" someone asked.
"Yes, I like it," he replied.
And it was on the record.
 
Glad-Handing Is Out
 What Mr. Arafat has not done, out of security fears, is to wade into crowds. For many Gazans who lined the roads waiting to glimpse him as he passed by standing in his open-roofed car, the most they saw in the last three days was a blur of a checkered headscarf under which presumably stood the short P.L.O. leader.
No one seemed to expect him to leap out of his car, Gorbachev style, to show the common touch, and so one cannot really say that people were disappointed. But while excited, many also were not ecstatic over having merely seen him. As soon as the motorcade passed, Gazans in most places lost little time going about their business.
 
Above It All
 On Tuesday, assuming all goes according to ever-shifting plan, Mr. Arafat will fly over Israel. It is difficult to overstate how implausible that sentence would have sounded not many months ago.
Aides say he would take a helicopter ride on Tuesday morning from Gaza to Jericho, to see the other sphere of the Palestinian self-rule that has been in effect for two months. The only way to do that is to cross Israeli air space, maybe even pass over Jerusalem, the forbidden city to the P.L.O. leader for now.
Together, Israeli and Palestinian security officials have been working out the delicate logistics of the Jericho trip, which should be Mr. Arafat's last major event before he leaves for Paris. Attempts by Israeli settlers this weekend to block the roads to Jericho reinforced the conclusion that taking a car to the West Bank town is a bad idea.
The journey to Jericho has lengthened Mr. Arafat's expected stay by a day. One reason, explained Nabil Shaath, a close adviser, is that Egyptian helicopters have yet to arrive and flight procedures must be arranged.
Why not use one of several helicopters that the P.L.O. itself has?
"They need a lot of overhaul," Mr. Shaath said.
 
The Stones Fly Again
 An important element of the self-rule deal is that the 5,000 Israeli settlers in Gaza are to stay where they are, their fate to be negotiated further down the peace road.
The potential for friction with Gaza's roughly 800,000 Palestinians was underlined on Friday only minutes before Mr. Arafat's arrival at an entrance to Gush Qatif, the main bloc of settlements along the coast. There, under their army's protection, the Israelis insisted on flying flags of their country next to Palestinian flags planted along the Arafat motorcade route from the Egyptian border. Indeed, unless he was not looking, the P.L.O. chairman could not have missed the Israeli banners as he passed.
At one point, a bearded settler driving out of Gush Qatif became enraged when he saw the Palestinian flags and tried to yank one down. Immediately, stones started flying at him from a group of angry Palestinians who were watching.
Armed Israeli soldiers posted at the Gush Qatif were models of restraint. All they needed was for one of them to shoot a rock-throwing Palestinian with Mr. Arafat on his way. In no time, they hustled the settler into his car and whisked him away. The stoning stopped.
 
Goodbye and God Bless
 It has been noted here that the P.L.O. leader came without his wife of the last four years, Suha Tawil. Mrs. Arafat says that the suddenness of the trip, announced hastily only four days ago, had caught her unwares, along with the rest of the world.
"To live with Arafat means to live with many secrets," the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronot quoted her today as saying in Cairo. "He doesn't involve me. He tells me when necessary. When he told me he was leaving, I only said three words, God bless you."

Companies
In a highly unusual move, a multibillion-dollar military contract awarded to TRW has apparently been canceled, with the General Accounting Office ruling that the losing rivals, Lockheed and Martin Marietta, be allowed to bid again. [Page 35.] 
 Television ratings for the World Cup are perhaps double what was expected. Canon, Coca-Cola, Mastercard, Snickers and other sponsors are hawking their image. And hotels are drawing more than they would have in early summer. [35.]

The Economy
Kevin Mitnick is a computer programmer run amok, suspected of stealing software and data from more than half a dozen leading cellular phone makers. And law-enforcement officials cannot seem to catch up with him. [1.]

The Media Business

The book publishing industry is growing much more quickly nationally than it is in New York, so the city's share of the publishing work force has fallen sharply, a city agency said. [39.]
By raising its newsstand price, The Daily News of New York appears to be daring The New York Post to make good on a threat to cut its price. William Glaberson: Press Notes. [39.]
The Fortean Times, a British journal of eccentric phenomena, does not see itself as a supermarket tabloid, even if it offers readers a free "alien defense kit." [39.]
 
International
When officials in Latvia wanted help in modernizing their antiquated telephone network, they did what they had always done under the old Soviet system and took the first offer that came along. But within a few months, the Latvians decided to try a concept they had read about: competitive bidding. They signed a contract with a consortium to rebuild completely the Latvian telephone network for nearly 10 times the value of the original deal. [36.]
The overseas stock markets that so dazzled investors in 1993 continued to fizzle in the second quarter of 1994, while 1993's also-rans are turning into a tough year's top performers. [37.]
Western Europe is at last emerging from its first post-cold-war recession, but with policy makers still grappling with the momentous changes that have swept the Continent. [1.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Trip to Stress European Unity Hopes

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
President Clinton heads to Europe on Tuesday for the third time this year to begin a weeklong tour that advisers hope can restore some shine to his foreign-policy credentials.
The main occasion for the trip is the annual meeting of the Group of Seven economic powers, which will open on Friday in Naples, Italy. But Mr. Clinton has framed that stop with visits to Latvia, Poland and Germany to show he is a champion of efforts to forge a truly integrated Europe. 
 From a celebration in Riga, Latvia, of the Baltic countries' hard-won independence to a ceremony in Berlin marking the end of the American military's presence, Mr. Clinton will proceed along stepping stones chosen as reminders of what the cold war's passing has brought and may yet promise.
With his stops in Riga, Warsaw, Naples, Bonn and finally Berlin, Mr. Clinton clearly hopes to retouch his portrait so he is given more credit for his efforts to rebind a recently divided Europe in ways that would make it more prosperous and more secure.
 
Outline of Clinton's Theme
 In an interview last week with a German reporter, Mr. Clinton sketched out what he said would be his theme as he becomes the first American President to visit a Baltic country and the first to set foot in Germany since the collapse of the Berlin wall.
"My message will be that we've torn down the walls, but now we have to build the bridges," the President said. "We have to unite Europe, and we have to move forward on security issues, on economic issues, to make a better world."
Mr. Clinton's advisers have made clear that they intend to spend the week trying to redress what they regard as an injustice -- that Americans' attention to trouble spots like Rwanda and Haiti has taken attention from policy successes central to the transformation of Europe.
Nonetheless, the President will also have to contend on this trip with problems that have dogged him since his foreign debut, including the war in Bosnia, tensions with North Korea over nuclear weapons and the plunging value of the American dollar.
The White House has thrown much of its energy for the last week into planning what promises to be a complicated journey. When Mr. Clinton visited Europe last month for the D-Day commemoration, he acted mostly as commentator and spectator; this week he is to hold what may in some cases be rancorous talks with at least 13 heads of state, including President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
Mr. Clinton will fly from Washington on Tuesday night directly to Riga, the Latvian capital, where he is to speak on Wednesday in Freedom Square to a crowd swollen by visitors from the neighboring Baltic countries of Lithuania and Estonia.
Now that Russian troops have withdrawn from Lithuania and are scheduled to be out of Latvia by the end of August, the President's visit is intended in large part to celebrate an end to five decades of occupation that the United States never recognized.
 
Issue of Estonia Pullout
 Russia has not yet agreed to terms for the pullout of its forces from Estonia, however. After meeting with Estonia's President, aides say, Mr. Clinton intends to tell Mr. Yeltsin in Naples that it is essential that Russia abide by its promise to withdraw all of its troops from the three Baltic countries by Aug. 31.
In Warsaw, where he is to arrive Wednesday night, Mr. Clinton hopes to reassure Poland and the leaders of other Eastern European countries that the United States does not regard them as falling under some new Russian sphere of influence, even though Washington and its allies are not yet ready to include them in NATO.
Mr. Clinton's speech before the Polish Parliament on that issue was conceived by his advisers as the main one of his European trip. Administration officials said last week that they were determined that he convey to the former Communists who have gained in power in Poland that the road to prosperity and security still leads westward.
Mr. Clinton proceeds later on Thursday to Naples, where he will hold a series of meetings including his first encounter with Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan.
 
Precarious Situation in Japan
 Mr. Murayama has just become Japan's first Socialist Party leader in 46 years, and his position at home remains so uncertain that Mr. Clinton made clear in an interview on Friday with a Japanese reporter that he saw little hope for quick progress in trade talks between the two countries, saying of the confused situation in Tokyo, "Nothing is stable forever."
Mr. Clinton's meeting with Mr. Yeltsin comes on Sunday, when the Russian President joins political discussions for the first time among the Group of Seven. That big meeting is likely to produce a statement endorsing a detailed proposal for peace in Bosnia due to be issued on Tuesday by the four-nation Contact Group. But the session could expose more frictions over North Korea's nuclear program, with Russia seeking a bigger role in the search for a solution.
The President's final stop, in Germany, was planned in part to soothe any hurt feelings left by the exclusion of German officials from the 50th-anniversary celebration of the Allied landing in the Normandy. But advisers say a main theme of his discussions in Bonn next Monday will be that Germany, a reluctant player since World War II, should now take a more active role in international affairs, assuming burdens befitting its size and power.
On Tuesday, July 12, the last day of his trip, Mr. Clinton will seek in an address at the Brandenburg Gate to recapture the spell cast 32 years ago by his political idol, John F. Kennedy, who spoke to 150,000 Berliners at the height of the cold war.
Mr. Clinton described that speech last week as "one of the formative political images of my childhood." But the final image of his trip will send a very different signal as he takes part in the deactivation of the Berlin Brigade, formed in 1961 at the height of the Berlin wall crisis. Its departure this summer will bring an end to an American military presence in Berlin that has been constant since 1945.

HEADLINE: Haiti Invasion Not Imminent, Envoy Says

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Amid mounting speculation that the United States is moving closer to an invasion of Haiti to oust its military rulers, William H. Gray 3d, the Clinton Administration's special envoy on Haiti, said today that an invasion was not imminent, but that the United States was prepared to take action to protect the thousands of Americans there.
In an interview on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Gray said that the fate of Haiti was of "vital interest to the United States, but added, "The United States is not contemplating an imminent invasion of Haiti." 
 While stressing that sanctions must be given time to work as the Administration tries to restore the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power, he repeated President Clinton's warnings that "we don't rule out any option, including the military option."
Other senior officials said that the huge flow of Haitians fleeing the country by boat in recent days had dramatically illustrated the shortcomings of the current policy.
 
'A Terrific Mistake'
 In five hours of meetings on Friday, Mr. Clinton and his top national security advisers discussed whether the Administration should speed up its planning for a military invasion, senior officials said. As Mr. Gray suggested today, however, the officials added that a decision about whether to invade remained weeks or even months away.
Other officials said that Mr. Clinton could decide at any moment to order an invasion and that such a decision would be made both quickly and secretly.
Speaking on the same program, Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, said that although the Pentagon opposed military intervention, "within the State Department and the White House they are clearly making plans toward an invasion." He added, "I think it would be a terrific mistake."
A number of senior officials believe that the refugee problem should not be used as the basis for an invasion to oust the military and restore Father Aristide, who was overthrown in September 1991, to power.
Indeed, Mr. Gray today laid out a different justification for an invasion: the protection of American citizens still living in Haiti.
 
'Great Concern' Noted
 "The President has a responsibility to protect American lives, and we have an embassy there with staff, and in light of the escalating human rights violations and the repression, which is really the driving force behind these refugees' leaving, there is great concern that we must be prepared to protect American citizens," he said.
He added, "The President and his advisers are looking at all potential options as we go through the process of applying economic and diplomatic sanctions."
A number of lawmakers have told the White House not to undertake any military action within two months of the November midterm elections. In addition, Mr. Clinton will be host at a summit meeting of Latin American leaders in Miami in December, and White House officials said they did not want the event to become a post-mortem for a Haiti invasion.
If those constraints hold and the Administration wants to take military action, Mr. Clinton has to decide whether it would be better to invade before Labor Day or after Christmas.
For the moment, policy makers are focused on persuading other countries to receive Haitians fleeing by boat and on moving faster to prepare other processing centers. The Administration has also intensified discussions with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to help find ways to resettle Haitians.
Mr. Gray took exception to criticism from Capitol Hill that economic sanctions, although well intended, were causing such hardship that they were forcing poor Haitians to flee. Instead, he blamed Haiti's military dictatorship, saying, "If you want to stop the outflow of refugees, you must instill democracy."
The rush of Haitians has quickened since June 16, when Mr. Clinton reversed his policy to immediately return Haitians fleeing by boat and the United States began interviewing refugees on ships. Mr. Gray, who has argued strongly for a more permissive refugee policy that allowed more Haitians to make their case for refugee status, did not say whether the new policy had caused the recent exodus.
About 7,000 Haitians have fled Haiti in the last two weeks, severely straining Coast Guard rescue missions. The refugees are taken either to a ship off the coast of Jamaica or to the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, where they can make formal applications for asylum. Another refugee-processing center is to be set up in the Turks and Caicos Islands.
 
Radio Plan Stalled
 An American plan to set up a radio station to broadcast anti-military programs to Haiti has been stalled because Father Aristide has refused to use it to call on Haitians to stay home, senior officials said.
Father Aristide must approve the radio station, and Administration officials are concerned that he could use it to repeat his depiction of Haiti as "a house on fire" from which everyone who can should flee.
Mr. Gray did not respond directly to questions about how many Haitians he expected to leave or how many the United States would accept.
He also declined to say whether there was a deadline for the sanctions to work before the United States decided to invade.

HEADLINE: In World Cup, Business Just Sees Net

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
More than halfway through the World Cup, here is the inescapable fact: you can't escape the World Cup.
Television ratings are perhaps double what ABC and ESPN expected, and greater than what tennis from Wimbledon or the United States Open Golf Championship has drawn. And who would have thought that the biggest sports event of the summer so far would be today's match between the United States and Brazil at 3:30 P.M.? 
 Canon, Coca-Cola, Mastercard, Snickers and other sponsors are happily hawking their image and their soccer connection to global audiences. Licensed tchotchkes are everywhere.
Hotels are generally drawing more tourists than they would in early summer, even if World Cup organizers may have overestimated the number of soccer-in-their-blood visitors to the United States and how much they would spend.
"It's a net 100,000 more bookings than we would have had anyway," said Dan Wheedock, the president and chief executive of ITT Sheraton, which has 53 hotels in the nine World Cup host cities.
 
 
'One Long Super Bowl Party'
 Carol Gifford, a spokeswoman for the Chicago Hilton and Towers, said, "It's been like one long Super Bowl party." Chicago had its fifth and last World Cup game on Saturday.
What must be understood about the business of this World Cup is that it cannot be compared with previous World Cups in the United States, because this is the first.
The average ABC rating for World Cup games has been a 4.8, including a best-ever American soccer rating of 6.8 for United States-Romania. (Each rating point is equal to 942,000 households.)
ESPN is averaging a 2.1 rating (or 1.3 million of the households that receive the cable channel) for 19 live telecasts. At Univision, home to the Spanish announcer Andres Cantor's 10-second "Goooooaaaaaaalllllll" calls, the network has averaged 12.3 ratings for 19 live games (with each point equal to 65,200 households), peaking with a 16.5 rating for Norway-Mexico. Mr. Cantor has turned into a cult figure worthy of bookings this week with Regis and Kathie Lee, and then with David Letterman.
 Sponsors appear pleased with their World Cup links, which cost five companies $20 million each. Yet there have been bumps along the way.
McDonald's pushed "The Flintstones" movie in a domestic marketing blitz, rather than making the same commitment to the World Cup. Mastercard and Sprint battled in court over who had credit card rights. Mastercard won. Anheuser-Busch nearly popped its pop-tops because of an early threat to ban beer sales at the World Cup stadiums. And perhaps, some marketers said, the World Cup did not push itself early and often enough.
"Leading up to World Cup, there were serious questions about the value they were getting because there was so little hyping of the World Cup," said Steve Disson of D & F Consulting, a Washington marketing firm that represents McDonald's. He said McDonald's chose to make a bigger impact internationally, where most of the chain's growth exists. Domestically, the choice was between soccer's feet and Fred Flintstone's feet-propelled car. "Could they have done more in the U.S.? Yes, but that wasn't their goal," he said.
 
 
Different Marketing Goals
 Most sponsors, and companies paying less to be marketing partners, like American Airlines, have various goals. Snickers is hawking youth soccer. General Motors is marketing GMC trucks to soccer fans in the United States, Chevrolet in Latin America and Opel in Asia and Europe. Canon simply wants broader global exposure of its name.
"It's the most popular event in the world, and you wouldn't sponsor the World Cup if it were just a domestic event," said Dave Farr, senior vice president and general manager of Canon U.S.A.
There is no way to quantify the effect that the spending, as with any sports sponsorship, has had on sales or brand exposure. And although the World Cup's effect on American television ratings is puny compared with that of the Olympics, the World Cup has an edge that makes sponsors happily wacky: advertising boards are allowed to adorn every inch of the perimeter of the World Cup stadiums, allowing for regular television exposure of the sponsors' names.
The sponsors hardly seem miffed by ABC's and ESPN's decisions to air the games continuously, rather than interrupt for commercials, except at halftime and after the game. To compensate for no spots during the game, the logos of each of the five sponsors alternates with the running time and score in a box in the upper left-hand corner of the screen. Each sponsor gets nearly 18 minutes each.
 "We've received a number of complimentary calls from viewers thanking us for buying telecasts without commercial interruptions," said Charles Fruit, vice president and media director of Coca-Cola. Mr. Fruit added that other sports might adopt the sponsored clock to replace annoyances like leaderboards, trivia quizzes or plays of the game, which now bear sponsorship.
Mary Ellen Dougherty, a spokeswoman for Snickers, said there was no way to quantify whether viewers were paying less attention to the 30-second commercials that follow the first or second halves because those were the only times the viewers could take breaks after uninterrupted action. "But we're satisfied," she said.
Time Warner Sports Merchandising, the licensing agent for World Cup merchandise, also sounds satisfied, expecting to sell $1 billion in goods worldwide, including $350 million in the United States. "We're doing very well, but we haven't received final numbers," said Ralph Irizarry, a vice president. "Of course, there will probably be some companies that may not have met their internal goals."
 
 
'The Euphoria Hasn't Built'
 One of those was Logo 7, the Indianapolis-based maker of athletic apparel. Tom Shine, the company's president, said: "Retail wasn't what we hoped for. I keep hearing it's not as strong as others had hoped for, too. The euphoria hasn't built. But we're doing much better at the nine sites, which is where we're getting 70 percent of our business."
The luck of the World Cup draw determined which teams played where in the first round. Thus, some of the nine host cities got teams with big followings, like Brazil, Italy and Ireland, and others had to fill stadiums with teams from South Korea, Morocco and Cameroon.
The impact for the New York-New Jersey area, estimated at $400 million previously, has been revised to $600 million because of the first-round Italy-Ireland game. The impact for Orlando, Fla., is estimated at $110 million, up from $80 million to $100 million.
Dallas sold out two of its first four games (drawing two games each with Bulgaria and South Korea, which are not noted for sending over thousands of cash-spending soccer revelers). But the city expects its quarterfinal game next Saturday, featuring the winners of the Brazil-United States and Ireland-Netherlands matches, to rustle up more interest than a Jerry Jones humility hoedown.
"The Brazilian Consul General told us to expect 15,000 Brazilians coming to Dallas, looking for tickets," said Jim Graham, co-chairman of the Dallas World Cup host committee.
World Cup organizers predicted a $4 billion economic impact before the draw last year. But Dallas does not expect its direct spending from the World Cup to reach much more than $125 million in direct spending. Boston will come close to reaching $255 million, without any Italian or Irish games. Jim Trecker, a World Cup spokesman, said the impact estimate had not been reduced.
 
 
Some Disappointments
 "The impact in Boston itself was not as dramatic as forecast," said Pat Moscaritolo, president of the Greater Boston Convention and Visitors Bureau. "Instead of the 70,000 visitors forecasted over the four weeks, we'll get maybe half that." Visitors have stayed for two days on average, not four or more, and many have stayed closer to Foxboro Stadium, 30 miles south of Boston.
But you look for business everywhere you can, especially when a team like Saudi Arabia, which did not expect to get far, lands in a second-round game in Dallas against Sweden.
"The C.E.O. of one of our local companies, Fina, got a call from a limousine in Saudi Arabia, asking for 20 of our most expensive tickets," Mr. Graham of the Dallas World Cup committee said. "And we got them."
The biggest problem for hotels serving World Cup visitors was a policy by the World Cup accommodations bureau to reserve huge blocks of rooms last year and then release them as they revised their visitor estimates downward. In some cases, the hotels did not have enough time to resell those rooms.
 
 
A Summer Boost for Hotels
 Yet for most hotels, World Cup business, even a disappointing amount of it, has bolstered the usually low summer occupancy rates. "We entered into a contract for 10,000 room nights," said Jim Howard, general manager of the Hyatt Regency in Dallas. The commitment kept getting reduced, "until last December when deposits showed it would be 1,000," he said.
The booking policy affected the two Sheratons in Manhattan and the Sheraton Meadowlands, near Giants Stadium, which had to hustle for business when the World Cup blocks faded. "Reservations weren't as strong as we expected," said Leora Halpern, a Sheraton spokeswoman, "but our occupancy was up 16 percent in July for the Meadowlands and 10 percent for the New York Sheraton."
Mr. Wheedock, the chief executive of Sheraton, said: "On balance, the news is good. Over all, we're only down in bookings 5 or 10 percent from what the original World Cup bookings were going to be."

Barnett/Allsport); Above, goalkeeper Zakaria Alaoui of Morocco leaps in front of a sponsor's ad. World Cup merchandise, meanwhile, seems to be everywhere. (Shaun Botterill/Allsport)
