HEADLINE: Fire Islanders Claim Victory On the Beach, and Over It

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FAIR HARBOR, L.I., July 1

 BODY:
Jack Gellatly held a fistful of sand as if it were gold dust and proudly showed off the vast expanse of beach that he and his neighbors created just a couple of months ago.
At this spot last summer during high tide, water would have been rushing around his ankles. Now there was a 200-foot-wide beach in front of him and the waves rolled gently up the bottom of a 14-foot dune. 
 "Isn't this beautiful?" said Mr. Gellatly, a Manhattan advertising executive who has summered here for 24 years. "People come up to me and say it's a miracle."
More than a year after storms ravaged this community on Fire Island, destroying 28 ocean-front homes and washing away much of the dune that sheltered the town from the waves, Mr. Gellatly and dozens of his neighbors have defied nature. They have taken their shoreline back from the Atlantic -- at least for now.
Usually such beach restoration projects are the domain of Federal and state agencies, but people in Fair Harbor and six other Fire Island communities have done it on their own, largely independently of government. Since October, they have pumped almost one million cubic yards of sand -- enough to fill Grand Central Terminal's main concourse twice -- onto their shores.
The state and Federal governments resisted undertaking such a project, questioning whether it made sense to support expensive beach homes with public money and arguing that nature should be allowed to take its course. Faced with such resistance, many Fire Islanders chose to forge ahead alone.
 
Vast Dredging Project
 One by one, the communities hired a company, Land Use Environmental Corporation in Baiting Hollow, L.I., to coordinate a vast offshore dredging project, and agreed to tax themselves about $8 million to pay for it. With one exception, the incorporated village of Saltaire, they did this outside of any government entity, relying instead on special coastal erosion control tax districts they set up.
Now they face tax increases totaling roughly $3,000 a household, assessed over 1 to 15 years, varying in each community depending on the number of houses and the scope of the job. Still, organizers say there have been few complaints from homeowners, noting that the alternative would have been to watch property values steadily decline, the rental market dwindle and potentially lose a place they cherish.
Although such an approach has been employed in other parts of the country, it is relatively new to New York, coming amid widespread debate over how to balance the cost between coastal homeowners and the government for the protection of the state's fragile shoreline. And it suggests that coastal communities may bear a greater financial burden for such projects in the years to come.
"This shows that they are accepting the fact that government is not just going to bail them out," said William W. Daley, chief of coastal erosion management for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation. "They have to accept a larger and more direct role."
A few decades ago, the Fire Islanders would have expected the state to shoulder this task, and indeed, until the mid-1970's, the state did extensive beach replenishment projects here, providing hundreds of thousands of cubic yards of sand.
But in recent years, the state has been reluctant to help the island. While it soon may offer some assistance, Mr. Daley cautioned that the state would expect property owners to share in the cost of that project as well.
Fire Island is a fragile 32-mile-long barrier beach, a spit of sand a few thousand feet wide that sits across the Great South Bay from Long Island's south shore, its dunes blocking the mainland from the Atlantic. It is a place without cars, mostly Federal wilderness area, with the remainder state and local parks and 17 small summer colonies totaling about 3,500 homes, ranging from the rustic to the opulent.
In December 1992 and March 1993, two northeasters buffeted the island, drastically changing its landscape. Some houses were destroyed, and many others, which once sat snugly atop dunes, were left perched on their posts, as high as 20 feet above the beach, with the water running under them at high tide.
Coastal engineers said that another serious storm could create breaches in the island that would allow the Atlantic to flow through to the South Bay, and there were dire predictions about the island's future.
The state reacted by commissioning a study, which islanders knew meant there would be no action for months. And Islip and Brookhaven, the towns in Suffolk County whose jurisdictions include Fire Island, were too financially strapped to offer assistance to summer residents who are only a fraction of their constituency.
"We had no choice," said Mr. Gellatly, who led the effort in Fair Harbor. "Either we could do nothing and watch a large part of what we love get washed away, or we could try to save it."
 
More Modest Projects
 Eventually Saltaire, Fair Harbor, Dunewood, Seaview, Ocean Bay Park, Point O'Woods and Fire Island Pines elected to dredge, while other communities, which had less damage or lacked the resources, chose more modest projects, building dunes from the remaining sand on their beaches. Together, the seven communities amounted to about two-thirds of the island's households and covered about four miles of shoreline.
The work was completed last week, with the final beach at Fire Island Pines.
Although this was the largest dune reconstruction and beach replenishment program on Fire Island in years, Chuck Bowman, the project manager and president of Land Use Environmental, said it did not present a great technical challenge. "This would be a normal project for the Army Corps of Engineers," he said.
The main difficulty was getting clearance from a host of local, state and Federal agencies, and doing it quickly. It required easily more than 100 permits, he said.
As an incorporated village, Saltaire was able to tax itself to finance the project, but it was more complicated for other communities. Several established erosion districts, and others that already had them needed to get approval from the local town governments of Islip and Brookhaven for the tax. To raise the money for the project, the towns had to borrow money on behalf of the district through bond sales, and then the districts would repay it in taxes.
Mr. Gellatly recalled an Islip town meeting to discuss Fair Harbor's bond proposal in which dozens of angry summer residents turned out to demand that hesitant town officials allow the plan. "We had to convince them that we wanted to tax ourselves," he said.
 
'A Gentle 1-by-5 Slope'
 On Wednesday, Mr. Bowman surveyed the work of a bulldozer that was putting the finishing touches on a new dune at Fire Island Pines, pushing sand closer to the homes and underneath their decks.
"Perfect," Mr. Bowman said, noting its "soft curve" and "gentle 1-and-5 slope," meaning one foot in height for every five in width. "It's not too steep for playing frisbee, and the waves will run up gently rather than smashing against it," he explained.
The sand is coarse and brown, noticeably different from the fine white variety there before. It was specially selected for all of the beaches, because it is more resistant to wind, wave and storm.
Dredges scooped up the sand from a site two and a half miles offshore, and then it was pumped through a pipeline to the beach. While usually the sand came gushing out onto already existing dune, Mr. Bowman noted one instance, in Ocean Bay Park, where there was no beach, and the land literally emerged from the water.
Cathy Goldman, a homeowner in Dunewood, said she sat on a friend's deck when they did her community's beach and watched late into the night. "All of a sudden there were huge mounds of sand," she said. "It was unbelievable."
Her husband, Don, agreed. "It took just four days to rebuild it, and suddenly we were not at the mercy of nature," he said.
But some critics oppose this work.
Dery Bennett, executive director of the American Littoral Society, a coastal environmental group, said: "I prefer to think of this as a real-estate investment rather than beach replenishment. Those residents with shore-front property want to hold the line rather than let the beach move back naturally."
While he favored having Fire Islanders foot the bill for such work, he warned that it was likely to lead to future government subsidies, such as flood insurance and more extensive restoration projects. He also questioned whether it was a fair solution, as poorer or smaller shore-front communities might not be able to afford it.
And ultimately, he noted, even the wealthiest communities may have difficulty continuing to finance it. "I think that anything that perpetuates the idea that you can make nature stand still at the ocean front is misleading," he said.
Fire Islanders acknowledge that this effort is only a temporary solution that will last only a few years at best, if there are no severe storms. Ultimately, to avoid future damage, the government must embark upon a larger program for much of the South Shore of Long Island, they say.
Although no project will be permanent, they contend that the cost of maintaining Fire Island is surpassed by the economic and ecological benefits it provides the region.
And their desire to save the beach comes from more than just a fear of declining property values.
"This is a place that means more to me than anywhere else," Mr. Gellatly said. "People say you shouldn't build on a barrier beach, and they're right. The problem is these communities have been here 100 years."
"And once you've been here," he explained, "you can't help falling in love with it."

HEADLINE: Five California Republicans Stalling Bill to Preserve Desert

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The biggest land conservation act in more than a decade has stalled in the House, as five California Republicans whose districts include parts of the eight million acres that would be designated as wilderness fight a rear-guard action.
The five concede that the bill will eventually be passed, but they have promised to prolong a debate marked both by deep philosophical differences and unusually vituperative exchanges on the House floor. 
 The measure, the California Desert Protection Act, would create 74 wilderness areas and 3 new national parks, largely in the state's arid southeast corner. The protected area, which would include Death Valley and the 1.2 million acres of the East Mojave National Scenic Area, would put substantial tracts of the fragile desert off-limits to miners, new livestock grazing and, most controversially, hunters.
The proposal is the biggest land conservation measure since the 1980 Alaska Lands Act, which protected 103.4 million acres from development. The desert region has the world's largest forest of cactus-like Joshua trees, the only known dinosaur tracks in California and more than 760 species of wildlife, including the endangered desert tortoise.
 
Backed by Administration
 The bill has the strong backing of the Clinton Administration, but that is part of its problem. The Republican opponents say the measure extends what they call the Administration's war on the West, even though it was conceived long before Bill Clinton became President.
Representative Jerry Lewis, one of the five Republicans, says elitists and environmental zealots who do not live in the desert want to protect it, while those who live there want to allow mining and other development to continue to maintain the economy. He says the East Mojave alone contains 14 rare-earth minerals that have enormous industrial potential.
The Mojave "has almost none of the elements that justify designation as a national park," Mr. Lewis said. "It has endless thousands of miles of roadways through it. There are transmission lines used by utility companies." In addition, a site designated for low-level radioactive waste is next-door.
It had long seemed that the Senate would pose the biggest hurdle to the bill. But now that California has sent two Democrats to the upper chamber, the Senate passed the bill in April. Most of the credit went to Senator Dianne Feinstein, who campaigned in 1992 on the issue and built compromises to have the bill passed.
 
Opposition Explains Tactics
 The five Republicans opposing the bill -- Mr. Lewis, Bill Thomas, Duncan Hunter, Al McCandless and Howard P. McKeon -- say they have had to use stalling tactics on the floor because the chairman of the Committee on Natural Resources, George Miller, a Democrat from the San Francisco area, rode roughshod over their concerns. They say they have been forced to address their concerns in the 45 amendments they have attached to the bill. Since discussion on the bill began on the House floor in May, only four amendments have been debated and voted on, with time-consuming roll-call votes, only to pass nearly unanimously. Members have debated the bill for almost eight hours and barely made a dent in the legislation.
For the most part, the Republicans simply repeated the same speeches on each amendment, raising Mr. Miller's ire and prompting bickering on both sides.
Finally, Mr. Miller went to the Rules Committee on June 20 and asked for a time limit on the debate, saying the Republicans were engaged in a "mischievous display of dilatory tactics." The time limit was denied.
Mr. Lewis says Mr. Miller then called him for the first time in the nine years that the measure has been considered to seek his help in speeding passage.
Mr. Lewis says he told his colleague that he wants a fair hearing for several amendments.
 
Compromises to Date
 Some compromises have already been reached or are on the table. The bill as introduced would have phased out grazing in 25 years; it now allows grazing at current levels in perpetuity in the Mojave and Death Valley parks. Unresolved questions include what level of law enforcement will be allowed and whether the armed forces can continue using established flight patterns over the area.
Opponents are especially eager to allow hunting to continue. A similar bill that passed the House in 1991 included an amendment, which passed 235 to 193, to allow hunting in the Mojave. But this year, a measure to allow hunting was defeated in the Natural Resources Committee by 25 to 17. Both sides say the hunting amendment remains a central element of contention.
The House bill in 1991 passed 297 to 136. The Senate bill passed in April by 69 to 29. Reminded that he did not have the votes to hold up passage of this bill, Mr. Lewis said, "We certainly don't, as of this moment." But, he added, he hopes the Republican amendments can influence the final bill when the House version is reconciled with the Senate version.
Both sides say work on the bill will resume after the Fourth of July recess with an eye toward getting the House version to conference by the mid-August recess. Pressure to act is increasing from Democrats, who see passage of the bill as important to Senator Feinstein's re-election, which in turn is central to the Democrats' maintaining their majority in the Senate.

HEADLINE: Investors Find 2d Quarter Better Than 1st, but Full of Traps for the Unwary

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Most everyone felt like a loser in the first quarter. Stock traders spent the last two months of the quarter in shock at what the Federal Reserve Board had wrought, raising interest rates for the first time in five years in February and then again in March.
After a spectacular rise in January, stocks plummeted. Issues in the Standard & Poor's 500 index lost value in the first quarter at an annual rate of more than 16 percent. 
 Then, in the second quarter, things changed. Traders became more Fed than the Fed, browbeating the Federal Reserve for acting too late against an inflation that is still not in evidence. The Fed replied with two more increases in short-term interest rates, and in the discount rate, to boot.
The surprising result: Traders over all started making money, if only a little. Stocks in the S.& P. 500 gained value in the second quarter at an annual rate of more than 5 percent.
 
More Issues Decline
 But if one thing is clear, it is that winners can become losers with shocking rapidity. The Fed, stock traders and the traders in bond, commodity and especially currency markets must contemplate a changed financial world. Because of modern high-speed technology, short-term investing means the next minute and long-term investing may mean this afternoon.
Of the 6,101 issues selling at $5 or more a share tracked by Media General Financial Services, 2,452 rose, while 3,388 declined in value during the second quarter. Two hundred sixty-one emerged unchanged.
On the nation's biggest exchange, the New York Stock Exchange, Glendale Federal Bank rose 90.9 percent to $10.50 a share from $5.50. It helped that Glendale, like most financial institutions, benefited from the Fed's repeated raising of interest rates -- in effect, a continuous marking up of its inventory. Late in the quarter, securities analysts also talked up Glendale as a possible takeover candidate.
A takeover also figured in the price appreciation of Nichols Institute's class A shares. On the American Stock Exchange, it rose 137.6 percent to $11.88 a share from $5, after Corning Inc. agreed to acquire Nichols, a clinical testing services company, for $325 million.
Griffith Consumers, whose stock symbol is FUEL, also rose at a triple-digit rate, in Nasdaq trading. The Maryland petroleum distributor was up 103.3 percent to $15.25 a share from $7.50. An acquisition of another petroleum concern last year helped expand the company.
Of the losers, which were more numerous than winners, the price drops were almost of the same magnitude.
On the Big Board, RMI Titanium had the biggest plunge in price -- 84.6 percent, to $2.50, from $16.25 a share. RMI, a producer of titanium metal products for the military and industry, helped bring about part of its drop. The company instituted a rights offering for shareholders to buy stock at $2 a share, when the market price was more than $9 a share.
USA Classic Inc. had an even steeper fall of 94 percent in Nasdaq trading, down to just 31 cents a share from $5.13 a share. The dive was not a complete surprise because USA Classic, a designer and seller of men's and women's clothes, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and was later delisted by Nasdaq during the quarter.
Wilshire Technologies, a financially troubled maker of disposable products for surgical and other use, foundered in the first quarter and its troubles continued in the second. Wilshire did not trade from mid-April to June. And only last Monday did the company file its annual report for the fiscal year ending Nov. 30, 1993.

HEADLINE: The City And Arts Team Up On Funds

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE 

 BODY:
The approval of New York City's new budget has kicked into motion an agreement between the city government and its cultural institutions that is intended to increase overall financing for the arts and encourage arts groups to raise more private money.
Under the agreement, announced in February by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, leaders in the city's art world offered to raise $10 million in private contributions if the Mayor restored the $4.2 million he wanted to cut from the arts budget. In addition, the city and state would have to match the pledge of private money with $5 million each. The city and state allocated the money in their new budgets, which were approved last month. 
 The funds budgeted for cultural programs were increased by $7.7 million, bringing the total to $93 million for the fiscal year that began on Friday, said Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson. Although the culture budget is just a small fraction of the total city budget of $31.6 billion, its importance is disproportionately greater, given the city's concentration of museums, galleries, dance groups and concerts. These are magnets for tourist dollars translating into thousands of jobs for New Yorkers, as well as tax revenues for the city and state.
 
'Culture Is Not Just Charity'
 "I hope this combination of private, city and state money will symbolize a heightened level of support for culture, by both the private and public sectors," said Wilbur L. Ross Jr., who participated in developing the plan as a co-chairman of the New-York Historical Society, a post he left in April. "Public officials seem now to understand that culture is not just charity but very much economic development."
The city provides financing for more than 400 cultural groups, including the 31 major institutions on city property (known collectively as the Cultural Institutions Group), and any group or artistic program would be eligible to apply for the matching grants for any new contributions.
A ceiling is to be set on the amount of money a single group may receive, and the larger institutions would have to show that the grants would be used to improve the public's access to the arts. Smaller groups could use their grants to pay the rent or other necessities.
"A cultural facility might want to stay open on Saturday afternoons for high school students to visit and couldn't afford to stay open without an extra $100,000," said Mr. Dyson, who was involved in negotiations with the city's cultural and arts establishment. "They would raise $50,000 from the private-sector contributions and the city and state would each give $25,000. We want new money to be raised."
Mr. Dyson caused a furor shortly after Mr. Giuliani's election when he suggested that the city might benefit more if it focused its cultural budget on the institutions that attracted tourists. In an interview last week, he said that the city's arts funds would be distributed according to a formula in which some 60 percent goes to members of the Cultural Institutions Group, which includes the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum and the New York Shakespeare Festival.
Some 20 percent goes to the other recipient arts groups in the city, he said, and another 20 percent to cultural institutions that had not previously received city money, including the Whitney Museum for American Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. In recent years, the major institutions traditionally received 85 percent of the arts funds and the other recipient groups got the remaining 15 percent.
The city's Cultural Affairs Department, whose head is Schuyler G. Chapin, is to oversee the matching-grants program in conjunction with its private sponsors.
"We are in discussions with the state arts council to put together a simple set of guidelines for organizations," Mr. Chapin said, "and as soon as we have all of that done we will be making a public announcement about the fact that this opportunity is available for institutions, and how people can apply. I hope this will be done in the next couple of weeks."

HEADLINE: Europe's Economy Looking Up, But Long-Term Worries Linger

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 3

 BODY:
Led by Germany, Western Europe is at last emerging from its first post-cold-war recession, but with its economic aspirations tempered and its policy makers still grappling with the momentous changes that have swept the Continent.
 So far the comeback has been driven primarily by increased exports to the United States, where the economy began picking up two years ago, and by the rapidly growing economies of Asia. European companies in crucial industries like automobiles are beginning to report higher sales. Inflation is largely under control. 
Assuming the nascent upturn continues, it would mark the end of a recession that cut short the euphoria that swept Western Europe after the collapse of Communism in the east and the reunification of Germany.
 Political and business leaders here are clearly hoping that a return to economic growth will give European nations a chance to turn their attention from domestic problems back to issues like strengthening the ties among the 12 members of the European Union and integrating the emerging capitalist democracies of Eastern Europe with the West.
 But European leaders also acknowledge that recovery, whatever its magnitude, will not carry away all of the region's woes.
 As President Clinton and the leaders of the world's six other leading industrialized nations -- Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy --gather for a summit meeting opening on Friday in Naples, they will confront a Europe that remains in the midst of economic upheaval.
 Sales and profits may be improving, but businesses continue to lay off workers, sending already high unemployment rates higher, sapping consumer confidence and keeping the political outlook unsettled for leaders in most countries.
 "The recovery is there, but it is still weak and insufficient," Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France said in a television interview last week.
 The outlook has not been helped by the recent turmoil in the world's financial markets. The decline in the buying power of the dollar is hurting exports of goods to the United States from Germany and to a lesser extent France as well as Japan. Long-term interest rates have risen sharply this year in Germany, making mortgages and loans for business expansion more expensive.
 Governments have yet to devise a strategy for reducing unemployment and stimulating the creation of jobs, an area in which Europe badly trails the United States, without slashing a social welfare system that most Europeans consider a birthright.
 Though they are making progress, companies have yet to reverse a worldwide loss of market share and prove that European industry, in many cases overstaffed and slow-moving, can remain competitive.
 The single European market, once seen as the key to growth, has not lived up to its promise since the end of the cold war, and plans for a single currency have foundered. Although Germany is shifting its sights eastward, most other Western European nations are still trying to decide whether the emerging capitalist democracies of Eastern Europe are an economic opportunity or a threat.
 "We've reached a critical couple of years in Europe," said Suzy Symes, the director of the Europe program at the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London.
 
Signs of a Rebound
 After seeing its economic output decline by 1.3 percent last year, Germany, traditionally Europe's economic engine, is beginning to hum along again. Its economy should grow by 1.8 percent this year and 2.6 percent next year, according to projections released on Thursday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based research group financed by the major industrial nations.
 "Growth will be modest, but it's much better than was expected only a few months ago," said Rainer Veit, head of the Germany department at Deutsche Bank Research in Frankfurt.
 After shrinking by 0.2 percent last year, the Western European economy is expected to grow 1.9 percent this year and 2.8 percent in 1995, according to the economic cooperation group. France, Italy and Spain, among others, are projected to resume growth this year, joining Britain, whose recovery is now in its second year.
 Signs of the improvement are apparent all over Western Europe. Fiat, Italy's largest private-sector company, said on Thursday that its sales were up 10 percent in the first four months of the year and that it expects to make a small profit for the full year after suffering its worst-ever loss in 1993. Cie. des Machines Bull, France's largest computer maker, said sales for the first five months of the year were up 14 percent.
 
German Inflation Reversing
 In Germany, the central bank, the Bundesbank, appears to have extinguished the inflationary pressures that arose from unification in 1990. The inflation rate, which was 3.9 percent last year, is projected to fall to 2.8 percent this year and 2.0 percent next year even as economic growth resumes.
 The Bundesbank, which has been cautiously reducing official interest rates despite a rise in long-term rates caused by the turmoil in the financial markets, is coming under increasing pressure from the United States to make further rate reductions to help strengthen the dollar.
 With the immediate strains of the recession ending, Governments and the European Union will have the opportunity to turn their attention to Europe's underlying economic problems, said economists, analysts and business executives. But it is unclear, they said, whether recovery will breed new cohesion and purpose among the Western European nations.
 
Deeper Problems Remain
 "The news is good, even though the economic data do not point conclusively to economic growth," Edgar S. Woolard, the chairman of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said in a speech on Wednesday in Brussels. "At the same time there is a danger that many in the business and government sectors will sit back and expect cyclical economic recovery to solve deeper problems."
In Naples, the leaders of the Group of Seven nations will be able to point to the salutary effects of the agreement they completed late last year to liberalize world trade.
 But the United States and Japan will arrive with little hope of breaking the impasse over reducing Japan's trade surplus. And European industry, which depends heavily on exports, will be watching carefully to see whether the seven nations make a strong commitment to supporting the value of the dollar.
 "Whatever the benefits of the trade agreements signed by the major powers, nothing is possible in the long term unless we achieve true monetary equilibrium that avoids situations like the current scandalous undervaluation of the dollar," said Jean-Rene Fourtou, the chief executive of Rhone-Poulenc, the French chemicals company.
 The Group of Seven leaders will also discuss ways of creating jobs and reducing unemployment, which stands at 12.7 percent in France, 11.6 percent in Italy and 24 percent in Spain, and is expected to increase in Germany from 8.3 percent now to 10 percent by year-end.
 A distinguishing characteristic of the European recovery so far, in fact, is that it shows few signs of solving unemployment. Although economic recoveries typically do not create jobs in their early stages, this one seems unlikely to spur large-scale hiring even when fully established.
 That is largely because European industry, saddled with the costs of comprehensive social welfare benefits, is in the process of paring back employment in an effort to get its costs down and remain globally competitive.
 Britain, among other countries, will argue at the Group of Seven meeting that the best way to promote creating jobs is to reduce the laws that make it difficult for European companies to hire and fire workers.

HEADLINE: Officials in Panama Say They'll Accept 10,000 From Haiti

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PANAMA CITY, Panama, July 4

 BODY:
The Government agreed today to accept as many as 10,000 refugees fleeing the political crisis in Haiti.
The decision comes in response to a request by the United Nations, said Tomas Altamirano Duque, the Vice President-elect. The United States government has also asked Panama to help with the refugee crisis, but he did not say whether that was a factor in Panama's decision, or when Panama would start taking in refugees. It was not immediately known what screening procedures would be used. 
 The decision will take some of the heat off the United States, which has been inundated with asylum-seekers since it liberalized its policy on Haitian refugees last month.
About 10,000 Haitians have been intercepted by the United States Coast Guard in the last 11 days, including a record 2,628 by late today.
White House officials said Mr. Clinton personally requested Panama's help in a telephone conversation with President Guillermo Endara.
Panama has supported economic sanctions on Haiti and has backed the suspension of commercial flights to Haiti, and sought to stop the sale of goods to Haitian citizens in the free economic zone in Colon, Panama.
Mr. Altamirano Duque said the United Nations would cover the costs of feeding and caring for the refugees, who would be taken to San Jose Island on Panama's Pacific coast.

Refugee Drownings Reported
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 4 (Reuters) -- More than 100 Haitians fleeing their homeland are believed to have drowned when their boat capsized, survivors said today.
 The survivors said they thought that between 100 and 150 people died when their overloaded craft overturned after leaving an area near the western town of St Marc. A similar number are thought to have survived, said two survivors at the the scene.
Although radio stations in Port-au-Prince reported the accident, there was no confirmation of the number of casualties. A Coast Guard spokeswoman in Miami said the Coast Guard had no details of the incident.

HEADLINE: Hevesi Rejects Compromise On Bond Sales

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Rejecting a compromise proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi recommended yesterday that the city temporarily retain two companies to act as financial advisers for two important New York City bond sales.
Mr. Hevesi also proposed that a panel of three to five independent financial experts be consulted on the issue, in which Mr. Hevesi has urged the hiring of two financial advisers, while Mr. Giuliani has advocated hiring just one company. 
 The dispute has evolved into a fight about more than just bonds. Last week Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson suggested that racial preference had been the basis of Mr. Hevesi's desire to retain P. G. Corbin & Company of Philadelphia, which is owned by a black woman.
But the issue became even more charged because Mr. Dyson, disputing Mr. Hevesi's contention that the cost would be the same whether there was one firm or two, said Mr. Hevesi "ought to know the difference between a bid and a watermelon." The comment drew angry complaints from a host of elected officials, who said that Mr. Dyson's comments were racially insensitive. Mr. Dyson later apologized for his remarks, saying he did not mean them as a racial slur.
 
Powers Rejects Use of a Panel
 Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said yesterday that the administration would study Mr. Hevesi's proposal to use two financial advisers, but he rejected the idea of assembling a panel of outside financial experts.
"The device he's suggesting, a commission, abdicates the responsibility of elected officeholders," Mr. Powers said. "People are elected to make decisions, and not to appoint commissions."
Under the charter, the mayor and the comptroller jointly select financial advisers and underwriters for the city's bonds. Typically, the choice is handled by the staff of both officials, and the process seldom produces conflict. But this year, the selection has become a public and emotional issue between the Republican Mayor and the Democratic Comptroller.
Mr. Giuliani's office has maintained that the city needs just one bond company, Public Resources Advisory Group of New York. Mr. Hevesi, on the other hand, has argued that the city would be well served by having two advisers, and that the city should retain the second firm, P. G. Corbin. The two companies have been acting as advisers for the city since 1990.
The Mayor has maintained that it would cost the city hundreds of thousands of dollars to do business with the two companies, a contention Mr. Hevesi said was untrue.
As a compromise, Mr. Giuliani suggested on Saturday that the city use a single adviser for the two important New York City bond sales that must be completed within the next six weeks while putting off a final decision on whether to hire another. The sales include a refinancing of bonds that would save $225 million and keep the city's budget balanced.
But Mr. Hevesi, in a letter to the Mayor, said that accomplishing the two in such a short time "would tax the resources" of Public Resources and added that "there is a risk that these two critical financings would not be completed in the most cost effective manner available."
Mr. Hevesi recommended that he and Mr. Giuliani convene an outside panel of experts to review "the overall structure of the debt program, including financial advisers, the underwriters and the various counsel."
In an interview in The Bond Buyer, Mr. Dyson disputed a claim by Mr. Hevesi that the cost of financial advice would be the same whether one or two companies were retained. Mr. Dyson said each company had submitted a bid for a fixed fee, thereby making the cost of one half as expensive as two. "The Comptroller ought to know the difference between a bid and a watermelon," Mr. Dyson said.
 
Suggestions for a Panel
 Commenting on the events of the last week, Mr. Hevesi said that Mr. Dyson's remarks had made "reaching agreement on the substantive differences between our staffs more difficult and time consuming than either of us originally expected."
Mr. Hevesi suggested a number of names for an outside panel of financial experts. They included Harrison J. Goldin, the former City Comptroller; Eugene J. Keilin, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation; Sally Hernandez-Pinero, who served as Deputy Mayor for financial and economic development in the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Also on the list are Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission; Carol O'Cleireacain, who served as budget director under Mr. Dinkins; Richard D. Parsons, chairman and chief executive of the Dime Savings Banks of New York, who headed Mr. Giuliani's transition team; Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association, and Barry F. Sullivan, chairman of the New York City Partnership and a former Deputy Mayor under Mr. Dinkins.
Mr. Hevesi, who was in England and Ireland yesterday for meetings related to the city's pension funds, said in a telephone interview that he believed his recommendation offered the best short-term solution to the impasse between him and the Mayor. And he recommended essentially extending the two companies' contracts for the fiscal year that ended June 30 until after the two bond transactions have been completed.
"The Mayor is proposing that we get past the immediate problem of two bond deals that have to be completed in the next month or so," Mr. Hevesi said. "They are complex deals, and we don't believe we should jeopardize any financing by having less than the total package of expertise that is now available."

HEADLINE: Crop Subsidies: Help and Headaches

SERIES: The Family Farm: A Year in the Field -- Third in a Series

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHAMPAIGN, Ill.

 BODY:
David Rothermel could have hardly asked for more from employees of the Federal Department of Agriculture when he dropped by the agency's county office on a nondescript cul-de-sac at the outskirts of this town last week.
Promptly, pleasantly, even sympathetically, they helped him through a stack of documents that would allow him to receive tens of thousands of dollars for growing corn this year. 
 Like many farmers, Mr. Rothermel praises the Government's efforts to become more helpful, without sounding grateful for its involvement. While state and Federal extension agents occasionally provide useful technical advice, Mr. Rothermel views many of his dealings with the myriad Government programs and regulations as a drain on the time he needs to spend on the 2,900 acres he has planted in corn and soybeans.
"The contract you get for the payments program is ridiculous," Mr. Rothermel said shortly before last week's meetings with the agency. "It basically says, 'This is what you get, unless we change it,' and there's lots of fine print."
The fastest growing area of regulation affecting farmers is the environment, but financial, employment, safety, marketing and transportation rules are also important and constantly changing.
"I never cease to be amazed at the number of regulations impacting these people," said Kay Shipman, who writes about such issues for the weekly newspaper of the Illinois chapter of the American Farm Bureau Federation, a trade group for more than four million farmers.
Some rules are hard to fathom and others hard to take seriously. Mr. Rothermel, who is 40, expressed wonder that a bone-dry patch of a soybean field can be classified as a wetland. And he spoke derisively of transportation regulations that he says require him to surprise himself with random drug tests to drive the semitrailer he uses to carry grain to market.
The Government program that means most to Mr. Rothermel and most other Midwestern farmers is the one that pays them billions of dollars a year to grow corn. The general belief among big grain farmers here is that the income support program -- which also covers wheat, rice, cotton and several smaller crops -- is a necessary evil to allow the United States to compete with more heavily subsidized foreign farmers in world markets.
"Individual farmers cannot go up against the treasuries of foreign countries," said Terry Francl, senior economist with the American Farm Bureau, which is based in Park Ridge, Ill.
But subsidies help keep less efficient farmers in business. That usually leads to overproduction of important crops, which depresses the long-term profitability of commercial farmers like Mr. Rothermel. It also keeps consumer prices low, which many farmers say is the Government's main objective.
The total subsidies for many farming sectors, including grain, have been declining sharply in recent years. Government payments for the major subsidized crops fell from a little less than $14 billion in 1987 to an estimated $5.5 billion last year, not including disaster payments, which are still being processed, stemming from last year's heavy rains in the Midwest and drought in the Southeast.
The subsidies remain large enough that the threat of losing them gives the Government leverage to influence what many farmers grow and the practices they use to grow it.
Here in the Corn Belt, the target price the Government sets for corn, the estimated yields on which it bases support payments and the amount of acreage it allows farmers to put into the corn program heavily influence how much land farmers plant in corn versus beans or other crops. And the carrot of the subsidies is used to get farmers to conform to wetlands preservation and soil conservation rules, whether they like them or not.
 
 
Subsidies Control Farmers
 "The subsidies are what give the Government control over us," Mr. Rothermel said. "Most farmers around here do not like the Government programs, but you push the pencil and then go along with what brings in the most money."
Like many large farmers, Mr. Rothermel's acreage consists of a number of farms, some of which he owns, on his own and in partnership, while others are rented. That gives him some flexibility in arranging which ones will be in the Government programs and which will not, but it also offers complicated choices with significant financial consequences.
Farms like Mr. Rothermel's, which gross more than $250,000, produce more than half the nation's output, measured by cash receipts. Although they make up about 5 percent of the two million farms, they received nearly a third of the Government payments in 1992, the most recent year for which the Agriculture Department has statistics.
In some cases, Mr. Rothermel has forgone much of his potential Government support. He grows a large portion of his corn for Frito-Lay and also grows crops that will be sold as seed next year by seed companies. To satisfy their needs, he has sometimes had to plant more corn than the Government would allow farmers participating in its programs. In 1991, his first big year with Frito-Lay, Federal payments accounted for just $6,159 of his $919,000 gross.
 
More Corn for Government
 This year, with corn stocks low, the Government said farmers would be allowed to plant corn on every acre they had traditionally put into the crop, without losing eligibility, thus making its program more attractive.
As a result of the Government's move and his decision to cut back on dealings with Frito-Lay until it raises the price it pays, Mr. Rothermel put much more land into the corn program.
Mr. Rothermel has received more than $35,000 in Government payments on this year's crop, either directly or by selling options that the Government gave him the money to purchase. The total is less than 5 percent of his projected gross receipts of $750,000. Under the complex rules of the price support program, Mr. Rothermel may end up receiving several thousand dollars more for this year's crop if corn prices fall, but may have to pay thousands back if prices exceed the Government's target of $2.75 a bushel.
Mr. Rothermel's misgivings about having Uncle Sam as a partner are usually private. He is not much of a complainer to begin with and, compared with many other farmers, his burden from the Government's regulatory efforts has been light.
His "wetland," which covers less than a half an acre and takes several days longer than the rest of the field to dry out after a heavy rain, falls into the category of land that is already farmed. He can continue to do anything on it that he does to the rest of the field, as long as he does not improve drainage. At the moment, a tiny patch of land at the edge of the field is a bigger concern. Mr. Rothermel recently discovered marijuana growing among the weeds there, a legacy of World War II, when marijuana was cultivated to make rope.
"The law says I've got to get out here to spray," he sighed.
 A Federal law aimed at reducing soil erosion has a bit more impact on Mr. Rothermel. The law requires all farmers to have Government-approved plans in place this year for controlling soil loss from "highly erodible land." He has only one 160-acre field that the Government has deemed hilly enough to fall under the law -- in contrast with farmers in southern Illinois or the western Corn Belt states who may find their entire farm covered -- but it has already given him some headaches.
Mr. Rothermel planted wheat on the field last year. He planned to follow with soybeans, planting each crop directly into the residue of the other. Such "no-till" farming reduces erosion by eliminating plowing. Combined with terracing on the field, it was a strategy that would keep soil loss within allowed limits, according to Government formulas that predict what will happen in various conditions.
Unfortunately, heavy rains left the field rutted by the equipment used in the wheat harvest last summer, and the wheat residue slowed evaporation on the field. As he waited in vain for the land to dry this spring, clover and other weeds grew rapidly. By late May, when he called in herbicide experts, he was told that his chances of controlling the weeds with chemicals were slim, even if he were to spend $35 an acre, more than four times what he would normally apply. So he burned off the wheat residue, plowed the field several times to dig up the weeds' roots and planted the beans.
 
 
'I'm Going to Do What I Have to'
 "It's the exact opposite of what the Soil Conservation Service wants, but at that point, I'm going to do what I have to and worry about it later," Mr. Rothermel said. At current bean prices, planting the field is worth more than $50,000 to Mr. Rothermel, assuming an average yield.
When he explained his actions to Government officials here last week, Mr. Rothermel received supportive suggestions rather than threats to seek deductions in his corn payments. Although he described the residue coverage after his actions as "virtually zero," in contrast with the plan's requirement that 30 percent of the soil be covered, he claimed 4 percent in his meeting here after an Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service representative suggested that there must be some residue left.
Then, Russ Miller, the Soil Conservation Service official supervising Mr. Rothermel's compliance, used the 4 percent figure as a calculation that Mr. Rothermel had not broken the rules. Other factors included a liberal allowance for how much fieldwork it would have taken Mr. Rothermel to get rid of the ruts and the fact that Mr. Rothermel followed the contours of the hill in planting.
When Mr. Rothermel pointed out that the beans, unlike corn, were not planted in rows, so that following the contours had no real impact on erosion, Mr. Miller nodded but said, "It still counts."

HEADLINE: IRAN'S DIFFICULTIES LEAD SOME IN U.S. TO DOUBT THREAT

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
In the three years since the Iraqi defeat in the Persian Gulf war, Iran's drive to become a regional superpower has been thwarted by a worsening economy and an internal political struggle.
Despite the Clinton Administration's official portrayal of Iran as a rogue regime with similarities to Iraq before its invasion of Kuwait, Teheran lacks the money, military equipment and trained personnel to seriously threaten its neighbors, say a number of experts on Iran outside and even within the Administration. 
 According to this revisionist view, Iran is getting weaker, not stronger.
"The regime is facing serious internal problems with no solutions," said Shaul Bakhash, author of a forthcoming book on Islam and politics in Iran. "This is an exhausted revolution. It is a regime out of touch and talking to itself, not one that can afford to project its power abroad in a major way."
For several years, the Government has suffered from high inflation and unemployment, a rapid population growth, a mounting foreign debt that it can no longer repay and waning popular support for the Shiite Muslim clerics who control the country.
The bombing last month in Meshed of the holiest Shiite shrine in Iran on the most solemn day of the year, killing at least two dozen pilgrims, has added to the Government's sense of vulnerability.
Because of declining world oil prices, Iranian oil revenues have fallen more than 30 percent over the last year. And because of declining production ability, Iran is unable to meet its full OPEC oil quota.
"The Iranians desperately need to rebuild their oil fields," said Vahan Zanoyan, an economist and senior director of the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm based in Washington. "They have serious production problems, primarily because they have not been able to get all the necessary spare parts and do all the maintenance work."
Although most of Iran's imports from the United States are oil-related equipment, Iran has been forced to buy less. Imports for the first quarter of this year totaled $90 million, compared with $217 million for the same period last year.
President Hashemi Rafsanjani has been repeatedly blocked in his five-year battle to control the bureaucracy, privatize the economy, unify the foreign exchange rate and promote economic development to conservative religious leaders and an obstructionist Parliament.
His standing has sunk so low that he is now regularly vilified in Parliament. In a speech to Parliament two weeks ago, Mohammed Saleh-Taheri, a member from Khorramabad, railed about the price of cucumbers and said that while Mr. Rafsanjani might be "the guardian of policy, culture, society and religion, economics is another matter."
 
Tussle Over Price Controls
 Instead of dismantling price controls as Mr. Rafsanjani has recommended, the Government put into effect a law two weeks ago requiring every bazaar merchant to put price tags on all products.
But the infighting in the Government is so intense that even as municipal officials soldered shut the gates of merchants who did not comply, Interior Ministry officials went around the capital cutting them open again.
Under the Iranian Constitution, Mr. Rafsanjani, who is a senior cleric although not an ayatollah, cannot run again when his second term runs out in 1997.
A number of Western and Asian diplomats in Teheran predict that his successor could be even more inward-looking, and more hostile to the West. Despite his flaws, they say, Mr. Rafsanjani combines political savvy with the religious authority to stand up to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the country's spiritual leader since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in 1989, and can therefore risk economic reform and diplomatic overtures to the West.
Although Iran has succeeded, despite American objections, in rolling over about $7 billion in debts with private banks in Germany, Austria, Belgium, Italy, Japan, Denmark and Switzerland in the last year, the Government has been unable to secure significant amounts of new credit or foreign investment.
 
Oil Deals With U.S. Companies
 Paradoxically, even though the United States bars imports from Iran, American oil companies have emerged as a major supporter of the Iranian economy. Some oil industry experts say these companies bought as much as $3.6 billion last year in oil in legal transactions for resale outside the United States.
Iran's economic woes are so severe that some Administration analysts have begun an informal reassessment of Iran's military abilities, although not of its expansionist intentions.
In 1992, Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence in the Bush Administration, told Congress that Iran was spending $2 billion a year on arms, could pose a threat to the United States and its allies in the gulf within three to five years and have a nuclear weapon by 2000.
James Woolsey, who succeeded Mr. Gates in the Clinton Administration, told Congress last year that Iran would need 8 to 10 years to build a nuclear weapon, perhaps less time with extensive outside help.
Now, Pentagon officials and others say Iran spent only about $800 million on foreign arms last year and has made much less progress on its nuclear weapons program than expected.
Although Administration officials have amassed substantial evidence that Iran is committed to developing nuclear weapons, recent intelligence reporting indicates that infighting inside the Iranian Government over how to spend shrinking resources has slowed down its nuclear program. Unless the Iranians can buy a nuclear weapon outright, it could take much longer than 10 years for them to develop one, some intelligence analysts have concluded.
 
Arms Purchases Slashed
 Iran has had to slash weapons purchases and cancel about $5 billion in arms deals, some independent estimates say.
Moscow is holding up the delivery of a third Kilo-class submarine until Iran proves it can pay for it. During a recent visit to Iran, a Russian Deputy Foreign Minister said publicly that his country's trade with Iran was plummeting because Teheran had not paid its debts. There are unconfirmed reports that Russia has canceled the sale of two nuclear power reactors because Iran cannot finance them.
China is poised to deliver 10 fast-attack missile patrol boats and an undisclosed number of anti-ship missiles with a range of 83 miles to Iran, Pentagon officials said. But these officials also said Iran's financial problems could delay a deal with China to build a nuclear reactor for Teheran.
Even North Korea has not delivered on its promises to send new long-range missile technology to Iran.
"What appears clear is that Iran's military buildup so far has been modest," an Iran specialist, Shahram Chubin, wrote in a book of essays published by the National Defense University in April. "It will be some time before it is translated into military effectiveness."
He cited the limited availability of resources and the Government's ambivalence about creating an effective military capable of using advanced weapons.
This trend does not mean that Teheran, with its contradictory foreign policy goals and its support for terrorist groups, has transformed itself into a Government with benign intentions toward the West.
Pentagon officials, for example, are convinced that Iran could terrify naval insurers and deter ships from using the Strait of Hormuz, the outlet from the Persian Gulf to the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea, simply by announcing that their two Russian-made submarines were in the Gulf of Oman and that the strait was closed.
 
'Containment' Questioned
 But the trend does call into question the Clinton Administration's policy of "dual containment" articulated in May 1993 by Martin Indyk, the chief specialist on the Middle East at the White House. That approach justifies an increased American military commitment to the Persian Gulf because, Mr. Indyk said at the time, "the current Iraqi and Iranian regimes are both hostile to American interests in the region."
Other senior Administration officials subsequently modified that grim assessment and stressed that no matter how badly the Iranian clerics behaved, they were simply not in the same league as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
But in March, Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, not only revived the term "dual containment" in an article in Foreign Affairs, but also lumped Iran and Iraq together as two of a handful of "reactionary backlash states" that "seek to advance their agenda through terror or intolerance or coercion" and therefore have to be neutralized, contained and pressed to change.
Indeed, senior Administration policy makers remain so suspicious of Iran that they interpret recent conciliatory remarks by Mr. Rafsanjani about the Arab-Israeli peace talks as a cynical tactical maneuver to seek debt rescheduling agreements from countries that have repeatedly questioned Teheran about its opposition to a lasting Middle East peace.
At a news conference on June 7, Mr. Rafsanjani said Iran would take no action to disrupt the talks, although Teheran would maintain its policy of formally opposing them and the carrying out of last September's agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. "We do not wish to intervene in practice and physically disrupt the process," Mr. Rafsanjani said.
 
Cleric Reviles Arafat
 By contrast, Ayatollah Khamenei last year described the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, as "that puny, ill-reputed blackguard," and called his agreement with Israel "treachery."
Similarly, Administration policy makers are generally dismissive of a statement by Ayatollah Ali Akbar Meshkini, speaker of the Iranian Assembly of Experts and one of the Government's most senior clerics, that Ayatollah Khamenei has the authority to change religious decrees issued by others.
Since it was a religious decree by Ayatollah Khomeini that condemned the British writer Salman Rushdie to death for blasphemy, the new ruling theoretically could provide an opening to lifting the death sentence.
But a suggestion in 1990 by Mr. Rafsanjani that the death sentence could be lifted was quickly denounced by other leading clerics, and Ayatollah Khamenei stated clearly last year that the death threat must and would be carried out, no matter what the consequences.
Such contradictions in Iran's policies have inhibited the Administration from formally reassessing Iran's intentions and abilities. Indeed, the subject is so sensitive and divisive within the Administration that despite the Central Intelligence Agency's professed policy of openness, Mr. Woolsey has banned his analysts from giving press briefings on Iran.

HEADLINE: Russia Lurches Further Along the Capitalist Road

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 4

 BODY:
Nearly two years ago, Russia embarked on the most crucial part of its effort to become a market economy: selling the property of a state that once owned everything and thus founding a nation of property owners with a stake in the success of economic reform.
When the end of price controls wiped out savings, the Government chose to conjure up a middle class by giving away most state property, issuing 144 million vouchers free to every Russian to turn into shares. 
 Now, with most businesses and two-thirds of the Russian work force formally under private control, the voucher program has effectively ended and real capitalism, using real money, finally begins.
This second stage will be the stiffest test of whether the free market will really catch on in this vast distorted economy. Private companies are being thrown into a perilous environment where credit is hard to get, debts among companies are high, management is weak, crime is rampant, taxes are punitive and consumers are poorer than they were three years ago.
This month, with some exceptions, the Government will begin selling its remaining enterprises -- for cash, not vouchers. The companies, many of them now starved for capital, are to get 51 percent of the purchase price.
Private enterprises will also be able now to own and sell land, and private investors should be able to exercise more control over management.
 
The First Stage Of Capitalism
 On its face, privatization has been one of the few economic successes of the Russian Government.
More than 100,000 state companies -- from small shops to oil conglomerates to enormous (and enormously inefficient) factories -- have been transferred to public ownership, at least formally. The 15,000 factories involved represent two-thirds of industry and 60 percent of the industrial work force. The 85,000 shops that have been privatized represent 70 percent of the national total.
More than 138 million vouchers have been invested. There are over 600 registered voucher-investment funds, embryonic mutual funds, really, with 40 million shareholders, and another 1 million people own small businesses.
In the second stage, selling companies for cash, there will at last be real capitalization. Companies will have cash with which to invest and retool. A real stock market should develop, and the shareholders, who have invested cash, are likely to throw their weight behind change.
But Russia's real transition to a market economy is only beginning.
W. Michael Blumenthal, Treasury Secretary in the Carter Administration and chairman of the Fund for Large Enterprises in Russia, a new investment bank funded by the United States Government, has few illusions. "Privatization itself means nothing if the organization doesn't change," he said. "Privatization really must mean making it efficient and competitive."
 
Politicians Send Conflicting Signals
 As with much else in the new Russia, nothing is simple. While Russian leaders plead for foreign investment, they also change their instructions almost daily. President Boris N. Yeltsin issues multiple and contradictory decrees. The Government, one Western businessman said, is acting "like a drunken sailor," altering tax, customs and investment rules without consistency or clear instructions to officials, thus furthering corruption and inefficiency.
Politics is never far away. Parliament could still amend the privatization program, and critics from Communists to free marketeers like Grigory Yavlinsky charge that "privatization without capital" has produced little management change and deluded people into thinking they own something of value while cheating them of any real share of the country's wealth.
A fight is raging over the scope of privatization, with Mr. Yeltsin choosing to allow Moscow and some regions to have their own rules, as if they were exempt from national laws and decrees. There are strong incentives to privatize, but in another compromise with Cabinet conservatives, there will be no list of companies that must do so.
A quieter struggle is underway over whether the last well-known reformer in Government, Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais, will keep his job. Mr. Chubais challenged the populist Mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, over his insistence that Moscow have its own program.
Mr. Yeltsin, who is indebted to the unelected Mr. Luzhkov for his political support, including the timely dispatch of police to surround rebellious legislators last October, backed him over Mr. Chubais. In a news conference, Mr. Yeltsin said bluntly that he had told Mr. Chubais "to keep his hands off Moscow," effectively creating another set of rules.
Asked about his future in a recent interview, Mr. Chubais said: "The only reason for my survival is that I never try to survive."
 
Daunting Challenges For New Businesses
 Assuming Mr. Chubais stays, many considerable problems remain. Inflation is still 10 percent a month. With interest rates high, it is hard for even profitable companies to get long-term loans.
Among the many tasks facing Mr. Chubais and the Government are these:
*Implementation of the bankruptcy law in order to close or reorganize companies that are a drag on the economy.
*Establishment of capital markets, which would require a new legal foundation for everything from regulatory agencies to the control of rampant fraud among voucher funds to the protection of shareholder rights.
*Attracting investors, domestic and foreign. Foreign investment last year was a paltry $1.5 billion, a figure depressed by political, economic and legal uncertainties that have only been compounded by new confusions over taxes and customs duties.
At last, however, Russia is getting Western aid specifically for this most important of transitions. A system of investment banks and 10 regional funds, with Western investment capital and technical assistance, are being set up all over Russia to give new private companies a chance.
Mr. Blumenthal is chairman of one such bank, whose aims include conversion of the military industry; E. Gerald Corrigan, former chief of the New York Federal Reserve, heads another, aimed at smaller businesses. Together, they will work with nearly $500 million of capital provided by Washington, with further aid from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, or OPIC, a for-profit agency that provides risk insurance for United States companies.
"They want to save themselves but don't know the first step on how to do it," said Maksim Boyko, director of the Russian privatization center. "What's important is to see whether this formal transfer of ownership will lead to changed behavior, and it will."
There are lots of examples of change in now private factories. The once huge Uralmash machinery manufacturer has broken itself into more competitive units and shed nearly 10,000 workers from an initial 28,000. LOMO, a defense and optical company, used American consultants and European banks' money to restructure and successfully sell its shares.
But many more are like Lespromservice, a private forestry company still controlled by its managers and workers, who successfully defeated a management challenge from a young American investor who had bought 23 percent of the company through vouchers.
 
A Moscow Company Makes Its Own Way
 The Koloros factory, Russia's largest maker of dyes, is a good example of the complications. The 115-year-old company, which began as a branch of I. G. Farben, the Germany chemical manufacturer, privatized itself, breaking off from the Ministry of Chemical Industry in 1989. The workers and managers formed a collective and "bought" their business from the state in 1992 for a song -- about $20,000, then formed a closed stock company. All shares must be sold to the directors, who must approve any new sales. The company is not open to outside investment.
All this contradicts the Chubais model, but was authorized by Mayor Luzhkov. The company's president, Aleksandr N. Ulyanets, 45, wants no outsiders buying up his company and perhaps defrauding it. As for vouchers, he said: "Let the teachers privatize their schools. Why should we share our factory with teachers? I know what Chubais wants for the country. I think Chubais is wrong."
At the same time, with the reinvested profits of a very profitable plant, Mr. Ulyanets has cut the work force by 15 percent, to 900 employees; replaced 400 of those with "harder workers and specialists"; set up a marketing department; found new business in dyes for leather and suede; started a store that sells directly to consumers; and begun a financial division, including a bank.
Koloros pays its workers $200 a month, twice the Moscow average, and decent dividends on their stock, and it has invested in new equipment to reduce pollutants. The factory, is only 400 yards from the Moscow River and still pollutes it, but the company, once one of the country's worst polluters, has made a deal with Mayor Luzhkov to build a water-filtration system in the next 18 months in lieu of local taxes.
Mr. Chubais himself acknowledges there is room for many different paths to the market. Russia, a stunningly rich country that has been mismanaged in ways few outsiders can fully understand, needs above all a commitment to profit, like Mr. Ulyanets's, even if his wealth results from luck as much as from talent.
Sergei I. Guzinets, 38, is a foreman with 11 years at Koloros. Work is harder, he says, with more responsibility. But he is paid decently, and gets stock dividends now. Would he or his colleagues go back to the old system? "To communism?" he asked, incredulous. "Are you kidding?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Koloros dye factory in Moscow is one of the more successful examples of putting industry in the hands of shareholders. But paying higher wages and decent dividends to workers like Sergei I. Guzinets, a shop foreman, has not spared Koloros from the debate over how far privatization should go. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)
