HEADLINE: Acorns Sprout Among the Oaks Of the Telecommunications Field

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Eighteen months ago, Shant S. Hovnanian was a home builder in New Jersey. Now he is the chief executive of a small telecommunications company in Manhattan, pushing a technology that did not exist a decade ago and preparing to do battle with some of the biggest names in corporate America.
"This is the mecca of technology being born," he said of greater New York. "Everybody's got a new idea." 
 Mr. Hovnanian, 35, exemplifies the entrepreneurship that is bounding through the New York metropolitan area in telecommunications, as technology and loosened regulation coalesce to make the region a national incubator. His company, Cellularvision, uses wireless cellular transmitters to send cable television programming. It has tested the service for two years in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, and this summer will begin expanding into the larger, more competitive markets of Queens and midtown Manhattan, where conventional hard-wired cable still rules.
But Cellularvision is just one of many acorns hoping to become oaks.
"This whole area is the hothouse of what the future is going to look like," said Peter A. Bernstein, a telecommunications industry analyst at Probe Research in Cedar Knolls, N.J. "There's never been the kind of frenetic activity you're seeing now in terms of pushing forward, in terms of new opportunities."
Throughout the region, new ventures and new companies are popping up. The Omnipoint Corporation, a Colorado company, is planning to try out its new cellular telephone technology in New York. The World Telecom Group, a California company, sells telephone service debit cards for people who phone a lot from the road. Some such ventures involve investments of hundreds of millions of dollars, but there are low-overhead mom-and-pops as well. Ken and Alison Hamje sell long-distance accounts from their home in Mendham, N.J.
And old companies are learning new tricks. Bell Atlantic, operator of the local phone system in New Jersey, is poised to enter the television business. Time Warner, a cable company going in the other direction, is seeking to provide telephone service in New York. In Connecticut, Southern New England Telecommunications, the parent company of Southern New England Telephone, is planning to offer everything from cable television to long-distance service under one roof.
"New York is probably the most competitive local communications market in the country and possibly the world," said Eli M. Noam, a professor at the Columbia University business school and director of the university's Institute for Tele-Information. He said the trend will only accelerate as it becomes easier for companies to stake a claim. "The barriers that once seemed formidable have continuously become lower," he said. "And for technological reasons, the hardware has become cheaper."
 
Blurring Lines
 To a degree, the New York region pioneered competition in telecommunications. Companies like Teleport and Metropolitan Fiber, for example, have offered telephone alternatives to big-business customers in Manhattan for about 10 years in competition with Nynex, which provides local phone service in New York and much of New England.
The difference now, and particularly in the New York metropolitan market, is that there are more players and more plays to make than ever before. The lines between telephone service and television programming have become blurred by innovation in computer technology. That means more market niches, more choices for consumers and -- every sales executive's dream -- rampant confusion about what it means and which deal is best.
"Confusion always creates opportunity," said Geoffrey W. Crowley, a vice president at Phoenix Network, a small long-distance telephone carrier that opened its first New York sales office in January. He said that small-business owners, the main target of much of the new competition, are being overwhelmed with choices.
"They're bombarded, really," he said. "They don't know the difference between their long-distance and local service, and virtually 100 percent of the time they don't know what they're paying per minute."
 
'Who Is This?'
 Regulators have continued to loosen the reins: New York City, for example, now has six companies authorized to offer local telephone service in addition to Nynex -- four got their franchises in December. In Connecticut, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. recently signed a bill opening every telephone market in the state -- from the local exchange provider on up -- to competition. So far, 63 potential service suppliers have applied, including companies like Hertz, the car-rental company, which wants to sell excess capacity from its internal network.
"We take a look at the names and we go, 'Who is this?' " said Beryl Lyons, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control. "We have no idea who some of these people are or how long they're going to last."
The region is also home to some of the most aggressive of the established players in the industry. Most notably, Bell Atlantic has pledged to begin an interactive fiber-optic home television system by early next year in four New Jersey communities -- Chatham, Florham Park, Madison and Dover Township -- and to have perhaps the second statewide interactive system in the nation by 2010. S.N.E.T. in Connecticut has vowed to be first, with a fully wired system by 2009.
 
Increased Demand
 And those expanded menus of channels -- Time Warner already offers 150 in a test market in Queens -- means more demand for programs, at least some of which will be produced in the region. One early entry: a pharmaceutical network, partly operated by several New Jersey-based drug companies that will allow doctors or their patients to call up a video brochure on prescription medicines. Television studios at the Arts & Entertainment Network and the Tribune Company in New York are developing niche cable channels for history buffs and food lovers.
There is also ample cross-fertilization. Bell Atlantic, for example, a minority investor in Mr. Hovnanian's Cellularvision company, will manage the network as it expands to its target of one million homes by October. Nynex recently began a "video dial tone" test in Manhattan with three cable companies. Customers get their television service through the Nynex line, then choose which cable provider to take after that.
Nynex and Bell Atlantic also announced last month that they would merge their cellular telephone businesses, creating a company serving most of the Eastern Seaboard. Cablevision Systems, meanwhile, which provides cable television service in Westchester County, in Connecticut and on Long Island, said it was considering a direct competitive assault on northern New Jersey.
Whether all this deal-making and investment will create new jobs is an open question, however. Economists say that while there has been some job growth, the scale is small and offset by the thousands of jobs being shed as competition compels telephone companies to slim down. Between April 1989 and April 1994, the region lost about 15,000 communications industry jobs, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 
Fortunes to Be Made
 But business people emphasize that the region is still mainly in the investment phase, and that new fortunes are mostly yet to be made.
"Our biggest problem is finding good people," said Charles L. Bakes, president of International Telecommunication Data Systems in Stamford, which provides computer billing software for cellular phone companies. He said revenue at his four-year-old company has doubled every six months for three years. The company has 69 employees now, up from 11 at the end of 1991, and up from just the four founding partners in 1990.
More common are start-up companies like Modalink, a computer network that went on line last month in Manhattan aimed at the fashion industry. The idea is to put copies of models' and photographers' published work in a telephone-linked information bank. Advertising agencies around the world, who might be looking for that certain sultry look, can then peruse offerings from their own computer screens.
Modalink has only six employees, all working in a 21st Street loft. As an information provider it probably will not need more space or workers, no matter how successful it gets, said the president, J. Randall Brockett.
 
Newcomer Versus Veteran
 The central belief behind most of these new ventures is that the New York region has entered a new gilded age in which a good idea, or a new of selling an old one, will find its market. Strip away the high-tech chatter, and the competition washing through the region is the same human-scale story that has always played here, like a Broadway show that will never close: Bright-eyed Newcomer Meets Battle-Scarred Veteran.
These are the stories of people like Aaron Chan. From the one-room office at Phoenix Network overlooking 34th Street in Manhattan, Mr. Chan, a 24-year-old resident of Queens who repaired tank engines in the Army until last year, was in his shirt sleeves on a recent hot afternoon, cold-calling business owners. Mr. Chan's task: convince people to reconsider their long-distance telephone allegiance on behalf of a company they have probably never heard of.
"I got two appointments," he said of his morning's work.
 
'I'm Always Awed'
 Douglas G. Smith's tiny Colorado-based cellular telephone company, Omnipoint Corporation, doesn't even have a New York City office, and he has yet to hire even the first of the thousand-odd employees he says he will need. But his ambitions, too, have been unleashed: Pending final regulatory approval, Omnipoint plans to blanket the area with up to 900 cell sites, then cut access charges to beat the competition and make cellular phones as common as beepers.
"I go to the top of the Rainbow Room," Mr. Smith said, "and I think, we've got one of the most enormous tasks imaginable -- I'm always awed."
But the new players also say that much of where they are now depends on chance, on getting financing, on meeting the right people. Mr. Hovnanian, for example, said it was a call from an old high school friend that put him on the road he is now. The friend, a stockbroker, had encountered an electrical engineer who was developing a wireless video system and was looking for a backer. Mr. Hovnanian was hooked.
"What we have is an opportunity to create a whole new industry here," he said. "I've made this the focus of the rest of my career."

HEADLINE: Observer;
Groggy With Health

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER; 

 BODY:
Written after deep health-care immersion:
America faces a grave health-care crisis, though maybe not. 
 There are five, or maybe nine or ten, different bills in Congress for dealing or not dealing with the crisis or non-crisis, depending on whether it is a crisis or not.
One of these is the Dole plan, and it is much too confusing to go into here, as are the other four, eight or nine plans, as the case may be, none of which will be enacted anyhow, permitting us to move ahead to the real questions. These are:
1. Why do you have to go bankrupt before you can die?
2. Is it true that Newt Gingrich is wearing President Clinton's old hair?
3. Whither coronary thrombosis?
4. Is Ira Magaziner the brilliant criminal-defense lawyer known as "the great white shark" who was seen being interviewed on television the other night about O. J. Simpson's health-insurance policy?
The answers will not be known until Senator George Mitchell starts melding the bills on the Senate floor, provided of course that the Senate's bill melder, which has been on the fritz for years, can be repaired.
If not, Senator Mitchell will become the baseball commissioner. This job will confront him with an entirely different health-care mystery; to wit, why the sudden decline in rotator-cuff surgery and the corresponding increase in medial-ligament operations on the knee?
Fortunately for people heavily invested in insurance companies, the insurance industry will continue to thrive, no matter whether a bill of any sort is passed or not. Everybody who counts, from Clintons to Evers to Breaux, fears American medicine will collapse if deprived of the insurance industry's genius for converting everything from colic to Huntington's chorea into easily collectable profit.
Most of the bills being proposed frown on the insurance industry's past practice of canceling their coverage of people who become ill. Senator Gramm of Texas would deal with any such insurance company by sending a note home to its mother.
Of utmost importance is universal coverage, because President Clinton has threatened to veto any bill that does not provide universal coverage.
But what does universal mean? Some say covering 90 percent of the population would be universal, and some say 95 percent. In other words, the universal coverage being discussed is not universal, nor should we expect it to be. Established theory holds that any politician who means precisely what he says is unfit to revise and extend his remarks in the Congressional Record.
Some say covering 90 percent of the population one of these days in some future century would fill the bill. Others say giving everybody the right to buy insurance from a private company would satisfy the universality requirement.
Since this is exactly where we seem to be at present, universality-wise, pessimists worry that Congress lacks the necessary zeal for universal coverage, which might compel Mr. Clinton to use his veto or face the classic question asked many years ago by a Minnesota Congressman named Blatnik. The Blatnik question:
"Why you Demos talk so much, do so nothing?"
Shocking though it is, politics also seems to figure in the health-care debate. This is because elections will be held not only this fall, but also in the fall of 1996.
The curse of elections is that they require politicians to attack each other. This is because the theatrical demands of the 10-second TV commercial for an audience marinated in gunplay and car crashes not only insist on violence, but also rule out sensible discourse .
So, our custom of incessantly holding elections requires a constant supply of government failures for which politicians can blame each other in campaign commercials. This explains why our statesmen are compelled to avoid trying to solve civic problems.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Quarterly Review;
Investors Show a Willingness to Take On Risk

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
Although they pulled back somewhat toward the end, mutual fund investors showed a strong stomach for risk last quarter.
Money flowed into stock funds at home and abroad, despite wild swings in stock prices here and some poor performances in foreign markets. Money poured out of the supposed bulwarks of safety, bond funds and utilities funds, as both suffered big losses because of the rise in interest rates orchestrated by the Federal Reserve. 
 Weekly cash flows into stock funds were, in fact, positive throughout the first half of the year except for one week, the first week in April, when a big drop in stock prices starting in mid-March apparently did unnerve investors.
But fund investors just as quickly returned to stocks and a total of $26 billion flowed into equity funds from April through June, down a bit from the relatively calm previous quarter, according to AMG Data Services, in Arcata, Calif. The two largest categories showed impressive gains, with growth funds adding $7.3 billion and the more conservative growth-and-income funds up $5.4 billion.
Aggressive growth funds showed the biggest percentage gain in the quarter, gaining $2.5 billion, or more than 8.5 percent. The equally risky emerging growth funds had inflows of $1.1 billion, up 2.5 percent, AMG said.
Investments in foreign funds showed a big increase in the quarter, to $8.2 billion. Earlier in the year, less than 10 percent of the money moving into funds went abroad; for the quarter, it was 30 percent, despite a very small outflow in the last two weeks.
Investors' willingness to take on risk surprised some of the "smart money" -- hedge fund and other professional money managers who had been predicting that individuals would sell shares into a declining market, magnifying the downward spiral for all. But experts say the new acceptance of risk is a reasonable strategy, as the unusually high fixed-income returns of the last decade settle into more historical ranges.
"The free ride given by the prolonged period of falling interest rates is over, and you'll have to be in stocks, foreign securities and other higher-risk investments to get good returns in the next decade," said Don Phillips, vice president of Morningstar.
That's not to say that fund investors may not yet get frightened by a prolonged bear market, or even by some events that roil the market. In fact, although money continued to flow into stock funds at the end of the quarter, the amount dropped markedly, from about $2 billion to $2.5 billion a week to less than $600 million, as the weakening dollar upset stock prices in mid-June. But inflows jumped again in the final week of the quarter, to more than $800 million, driven by big gains in aggressive growth and emerging growth funds, AMG said.
And so where from here for fund investors?
Six advisers agreed on little but one thing: that the "free ride" is indeed over and making money is not going to be as easy as before. Some urged investors to take less risk, at least in the short term, while others advised riding out the current bumpiness and aiming for the long term.
Robert D. Bingham, partner in Bingham, Osborn & Scarborough, investment advisers in San Francisco, has pulled back on equities in general, but where he sees value it is in smaller stocks. At least half of domestic equities should be invested in smaller stocks, he said, because even though they aren't the screaming buys they were three years ago, they are still relatively attractive. He likes Royce Premier, Dreyfus Small Cap Target Value and Vanguard Explorer.
Among small-cap value funds, Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo, likes Royce Premier and Greenspring. Growth favorites of Craig Litman, a San Francisco-based adviser, are Montgomery Small Cap and Brandywine ($25,000 minimum).
But Mr. Litman says big-cap growth stocks are looking good now because valuations have lagged for more than two years. "We don't see a lot of downside risk," and the sector has upside potential in a fairly flat market, he said. Three favorites: Vanguard U.S. Growth, Janus Fund and Harbor Capital Appreciation.
By contrast, "we believe," Mr. Bingham said, "that the recent correction in the stock market hasn't been significant and the U.S. market, particularly large caps, are overpriced." So, he said, "our clients are in fewer stocks than they would normally be."
Mr. Bingham advises aggressive investors to reduce stock allocations to 50 percent from 70 percent; others, to 40 percent from 50 percent. Before starting to move back into stocks in a big way, Mr. Bingham wants price-earnings ratios to fall below 18 from today's 19.5.
Also bearish is Charles E. Cain, a New York-based adviser who would keep 50 percent in cash. He is worried about the impact on stocks if the Fed is forced to push up interest rates again, sooner than it may have planned, because of the weak dollar. He is steering money into conservative funds like Mutual Shares and Fidelity Equity Income II.
One-third cash is good enough, said Robert J. Markman, an investment adviser in Minneapolis. The rest he would split 60-40 in the United States and abroad with managers "that have shown consistent results, particularly in sloppy markets like these," he said. Three favorites: Mutual Shares, Lindner Dividend and Sogen Overseas, which is "worth the load," he said.
Since the year began, utility funds have been the only equity losers, with money flowing out in all but three weeks of the last six months. The funds are sensitive to interest rates and have been badly hurt as rates rose.
But low prices are not enough to make the group attractive to A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. "There's a long-term issue of industrywide competition that has changed the equation that had made utilities attractive in the past," he said. The problem: deregulation and competition mean smaller dividends ahead.
In terms of investing abroad, Mr. Litman sees potential in emerging markets debt, which he said investors have been dumping unreasonably. He expects gains of roughly 15 percent in the sector over the next six months to one year, and recommends Scudder Emerging Markets Income and Fidelity New Markets Income.
Mr. Cain would split stocks equally between the United States and Japan because of "strong indications" that the Japanese market "may move onto a new uptrend." He likes Scudder Japan, Fidelity Japan and T. Rowe Price Japan.
By contrast, Mr. Markman said the long-term potential for the Pacific Rim is strong, except for Japan, where fundamentals are very negative. He likes two diversified funds: T. Rowe Price New Asia and Newport Tiger.
When it comes to bonds, the picture is very different. Money has flowed out of most bond funds in the latest quarter to the tune of $7.6 billion for taxable funds, and $10.8 billion for government bond funds. That trend reversed in late May, but most of the reversal was attributable to the attractiveness of junk bond funds, which remained strong until they dipped in the final week.
At this point, Mr. Bingham said, junk remains "a decent market to be in in any situation" for diversification. He recommends that 10 to 20 percent of the domestic bond portion of a portfolio be in junk. He likes the Vanguard and Federated High Yield funds.
As for corporate and Government bonds, short- to intermediate-term is still best, the advisers say.

HEADLINE: How Downsizing Diminishes Bennington

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Radical Answer to a Small College's Woes" (news article, June 23), on the drastic transformation of Bennington College, is uninformative. The idea of a college's attempting something like "corporate restructuring" may be amusing, but tells nothing about consequences. 
 Here is what the board of trustees has decreed: all the literary critics and scholars have been fired and the study of literary history has been terminated. Students who wish to study a foreign language or literature will have to make arrangements with local teachers or others in the not exactly cosmopolitan region of Bennington, Vt. The same arrangements must be made by students studying musical instruments. (This for a tuition of $23,000 a year.)
 Other vital disciplines have likewise been eliminated, including art history, sociology, politics and economics. The board says that the college, faced with "financial exigency," must reduce faculty and resources.
Under the most intelligent scheme this would be a perilous act; when Bennington decided to expand its faculty and enrollment in the late 1960's, it reasoned that a modern college had to achieve a minimum size and diversity to remain academically solvent. Today this principle is even more compelling: a downsized college is always in danger of losing its place in the company of respectable educational institutions.
But the way the board has gone about its trimming is imbecilic, a parody of pragmatism in which a do-it-yourself education is presented as a superior alternative to having qualified professors on hand.
A college cannot be jump-started. It is an intricate institution, whose character derives from history. Its faculty cannot be swept away in massive numbers -- there have been at least 26 firings from a faculty of 60 -- and replaced like Job's children.
We merely mention the human costs: the firing of tenured professors, who in many cases have served the college for decades, and the predicament of students, who have been robbed overnight of their education.
We received our bachelor's degrees from Bennington in literature and languages in 1992. The majority of professors with whom we studied are among those who have been fired. We are certain we are not alone in lamenting the disastrous new "reformations" that will destroy a once-great school.
 
DEBRA HECHT
ANAHEED ALANI
New York, June 26, 1994

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBAT: BEHIND THE SCENES;
First Lady's Health Strategy: Accept Less or Gamble It All?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton faces a dilemma, and it can be summed up in a barb she once tossed at health-care lobbyists in a private bargaining session here. "We were trying to work out varying ways of dealing with some of the differences" over national health insurance, recalled Pam Bailey, who heads a coalition of hospitals and medical companies, "and suddenly she said to us: 'Bill and I did not come to Washington to fudge the issue.' "
That was January. Now, in July, many experts say a national health insurance plan will be passed by Congress only if the Clintons fudge the issue, relaxing their bottom-line demand that the insurance cover everyone and casting the passage of a less ambitious plan as a victory for society. If the Clintons hold firm, they will be taking a high-stakes political gamble that they may easily lose. It is a contest of politics and principle, and it is the mark of Mrs. Clinton that principle remains a contender, at least in the minds of people who know her well. 
 It is also why some suggest that Mrs. Clinton, whose tenacity many credit with pushing health care to the House and Senate doorsteps, is less suited for the double-jointed bargaining that is probably needed if an insurance plan is to become law.
"Her biggest attributes are also her biggest weaknesses," said a Democratic Senator at the center of the political debate. "I think she's a person with very firm convictions. I think her husband is much more willing to say: 'I've got to compromise. I've got to get things done.' "
Of course, this is the stereotype of the Clintons: the inflexible, ideological and rather lawyerly First Lady as spine-stiffener for a malleable, anxious-to-please President. Some White House officials say that portrait is a half-truth and that Mrs. Clinton's poker face is just the mask of an extremely tough negotiator.
In the White House, aides say, she is the senior adviser and senior strategist on health care, meeting every few days with the President and perhaps a dozen policy aides and political advisers to map the legislative and public-relations campaigns. She meets somewhat less often with Democratic leaders and individual legislators in Congress.
"She's a pragmatist," said an official who has worked on the plan, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "She won't send health care down the tubes -- no doubt about it. For one thing, she doesn't want to blow her husband's Presidency after two years in office. And face it, that's what this is."
Mrs. Clinton will not tip her hand one way or the other. In the midst of a speaking campaign for the Administration health plan, she declined last week to be interviewed. Still, with national health insurance on the brink of epochal legislative victory, or maybe ruinous defeat, she seems unflinching so far.
That stance is most notable on the major sticking point in the negotiations: the repeated warning that Mr. Clinton will veto legislation that does not guarantee insurance to everyone.
 
Firm Opposition
 The notion of guaranteed insurance is popular, in part because it would spread insurance costs over the entire population and simplify accounting. But its political prospects seem dim to some because the small-business lobby, most Republicans and some Democrats oppose the only realistic ways to get there: raising taxes, or forcing people to buy insurance against their will.
In a White House meeting three Sundays ago, on June 19, both Mrs. Clinton and the President sharply rejected advice by some political and economic advisers that the time for bargaining was running out and that the odds against passing legislation would rise unless some movement was made toward an accord with opponents on universal coverage.
Mrs. Clinton went into private meetings to give fist-shaking speeches to supporters in unions, consumer groups and retired people's organizations, warning that universal health coverage was in grave danger. That helped stall one attempt in the Senate Finance Committee to back away from guaranteed insurance.
The Senators said nothing publicly, but some who believe that guaranteed insurance is politically unrealistic were privately furious. "We would have been in the reality zone a long time ago," said one senior aide, had it not been for what he called Mrs. Clinton's "health care cult."
Whether this is standing on principle or simply political calculus is hard to tell. "What in the world is she supposed to do?" asked a second Democratic Senate aide. "The President has said he will veto a bill that doesn't have universal coverage. That's her position, too."
If it is a ploy, it is the wrong one, said Ms. Bailey, whose Health Care Leadership Council opposes many features of the Administration's plan. She argued that inflexibility had only stiffened the resolve of Democratic supporters without luring votes from other factions.
"If she'd been more in a consensus-building mode earlier, we could have moved this a lot earlier," she said. "At the end of day, she's going to have to help sell a compromise to the very groups she's been working closest with from the beginning."
 
Criticizing Her Leadership
 Some outsiders, and even some Administration advisers, now say that whatever Mrs. Clinton's strengths, the White House decision to place its entire health care agenda in the hands of the strong-willed First Lady has resulted in a plan that will be harder to sell.
"I would periodically hear from people outside and inside the Administration who had fundamental qualms about some aspect of the plan and weren't going to raise it because of who she was," said Gail Wilensky, a health care adviser in the Bush Administration who is now a senior fellow at Project HOPE, an international charity. "Nobody was going to cross Hillary Clinton."
While Mrs. Clinton can appear inflexible and even didactic on this issue, many experts say health-care legislation would probably not be an overriding issue this summer -- for the first time in almost 30 years -- had she not been so fervent.
By the count of her aides, the First Lady has spoken on behalf of national health insurance to nearly 300 local and national groups in 30 states since the Clintons' political crusade began last year. Her summer schedule is salted with meetings with important health care constituencies.
A sampling of speeches, supplied by her office, shows that they can be preachy. Mrs. Clinton talks about people who were denied care for lack of insurance, including one heartbreaking account of a child who died of meningitis as a result. But she is quite capable of appealing to logic as well. Before the Economic Club of Washington last week, without a prepared text or notes, she gave an almost seamless economic analysis of health care for some 30 minutes, never even pausing for an "uh."
Medical costs, she argued, will overwhelm the public and the Government unless they are controlled, and medical costs cannot be controlled until the uninsured pay their share of the bill. Therefore, everyone must be insured.
"Like Ronald Reagan before her," said John Rother, an Clinton ally who is the chief lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons, "she understands that to be in the strongest possible position, you've got to state your case forcefully and as much on principle as you can."
No one disputes that Mrs. Clinton has been a superior saleswoman for national health insurance. To the extent questions exist, they turn on whether zealousness and a steamroller approach can succeed in a town whose motto is "split the difference."
 
Standing Her Ground
 "When she thinks she's right, she'll stand her ground with anybody," said Charlie Cole Chaffin, who served with Mrs. Clinton when she led an education task force in Arkansas and who is now a candidate for lieutenant governor there.
But in Washington, Mrs. Clinton's singlemindedness in pursuing what she sees as right has hurt politically. She was roundly criticized last year when, as her husband touted his efforts to form a bureaucracy that looked like America, she summoned 500 experts and political allies to Washington to research and draft health-care legislation in secret.
The result was a 240,000-word bill that attacked health care costs with price controls and new Government boards. Conservatives pounded on it as we-know-best bureaucracy run amok. Although Mrs. Clinton campaigned for it and the White House said ordinary Americans would soon rally behind it, the groundswell never developed and Congress has since discarded large chunks of it.
To save what remains -- especially the commitment to universal coverage that is in most of the plans now moving to the House and Senate floors -- the Clintons clearly are betting that public support will sweep away political resistance.
Supporters liken the coming health-insurance debate to the great debates over social legislation in the 1960's, when tides of citizen activism washed away opposition to laws protecting civil rights, health care for the elderly and care for the poor. The job of rallying the troops is likely to fall to Mrs. Clinton, who will intensify her speaking schedule once Congress begins to address legislation seriously.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 7, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
(July 6, 1994, Wednesday) A chart yesterday describing the work of Congressional committees on health care gave an incomplete description of legislation proposed by the House Education and Labor Committee. In addition to a version of President Clinton's plan, the committee also approved a bill that would create a Canadian-style single-payer system. This bill would provide all Americans with a standard package of benefits, paid for by a payroll tax of 8.4 percent on big companies and 4 percent on small ones, a 2.1 percent tax on incomes, an increase of the cigarette tax to $2 and a tax on ammunition.
Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's health care efforts referred incorrectly to the beneficiaries of Project Hope. The organization -- which employs Gail Wilensky, a former Bush Administration health care adviser who was quoted -- provides health care assistance to developing countries, not to residents of public housing in America.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hillary Rodham Clinton, with President Clinton, discussing health care last week. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A1); As health care proposals make their way through Congress, some in Washington say Hillary Rodham Clinton and her husband will have to relax demands for universal coverage, but those who know her well say Mrs. Clinton is not inclined to take that step. Mrs. Clinton greeted members of the National Education Association after a speech on health care at the group's convention in New Orleans on Sunday. (Associated Press) (pg. D13)
 
Chart: "THE DETAILS: The State of the Health Care Debate: Five Committees, Four Bills"
 When theSenate Finance Committee approved a healthcare bill onSaturdya, it brought to an end the first round of Congressional action on the subject. Five committees considered the plan put forward last fall by President Clinton. One, the House Energy and Commerce Committee, deadlocked and produced no bill. The bills approved by the four others will now go the Democratic leadership to be melded into proposals that will be presented on the House and Senate floors in late July or August. Below is a comparison of the major provisions of the Clinton plan and the bills that emerged form the committees.
 
CLINTON PLAN
 
BENEFITS: Basic benefit package includes doctor, hospital and emergency services; some coverage for mental health and drug and alcohol abuse; prescription drugs; rehabilitation services; hospice, home health and extended nursing care services; preventive care, and lab and diagnostic services.
 
ALLIANCES: Requires most Americans to obtaincoverage through regional insurance purchasing alliances. All companies with 5,000 or fewer employees must buy coverage through an alliance.
 
FINANCING: Requiresw employers to pay about 80 percent of the costs of the average health insurance plan in their areas for a single person and about 55 percent of the cost of the average family plan, but no more than 7.9 percent of their payrolls. Companies with 75 or fewer employees and average annualwages of less than $24,000 are eligible for subsidies that limit employers' costs to 3.5 percent to 7.9 percent of the payroll. Individuals pay up to 20 percent of the premiums.
 
TAXES: Requires a 1 percent payroll tax oncompanies with 5,000 or more workers. Raises the current 24 cents-a-pack cigarette tax by 75 cents, to 99 cents.
 
SENATE LABOR AND HUMAN RESOURCES
 
STATUS: Approved by committee June 9.
 
BENEFITS: Follows outlines of Clintonpackage but provides additional benefits for women, children, the disabled, low-income people and for mental health and drug and alcohol abuse. Provides increased coverage for preventive examinations and long-term nursing home care.
 
ALLIANCES: Individuals have three options: 1. buying private insurance; 2. participating in states' consumer health purchasing cooperatives, or 3. participating in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Plan, which currently offers a variety of insurance options.
 
FINANCING: As in Clinton plan, most companies pay 80 percent of the average premium for individuals and 55 percent for families. Businesses with a low average wage and fewer than six workers are exempt and instead pay a 2 percent payroll tax; their employees buy their own insurance but pay no more than 4 percent to 6 percent of their annual wages.
 
TAXES: Requires companies with 1,000 or more employees to pay a 1 percent payroll tax. Increases the cigarette tax to $1.49.
 SENATE FINANCE
 
STATUS: Approved Saturday
 
BENEFITS: Provides a standard package of benefits, comparable to those provided now to Federal workers. Includes a new home health care benefit for the disabled.
 
ALLIANCES: Creates voluntary insurance purchasing pool open to individuals and small businesses.
 
FINANCING: No mandate for employers. If changes ininsurance rules, subsidies and voluntary measures do not produce coverage of 95 percent of Americans by 2002, a national commission makes recommendations to Congress on how to go further.
 
TAXES: Increases the cigarette tax to $1.24. A 1.75 percent tax on insurance premiums supports academic medical centers. Raises $14 billion to $17 billion over five years through a tax on high-cost insurance plans. Affluent Medicare recipients face higher premiums and co-payments.
 
HOUSE EDUCATION AND LABOR
 
STATUS: Approved June 23.
 
BENEFITS: Follows outlines of Clinton package, but expands benefits for mental illness, dental coverage and women's and children's care.
 
ALLIANCES: Eliminates mandatory alliances, replacing them with consumer purchasing cooperatives established by the states on either a voluntary or a mandatory basis. Companies with 1,000 or more employees are excluded from the cooperatives and are permitted to establish their own plans.
 
FINANCING: Retains the Clinton provision but provides greater subsidies for the smallest employers, who are not required to pay more than 2 percent of their payrolls.
 
TAXES: Requires a 1 percent assessment of employers of more than 1,000 workers. Retains the tax recommendations in the Clinton package.
 
HOSE WAYS AND MEANS
 
STATUS: Approved Thursday
 
BENEFITS: Less generous than the Clinton plan. The basic package would include everything covered under the current Medicare program, plus coverage of prescription drugs, improved mental health and drug and alcohol abuse benefits, pregnancy-related services and preventive services for children.
 
ALLIANCES: Expands Medicare to allow individuals not covered elsewhere to enroll in a new Part C. States have the option of creating mandatory alliances.
 
FINANCING: Retains the requirement inthe Clinton package that employers pay up to 80 percent of premiums for their employees. Allows employers with more than 100 employees to insure themselves. Provides tax credits to small businesses: inthe case of companies with 25 or fewer employees, the maximum credit reduces the employer share to 40 percent of premium costs; for companies with 26 to 50 employees, employers could pay as little as 50 percent of premium costs.
 
TAXES: Increases the tobacco tax by 45 cents by 1999. Imposes a 2 percent tax on premiums.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Quarterly Review;
Vanguard's Ace Stock Picker Is Back on Top

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: VALLEY FORGE, Pa.

 BODY:
JOHN B. NEFF, the man behind Vanguard's giant Windsor fund, has been vindicated this year after a highly publicized slump.
"He has had a good turnaround, not only on an absolute basis but when compared with his peers," said Ken Gregory, editor of the No-Load Fund Analyst, an industry newsletter based in San Francisco. 
 Mr. Neff's approach, buying stocks that are underpriced, has never changed. But that style, called value investing, fell out of favor for several years, and even when the fund advanced in 1991, it lagged behind competitors. Some analysts began to wonder whether Mr. Neff and some like-minded managers, including Michael Price of the Mutual Series Fund, had lost their touch.
"You don't like to stink, obviously, and we did quite badly in '89 and '90," Mr. Neff said in an interview at his Vanguard office here.
But as Mr. Neff's 30-year record at Windsor suggested, the tide would turn -- eventually. Among stock funds seeking growth and income, Windsor posted the best performance for the second quarter, with a 3.8 percent total return. Among all mutual funds with more than $5 billion in assets, the $11 billion Windsor fund is on top for the quarter and for the year.
Of the down years, Mr. Neff complains not of an overdemanding or fickle public, but of a stock market that was irrational. It assumed the worst about the battered bank and savings and loan group in which he had sunk 30 percent of assets.
The ensuing rally in that sector mocked the theory, beloved in academe and ridiculed on Wall Street, that security analysis had become such an exact science that one software-armed portfolio manager was as good as another.
"Everybody's got a master's degree now and there are computers and instantaneous electronics and history that's been well massaged," Mr. Neff said, putting aside a copy of Value Line, an advisory service he peruses regularly for corporate snapshots. "But the market still isn't very efficient, very intelligent or very bright."
Mr. Neff's investing approach relies on uncovering hidden value in downtrodden stocks and on a willingness to back decisions with exceptionally large bets. No timid diversification for Windsor, which in the halcyon 1980's attracted so much money that it has been closed to new investors since 1989.
His fans, though, have alternatives. Mr. Neff also manages Gemini II, a closed-end investment company trading on the New York Stock Exchange with a portfolio similar to Windsor's, albeit with more convertible bonds. For added attraction, Gemini II sells at about a 12 percent discount, which becomes guaranteed profit when it converts to an open-end fund in January 1997.
A paler alternative is Windsor II, which follows the Neff value-oriented approach but is run by four outside managers. It rose 2.6 percent in the second quarter.
In sizing up a company, Mr. Neff looks at the rate of earnings growth, the price-earnings ratio and dividend. This is preceded, of course, by his analysis of economic conditions, which occupies 25 percent of his time.
"You have to be half an economist and be able to develop some convictions to capitalize on your portfolio," Mr. Neff said.
Suggesting the Federal Reserve has hit it about right in raising short-term rates, he has wagered that no rate increases are imminent despite the weakness of the dollar, which he considers "undervalued." In fact, he recently bought a bunch of 14-year Treasuries, a rather unusual wager for stock-oriented Windsor.
While Mr. Neff's comeback has been powered by financial stocks -- and aided by positions in Chrysler, the oil and gas sector, chemicals and European issues -- he contends that the banks have a lot further to go.
"What you've seen so far is recovery from an unduly low point," Mr. Neff said. Most banks still sell at just half the average price-earnings multiple. Because they are loaded with capital, he expects them to be actively repurchasing shares and raising dividends by 12 to 14 percent a year. Windsor, consequently, has 20 percent of its portfolio in the sector.
The fund is also investing heavily in Atlantic Richfield, a position that went from nothing to the legal maximum of 5 percent in just a few months. The reasoning is that ARCO stock, which the fund has bought and sold five times previously over three decades, offers the highest leveraged play on the price of crude oil and has not yet risen in response to the latest jump in oil.
Windsor is building a fresh position in technology, with a speculative parlay in Seagate, Intel and Advanced Micro, which have been beaten down to the point that they sell as a group for about eight times 1994 earnings.
Mr. Neff, who will be 63 in September, could certainly afford to retire -- his holdings of Windsor and Gemini II alone are worth some $90 million. But a life of full-time travel, golf and tennis on his court at home is not yet in sight.
When it comes, there seems little doubt that his successor will be Charles T. Freeman, the assistant portfolio manager who has worked with Mr. Neff for 25 years and weathered the bear market of 1973 and '74.
Big-time investing "isn't like finding the ultimate microprocessor and coasting for 30 years," said Mr. Neff, who took over when Windsor was a $75 million fledgling. "It's as big and broad as life itself."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 7, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in the Mutual Funds Quarterly Review pages of Business Day on Tuesday about John B. Neff, the money manager of the Vanguard Group's Windsor mutual fund and the Gemini II closed-end fund, misstated the value of his holdings in the two funds. They total about $6 million, not $90 million.

HEADLINE: In Shift, U.S. Will No Longer Admit Haitians at Sea

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
After a sharp increase in the number of Haitians seeking asylum, the Clinton Administration abruptly shifted policy today and said it would no longer allow refugees intercepted at sea to be resettled in the United States.
Instead, Haitians fleeing by boat who qualify for asylum will be taken to Panama or other Caribbean countries until the political crisis in their country is resolved. 
 "Those who take to the boats will not have resettlement possibilities in the United States," William H. Gray 3d, President Clinton's top adviser on Haiti, said at the White House.
The new policy comes just three weeks after the Administration stopped returning all those picked up at sea to Haiti and began hearing their claims for asylum aboard Navy ships. That move was part of a broader shift aimed at mollifying critics like Randall Robinson, who went on a hunger strike and protested that the Administration was ignoring the plight of Haitians who opposed the military Government.
Some experts warned then that the policy might set off a mass exodus. In fact, the State Department says, more than 10,000 Haitians have been picked up at sea since June 15.
With the policy announced today, the Administration has in effect tried to buy time by handling the flow of Haitians in a humane way while it waits to see if economic sanctions will force out the military. Under the new policy, only Haitians applying for asylum at the United States Embassy in Port-au-Prince will be eligible for settlement in the United States.
"If we're going to be able to withstand the surge in refugee outflow, we've got to do things to discourage that as well as to absorb them," a State Department official said. "Now you can make it to ship, but that ship's going to Panama, not a U.S. base. These countries are not necessarily an improvement over Haiti."
The Pentagon said today that it was sending four ships carrying 2,000 marines to join the flotilla near Haiti so they could rescue any Americans who might be in danger. The marines returned just 10 days ago from six months in the Mediterranean and Indian Ocean. The decision to send them to Haiti marked an unusual departure for the Navy, which has sought to limit time at sea.
While Mr. Gray described the dispatch of the marines as a precuation, he acknowledged that the White House was keeping open the option of a military intervention.
"There is no military invasion imminent," Mr. Gray said. "However, the military option is on the table. 'Imminent' is defined as something that is going to happen in a few days."
The United States has been screening refugees at Guantanamo Bay and on a hospital ship anchored at Kingston, Jamaica; another center is to be opened soon in the Turk and Caicos Islands.
"They will be processed to seek to learn whether or not, just as we have been doing over the last few weeks, there is a real and credible fear with regard to political persecution," Mr. Gray said. "Those who are found to have such a fear, those who are granted asylum, that asylum will be granted at the refugee camp in Panama, and later, as we bring on board other safe havens, they will be granted status there."
Those that do not qualify will be sent back to Haiti.
Other Administration officials said, however, that the precise standards for deciding who would be sent to Panama and who would be returned to Haiti were still being worked out. The standards for sending Haitians to Panama may be less strict than those for admission to the United States.
At first the Haitians sent to Panama will be housed on United States military bases; eventually, they may be moved to an island off Panama. Mr. Gray said the United States and Panama had agreed on a limit of 10,000 refugees sent to Panama.
The Panama plan is being supported by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and American officials expect that group to play a major role in running the camps.
Other camps are to be set up in Antigua and Dominica and possibly elsewhere, State Department officials said.
 
Criticism by Rights Groups
 Arthur C. Helton, the director of the migration program at the Open Society Institute in New York, urged the Administration not to screen the Haitians too strictly.
"Screening people in the midst of flight has failed and will fail again," he warned.
Amnesty International today assailed the move, saying Haitians face tougher standards than other groups in trying to settle in the United States.
"It appears that the Clinton Administration and the U.S. Congress are still afraid of Haitian refugees," said the Rev. William F. Schulz, executive director of Amnesty International U.S.A.
But an Administration official rejected this criticism, insisting that Washington was being true to the logic of its policy: that Haitians who have reason to fear persecution will be granted a refuge.
"The fundamental policy is to provide protection to those who need protection," the official said. "The means were adjusted today to make that policy more workable."
 
As the Odds Improve
 In recent weeks, about a third of the fleeing Haitians have been given refugee status in the United States. According to the State Department, of the 1,705 refugees who have been interviewed in Kingston, 515 have been approved for refugee status and 1,190 have been denied.
The possibility of asylum has prompted many more Haitians to flee. On Monday, the United States reported picking up more than 3,000.
Administration officials noted, however, that if the Haitians continue to take to the seas, camps throughout the region will soon be filled, and there will be new pressure on Washington to consider military action to remove the military leaders of Haiti.

 President Clinton on May 8, announcing the policy of interviewing Haitian refugees at sea:
 "I have become increasingly concerned that Haiti's declining human rights situation may endanger the safety of those who have valid fears of political persecution, who flee by boat, and who are then returned to Haiti, where they are met at the docks by Haitian authorities before they can be referred to in-country processing. Therefore, I have decided to modify our procedures. We will continue to interdict all Haitian migrants at sea, but we will determine aboard ship or in other countries which ones are bona fide political refugees. Those who are not will still be returned to Haiti, but those who are will be provided refuge. We will also approach other countries to seek their participation in this humanitarian endeavor."
 William Gray, special envoy to Haiti, announcing a change of policy yesterday:
 "What we are providing is a safe haven -- safety from persecution and from the fear of persecution for all. Those who take to the boats will be offered safe haven in camps in Panama. Those who go to in-country processing sites will be offered the potential for resettlement after the processing in the
United States." (pg. A8)

HEADLINE: Colleges Caught in Middle As Parents Seek Best Deal

BYLINE: WILLIAM CELIS 3d 

 BODY:
To get into the college of his choice, Lyndon Allin knew that he needed good grades, high scores on his college entrance examination and a lot of financial aid. He also needed some gamesmanship.
Mr. Allin, one of the nation's top-ranked high school graduates, was accepted by some of the nation's leading institutions. Northwestern University, which costs $24,283 a year, offered him $8,700 in scholarships and loans; Vanderbilt University offered $13,000, about half its annual costs. 
 But Duke University, on which Mr. Allin had set his sights, offered him just $2,140 to help cover its $25,487 annual costs. So Mr. Allin called Duke about the competing bids, noting as he had in his aid application that his family's financial status might soon worsen. The next day, he said, Duke increased its offer to $14,250 a year, saying it had erred in calculating his aid package.
Duke does not bargain with students over financial aid, said James A. Belvin Jr., Duke's financial aid director. But, Mr. Belvin said, it is always willing to review aid packages if there are changes in a family's financial status.
And students like Mr. Allin are bombarding colleges and universities with calls for such reviews, playing one institution against another, pointing up their own merits and their financial needs as would-be undergraduates.
Mr. Allin, for example, was the 1994 valedictorian of Woodrow Wilson High School in Washington. He is a National Merit Scholar whose combined score of 1510 out of 1600 on his Scholastic Assessment Test for college admissions put him in the top 1 percent of all high school graduates.
"You have these cards and you have to play them," said Mr. Allin, whose father, a retired Federal employee, and mother, who works for a nonprofit foundation, declined to disclose their combined incomes. "I'm being a good consumer."
But such consumerism is fast becoming a nightmare for college financial aid officials. The combination of high college costs and smaller amounts of available aid has particularly made higher education more expensive for the middle class. Some families will seemingly try any bargaining ploy to pry a few more dollars out of an institution.
 
About 60% Receive Aid
 "Parents are not just willing to say that my kid is an extremely good student and take what they get in financial aid," said Lynn Caldwell, director of counseling at the Highland Park Independent School District in a Dallas suburb and a former member of the College Board's committee studying financial aid issues. "It's a consumer-conscious market."
Nearly 60 percent of all full-time college students receive some type of aid, according to a Federal Education Department survey in 1990, the last available. Given higher college costs and dwindling aid, that figure could grow by two percentage points when the department's new survey is released later this year, college aid officials say.
To insure that all needy students receive the aid they needed and to curb bartering, the Ivy League and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for decades met to compare their aid awards to the same student. The Justice Department called that practice anti-competitive and had it halted in 1992. But last year M.I.T. won right to compare financial data with other institutions, with some restrictions. Financial aid officials said that would help cool the wheeling and dealing that occurs among all universities.
 
Reports of Financial Woes
 But still, the competition has heated up for top students among colleges in the second and third tiers. Indeed, as families demand more aid or push for more scholarships over loans, some applicants and their parents do not think twice about faxing competing offers to colleges and writing at the bottom: "Can You Match This?"
College officials also tell of families who will call the same aid office several times a day, literally sobbing into the telephone for more aid.
Last month Tennessee Tech University in Cookeville received calls from the parents of two students who said that religious beliefs prevented them from accepting loans. They asked the university to eliminate the loans from their children's financial aid packages and replace them with scholarships. Tennessee Tech balked.
"There are things happening out there that would curl your hair," said Elizabeth Coleman, president of Bennington College in Bennington, Vt., which last month announced restructuring plans that included reducing its tuition, now $25,800 a year, by 10 percent over five years to help increase enrollment. "We make our decision, and that's it."
Still, some institutions encourage families by bidding for students who offer special skills or come from minorities, and both economics and demographics explain why institutions fan the competitive war for good students.
Nearly 2.3 million students graduated from high school this year, a level that has remained relatively flat in the 1990's and is down by nearly a half million students from the early 1980's. Second- and third-tier colleges and universities rely more on enrollment to generate revenue than do their larger rivals, where enrollment revenue is overshadowed by income from endowments.
 
Meeting Enrollment Goals
 As a result, the smaller institutions -- and sometimes even the pre-eminent giants -- will enrich financial aid packages to insure that they get all the freshmen they need to meet their enrollment goals. But even institutions that do not have the money to award scholarships do so anyway -- by discounting tuition.
While every institution has a fixed amount of scholarship money available to apportion among needy students, the number of discounted tuitions that can be made is limited only by the institution's ability to absorb the lost revenue.
The practice of offering discounts is defended by the institutions.
"We don't like to do it," said Michael White, financial aid director at Coe College, a liberal arts institution in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, which says it will look at competing offers presented by students and occasionally increase aid. "The reality is you still need to meet your enrollment objectives to keep the college functioning. It's a revenue question."
The haggling over financial aid noticeably surfaced in the 1980's as college costs began climbing, sometimes outstripping the rate of inflation. It has accelerated in the last five years, and more colleges have crossed the $20,000- and $25,000-a-year thresholds in total costs.
At some institutions, like Dickinson, a private liberal arts college in Carlisle, Pa., which costs $25,670 a year for tuition, room, board and fees, the bargaining "has easily doubled over the last five years," said Donald Raley, the college's financial aid director.
Congress unwittingly gave the jockeying new impetus two years ago when, as part of the reauthorization of the Higher Education Act of 1965, lawmakers ordered the Education Department to simplify its financial aid forms. The new form asks fewer questions about a family's finances.
Gone, for example, is the question on home-ownership. That is important, financial aid officials said, because families that own their dwellings can take out home equity loans and assume a greater part of college costs.
Some colleges and universities have added the home-ownership question to their own financial aid forms while others have not. As a result, disparities of several thousand dollars in college aid packages arise from institutions working with different financial data from the same student. Thus, the bidding begins.
 
Offer as Bargaining Tool
 At Dickinson, for example, one father called trying to sweeten his son's financial aid package. Mr. Raley said the father told him that the son was not interested in Dickinson but wanted to use its financial aid offer to squeeze more money out of Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, which his son wished to attend.
"After I closed my mouth, I told him to take his approach elsewhere," Mr. Raley said. "It was so tacky."
Coe and Buena Vista College, a small private liberal art college in Storm Lake, Iowa, can top that. Last month, a Buena Vista officials said, a mother berated the college for not sending her son a financial aid award while Coe had. Never mind that the son had never even submitted the forms to Buena Vista, the officials said. Leanne Valentine, the director of financial aid at Buena Vista, called Coe to ask for a copy of the student's financial aid forms. The student was clearly bright, having scored 30 out of a possible 36 on the American College Test, and had received a substantial award from Coe, which costs $18,440 a year.
But as Buena Vista began reviewing the financial data, the mother called Coe, telling officials that Buena Vista had put together a financial aid package covering all but $200 of its $17,103 annual cost and that all of it was in the form of a scholarship.
Not true, said Ms. Valentine, who said she learned of her college's phantom offer when she telephoned Coe officials for the student's financial aid documents.
The student eventually enrolled in Coe, which did not increase his aid package.
Relieved that the ordeal was over, Ms. Valentine of Buena Vista, said, "To be honest, I was thankful that this student did not come here."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed on Hints Nations Don't Plan Support

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against leading currencies yesterday amid signs that leading industrial nations would not take steps to support the dollar when they meet later this week in Naples.
A draft of the economic document to be considered at the meeting of the Group of Seven made no mention of the dollar. Instead, it called for looser regulation of the world's labor market, freer trade and continued support for economic reforms in Russia. 
 "It looks like the dollar will be left vulnerable," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Smith Barney Inc.
The dollar was quoted in late trading yesterday at 1.5810 German marks, down almost 2 pfennigs, or 1.1 percent, from 1.5972 marks on Monday in European trading. United States markets were closed on Monday in observance of the Fourth of July.
The dollar settled at 99 yen yesterday, up from 98.75 in New York on Friday.
Traders were less willing to sell the dollar aggressively against the yen because it is near the post-World War II low of 97.73 yen set in Tokyo on Friday. Trading was sluggish yesterday as many market participants had not yet returned from the holiday weekend.
Speculation that the Group of Seven would mount a dollar rescue faded after President Clinton was quoted as saying that "great care should be taken before unusual actions are taken" to prop up the dollar. Mr. Clinton's comments came in a transcript of an interview with foreign reporters on Friday, which the White House released on Monday. "Over the long run, the markets tend to align with market realities," the President said.
 
Less Backing Seen
 So far this year, the dollar has fallen 9 percent against the mark and 11 percent against the yen.
"It's becoming clear that no one wants to do anything to support the dollar," said Amy Smith, senior currency market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm. "It looks like the G-7 is having the meeting only because they have to."
The dollar fell against other currencies yesterday. The British pound was quoted at $1.5440 late in the day, up from $1.5390. The dollar fell to 5.4180 French francs from 5.4700, and weakened to 1.3260 Swiss francs from 1.3403 francs. It fell to 1,566 Italian lire from 1,584. The Canadian dollar was steady at 72.09 United States cents.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Mary L. Landrieu, the Louisiana State Treasurer, has shaken up the old-boy network that let politicians steer municipal finance business to their families and friends. Her latest attack is on an arrangement in which First Boston and Lazard Freres say they were coerced into giving half their fees from a recent deal to a firm that did no work -- but whose owner can deliver votes for Gov. Edwin Edwards. [Page A1.] 
 Small business is lobbying frantically, and successfully, to kill health care reform's employer mandates. [A1.]
 
Companies
Texaco said it would sell about half its 600 producing oilfields in the United States and cut 2,500 jobs as part of broad move to reduce costs. The company said the moves would result in a charge of $165 million in the second quarter. [D1.]
Bidding for Viacom's Madison Square Garden properties has apparently been narrowed to five prospective buyers, executives familiar with some aspects of the sale said. [D1.]
Wellfleet Communications and Synoptics Communications plan to merge in a deal valued at about $2.7 billion, creating a leading participant in computer networking equipment. [D1.]

Business Technology
Even as cable television and telephone companies clamor to provide the main information pipeline into American households, another industry looks for an opening. Electric companies, which already have wires running to virtually every home, are devising ways to send bits and bytes along with the kilowatts that course through those circuits. [D1.]
 
International
The tone has been upbeat during the visit to Germany by Prime Minister Li Peng of China, befitting the nearly $3.5 billion of contracts and letters of intent to be signed during his trip. [D6.]
 
Markets

HEADLINE: Drownings of Haitians Rise As Island Exodus Continues

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 5

 BODY:
As the number of Haitians seeking to flee the country by boat continues to rise, the number of people drowning at sea is also mounting.
Many here say that rough seas and the flimsiness of the craft many Haitians use in attempting their flight will create even more casualties if the exodus of people by boats continues. 
 In the latest accident, about 150 people drowned on Monday near the coastal city of St.-Marc, about 100 miles northwest of Port-au-Prince, the capital. According to news reports and diplomats, more than 300 people were crammed aboard a 40-foot vessel when rough waves capsized it.
The danger is all too familiar to Haitians, who refer to attempts to flee by sea as "taking a shark visa."
 
Four Killings a Day
 For many here, a boat trip, despite its risks, is more attractive than staying in Haiti, where military leaders have increased their campaign of terror. Every morning at least four mutilated bodies are found in the capital. A common method of killing is to put a bullet through the temple. The victims' arms are usually tied behind their backs and the bodies are dumped in garbage heaps.
Human rights workers here say that the campaign of violence increased last fall, after the military realized that diplomatic efforts to restore the country's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, had failed.
The terror campaign, aimed largely at wiping out resistance to the military's rule, has relied on other techniques, like raping women and burning down entire neighborhoods, human rights workers say. The workers say as many as 20 rapes a month have been reported in recent months.
In a communique issued late Monday, the military-backed government of Emile Jonassaint accused the United States Coast Guard of picking up Haitian fishermen at sea in an attempt to inflate the official figures on the number of Haitians trying to flee.
United States officials here deny the assertion strongly.
"That's ridiculous," said Stanley Schrager, an American Embassy spokesman. "This de facto government is obviously embarrassed by the number of people leaving."
 
Highest One-Day Total
 On Monday 3,247 Haitians were interdicted by Coast Guard cutters patrolling the Windward Passage. It was the largest number of refugees picked up in a single day since Haitians began to take to the seas in large numbers after the coup that overthrew Father Aristide.
The United States Embassy has expanded a radio campaign in which it broadcasts messages intended to discourage Haitians from fleeing. The minute-long Creole-language broadcasts, which began June 13, tell Haitians that economic refugees will not receive asylum, that the United States is not "a land where the streets are paved with gold" and that Haitians can apply for asylum at one of the three processing centers in Haiti.
The latest exodus of Haitians began after President Clinton announced on May 8 that he was reversing his policy of summarily returning Haitians without first granting them an interview to judge whether they should be granted refugee status.
In a move intended to discourage the tide of boat people, the Administration announced today that it would no longer accept Haitian refugees to the United States. Instead, Haitians picked up at sea will be granted an interview and those deemed to be fleeing economic hardship will be returned to Haiti. Those determined to have a well-founded fear of persecution if they are returned will be sent to temporary camps in Panama until Father Aristide is returned to Haiti.
While the main destination of those who flee has been the United States, advocates of refugee rights say that the new policy will not significantly reduce the number of boat people, many of whom are escaping a wave of terror and increasing economic hardship.
"It's a terrible tragedy," said Anne Fuller, associate director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees. "There is no easy way to stop it. We have to make it so that people don't have a reason to leave."

HEADLINE: Clinton Focusing on the World Economy

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
President Clinton declared today that United States security and the success of his Presidency are tied to economic growth worldwide, and that the major industrial nations have a rare chance "to create jobs in a world of prosperity."
Just before leaving for Europe and the annual summit meeting of the seven major industrial democracies, Mr. Clinton used a gathering of business leaders and diplomats at the Commerce Department to make the case that his policies have revived the economy and asserted global leadership. 
 "Now we have to use this new-found strength to address how to give the citizens of our nation and all other nations the confidence they need to prosper in uncertain times," he said. "We have to move from coping with crises to planning for prosperity.
"In other words, we have to lay the foundation for the 21st-century economy, one in which change will be the order of the day, and the real question will be whether change is our friend or our enemy."
 
Begins Eight-Day Trip
 Mr. Clinton left Washington this evening for an eight-day trip, beginning with a speech in Riga, Latvia, and a stop in Warsaw before the four-day economic summit meeting begins Friday in Naples. Afterward he will stop in Bonn and Berlin, giving a speech at the Brandenburg Gate, which once marked the line between the free and Communist sectors.
Today Mr. Clinton sought to unite all the stops under a single theme: that the ability of the United States to promote economic expansion is the key to peace and political stability worldwide. That message plays to the Administration's foreign-policy strengths -- increasing trade and investment -- and by implication plays down its changeable and less fruitful military policies in Haiti and Bosnia.
Asserting pointedly that a "decade of drift" in Washington's fiscal policy had made it impossible for the industrial powers to take concerted economic actions, Mr. Clinton said his policies had rebuilt Washington's credibility and ended the summit meetings' recent status as high-powered photo opportunities.
"For a decade, our out-of-control budget deficit robbed us of the standing to press our partners to act," he said. "Well now, instead of having the biggest deficit in the G-7, we have among the smallest." G-7 is bureaucratic shorthand for the Group of Seven, as the members style themselves.
Mr. Clinton was referring to one common yardstick of government debt, the ratio between a nation's annual budget deficit and its gross domestic product. In absolute terms, the United States' $4.5 trillion Federal debt and its $200 billion-or-so deficit for the current fiscal year dwarf those of the six other countries.
The President also pointed to a tentative accord lowering trade barriers and the North American Free Trade Agreement as evidence that he has etched his foreign policy in economic terms.
Indeed he said "the purpose of my Presidency" is to harness sweeping changes in trade, technology and economic growth for the world's benefit.
Mr. Clinton estimated that if the industrial nations carry out the new world trade agreement, it will create 500,000 jobs in the United States and reduce tariffs by nearly $750 billion over the next decade.
"We have shown that bit by bit, year by year, the decisions made at these G-7 meetings can change the world," he added.
Mr. Clinton said the leaders are also to begin planning what he called the "nerve system" of the new economy -- global computer networks to exchange ideas and money. They also will discuss environmental concerns and will meet with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to explore ways to integrate western economies with those of eastern Europe.

HEADLINE: Business Leaders Urge Gun Restrictions

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 5

 BODY:
Gun control is good for the economy, business leaders said today, adding their voices to those urging passage of new gun restrictions by the Legislature.
Gun control "is a public safety issue, but it is also an economic development issue of the first order," said Timothy J. Moynihan, president of the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce. 
 On the eve of a special legislative session, Mr. Moynihan and about a dozen other business and community leaders gathered at the state Capitol to urge passage of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s gun control package.
Violence in Hartford's neighborhoods has hurt business and life in the city's downtown and led some residents and businesses to leave the area, the business officials said.
Mr. Moynihan asked gun owners and sportsmen to join the efforts to win passage of Governor Weicker's proposal to tighten the flow of handguns and stiffen the penalties for gun-related crimes.
"The bill is directed at the criminal use of weapons . . . not at the sportsmen," said Mr. Moynihan.
