HEADLINE: THE SIMPSON CASE: THE HOMETOWN;
Where Thoughts of Simpson Linger

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2

 BODY:
At the Potrero Terrace Market, a short uphill walk from where O. J. Simpson grew up in a housing project, Jack Woo watched the first week of televised court proceedings against his former customer and offered his own snap analysis. "So far, so good," Mr. Woo said. "Not much evidence against O. J."
He remembers an 8-year-old boy who used to come in, the picture of politeness and youthful energy. "Give me a bubble gum, Mr. Woo; give me Bazooka bubble gum," the market owner, now 70, recalled his words. 
 Mr. Woo also remembers, many years later, a sleek black limousine slowing at the curb outside his store. Mr. Simpson, now a famous sports figure, rolled down his back-seat window to offer an outstretched hand.
The corner food market is one of the landmarks of Mr. Simpson's youth, and it is flooded with memories. Simpson family members still visit, sometimes to shop, sometimes to banter. Mr. Simpson's older brother, Truman, stopped by last week and was treated to free slices of salami.
 
'He's All Right'
 These places, far from the city's clanging streetcars and waterfront tourist attractions, are filled with echoes of Mr. Simpson's life. Mr. Woo keeps a signed photograph of him on a shelf, in front of the cheap champagne.
"I know O. J., and he's not the kind of guy who would do something like this," Mr. Woo said of the murder charges Mr. Simpson faces in the slaying of his former wife and a friend of hers. "Maybe somebody framed him. He's a good man. He's a gentleman. He's all right."
Down the hill is the Potrero Terrace housing project where Mr. Simpson came of age. In a dense morning fog, the dozens of low-rise buildings grip the hillsides with an almost Mediterranean charm. Their paint is creamy tan, and their roofs are tiles of red clay. Monterey pines and eucalyptuses tower in clumps over what, on closer inspection, are worn boxy buildings, some with boarded-up windows and graffiti-strewn walls.
On the steep rise of Connecticut Street, near the apartment where Mr. Simpson used to live, the view south is of Candlestick Park, where a young O. J. watched his idol, Willie Mays, play center field for the San Francisco Giants. When the boy was 13, Mr. Mays appeared at his front door, responding to an appeal from a youth counselor about a promising athlete straying into a young hardened tough.
 
Conflicting Views
 Herschel Brown, 49 and unemployed, lives on the same street as Mr. Simpson once did. He said he could outrun and outplay Mr. Simpson in their high school days. But he saw Mr. Simpson's star rise, not his. He has never left the projects.
Mr. Brown blames the liquor bottle and bouts of rheumatic fever for his own failures. Yet he said his former schoolmate's current troubles made him reflect on the perils of fame. The old neighborhood saw less of Mr. Simpson after he was awarded the Heisman Trophy, he said.
"Some of them get like that when they get up there," Mr. Brown said airily. "After he made it, he didn't care about the other brothers. He didn't come around. I guess the high life went to his head."
But just up the hill on Arkansas Street, a route a young O. J. scrambled up to get to the Potrero Hill Recreation Center, that sentiment is not shared. A mural of the hard-charging back, wearing No. 32 for the Buffalo Bills, is painted high above the entrance of the green bunkerlike building. Mr. Simpson played baseball and tag football on the center's athletic field and met friends there after school.
Mr. Simpson has quietly helped the center with equipment, awards and field trips for neighborhood children, said Jon Greenberg, the director. Another large picture of Mr. Simpson hangs above the gleaming basketball court where 12-year-old Marquez White was dribbling a basketball.
 
Questions About Heroes
 The seventh grader said he believed completely in the sports star's innocence. He could not explain why, saying only, "They're going to let him go, I bet." The boy said he had not thought much about Mr. Simpson before his arrest. For his part, Marquez said he wanted to become a professional baseball player.
It is unfortunate, said Otis McGee Jr., that so many young people look to sports figures as their only models.
As a teen-ager, Mr. McGee, who is now a civil lawyer here, got to know Mr. Simpson through a social group called the Superiors at the Booker T. Washington Community Service Center, a cross-town bus ride from where Mr. Simpson lived.
The group of about 15 teen-agers paid a quarter a week in club dues and organized dinners, fund-raising events and dances heated up with recorded music by the Temptations and the Four Tops. Mr. Simpson was known as a natural leader who could corral other members into regularly attending meetings. Their common bond was sports.
 
A Center of Support
 But Mr. McGee eventually turned to the law books, while his friend went on to the high-profile world of sports. Just as the accusations against Mr. Simpson have dismayed the lawyer, so has all the talk about the fall of another role model. If there is one cautionary message in the scandal, Mr. McGee said, it is that the ball field is not the only place that young people can find heroes.
"They need to be looking to leaders throughout the community," he said. "They need to be looking at more than just athletes as people to emulate."
In Mr. Simpson's life, there are some places that have served not only as landmarks, but also as bedrocks. The Evergreen Missionary Baptist Church is one such place. Mr. Simpson's mother, Eunice, is the Sunday school pianist there, but she has been out sick since her son's arrest.
Last Sunday, Mae Wooten bowed her head and prayed hard for the Simpson family. The 70-year-old church member, dressed in a pink dress and matching hat, remembers Mr. Simpson as a young boy who obediently attended Sunday school. As an adult, he visited the church two or three times a year and supplied fruit for the Christmas program.
Mrs. Wooten said she would remain tight-lipped about Mr. Simpson now. But it has not stopped her tears.
"We are hurt, very hurt, and we are concerned," she said. "We are a church that is one for all and all for one. When one person is in trouble and having a hard time, we all feel it."

Mr. Woo, 72, who held a photograph of Mr. Simpson, has owned the Potrero Terrace Market for 34 years. One customer was the future sports star. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Goal! Goal! How Italian Scored Big With Voters

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FLORENCE

 BODY:
Time was, especially in a World Cup year, when a stranger could walk into any bar in Italy, order a beer or an espresso, and find instant camaraderie simply by offering the toast, "Forza Italia!" It was about as safe as shouting "How 'bout them Cowboys!" at a Super Bowl party in Dallas.
Nowadays, depending on the bar and its clientele, the stranger could just as easily be picking a fight. Ever since Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi co-opted Italy's national cheer as the name of his new party, "Forza Italia" has become a muted cry. 
For one thing, it is hard to tell whether the proverbial stranger is uttering a sporting exhortation or making a political speech.
The association, of course, is intended. Mr. Berlusconi, owner of the AC Milan soccer team as well as television stations, newspapers and magazines, is nothing if not a marketing genius. Part of his political power base is built on political clubs named Forza Italia that he established throughout Italy, a country in which soccer is the national passion and politics the pastime.
In fact, the early betting on the duration of Mr. Berlusconi's political honeymoon was linked by some to the success of Italy's national soccer team in the World Cup. The new Prime Minister invited the comparisons, warning the team, hopefully in jest, before they left for the United States that if they came back too soon he would lift their passports.
[So far, so good. On Tuesday, Italy won a place in the quarterfinals by narrowly defeating Nigeria, 2-1, with a penalty kick in overtime. SportsWednesday, page B9.]
 
Unkind Words for Mitterrand
 Oddly enough, Mr. Berlusconi received a big political boost from the most unlikely of sources. Criticism of his inclusion of neo-Fascists in his Government by Belgium, Greece and, most of all, President Francois Mitterrand of France has rallied even the Prime Minister's most ardent enemies to his side. Italians have never taken kindly to outsiders who try to tell them how to run their country, especially the French.
"I haven't voted in 15 years," an Italian businessman in Orvieto explained to a visiting American. "But Italian voters elected Berlusconi democratically. When Clinton came here he didn't make an issue about who was in the Government. Mitterrand has no right to say anything about a government freely elected."
It was a sentiment expressed even more forcefully in Monteriggioni, a ancient fortress town near Siena. Encircled by 13 stone towers that Dante compared to giants in "The Inferno," and that still look like a medieval crown set upon a Tuscan hill, Monteriggioni is in the heart of what was once called the Red Zone for its solid Communist vote.
"I'll tell you who is Fascist," a waiter at a local restaurant assured a visitor, conceding that he himself had still voted for "the left," as the Communists are now known. "Le Pen is a Fascist. Mitterrand should worry about his own Fascists in France and keep quiet about Italy."
But Mr. Berlusconi seems bent on reminding the public of the neo-Fascist tint to his Cabinet as well its connection to the soccer team. The governing bloc in Parliament now refers to itself as the Azzurri, or "the Blues," the nickname of the Italian team, and the Prime Minister himself is sometimes known as "Il Azzurro," or "Big Blue." If Azzurri does not carry quite the same menace as "the brown shirts" or Il Azzurro fails to convey the same bombast as Il Duce, the names still keep eyebrows raised.
 
Italy Jumps Into Cyberspace
 For many in Italy, however, the dangers Mr. Berlusconi represent are more in his vision of the new Italy he promised voters and his vague plans for "development." After decades of dog paddling in the backwater of modern technology, Italy has moved into cyberspace at full throttle.
Every country inn on the back roads of Tuscany and Umbria now has a fax, and cellular phones constantly beep all along the cobbled streets of hill towns that once only heard bells from ancient campaniles.
At lunch the other day at an old farmhouse-turned-restaurant between San Sepolcro and Monterchi, two sleepy towns known more for their Piero frescoes than as hectic commercial centers, local business executives chattered away on their cellular phones with more urgency that movie moguls doing lunch at Spago.
"When Berlusconi talks of development," a Florentine documentary film maker warned, "what he means is that he wants to turn Italy into a nation of malls and industrial parks."
In the end, the new Government will succeed or fail on whether the Prime Minister can find solutions to the country's very real fiscal problems. Italy is suffering from a galloping trade deficit and creeping inflation, and the lira, never the sturdiest of currencies, would not buy Baltic Avenue at current exchange rates.
Still, this is a World Cup year, making it hard to separate the fortunes of the new Government in Rome with those of the Italian soccer team in the United States. Discussing Italy's mediocre showing in the first round, the owner of a popular coffee bar in Piazza Commune in Assisi said: "We have to face the facts. Italy has become marginal."
It could just as easily have been a political observation.

HEADLINE: Turmoil in Haiti Dims Future of Its Students

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 5

 BODY:
Like most other children of eighth-grade age here, Yves St. Hilaire has never known regular schooling.
This year Haiti's schools were open for a total of about five months as classes were delayed, interrupted and then abruptly ended because of the economic sanctions and ensuing turmoil. It has been like this since February 1986, when a popular uprising forced Haiti's President, Jean-Claude Duvalier, to flee the country. 
 "It's discouraging," Yves said the other day. "Most of what I know comes by watching television."
As the nation struggles with its economic and political problems and as thousands of Haitians flee, the long-term question that concerns some Haitians left behind is whether their nation can become a true democracy when a generation of children -- about two million school-age youngsters from rich families and poor -- is growing up without adequate educations.
 
Deteriorating Public Schools
 Most of the children in the country's poor majority attend schools that are deteriorating -- when they are open. Parents still pay an entry fee of $10 a year, but that barely covers operating expenses, let alone books and teachers' salaries.
With Haiti's bureaucracy turning over with each change in leadership -- there have been nine such changes since 1986 -- statistics are hard to come by. But it is a given that in recent years the Haitian Government has done little to support public education, spending only about 8 percent of its budget on education. Teachers seldom receive paychecks, so the best emigrate to the United States, Canada and Europe.
Even the once-vaunted system of private schools is crumbling: many are closed. The few private schools that remain open are seeing student enrollment dwindle, since many parents can no longer afford the $30-a-month average tuition that is the schools' sole source of revenue.
The College St. Pierre, a private school in Port-au-Prince that Yves attended, is typical. Classrooms are Spartan: there are no wall charts, no letters of the alphabet, no maps, no libraries, no laboratories, sometimes no lights. There is a blackboard and chalk, and students sit on long wooden benches.
 
'Consequences Are Grave'
 "If this continues, a Haitian student will be worthless," said Roger Petit-Frere, a history professor at the University of Haiti. "It's a phenomenon that parents are beginning to feel. And the consequences are grave because the schools do not serve the people."
The failings of today contrast sharply with the achievements of three decades ago. Haiti's public and private schools were then the envy of the Caribbean. Haitian graduates, well versed in French, were a catch for foreign governments and educational institutions. Haitian-educated administrators and intellectuals were heavily recruited to run schools and government offices in the emerging Francophone countries throughout Africa.
That all started changing in the 1960's. The quality of Haiti's public schools eroded as the Duvalier Government withdrew its support. Eventually, the nation became divided into educational haves and have nots.
At the same time, neither the public nor the private schools here have modernized their curriculums.
Like most institutions in Haiti, the schools are based on a rigid 19th-century French aristocratic system. The schools, which extend two grades beyond American high schools, emphasize Latin, Greek, mathematics and the sciences. Students learn largely through memorization. Lecturing is the norm, and the teacher's authority is seldom questioned.
 
Classics, but No Computers
 And while France long ago modernized its educational system, Haiti has lagged behind. Classes are still taught in French instead of Creole, which every Haitian now speaks. Computer literacy has yet to join the classics in the curriculum.
"We have to radically rethink our way of teaching," Mr. Petit-Frere said. "We are falling behind."
Michel Soukar, director of the College of Port-au-Prince and a radio commentator who has advocated changes in the school system, agreed. "The system is broken," he said. "It all goes hand-in-hand with the country's economic system. You cannot rebuild the educational system without knowing what economic course you are taking."
The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was elected President in December 1990, promised to fix the system and to provide a decent education for every Haitian child. But his administration, which ended in September 1991 when the military arrested and expelled Father Aristide from the country, was too short-lived to make good on his promises.
For students, the turmoil, violence and deterioration has been devastating.
"There's no future for us," said Sherley Louis, an 11th grader, at the public High School for Girls in Port-au-Prince, who said she would like to study medicine when she graduates. "Haiti does not allow us to live our dreams."
Martine Mabial, a 12th grader at College George Marc, a private school here, agreed. "I am going to school, but I really don't know why," she said. "Sometimes I ask God where this is going to lead."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Beset by economic and political turmoil, Haiti finds its educational system all but broken. In a crumbling schoolyard at a parochial school in Port-au-Prince, children played last month during a classroom break. (Daniel Morel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Shortage In Builders Cited

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
Builders in the United States report a shortage of skilled construction workers as they meet demand for new housing, especially in the Midwest and Southwest, a trade group said today.
The Associated Builders and Contractors said a survey of its 80 chapters determined that the 18-month-old recovery in housing was "taking its toll on the available pool of skilled labor." 
 Shortages of skilled workers are the most severe in Kansas, Oklahoma, Iowa, Nebraska, Indiana, Ohio, Wisconsin and Michigan, the trade group said. Shortages are also reported in Arizona, Utah, Colorado, Georgia and Florida.
But labor surpluses were reported in Alabama, California, Connecticut, Hawaii, Maine, New York, and Corpus Christi, Tex., and vicinity.
Builders "are scrambling to find enough craftsmen to get their projects built and are in some cases turning away work -- an unthinkable prospect a couple years ago," Leo Anhalt, president of the trade group, said.
Builders' labor costs could increase significantly if the demand for housing remains strong. "If they're busy and need people, they'll bid for them," Paul Kasriel, an economist for Northern Trust in Chicago, said.
Last week, the Commerce Department reported that sales of new single-family houses rose 4.2 percent in May even as mortgage rates climbed to a two-year high.

HEADLINE: Old Enemies Now Allied Against Crime

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 5

 BODY:
The director of the F.B.I., Louis J. Freeh, signed an agreement today to cooperate with Russian authorities in the fight against Russian-based organized crime.
Mr. Freeh and the Russian Interior Minister, Viktor Yerin, said that both countries were at risk from well-funded criminal gangs, parts of which have increasingly broad international connections. The prevalence of organized crime in Russia and the evident corruption of many underpaid officials and policemen are widely considered to be undermining the faith of ordinary Russians in market-oriented economic changes. 
 Opinion polls suggest that Russians regard criminals as the major beneficiaries of these changes, including the privatization of state property.
"Much remains to be done," Mr. Yerin said, "so that the professionalism, honesty, orderliness of every worker of the Interior Ministry organs will meet the standards of the society we are building together."
Mr. Freeh, who was quick to admit that the United States has a severe organized-crime problem of its own, praised draft anti-corruption legislation now before the Russian Parliament.
 
Exchange of Information
 The protocol signed today calls for the exchange of information among police forces, cooperation in investigations, the detention of alleged criminals in each other's countries and the training of Russian officers in the F.B.I.'s more modern techniques.
Both sides also welcomed the establishment of a legal attache office of the F.B.I. in the American Embassy here, which will house two F.B.I. agents. Although office space has not yet been set aside and the first agent to be assigned here will first undergo six months of language training, liaison with Russian authorities will continue, as in the past, through regular visits by European-based agents.
The Germans and Finns already have similar offices here, and the Italians are about to open one.
Mr. Freeh said he would welcome a similar Interior Ministry office in Washington at the Russian Embassy, though he said there had been no formal request for one so far.
Mr. Freeh left Moscow today after a two days of meetings with the chiefs of the Russian domestic security apparatus, including Mr. Yerin; the director of the Federal Counterintelligence Service (the domestic branch of the old K.G.B); the national security adviser; the deputy Justice Minister and the First Deputy Prime Minister, Oleg Soskovets.
 
No Meeting With Yeltsin
 He did not get to see President Boris N. Yeltsin, however, despite a request from the American Embassy.
American officials said that among the issues that brought Mr. Freeh here were concerns over narcotics trafficking from Colombia to Europe through Russia, the illegal transfer of money and the impact of Russian gangs among Russian emigres in the United States, especially in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn.
Mr. Freeh also stressed the risks of nuclear proliferation through the efforts of organized crime to steal or buy weapons-grade nuclear material, calling the possibility "the greatest long-term threat to the security of the United States."
Russian officials, including Mr. Yerin today, said there was no evidence of any such theft of weapons-grade nuclear materials or any nuclear materials from power plants, though much lower-grade fissionable material used in health care and "welding quality control" had been stolen. There were currently 50 such criminal cases under investigation, Mr. Yerin said.
 
The 'No. 1 Threat'
 American diplomats have said that responsibility for nuclear proliferation actually lies with the C.I.A. and Defense Intelligence Agency, not with the F.B.I. But Mr. Freeh said today that his agency intended to become more involved in anti-proliferation issues outside the United States, citing a law that gives the bureau, he said, "extraterritorial jurisdiction with respect to investigating and interdicting the illegal transfer of nuclear materials." He added: "I'm happy to report that we haven't used that jurisdiction much."
Mr. Yeltsin has called organized crime "the No. 1 threat to Russia's strategic interests and national security" and accused Russian criminals of "trying to take the country by the throat."
Russian Interior Ministry officials have said that some 5,600 gangs operate from Russia, averaging about 20 members each, and with little coordination and many rivalries over turf. Some of them are engaged only in vice or protection rackets. But an official said that some 160 gangs have international connections, large sums of money and operate in more than 30 countries.
The gangs deal in drugs, prostitution, oil, minerals, arms and money laundering, all across the former empire's still porous borders. Russian gangs have also threatened a number of Russian and Western businessmen, seeking protection money or partnerships.

HEADLINE: New Bosnia Peace Plan Has Serb Corridor

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Switzerland, July 5

 BODY:
The United States, Russia and the European Union unveiled a new plan today to end the war in Bosnia that they described as a "peaceful ultimatum" and a last chance to avoid a mounting conflict in the area.
"It would be a mistake of historic proportions for either party to believe they can serve their people well by rejecting this plan," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said after a sometimes strained meeting of foreign ministers here. 
 The plan is the latest of many international efforts to draw lines through the ethnic confusion of Bosnia, but it is the first in which the United States Government has actively participated. It will be formally handed to the warring parties on Wednesday and they will be given two weeks to respond.
The new map offers 51 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina to a Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia, linking the now marooned Muslim enclaves of Srebrenica, Zepa and Gorazde in eastern Bosnian, and connecting them in turn to the Sarajevo area, the United States special envoy to the Bosnian peace talks, Charles E. Redman, said.
The proposed map offers the remaining 49 percent to the Bosnian Serbs, including a crucial corridor near the northern town of Brcko that would link Serbian holdings in eastern and western Bosnia, Mr. Redman said.
 
Serb Corridor Is Crucial
 The Serbs, who control about 70 percent of Bosnia after 27 months of fighting in Europe's worst conflict since World War II, have rejected earlier peace proposals because they failed to provide this corridor.
"This plan preserves the state of Bosnia as a single state within its international boundaries," Mr. Christopher insisted in an attempt to clarify that the United States is not underwriting the carving up of Bosnia.
It was far from clear, however, how the Muslim-Croat federation and the Serbian entity would be constitutionally linked or what would prevent the Serbs from eventually opting for their long expressed desire -- union with neighboring Serbia.
It was also unclear what -- beyond extreme fatigue with the war -- had led the Clinton Administration to prefer this map to earlier ones.
The foreign ministers described the plan as a "turning point" and Andrei V. Kozyrev, the Russian Foreign Minister, said it constituted a "peaceful ultimatum." But the means by which the ultimatum would be enforced, including how an arms embargo on Bosnia might eventually be lifted, were left somewhat unclear amid clear signs of difficulties at today's meeting.
 
Many Issues Unresolved
 In the end, no communique was issued on the incentives and punishments to be presented to the parties, and the eventual lifting of the arms embargo was mentioned only as an alternative that would be adopted if all else failed.
Mr. Kozyrev said that if the Muslim-led Bosnian Government agreed to the plan, it would receive substantial aid for the reconstruction of Bosnia.
If the Serbs agreed to a withdrawal to the lines on the proposed map -- a surrender of close to a third of the territory they hold -- a progressive lifting of an international trade embargo that has crippled the Serbian economy would follow.
Alluding to what might happen if the Bosnian Government accepts the plan and the Serbs reject it, Mr. Kozyrev added that, "As an extreme measure, removing the arms embargo may be inevitable." Mr. Christopher said that "at the end of the day," lifting the arms embargo could become "a very strong possibility."
In effect it was clear that any lifting of the embargo would only come as a last resort, after several months and elaborate preparations.
 
Little Mention of Embargo
 The embargo has enraged the Government of President Alija Izetbegovic because it locked in a huge Serbian advantage in weaponry and has often appeared to lead to the widespread slaughter of Muslim civilians by Serbs.
President Clinton has been under growing pressure from Congress to lift the embargo. But Russia, a traditional ally of the Serbs, is deeply reluctant to endorse such a move and West European governments are worried that their troops in Bosnia would be endangered.
Indeed Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France and Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd of Britain both made clear today that their contingents in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia would almost certainly be removed if the arms embargo were lifted.
"There is a contradiction between lifting the arms embargo and maintaining the peacekeeping mission," Mr. Juppe said. "We would draw our conclusions."
Mr. Kozyrev said that "nothing new" had been decided on using the threat of NATO air strikes to enforce the plan. But Mr. Christopher said a tougher enforcement of weapon-exclusion zones around towns such as Tuzla and Gorazde would be "a way to ensure that there are consequences if one side agrees and the other does not."
 
Muslims Studying the Plan
 Haris Silajdzic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, held a meeting today with Mr. Christopher and said his Government would study the new plan carefully.
President Alija Izetbegovic said "it would not be wise to reject the plan fully."
There was no immediate reaction from the Bosnian Serbs, whose leader Radovan Karadzic last week described the proposed map as "humiliating for the winning side."
There have been clear signs in recent weeks that the Bosnian and Croatian Governments are preparing for a coordinated offensive against the Serbs in the fall if the latest peace initiative fails.
Mr. Christopher reiterated that if a peace agreement were reached, the United States would probably be ready to commit troops to police and to enforce the accord.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds in Lull As Traders Watch Fed

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
As Federal Reserve policy makers began meeting in Washington yesterday, bond traders sat on their hands, watching and waiting for something that most of them did not expect to happen, at least this week: an official increase in short-term interest rates.
As a result, Treasury securities ended the day almost unchanged. The yield on the bellwether 30-year bond edged down, to 7.58 percent, from 7.60 percent. The bond's price, which moves in the opposite direction from its yield, rose 6/32 , to 8414/32 . 
 Bond prices had started to slip early in the day, but were buoyed by a decline in commodity futures, a leading indicator of inflation. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of commodity futures dropped more than 3 points, its first decline in almost two months.
 
Fears of Inflation
 Inflation fears always weigh heavily on the minds of participants in the bond market, because inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments.
But such fears tend to be particularly acute when the Fed's Open Market Committee is meeting, as it continues to do today, to set interest-rate policy for the next six weeks.
Yesterday, an Administration official said there did not seem to be any attempt to dissuade the Fed from a rate increase in case it might be so inclined. Laura d'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economic adviser, has not raised the subject with Alan S. Blinder, her former colleague who was just sworn in as the Fed's vice chairman and is attending his first open-market meeting, the official said.
If the Fed decides that the economy is growing too fast and that inflation is heating up, it will likely raise short-term rates, as it has already done four times since February.
Short-term interest rates have indeed risen sharply. Three-month Treasury bills, which began the year at a rate of about 3 percent, were auctioned yesterday at a discount rate of 4.31 percent, up from last week's 4.20 percent. Six-month bills were sold at a discount rate of 4.74 percent, up from 4.60 percent a week ago and the highest rate since early May.
Long-term rates have also jumped since they hit bottom in October; at that point, the 30-year Treasury bond was yielding about 6 percent.
Though traders were not so confident in their opinions that they bid up the price of bonds, few market analyst expect the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, to announce another rate increase today or tomorrow. They note that employment data, scheduled to be released on Friday, may help clarify how fast the economy is growing, and thus whether inflation is really a threat. Recent economic forecasts have been all over the lot, depending on whether economists focus on production, which seems strong, or consumer demand, which seems weak.
 
Guessing About Greenspan
 "My personal guess is that at this point, Mr. Greenspan and company would like to hold off a little longer, to have the chance to weigh the effects of higher interest rates," said Laurence L. Kreicher, a senior vice president and economist at Alliance Capital Management.
One reason the Fed may be willing to wait for more evidence of inflation, he added, is that in August, Mr. Greenspan must appear before Congress to explain his policies -- and Congress has been increasingly critical of the Fed's actions. "I think he'd like to be able to say, 'We're not letting our guard down against inflation, and if necessary, we'll tighten again in the future,' " Mr. Kreicher said. "He doesn't want to say, 'I think there's a bogyman in the closet and that's why I tightened.' "
There has been some speculation that the Fed would raise interest rates in an effort to bolster the dollar, which is trading at postwar lows against the Japanese yen and has also been falling against the German mark. But yesterday, the betting was against a rate increase for that reason.
"We would say it's unlikely," said Scott F. Grannis, a director of the Western Asset Management Company in Pasadena, Calif. "The Fed's traditional focus is, if they take care of the economy, the dollar will take care of itself."
That might not be the case if the falling dollar were really likely to make inflation worse, Mr. Grannis said, but the United States economy is too big for that to be a problem. "The economy is the dog, the dollar is the tail, and it will not wag the dog."
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Stocks End Day Mixed, With the Dow Up 5.83

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, following the lead of the dollar, bonds and commodity prices. After opening narrowly lower, blue-chip issues were able to quickly reverse course amid strength in the oil sector.
Aside from that, many market participants either did not make it back from the holiday weekend yet, or they simply preferred to await the outcome of the meeting of the Federal Reserve's open market committee, the Fed's policy-making arm, that began yesterday and concludes today. 
 The markets are wary of another rate increase by the Fed. Some analysts have expressed the belief that the Fed will raise interest rates to protect the dollar, while others say coming data about the economy will act as the trigger to the next credit tightening. That could come sooner rather than later, or not until the Fed sees a clear trend developing. But a growing number of investors in the market are starting to say it may come next month.
 
195.4 Million Shares Traded
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.83 points to finish at 3,652.48, in lighter than normal volume of 195.4 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
Market sentiment was almost split down the middle as the number of advancing issues barely surpassed the number of decliners, 1,091 to 1,030.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.17 point, to 446.37. The Big Board composite also rose 0.17 point, to 246.51. In Nasdaq trading the composite index dropped 3.26 points, to 703.59, while the American Stock Exchange composite slipoped 1.02 points, to 423.70.
In the related markets, bond prices moved slightly higher as the 30-year Treasury yield, which moves in the opposite direction of price, moved lower to 7.58 percent. On Friday, the yield was 7.60 percent.
Commodity prices as measured by the Commodity Research Bureau index, a barometer of inflation, also helped to stablize bond prices, as the CRB fell 3.30 points, to 226.73.
"Except for the Dow industrial average, the markets showed little movement, reflecting a belief by traders that the Federal Reserve may wait until Friday's June unemployment report before taking any action in interest rates," Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc., said.
"We're getting close to a turning point, but we may have to test the April lows once more before starting the anticipated summer rally," Mr. Laubscher said. Those April lows on the Dow, he said, were around 3,520 and 3,550.
However, Mr. Laubscher said, "any move below 3,600 would signal traders to start buying some of the better looking groups, such as aluminum, oil well service stocks, major oils, drugs, hospital supplies and papers."
 
Texaco Restructuring Plan
 Texaco, up 3/4, to 60 7/8, led the oil group higher after announcing a restructuring plan to cut costs by $300 million. Analysts saw the plan as a response to pressure from the investment community. The analysts also pointed out that most major international oil stocks were higher despite softness in the price of crude. Other gainers included Royal Dutch, up 2 1/8, to 107 1/8 for its American depository receipts; Mobil, up 1 3/8, to 82 5/8; Shell Transport, up 1, to 64, and Chevron, up 1/2, to 42 7/8.
Along with Texaco, Caterpillar, up 1 1/8, to 101 3/4, and Boeing, up 3/4, to 47 1/8, accounted for most of the move in the Dow index yesterday, analysts at Birinyi Associates said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Corn, Soybeans and Coffee Lead a Broad-Based Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Commodity prices fell broadly yesterday, prompted by steep losses in corn, soybeans and coffee.
Wetter Midwestern weather caused the selloff and the collapse in grain prices. Coffee futures were affected by profit taking after a gain of 55 percent last week that was linked to frost damage in Brazil. 
 The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 3.30 points, to 226.73.
Corn and soybean futures prices dropped sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade as weather forecasts for the Midwest promised adequate moisture for corn pollination. Corn for July delivery fell 11 cents, to $2.37 a bushel, while July soybeans plunged 27 1/2 cents, to $6.15 1/2 a bushel.
Some contracts for deferred delivery of corn and soybeans fell their permitted daily limits of 12 cents and 30 cents a bushel, respectively.
Weekend rain and forecasts for more precipitation this week alleviated concerns about crop weather at the start of the three-week corn pollination phase, when adequate moisture is crucial.
"Certainly, we're going to need to see more rain in July, but there's good rain in the forecast and that's why we're going down," said Dan Cekander, grain analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. in Chicago.
He said hot temperatures in the region were expected to abate later this week as showers moved through.
"Heat is not a problem as long as we get the moisture," said Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter, Discover & Company in Chicago.
Corn and soybean crop conditions improved last week, the Agriculture Department said late yesterday in a weekly report released after trading ended.
Meanwhile, coffee prices fell as investment funds and other speculators took profits after a weekend with no further frost damage to the Brazilian crop. The freeze a week earlier is believed to have wiped out a quarter to a third of the 1994-95 crop in Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer.
Unroasted arabica coffee beans for July delivery fell 8.75 cents, to $1.847 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York. The July futures contract rose nearly 69 cents last week.
"The bottom line is that supplies are tight, and you're likely to see good roaster support under the market," said an analyst for Merrill Lynch, Judy Ganes.
The sinking commodity prices eroded inflation concerns, pushing precious metals lower. August gold fell $1.20, to $386.90 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while July silver fell 8.4 cents, to $5.321 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Message From Insiders Is 'Buy'

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The dollar is down, and interest rates are up. There is talk of a new bear market. In that atmosphere, who would want to buy stocks?
Corporate insiders. 
 Buying by insiders -- officers and directors of companies -- is by some measures running at its most intense since early 1991, when the stock market was taking off in the bull market that began with the Persian Gulf war.
"Insiders started picking up when the market bottomed," said David Coleman, the editor of Vickers Weekly Insider Report, a Washington newsletter that tracks insider buying and selling. "In 1987 and 1990, they did the same thing."
 
Reading the Signs
 Last week, Vickers recorded more purchases than sales among insiders whose stocks are listed on the New York or American Stock Exchanges, by a margin of five buys for each three sells. For the last eight weeks, the average such figure is almost even: 1.07 sells for every buy.
That may not sound all that bullish, but it is. Insiders have lots of ways to get their hands on stock before they resort to buying it on the open market. Many have shares from before the company went public. Even more get options to buy stock. Such options are often exercised at the same time the stock is sold, leaving the insider with no market risk.
As a result, there are almost always more open-market sales of stock by insiders than there are similar purchases. And while insider selling is often a warning of bad news, insider buying is viewed as an even better indicator of a stock's being worth consideration. After all, as many a corporate officer has explained, there are lots of reasons for an insider to sell besides bearishness. The insider wants to diversify investments, or pay for a new house, or college tuition. But there is no obvious reason to buy, except hope that the price will rise.
There is, of course, no guarantee that an insider will be right. And it is a crime for an insider to buy if he or she has material nonpublic information.
Nonetheless, as Mr. Coleman noted, "they are the people that know companies best, and when they start buying, that is a good signal."
A level of buying as high as the current one has often served as an indicator for the entire market. Vickers regards as bullish a ratio under 1.32 sales for each open-market buy.
Insiders are required to report their transactions to the Securities and Exchange Commission by the 10th day of the following month. Thus all June trades are due at the S.E.C. by next Monday. Many such reports still come in late, but stiffer rules -- including a requirement that companies report to shareholders why officers and directors were late in filing -- have improved the promptness of filing.
As a result, the ratios now being reported include activity in May, as well as June, and thus are somewhat behind the time in terms of actual activity.
Vickers compares the number of sales by insiders with the number of open-market purchases, regardless of the size. And while Vickers reports weekly figures -- last week's ratio of 0.61 sell to each buy was the second lowest in the last three years -- it focuses on an eight-week moving average to smooth out the data.
"Since October 1974, when we began plotting this data, the market has not failed to improve significantly when our eight-week sell-buy ratio fell below 1.0," Mr. Coleman said. The ratio fell below that figure last month, although it edged back up at the end of the month.
Mr. Coleman said he also computed a ratio showing the rate of change for the eight-week moving average. Rapid falls, he said, can warn that even an otherwise bullish indication is suspect, while fast rises can indicate that insider opinion is turning. That indicator, which was negative as recently as early May, has grown to its most positive level since, once again, 1991.
Among individual stocks, Mr. Coleman said he had seen considerable interest in a number of gambling stocks. Casinos were darlings of Wall Street in 1993, and a lot of insiders chose to sell then. But the stocks have been driven down this year, and recently there has been interest shown by insiders in such companies as Boyd Gaming, Circus Circus, Casino Magic, Station Casinos, Grand Casinos and Sahara Gaming.
Several real estate investment trusts have also seen insider interest, including Storage Equities, Partners Preferred Yield and Crescent Real Estate Equities.
And I.B.M. has had substantial insider buying, at prices from $55 to $58 and a bit higher, Mr. Coleman noted.

HEADLINE: Paramount Takes Write-Off

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
Paramount Communications Inc. has recorded a $20 million charge to reflect a decrease in the value of its derivatives, joining a growing list of companies harmed by these financial instruments.
Paramount, a New York-based entertainment and media company, was acquired by Viacom Inc. earlier this year in a deal that is to be formally completed soon. 
 Paramount listed the charge to reflect the current value of derivatives it holds in the form of interest rate swaps, according to a filing last week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Procter & Gamble, Dell Computer and Gibson Greetings Inc. have all reported losses from derivatives, the financial instruments that many companies use to limit their exposure to changes in currency prices and interest rates.
"There was a significant change in the market value of the swaps," a Viacom spokesman said. Paramount "had to adjust the reserve," he added, attributing the decrease in value to "the change in the interest rate environment."
Paramount appears to have recorded the charge in February or March, when a drastic increase in interest rates was taking place. The company did not include the charge in its results for the nine months ended Jan. 31, but did include the figure as a component of interest expense for the 11 months that ended on March 31.
Paramount filed a report for the 11-month period rather than the standard 12 months because the company recently changed the end of its fiscal year to March 31 from April 30.
The company entered into interest rate swap agreements that enabled it to exchange fixed-rate payments for variable-rate payments, the filing stated. In general, this type of swap would require Paramount to make payments to another party if interest rates rose and receive payments if interest rates fell.

HEADLINE: More Hope for Spinal Injuries

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
THE longstanding assumption that severe spinal cord injuries cause permanent, incurable paralysis is being challenged by studies suggesting that some "dead" nerve cells can revive or regenerate.
The findings open the possibility that doctors may one day be able to reverse part or all of the crippling caused by accidents that crush or sever the spinal cord. Most of the studies, conducted in animals, involve the transplantation of nerve cells from fetal spinal cords. 
 Nerve growth stimulants are already being used experimentally in people who suffer spinal injuries. When given soon after the injury occurs, the treatments seem to promote growth of nerve fibers, only a small percentage of which are needed to produce significant functional gains. And steroids now being used routinely within hours of the accident can limit the extent of damage to the spinal cord and often enable patients to regain at least some of the functions lost at the moment of impact.
Even after initial recovery, surgery to reduce pressure on the spinal cord or to remove cysts, which often form as a result of the injury, sometimes results in life-enhancing improvements, like the ability to get in and out of a wheelchair unaided or even to walk with special aids.
After the football player Dennis Byrd of the New York Jets was injured in 1992, he was treated with Sygen, an experimental drug that helps repair damaged spinal cord nerves, and steroids. Although initially he could not move his legs or arms, he can now walk.
 
Vital Links to Brain
 The spinal cord, the brain's link to the rest of the body, is like a telephone trunk line with 31 pairs of individual lines extending from it to transmit messages from the brain to the rest of the body and to send sensory signals from organs and tissues along the lines back to the brain. When the cord is severely injured or severed, communication is cut off to and from all points beneath the injury site, resulting in paralysis and loss of feeling.
The extent of crippling effects depends upon where the disruption occurs, with injuries higher up on the spine the most severe. Injuries to the cervical spine, in the neck, like those that occur in diving accidents, cause the greatest devastation. For example, people who have injured the cord at cervical vertebrae numbers 2 through 4 have no ability to move their upper and lower extremities, although there is some remaining control of neck muscles. In addition, those with cervical 2 injuries require breathing assistance. But if the injury occurs one vertebra lower, at cervical 5, patients can use their biceps, enabling them to take care of simple grooming tasks and feed themselves with the help of special equipment. Patients injured at cervical 6 are able to bathe themselves, drive and prepare simple meals.
Although paralysis occurs immediately when the spinal cord is severely injured, much of the permanent damage to nerve tissue takes place during the first four to six hours after the injury. Circulation is impaired and hemorrhages at the site further disrupt the oxygen supply, causing surrounding nerve cells to die. Swelling and scar tissue complicate matters, spreading the damage up and down the cord. Timely treatment with steroids and other drugs can limit the severity of the injury and the extent of paralysis and loss of sensation.
But the most exciting developments are still highly experimental, involving the transplantation of fetal nerve tissue to fill in the gap in the spinal cord or bypass the injury site. Many rats and some cats given fetal tissue implants following spinal cord injuries showed significant return of function. However, researchers say it will be at least a decade before such measures are tried in patients.
Meanwhile, at spinal treatment centers around the country, doctors and rehabilitation therapists are helping people with spinal cord injuries make the most of the functions that are intact and cope better with those that are not.
 
2 Sets of Goals
 Dr. Barth Green, who directs the Miami Project, which he describes as the world's largest spinal cord research center, said, "Our long-term goal is to reconnect the spinal cord, but our short-term goal is to improve the quality of life of spinal injured people."
At his and other centers, patients get help with such common problems as pain control, pressure sores, spasms, bladder function, sexuality and reproduction. The techniques used include surgery, biofeedback and computerized neuromuscular electrical stimulation.
Perhaps most challenging of all are the psychological adjustments required after a spinal cord injury. In a recent review of the problem in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. John F. Ditunno Jr. and Dr. Christopher S. Formal of Philadelphia noted that "the majority of people with chronic spinal injuries are not depressed" and that "the majority still rate their quality of life as 'good' or 'excellent.' "
Still, they added, the divorce rate is high during the first years after the injury, half of the patients who were working before the accident never return to work, and suicide is more frequent, especially among those who remain unemployed and socially isolated after the injury. Psychosocial and occupational therapy can be as important as physical rehabilitation in improving the lives of people with spinal cord injuries.

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
BAGELS have become a staple of the healthful eater as well as the dieter, taking the place of Danish pastries, croissants and even muffins for those pursuing fewer calories and less fat.
But those virtuous eaters are in for sticker shock. Even without a slathering of butter or cream cheese, some bagels sold in New York contain more than 500 calories each. 
 Call it bagel inflation. When bagels made their debut in New York at the beginning of the century, they weighed just two or three ounces. The United States Department of Agriculture has the quaint idea that bagels are still about the same weight as they were back then and provide about 150 to 200 calories each. But there's nothing uniform about bagels today.
In the beginning, bagels were small. They became hard in six or seven hours and were affectionately known as cement doughnuts. They were served with salty lox and a very thick layer of cream cheese, known as a shmeer, which helped moderate the saltiness of the lox.
Since Americans like everything big, bagels ballooned when they started to become as popular as doughnuts. Even traditionalists like Bagel Oasis in Queens have begun making bagels bigger, because everyone else does.
"We used to make 2 1/2-ounce bagels that had a crust on all sides," said Mike Edelstein, a partner in the bakery. "They had a crust that was hard," he said, knocking a counter for emphasis. "But now we've come down to making a more neutral bagel, not as tough, and it weighs four ounces."
Bagel Oasis still makes bagels by hand and still boils them before baking. But the company is an exception. It's hard to find a handmade bagel or a bagel that isn't all puffed up from the addition of dough conditioners.
For the first half of the century in New York, only members of the Bagel Bakers' Local 338 could make bagels. Today, anyone with $100,000 to $200,000 can buy a bagel bakery package, which includes cooking equipment and just about anything else you might need to start up, except the desire to make bagels the traditional way. It's not much different from buying a complete package to go into the coffee bar business.
Bagels were once flour, water and malt. Today, they may contain sugar or honey or even, if the word on the street is to be believed, Crisco or saccharin. And plain bagels have given way to blueberry bagels and cheese bagels and raisin-nut bagels and pizza bagels. When the calorie and fat tally for cheese and nuts is added, the healthy halo of the bagel disappears.
To find out where the standard bagel stands in relation to the contemporary New York bagel, plain bagels were collected from 15 bagel shops and markets in New York City. Most of the bagel shops make their own, but some buy from suppliers.
The bagels were delivered to Certified Analytical Group Inc. in Corona, Queens, for a weigh in. Most of them weighed at least half again as much as the standard Agriculture Department bagel. Some are three times as much -- it's easy to find a bagel that weighs six or seven ounces.
In the test, two bagels were bought from each of 10 shops, weighed and analylized for calories. An average of the two was calculated. In addition, bagels were bought from five other shops and simply weighed.
For those who believe bigger is better, Bagel on the Square was the winner. The average weight of a bagel there was seven ounces, with 552 calories per bagel. Pick a Bagel was not far behind, with a bagel that weighed on average just under seven ounces and contained 518 calories. Ess-a-Bagel and Dean & Deluca also had 500-plus bagels and Nosh a Bagel came in at 472 calories. The others analyzed were in the 300-plus range. The lightest bagel, three ounces, was from Dunkin' Donuts.
In general, it is safe to conclude that all plain bagels of the same size will have approximately the same number of calories -- about 75 to 80 calories an ounce -- and between one and two grams of fat. Unless, of course, someone adds Crisco.
Should the bagel lover decide on a modest amount of cream cheese -- say, two tablespoons -- that means another 100 calories.
A slice of smoked salmon? Don't ask.
 
Weighing In (Shmeers Not Included)
TWENTY plain bagels were analyzed for weight and calorie content by Certified Analytical Group Inc., Corona, Queens. The weight listed below is an average of the two bagels tested from each place. Some of these shops have more than one location in New York.
BAGEL ON THE SQUARE 7 ounces, 552 calories.
PICK A BAGEL ON SECOND 6.7 ounces, 518 calories.
DEAN & DELUCA (made by A & S Bagels): 6.4 ounces, 507 calories.
ESS-A-BAGEL 6.4 ounces, 503 calories.
NOSH A BAGEL 6.2 ounces, 472 calories.
H & H 4.5 ounces, 347 calories.
ZARO'S 4.3 ounces, 355 calories.
ZABAR'S (made by Columbia): 4.3 ounces, 338 calories.
BAGEL OASIS 4.1 ounces, 323 calories.
E.A.T. 3.9 ounces, 307 calories.
The average plain bagel has around 75 to 80 calories an ounce. Bagels from five other stores were simply weighed. The lightest of all the bagels tested was from Dunkin' Donuts, at just 3 ounces. One from Hot Jumbo Bagels came in at 3.5 ounces. D'Agostino's bagel was 3.8 ounces, and Moishe's bagel weighed 4 ounces, as did Balducci's. To learn the approximate caloric content of any bagel, simply multiply the weight by those figures.

HEADLINE: In America;
Dyson the Disdainful

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The thing about John Dyson is that he doesn't even bother to keep up a front. Most politicians, as they engage in the long-term mugging of the electorate, try to finesse things a little. They tell you how wonderful you are and what great things they are going to do for you. They lie, but they do it engagingly, with pretty words and lots of embraces, the political equivalent of flowers and chocolate.
Ronald Reagan was peerless at this. Americans seldom felt better than during the period when Mr. Reagan and his henchmen were masterminding the wholesale transfer of capital from the middle class and the poor to the very, very rich. 
 Mr. Reagan had an instinctive understanding of the principle known to even the lowliest three-card monte dealer on 42d Street: the fleeced must be kept amused during the fleecing, or things can get ugly.
This is a point lost on John Dyson, New York City's arrogant and obnoxious Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. The only amusement Mr. Dyson is interested in is his own. Like so many politicians, he disdains the vulgar masses he is sworn to serve. Only he doesn't hide it. He revels in it.
So it's not as odd as it might seem that Mr. Dyson would insult the city's African-American population with a watermelon crack. "The Comptroller ought to know the difference between a bid and a watermelon," said Mr. Dyson, in a dispute over whether to retain a company owned by a black woman.
It's the kind of thing you can expect from John Dyson -- gross and ugly and demeaning.
Earlier this year, at a special cabinet meeting held on Staten Island, he made it clear that a similar meeting would be unlikely for Harlem. Harlem, he said, has gotten "the vast proportion of the attention over the last four years." It was a gratuitous, divisive and untrue comment. But probably amusing to Mr. Dyson.
In any event, he's left no doubt that the kind of people who live in Harlem are not the kind he is interested in helping. Mr. Dyson is interested in people like himself, the very rich. So while the Giuliani administration was furiously lopping off jobs and slashing city services in an effort to reduce budget costs, Mr. Dyson came up with the bright idea of restoring $50 million in capital funds to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority as a way of easing the financial burden of the wealthy developer Mortimer Zuckerman. The idea was to offer the budget restoration (to be paid for by taxpayers) as an inducement for the M.T.A. to settle its fight with Mr. Zuckerman over the sale of the Coliseum site in Columbus Circle.
The proposal was widely denounced, and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, scorched by the criticism, finally had to say, "That is John Dyson's proposal, not mine."
Mr. Dyson got his appointment via political kingmakers and he loves wearing the Deputy Mayor's crown. But he doesn't know the city and he doesn't like it. He only lives here (sort of, in a pied-a-terre) because the law says he must. His normal digs are a 200-acre farm and vineyard in Dutchess County. His personal view of the great and rowdy city he is now helping to govern was summed up years ago when he told an upstate audience that he had "the normal disregard for New York City that you do."
Now that Mr. Dyson is a top municipal official, his expressions of contempt for ordinary New Yorkers are especially maddening. In the wake of a newspaper article that noted the absence of blacks in top jobs in the Giuliani administration, Mr. Dyson wrote a memo to the chief Deputy Mayor, Peter J. Powers, that said: "Do not worry. Two white guys have been running this city of immigrants for over 200 years."
The theme that runs through most of the controversies surrounding Mr. Dyson is the perverse idea that those who are less fortunate have too much, while those who are most fortunate do not have enough. One of his many nutty ideas was to provide additional financial support to the city's elite cultural institutions by shifting funding away from less-established organizations. Amid loud protests, that idea also was shelved.
New York, a city that can appreciate a genuine rogue, deserves better than John Dyson. He's an amateur and he's annoying. He can't go back to Dutchess County soon enough.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 477 words

HEADLINE: Ground Shifts in California's Water Wars

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "As Drought Looms, Farmers in California Blame Politics" (front page, June 24): 
 Changing wasteful, destructive and costly habits is always a challenge, whether in the case of spending, deficits or water in California. Only a minor amount of the dislocation you document is attributable to recent legislation, such as the Central Valley Project Improvement Act of 1992, of which we are the authors. Seven years of drought in the last eight (including this year, the four driest on record), plummeting commodity prices and numerous other factors are affecting the Golden State's agricultural economy.
Although farm spokesmen warn of dire food shortages if their water supplies are reduced, it should be noted that among the most heavily irrigated crops are cotton, alfalfa and irrigated pasture. Hundreds of thousands of acres of land are reverting to desert not because of diminished water supply, but because of the same process of desertification that has dried up artificially irrigated lands since Mesopotamia.
Some of that irrigation is also generating millions of gallons of toxic waste, which endangers wildlife and, potentially, human health. And tens of thousands of acres ineligible to receive subsidized water have been irrigated by the exercise of political power. Taxpayers need not feel guilty about demanding that the system return to some semblance of reality.
Water is no longer the exclusive right of farmers because it can be used better in other places. You fail to note the enormous public subsidy these growers receive: Central Valley Project customers may pay as little as $10 an acre foot for water for which non-Central Valley Project growers pay $400. Taxpayers and power customers pay that subsidy, often to grow crops we are encouraging farmers elsewhere in the country not to grow. By contrast, that water provided to urban areas generates far more jobs and far greater revenues for California and the country.
It is absurd to predict that water reforms will drive agriculture out of California. But farmers must recognize the state has changed drastically, and agriculture is a relatively minor feature of the state's diverse economy. The future of California depends on the efficient use of limited water resources, rather than just handing 85 percent of it over to irrigation. Urban residents, recreational activities, commercial fishing, as well as fish and wildlife restoration are all legitimate competitors for water. Financially and scientifically, allocations must be made soundly and reasonably in the years to come, and that is the basis of our long-overdue legislation.
 
(Senator) BILL BRADLEY
(Rep.) GEORGE MILLER
Washington, June 24, 1994
 
The writers are chairmen of, respectively, the Senate Subcommittee on Water and Power and the House Committee on Natural Resources.

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN HAITI: U.S. STRATEGY;
U.S. TROOPS STAGE MILITARY EXERCISE WITH EYE ON HAITI

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Stepping up preparations for a possible invasion of Haiti to oust its military leaders, United States forces have secretly rehearsed a plan to seize airfields and ports there, Pentagon officials said today.
The exercise, which involved more than a thousand commandos who would most likely serve as a vanguard, took place two weeks ago in the southeastern United States and the Gulf of Mexico, the officials said. 
 A battalion of Army Rangers flew from Savannah, Ga., and "seized" an isolated airfield at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, which was intended to represent the airfield at Port-au-Prince, Haiti's capital. Navy SEAL commandos operating from ships in the Gulf of Mexico practiced capturing a port.
Army Rangers conducted the same kind of exercises at Eglin just before the United States invaded Panama in December 1989 to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.
The Administration says it is still pursuing economic sanctions in the hope of forcing the military leaders to step down. But officials have warned that they are keeping open the option of using force to restore to power the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and stem a flood of Haitians that is overwhelming refugee centers in the Caribbean.
As long as the Administration continues to hold out the possibility of military intervention, the Pentagon must be prepared to execute it, but military officials say the White House has not yet decided on an invasion.
United States intelligence officers have long been skeptical that economic sanctions will induce Haiti's military leaders to leave. A classified National Intelligence Estimate prepared in January 1993 stated: "Neither tougher sanctions nor a blockade alone would lead the de facto regime to capitulate to demands for Aristide's return," but "the credible threat of force to restore him could persuade the military to reach an agreement."
American officials said there were indications of dissatisfaction in the lower ranks of the Haitian military. Visible military preparations could add to their unease and, the officals hope, encourage the ouster of the military leaders.
The exodus of Haitians has put added pressure on the Administration.
The State Department said today that since June 15, the Coast Guard had picked up 14,000 Haitians, including about 2,900 in 46 boats on Tuesday. Almost 1,200 were picked up by early evening today.
The Administration has tried to buy time for sanctions to work by announcing on Tuesday that it was sending refugees who flee Haiti in boats to temporary camps in Panama and other Caribbean countries. But officials concede that the new plan is at best a stop-gap. The agreement with Panama, which is to last for a year, limits the number of refugees there to 10,000.
 
Six Months, and Counting
 Reflecting the White House's sense of urgency, William H. Gray 3d, President Clinton's special envoy on Haiti, said today in a television interview that the military leaders must leave within six months.
"We don't expect the military regime to be there six months from now," Mr. Gray said on the NBC News program "Today." "We believe that the dictatorship will step down, will leave. If they don't, then there are options that are open. The President has made it very clear that the military option is just one of those options."
American officials said the invasion plan calls for about 20,000 troops, most from the Army. The first task would be to seize airfields and ports so an invasion force could be deployed. Army Rangers performed a similar mission in Panama, taking over an airfield near Panama City.
In addition, 2,000 marines now being dispatched to the coast off Haiti, officially to be prepared to evacuate Americans, include troops trained in special operations. Adm. J. Michael Boorda, the Chief of Naval Operations, sent a message on Tuesday to the marines and sailors en route to "be prepared for at least 30 days of operations."
 
The Forces Involved
 The 82d Airborne Division, which was used during the invasion of Panama, is trained to deploy quickly to trouble spots. Officials said it would be well suited to serve as the larger invasion force.
American officials said the rehearsal by the special forces included a Ranger battalion, which normally numbers about 900 men.
The C-130 planes that carried the Rangers flew for about the same amount of time they would fly if they went to Haiti. Then the Rangers parachuted at Eglin, in the Florida Panhandle, to "seize" the airfield.
Officials said the rehearsal also involved about eight Army Special Forces A-Teams, which are 10-man commando units. Two SEAL teams, each of which had about 120 men, were also involved, along with numerous support units.
In all, more than 2,000 troops were directly or indirectly involved.
 
'Contingency Plans'
 One military expert described the exercises as a "final rehearsal" and said the proficiency demonstrated would remain high for three to six weeks; after that, more training would probably be required.
The Pentagon declined to comment directly on the rehearsal.
"The President has not ruled out the military option," said a Pentagon spokesmen, Dennis Boxx. "We obviously have contingency plans should he direct military action. We will not discuss any specifics of what those plans might be. I would remind you that Mr. Gray said yesterday that a military invasion is not imminent."
But other Pentagon officials said that in recent weeks, military units and staff officers have focused on a possible invasion.
"In the last month or so we've had different types of training in that area," a ranking Army officer said. "There are three options for doing something like this: dropping troops in, air assault and amphibious landing. Training on all three probably makes sense."
 
Practice Sometimes in Vain
 Special forces have previously rehearsed operations that later proved to be unnecessary. After Iraq invaded Kuwait, for example, United States special forces practiced for a rescue of diplomats trapped in the Embassy in Kuwait. But Saddam Hussein's decision to release his hostages made that operation unnecessary.
And while preparations are continuing, the armed forces have not taken the final steps needed to launch an invasion, like establishing a joint command.
Still, senior officials describe the situation as a crisis.
"There is no military invasion imminent," Mr. Gray told reporters on Tuesday. "However the military option is on the table. 'Imminent' is defined as something that is going to happen in a few days."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN HAITI: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Clinton's Haiti Problem: What Price Democracy?

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
As American commandos rehearse for war and Administration officials insist that the crisis in Haiti must end soon, the unanswerable question is whether President Clinton himself is really willing to risk American lives to restore democracy to Haiti.
His aides insist that despite intensified military planning for an invasion and increased war talk, Mr. Clinton has not yet decided what to do. 
 The decision on Tuesday to change policy on Haitian refugees once again was an ad hoc response to a particular problem and not part of an overall strategy to oust Haiti's military leaders. And officials stress that they are still considering other ways the United States can pile more pressure on Haiti's military leaders before sending in the marines.
The Administration's public actions and statements offer little help in deciphering Mr. Clinton's intentions. As happened with the shift on refugees, the White House seems to be lurching from one short-term solution to another, often creating new problems that in turn require new quick fixes.
The President's special envoy on Haiti, William H. Gray 3d, said today that Washington does not expect the Haitian military to be in power six months from now. But the Administration has delivered no such formal ultimatum to the military junta, ordering them to leave or risk an invasion by a date certain, despite the request by the American Ambassador to Haiti, William Swing, that he be given the authority to do so, officials say.
 
No Consensus on Sanctions
 The Administration has debated, but failed to agree on, authorizing a covert program by the Central Intelligence Agency to sow dissension among the military or finance the departure of the country's three top military leaders, the officials add.
Moreover, there is no consensus among Mr. Clinton's national security advisers on how much longer the United States should give the stringent economic sanctions to work before it moves to an invasion.
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, for example, argued strongly in recent interagency meetings that American credibility was at stake and that there had to be a change in government by the end of the year at the latest, even if it took an invasion, officials said. The Pentagon remains strongly opposed to an invasion, and Pentagon officials have continued to point out the problems with an invasion.
Part of the problem in the Administration's decision-making on Haiti is that the tension between Mr. Clinton's desire to do what he calls the "moral" thing has clashed with political reality; another part of the problem is that the Administration has imposed punitive measures on the military only in stages. The result: a policy that seems to shift with every new development at home or in Haiti.
 
A Temporary Solution
 Mr. Clinton's decision on May 8 to end the practice of forcibly returning Haitians intercepted at sea came after he told aides that he could no longer continue a policy that was "making Haitians choose between being drowned at seas or having their faces cut off on land."
But the Administration estimated that only hundreds of Haitians a day would try to seek refuge in the United States; when thousands a day began to leave, Mr. Clinton found a way to deny them the opportunity to settle in the United States eventually by finding refuge for them in other, less attractive countries.
Senior Administration officials admit that Mr. Clinton's decision to divert refugees to third countries is at best a temporary solution that buys a few more weeks or months to test whether the strategy of painful economic sanctions will topple the military.
By contrast, the decision to send a landing force of 2,000 marines into the Caribbean and statements by Mr. Gray that American lives in Haiti must be protected at all costs, move the United States closer to war.
Mr. Clinton is hoping that what his senior aides call a "credible threat of force" to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, will somehow persuade Haiti's military leaders to leave the country quietly. Instead, it may simply push Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras to call Mr. Clinton's bluff by threatening the lives of American citizens.
 
Clinton Called Ambivalent
 "The Administration has created a situation it may not be able to control," said Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, who has been highly critical of the Administration's policy to try to restore Father Aristide to power. "Armed intervention is becoming its only option."
Still, Mr. Clinton is said to be ambivalent about whether he should exercise his prerogative as commander and chief and order the use of force in Haiti. According to people familiar with his thinking, he has vowed not to let the Haitian crisis become a vehicle for overcoming lingering skepticism about his attitude to the use of force stemming from his opposition to the Vietnam War and his avoidance of the draft. On the other hand, he has told intimates that he is not willing to prove the skeptics wrong by risking people's lives.
Last May, for example, Mr. Clinton laid out six good reasons why an invasion was justified, among them: "It's in our backyard"; several thousands Americans live there, and there is a "continuous possibility" of a huge exodus of Haitians if democracy is not restored. But that same month, at a "town meeting" on the Cable News Network he undercut his own position when he said, "We are doing our best to avoid dealing with the military option."
If Mr. Clinton wants to invade Haiti, he may not have much of a battle with Congress. In a little-noticed action last Wednesday, the Senate rejected, by 65 votes to 34, an amendment to the 1995 Foreign Operations Appropriations bill binding President Clinton to get Congressional approval or justify the use of force before ordering an invasion of Haiti aimed at ousting its military rulers.
Not that Mr. Clinton is insensitive to the wishes of Capitol Hill. Even though he has not decided whether to invade, he knows that there are certain blackout dates for the use of military force. Aides say that he is keenly aware that the optimal time to invade is after Congress recesses in the first part of August and before Labor Day, because lawmakers do not want their campaigns complicated by an invasion.
