HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Growing Up in the Melting Pot Called Hope, Ark.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, July 6

 BODY:
Today was the first time Bill Clinton had ever laid eyes on Poland and the Baltics. But to listen to him tell it, a boyhood in Arkansas amounted to pretty good preparation.
Even before he spoke this afternoon of an "unbreakable" chain binding the United States and the Baltic countries, Mr. Clinton was making out that his hometown, Hope, was a pretty worldly spot. 
 "I grew up in a little town in Arkansas that had a substantial Lithuanian population," the President told a gathering of foreign reporters not long before he left Washington. "So I grew up knowing about the problems of the Baltic nations."
Mr. Clinton proclaimed himself "very excited" to be beginning his Baltics trip with his visit to Riga, Latvia, this morning. (His spokesman, Mark D. Gearan, announced there that the President was still "very excited.") He separately described himself "so excited" to be traveling on to Poland, where he arrived this evening, and he suggested that was in part because life in Hope had taught him something about the place.
"Interestingly enough, we had a lot of people from Central and Eastern Europe, a lot of people from the Czech Republic in my hometown in Arkansas who came down from Chicago," the President told his visitors. "Most of them came from Chicago and moved to my state because it was a little warmer but still it had four seasons. So I'm very excited about it."
 
Remember the Colonel ...
 It wasn't, by any means, that his education was complete. Among the bits of lore that neither his neighbors nor his advisers had taught him was the case of Col. Ryszard J. Kuklinski, the Polish officer who became one of the United States' most important spies.
In the 1970's and early 1980's, Colonel Kuklinski provided American handlers with more than 35,000 pages of secret Warsaw Pact documents and tipped off the Central Intelligence Agency to the pending crackdown on the Solidarity labor movement before finally fleeing to the United States. He was convicted of treason in 1984 and sentenced in absentia, but his case has since become a cause celebre among Poles who regard him as a hero, not a traitor.
Even President Lech Walesa of Poland wrote to Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national secrity adviser, three years ago to tell him that the Kuklinski case "lies on my heart."
Mr. Clinton nevertheless could only profess ignorance last week when one of his visitors presented him with a request from Polish Clubs of Chicago that he join in the calls for amnesty for the 64-year-old colonel, who is living under a false identity in the United States.
"I knew nothing about this issue before I read this letter," the President confessed. But he latched quickly upon another memory from his Arkansas youth.
"When I was a boy I went to school with a man named Richard Kuklinski," he mused. "I wonder if he was related to this man."
 
... Don't Forget the Broker
 Playing his part as a beacon of capitalism, Mr. Clinton borrowed the Latvian stock exchange building this morning for a meeting with 80 of the country's leading politicians, intellectuals and businessmen.
But one person not invited was Evgeni Kopits, who supervises the country's only commodities market from a small upstairs room, watching over 500 brokers who trade everything from tennis rackets to oil tankers and who operate strictly in longhand.
Perhaps worse, to make room for Mr. Clinton's pilgrimage to the once-captive nation, its market had to shut down.
"We won't be able to take any orders," Mr. Kopits said, "but for the sake of Mr. Clinton we are happy to do it." He was less magnanimous toward the Latvian Government officials who left him off the list. "We have been here for three years and they act like we don't exist," he said huffily. "Those politicians don't realize how vital a stock market is for a real economy."
Mr. Kopits, whose title is general director of Latvia's universal market, described his country's leaders as former "Soviet functionaries." And in what sounded a little like a 100-year curse from a Latvian fairy tale, he gleefully predicted that the free market would not flourish in Latvia until after their death.
 
The Vacant Chairs
 Nothing about a Presidential visit is supposed to be unplanned.
When Air Force One landed in Riga this morning, for example, Mr. Clinton descended a stairway that had been trucked all the way from Germany for the occasion. Secret Service agents and military and civilian advance teams had filled the capital's best hotels and high-priced outdoor cafes for more than a week, and American frogmen had paddled in the muck of a downtown canal to be sure it was free of explosives.
Near Freedom Square, where the President delivered his speech this afternoon, residents had been warned to keep their heads behind their curtains lest Secret Service sharpshooters mistake them for a threat.
And with every step choreographed to the minute, an escort was awaiting even 14-year-old Chelsea Clinton, who was guided on a private tour through a Latvian art museum by 16-year-old Nicholas Silins, a gentlemanly youth in blue blazer and horn-rim glasses who just happened to be the son of the American Ambassador.
But politics is not a friend of plans, and this day-old journey has already brought evidence of that. For the first time in his Presidency, Mr. Clinton flew abroad from Washington unaccompanied by a chief of staff: both Leon E. Panetta, the incoming chief, and Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the old one, decided to stay behind, at least for a few days, to wrap up the settling out from last week's shake-up. Lloyd N. Cutler, the White House counsel, who joined Mr. Clinton on his European jaunt, has stayed behind this time to prepare for Congressional hearings on the Whitewater case.
That still leaves Mr. Clinton surrounded here by many of his top experts on foreign policy, politics and communications, including George Stephanopoulos and David R. Gergen, who are supposed to help him mesh all three. Mr. Gergen was given that job formally last week, and said he expected to spend much of his time at the State Department, but he arrived in Riga this morning not with the Secretary of State but in his old spot aboard Air Force One.
None of the surprises has quite compared with last week's power shift in Tokyo, but even that has left American planners who penciled in a joint news conference featuring Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata of Japan at the weekend Group of Seven summit meeting with something of a red face.
To the discomfort of the Japanese press, that same false anticipation remains emblazoned in bold color across a T-shirt that was being peddled on a chartered flight here by a freelancing Government employee. Its silkscreened image, intended as a memento of the coming gathering, depicts Mr. Clinton side-by-side with Mr. Hata, the suddenly former Prime Minister, and not with Tomiichi Murayama, the lifelong Socialist who will now attend the meeting as his successor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hillary Rodham Clinton and her daughter, Chelsea, touring the Riga Cathedral yesterday. They were with the President on a visit to Latvia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Department of Energy Pushes Competitive Bids

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
The Department of Energy said today that it would put up for competitive bid contracts valued at tens of billions of dollars, shaking up the companies that manage some of the Government's biggest laboratories and nuclear sites.
The announcement would more than triple the potential value of the contracts already under competition at main nuclear sites, and could present the Westinghouse Electric Corporation with especially intense competition as a prominent manager of big parts of the Government's nuclear complex. 
 Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary and other top agency officials characterized their plan as a wholesale revolution in the way the department does business with its primary contractors.
 
 
'Belong to the Public'
 They said their aim was to wrest control of the nation's nuclear complex from the contractors, who the officials said had become complacent in their decades-old roles. The officials vowed that the result would be to accomplish more and to spend less.
"These are our sites -- they in fact belong to the public," Mrs. O'Leary said. "They are not the contractors' sites."
At a lunch meeting with reporters, Mrs. O'Leary and her senior aides repeatedly described the existing arrangements with contractors as a hidebound and wasteful "entitlement" program, a kind of high-technology dole for corporations.
A single contractor would no longer control a Federal plant employing thousands of people, with its costs routinely covered by the Government and its fees calculated as a percentage of costs, the officials said.
Under that system, Deputy Energy Secretary Bill White said, "the more costs you incur, the greater the likelihood you will get a bigger fee."
Under the old system, officials said, big contractors handled even mundane tasks, like running laundries where special work garments were washed, under contracts awarded without competition.
In the future, a contractor would compete for a basic contract to integrate the services of several smaller contractors, each performing specialized work. And much of the work would be done on a fixed-price basis, with the contractors rewarded for holding down costs and performing well-defined tasks on time.
By making competition the rule rather than the exception, the department's officials hope to save at least 15 percent of the costs of managing its vast programs.
The Energy Department's programs focus on designing, building and dismantling nuclear materials and warheads, but in recent years it has also been overwhelmed by the costs of cleaning up pollution from five decades of bomb production.
Among the plants where the incumbent managers will face competition are the Hanford Reservation near Richland, Wash.; the Savannah River nuclear operation near Aiken, S.C., and the Nevada atomic testing site near Las Vegas. The current contracts to manage those sites are valued at an estimated $19 billion.
Westinghouse is the company most affected by the new plan. It is the principal contractor at Savannah River and Hanford, where it holds five-year contracts valued at more than $16 billion.
 
 
Reducing Costs
 Officials said Westinghouse and other contractors had already begun to reduce their costs in the face of potential competition, and that they expected the latest announcements to spur even greater economies.
"We were the first contractor to fully embrace the Department of Energy's contract reform, and look forward to the opportunity for the Department of Energy to compare our outstanding performance record against other competitors for the Hanford and Savannah River Site contracts," Westinghouse said in a statement today.
Counting previously disclosed competitions for contracts to manage the Rocky Flats plant near Denver, the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory near Idaho Springs and other contracts that will be renegotiated without necessarily seeking new bidders, the Energy Department said 21 contracts valued at $41 billion over several years would be rearranged.
By contrast, in the last 25 years there have only been seven instances of contracts, with a total value of about $14.5 billion, in which the Energy Department required an incumbent contractor to face competition.

HEADLINE: In Aftermath of Oil Spill, Alaska Waters Languish

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CORDOVA, Alaska

 BODY:
Before the Exxon Valdez ran aground in 1989 and spilled 11 million gallons of crude oil in Prince William Sound, spring was a season of joyous preparation for the fishermen in Cordova.
The sound teemed with herring and salmon and the promise of bulging summer catches, worth as much as $40 million a year to this port village of 2,100 people, 800 of whom are fishermen. 
But since the spill, the sound's overall ecological condition appears to have suffered, state and Federal scientists say.
Sea otters are reproducing, but their young are dying in unusual numbers, several scientists say. Other scientists have found that some species of water birds, particularly Harlequin ducks, are failing to reproduce in areas of the sound that were covered in oil. State studies show that although there were record catches of salmon in 1990 and 1991, and of herring in 1991 and 1992, the numbers of both species have now plummeted.
 
Trials to Decide Blame
 Whether any or all of these changes are due to the Valdez spill is now an issue in separate state and Federal trials in Anchorage. The Exxon Corporation, the owner of the oil tanker, has spent tens of millions of dollars hiring marine experts and preparing studies that essentially contend that Prince William Sound, an arm of the Gulf of Alaska, has recovered from the spill and that the continuing problems with the fishing industry stem from cyclical changes in ocean temperatures that reduce food supplies for herring and salmon. They also note that fishing is on the decline around the world.
The plaintiffs in both cases -- thousands of fishermen, native villagers, and property owners -- will cite data largely prepared by the state and Federal governments that conclude that oil from the spill continues to produce subtle toxic effects on fish and wildlife, affecting their growth, behavior and immune systems.
The plaintiffs in both courts are seeking a total of about $2 billion in compensatory damages. In June, Exxon lost the first phase of the Federal trial when a jury decided that the company had been reckless in allowing a captain with a history of alcohol abuse to command the Exxon Valdez. The decision makes Exxon vulnerable to a $15 billion punitive damage award that the plaintiffs will seek later this summer in the third phase of the trial.
 
Two Factors Cited
 Exxon long ago acknowledged that its own negligence contributed to the accident on March 24, 1989. But in the second phase of the Federal trial, which began on June 20, Exxon is seeking to reduce the compensatory damages by arguing that the collapse of the salmon and herring fisheries in Prince William Sound was a result of two factors.
First, natural fluctuations in ocean temperatures reduced the amount of food for the fish, weakening them and making them vulnerable to diseases.
Second, Cordova fishermen themselves may have hurt the catches by establishing a network of private salmon hatcheries that overloaded the sound's ecosystem with hundreds of millions of young fish, many of which starved.
"The commercial fishing industry in Alaska, like much of the rest of the world, has been experiencing hardships," said Douglas O. Walt, a spokesman for Exxon. "As shown by worldwide conditions, there is much more to the problems in Alaska than the oil spill, which occurred five years ago. To simply say that everything seen in the sound is because of the oil spill is an overly simplistic approach."
In Cordova, such statements are met with sputtering anger. The supply of fish is the lowest it has been in decades. This spring, Alaska closed the sound's herring fishery because there were too few fish. The number of herring caught in other Alaskan coastal areas has not had a similar collapse, said Evelyn Brown, a herring specialist here with the Alaska Department of Fish and Game.
The dwindling supply of fish and the plummeting prices, which the fishermen laid to the taint of oil and a ruined market, have led to both economic and emotional depression in Cordova. Fishing is now so bad, many boats will not leave the docks this summer.
In the 1970's and 80's, Cordova was a magnet for young men and women from the lower 48 states who took jobs as crew members and quickly earned enough money to pay for their own $200,000 boats and the state herring and salmon permits, which cost more than $100,000 each.
Fishermen like 37-year-old Tom Masolini, who came here from Northern California in 1976, were clearing $150,000 a year and more after paying their crews and other expenses. Winters were spent in Hawaii.
Now Mr. Masolini spends six months a year away from home to support his wife, Linda, and their three children by fishing for swordfish off California, 3,500 miles to the south. He has sold everything he can to make ends meet. The value of his boat and his fishing permits have been cut by more than half. He is dogged by creditors.
"I'm so angry at Exxon I can't even express how I feel," Mrs. Masolini, 41, said in an interview at their home, which is surrounded by the steep slopes of the Heney Range. "Our life is totally changed. Tom was away so long this winter, it just started to wear on me. People were going places and being with their families. It was just like he wasn't here any longer. I thought I just cannot take any more. But you couldn't express it with people who were doing worse than you were because at least my husband was earning money."
Mr. Masolini, who will not be fishing for salmon in Prince William Sound this summer for the second year in a row, added: "It gets you to talking about all kinds of weird stuff. We talked about opening an espresso bar or owning an ice cream cart in Hawaii. But I don't know if I'm cut out for that."
 
Biologist Blames Oil Spill
 From his office near the entrance to Cordova's snug harbor, Rick Steiner, a 41-year-old marine biologist with the University of Alaska, has been studying the volumes of scientific reports published about the sound since 1989. He says most of the evidence points to a single source of the problems: the Valdez disaster. Mr. Steiner argues that the spill tore the membrane of ecological and economic life in Prince William Sound to a point where it will take decades to recover.
"It was a massive toxic shock of oil," Mr. Steiner said. "Essentially, the spill sterilized the waters of Prince William Sound. Initially it had a stunning lethal effect. And now there are sub-lethal effects on the development of fish larvae, mussels, birds, otters."
The great paradox for Cordova's residents is that not a drop of oil from the nation's worst tanker spill came anywhere close to the village, which is at the entrance to Prince William Sound on its eastern shore.
The vast oil slick was pushed by the currents down the western part of the sound, eventually fouling 1,500 miles of shoreline and covering more than 10,000 square miles, an area roughly the size of Vermont. The spill occurred as the sound was coming out of winter dormancy and preparing for the spring migration of sea birds, the return of whales, the births of sea lions and otter pups, and the reappearance of swarms of herring and pink salmon to spawn.
 
Extensive Toll on Wildlife
 According to the damage assessment studies compiled by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and other state and Federal agencies, the toll on wildlife was extensive. Some 3,500 to 5,000 otters died, or a third of Prince William Sound otters. One pod of killer whales lost 13 of its 36 members. Some 200 to 300 bald eagles died; 175,000 to 300,000 common murres perished. The fry of pink salmon were found to be genetically abnormal. Millions of herring larvae that hatched in oiled areas developed extraordinary structural defects, like kinked spines, that led to their deaths, said Ms. Brown, the state herring specialist.
Exxon says it spent $2.1 billion in 1989 and much of 1990 amassing a fleet of boats and an army of workers to scrub the oil off the sound's beaches. Exxon's executives and scientists contend that the cleanup, as well as the winter storms that pound the beaches, have not only scoured the region but also eliminated the toxic effects of the oil.
Indeed, viewed from an airplane, the sound's beaches were free of any visible oil. Bald eagles soared above the trackless wilderness. Sea lions and otters were plentiful along the rocks. Families of humpback whales surfaced in the dark blue waters, and one slapped the water with its great fluke.
But state and Federal scientists say the real story of the sound's condition lies below the surface of the grand Alaskan landscape, beneath the rocks on the beaches and in the tidal areas, where the worst oil damage occurred and where many of the animals live and feed.
During a trip to Sleepy Bay, an area of the sound heavily hit by oil, Mr. Steiner found innumerable places on beaches where oil was oozing between the rocks.
 
Beneath the Surface
 Mr. Steiner said it cannot be proved yet that oil is still causing ecological trouble, but there are plenty of suggestions that it is. For instance, he said, one reason the otter population appears to be having trouble recovering is that oil is in the tidal areas that support mussels. Since mussels are the favorite food for young otters, that may explain why juvenile otters are not surviving to adulthood in the western part of the sound.
But Exxon, citing surveys by the Coast Guard and other government agencies, contends that the number of beaches where oil still lies below the surface is small. The company also says there is no evidence that oil seeping into the sound from the beaches or the tidal areas is harming otters or having an effect on other creatures, including herring and salmon. The conflicting assessments have put science on trial in Anchorage along with Exxon.
In Cordova, though, most fishermen share Mr. Masolini's wishes. "I just want the fish to come back," he said, sighing.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Labatt to Buy Part of Mexican Brewer

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 6

 BODY:
John Labatt Ltd., the Canadian brewing giant, said today that it would spend $510 million to acquire a stake in one of the two largest beer companies in Mexico in a transaction signaling the dramatic growth of Canadian business interest in Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Labatt, one of the most profitable beer companies in North America, has chosen as its Mexican partner Fomento Economico Mexicano S.A., known as Femsa, which controls 48 percent of the Mexican beer market with brands like Tecate, Carta Blanca, Superior and Dos Equis. 
 Mexico's other leading brewer, Grupo Modelo, which makes Corona, Mexico's best-selling beer, is 17 percent owned by the Anheuser-Busch Companies of St. Louis.
Femsa also operates 624 Oxxo convenience stories throughout Mexico and a packaging business. It also holds the largest Coca-Cola franchise in the world.
Labatt said it would buy a 22 percent stake in the beer enterprise, which accounts for about half of Femsa's total business, with an option to buy another 8 percent within three years.
 
Stock Offering Planned

 
Femsa Cerveza, as Femsa's beer division is known, would then be spun off as a separate enterprise. An initial public offering of 19 percent of Femsa Cerveza's shares is planned soon after Labatt closes its deal with Femsa, expected before Sept. 30. If the offering is completed as planned, Femsa would retain 51 percent of the beer unit.
"We think Labatt is the perfect fit for what our needs are," the chief executive of Femsa, Othon Ruiz Montemayor, said in a telephone interview from New York, where he and Labatt's executives met with securities analysts. He noted that today's announcement was the culmination of a three-year effort to find an appropriate partner for Femsa's beer business."
The chief executive of Labatt, George S. Taylor, said the alliance "clearly positions us for growth." He said Mexico, with its rising net disposable income and youthful population, was "one of the fastest-growing beer markets in the world."
In Mexico, all of Labatt's brands will be available to Femsa for distribution. In Canada, Labatt will distribute Femsa Cerveza's brands. In the United States, the two companies will unite their operations, focusing on specialty beers.
The position of Labatt in the Canadian market is similar to that of Femsa in Mexico. In each country, two companies control the bulk of the market.
Labatt's chief rival here is Molson Breweries of Canada Ltd. Labatt also has extensive sports and entertainment holdings. It owns 90 percent of the Toronto Blue Jays baseball club, the World Series champions for the last two years, and 100 percent of the Toronto Argonauts football team of the Canadian Football League.
 
Trade Pact Made Deal Possible

 
Violy McCausland, partner of James D. Wolfensohn Inc., an investment house in New York, who helped put the deal with Femsa together, said the North American Free Trade Agreement, which came into effect earlier this year, "created the right environment for it to happen."
Labatt, founded in 1847, reported sales of $2.3 billion (Canadian) in its latest fiscal year, and earnings before interest and taxes of $284 million (Canadian).
Femsa started in 1890. Its consolidated sales in 1993 were $2.437 billion (United States), and earnings before interest and taxes were $250 million. Its Femsa Cerveza unit had sales of $1.358 billion in 1993, and earnings before interest and taxes of $132 million.
Some Canadian analysts said the move should be positive for Labatt. "Labatt has an impressive track record," said Glynn Williams, a director of the Gordon Capital Corporation, an investment house in Toronto. "This acquisition is easily affordable and provides an excellent opportunity for them." Shares of Labatt rose 37.5 cents (Canadian), to $20.625 (Canadian), on the Toronto Stock Exchange today.
The Miller Brewing Company of Milwaukee also has a stake in Femsa. Miller's parent, the Philip Morris Companies, acquired a 7.9 percent interest in the overall Femsa enterprise from Citicorp in 1992. Miller, which owns 20 percent of Molson, Labatt's leading rival, had bid unsuccessfully for the Femsa Cerveza holdings and is now trying to revamp its Mexican strategy.
Mr. Ruiz of Femsa declined to say what went wrong with the Miller deal. "I prefer to put it in positive terms," he said, "that this is going to work great with Labatt."
 
Philip Morris Also In the Game

 
Darienne Dennis, a spokeswoman for for Philip Morris in New York, said Philip Morris "will continue exploring expanding Miller brands in Mexico."
Labatt is only one of a number of Canadian companies that are increasing their presence in Mexico to take advantage of the free trade accord, which took effect in January.
BCE Inc., the conglomerate in Montreal that controls Bell Canada, has expressed an interest in acquiring a stake in a telephone company in Mexico, and has held talks to form a partnership there with the American long-distance carrier, the MCI Communications Corporation.
Canadian mining companies and banks are also becoming more active in Mexico.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
The Rising Star From Dime Savings

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The ideal of an American meritocracy wouldn't appear to have too many better representatives than Richard D. Parsons.
Born in Bedford-Stuyvesant and raised in Queens, he finished first in his law school class, served on the governor's staff in Albany and on the White House staff in Washington. He then became a partner in a blue-chip New York law firm and the chairman of a bank. 
 Now, with the merger of the Dime and Anchor Savings Banks, Mr. Parsons, who will be chairman and chief executive of what will be one of the largest thrift institutions in the country, may also become one of the country's most visible African-American business executives.
As the former chairman of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's transition team and a ranking member of his kitchen cabinet, Mr. Parsons, 46, is a rising political power broker, and perhaps, one day, even a candidate himself.
 
Staying at the Dime
 During an interview yesterday at his corner office overlooking Fifth Avenue and 48th Street, Mr. Parsons gave assurances that he had no intention of leaving the Dime anytime soon. Both he and James M. Large Jr., the 62-year-old chairman and chief executive of Anchor, who will serve as president of the combined holding company, have just signed new, three-year employment contracts, he said.
But Mr. Parsons bridled slightly when asked if he thought of himself as a banker (he prefers to describe himself as a "businessman") and made clear that he did not see himself remaining in the same job indefinitely. "I'm not the kind of guy who will want to do the same thing forever," he said.
 
The Place of Public Service
 Recalling his days as legal counsel to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and as associate director of President Gerald R. Ford's domestic policy council, he referred to public service as the "highest calling, large and important work."
"It's a venue to which I could see myself returning at some point in time; whether in elective office or appointive office is an entirely different question." he said.
According to admirers of Mr. Parson -- and they are numerous -- there are not many limits to how far he could go.
"In my view, Dick Parsons is one of the great black leaders in the country," said Harry W. Albright Jr., the former chairman of the Dime, who recruited him to run the bank six years ago. "I think he will be a hugely successful leader of this new $20 billion corporation. I also believe that he could be hugely successful in any position in the country, whether it be senator, governor or President."
 
Earning Loyalties
 "He's a leader," added Peter J. Powers, New York City's First Deputy Mayor, who worked with Mr. Parsons on the Giuliani transition and has known him for more than a decade. "He really knows how to bring people together and find common ground."
A gregarious and thoughtful man, Mr. Parsons has risen by winning the affection and loyalty of influential mentors. After graduating as valedictorian of his law school class at Albany Law School in 1971 and earning the top score that year in the New York State Bar exam, he was recruited by a member of Governor Rockefeller's staff.
"The old-boy network lives," Mr. Parsons remarked. "I didn't grow up with any of the old boys. I didn't go to school with any of the old boys. But by becoming a part of that Rockefeller entourage, that created for me a group of people who've looked out for me ever since."
Mr. Parsons followed Mr. Rockefeller to Washington after he became Vice President in 1974, and later moved on to the White House staff under President Ford.
"Rockefeller took a great liking to him," Mr. Albright recalled. "He kept him with him as his private counsel until the time of his death."
In 1977, Mr. Parsons joined the law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, where he worked as a litigator and grew close to Harold R. Tyler Jr., a former Federal judge and head of the firm. In 1988, he accepted the offer to head the Dime.
"Judge Tyler wanted him as his successor and he was mad as hell at me because I wanted him to take my place, so we competed for him," Mr. Albright said.
 
Through Difficult Times
 Since joining the bank, Mr. Parsons has seen it through a difficult time. After real estate prices crashed in the late 1980's, the bank was stuck with a large number of nonperforming loans and suffered huge losses. Under his leadership, the bank has been slowly nursed back to health, culminating in a $300 million recapitalization completed last year.
Around the same time, Mr. Giuliani, the newly elected Mayor, asked Mr. Parsons to be his Deputy Mayor for Economic Development.
"I was not in a position to accept it," he said. "You cannot go out and raise $300 million on the assumption that you are going to be there, and then turn around three months later and say, 'Well, I changed my mind.' "
But he has agreed to serve as chairman of the city's Economic Development Corporation, and he often advises the Mayor and his staff.
Not surprisingly, Mr. Parsons' political beliefs are in the mold of his mentor, Mr. Rockefeller. He sums up that philosophy as "fiscal conservatism and social activism."
"You have to structure programs that are designed to modify or ameliorate social ills," he said, "but that requires investment on the part of the people who are being helped. "Otherwise, they won't value what they've got."
Mr. Parsons said race had never been a "defining character" in his life, and he does not consider it a burden that he might be a role model for other blacks.
"I don't do anything differently than I would otherwise because I have that responsiblity to my family," said Mr. Parsons, who is married and has three children. "Whether I was an African-American, an Arab-American, a Jewish-American, or some other American, there are a lot of people who I cannot let down, so you have to live your life a certain way to be a role model to the peoole who are important to you."

HEADLINE: Striking Oil but Straining Families

DATELINE: HOUMA, La.

 BODY:
When Jimmy Josey left for work recently, he hugged his two young sons and kissed his wife goodbye.
 But instead of heading to nearby Bilco Tools in his pickup truck, he drove about 40 miles northeast to New Orleans International Airport. Then, starting his 28-hour journey to the oilfields of Kazakhstan, he moved into the routine that is now part of his life in the domestic oil industry: He heads overseas, for a month at a stretch, to teach Kazakh, Hungarian and Russian workers to operate drill pipe-handling equipment made by his company. 
 Stocky and deep-voiced, Mr. Josey, who is 38, has worked on rigs across the Gulf of Mexico and thought he always would. "If you worked hard and hustled," he said, "there was always a place for you because there was so much activity."
 Now that activity is shifting, to Russia and other former Soviet republics, Brazil, China, Angola and, soon, to Vietnam. And oil workers like Mr. Josey are learning to adapt in mid-career -- a time when many Americans expect to be settled into a work and home routine -- to spending up to half their time working abroad, living in dormitories and struggling to learn other languages, diets and ways of life.
 Though energy companies have always gone overseas in search of oil and natural gas, that activity has picked up in the last four years and is likely to accelerate as more deals are completed. Encouraged by firming oil prices and promises of big profits from abroad, big oil companies now spend almost 65 percent of their exploration budgets overseas, up from 51 percent in 1990, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
 The industry does not tally how many of its employees work abroad, but executives and blue-collar workers say there is no question that companies are increasingly relying on overseas projects for future earnings. Being in the domestic energy industry, they say, now means being willing to go overseas.
 "I didn't anticipate I'd be working in a foreign country, but that's what it takes these days," said Jim Henley, regional manager for the<cobi>Chevron<coei>Corporation's offshore operations in Cabinda, Angola. He is gone from his wife, Frances, and their home in Mandeville, across Lake Pontchartrain from New Orleans, for a month at a time.
 Mr. Josey once believed that the oil in the warm, rich gulf would always put a paycheck in his pocket. But now he and other lone men, lugging duffel bags and trunks, are seen more frequently among the travelers at the New Orleans airport. Mr. Josey's neighbor, Kirby Falcon, routinely heads to Norway and the North Sea for Hydraulic Well Control, a drilling support company also based in Houma. Another man from Houma, John Triagle, oversees oil-rig crews for the Halliburton Company in the Far East. And Jeff Cetodal teaches Brazilians about Bilco technology that helps bring oil wells into production.
All had expected to finish their careers in the gulf. All now work overseas several months or more each year.
Mr. Josey is gone for up to four times a year, 28 days at a stretch. When he is overseas, he quadruples his usual weekly paycheck in Houma. But the work takes a toll on him and his family.
 
Starting Support Groups
 Overseas, many men work in such remote areas that they can call home no more than once a week, and their employers try to limit them to 15 minutes a call on scarce phone lines. So many men from Houma and the small nearby cities of Thibodaux and Morgan City work overseas that their wives have formed small support groups to ease their lives as single mothers.
Mr. Josey's wife, Dana, belongs to a group that she and four local friends call the Oilfield Wives.
"Sometimes you just feel that the whole burden is on you," said Mrs. Josey, 35, lighting a cigarette. The mother of two sons, ages 4 and 8, said the boys tested her when their father was not around. "You have to be real tough like daddy," she said, looking at the two. "Then you have to be tender like mama."
Jamie Falcon, who is 23, says that when her 2-year-old son hears a plane overhead, he sometimes asks: "Is Daddy coming home?" Recently, her husband was home for two days before his schedule changed and he had to board a flight back to Norway. This time, he'll be gone for several months.
The changes have hit blue-collar workers and managers alike. Mr. Henley, Chevron's manager in Angola, is 50 years old and had worked his way up the corporate ladder to become manager of environment and safety in an area that includes the gulf. But seven years ago, when Chevron decided to step up its exploration and production in Africa, it sent him to Angola. He recently left Houma for a 28-day stint there.
"After a few years, you get used to it," said his wife, Frances, who teaches piano and plays the organ at the First Baptist Church in Mandeville.
 
Dorms and 12-Hour Shifts
 The men adjust, too, but differently. In Angola, Mr. Henley works 12-hour shifts, six days a week, overseeing drilling and production platforms. He lives in a self-contained complex with dormitories that house 580 workers.
Mr. Josey has learned to work on rigs in temperatures that sink 40 degrees below zero. In the Tengiz oilfield of Kazakhstan, he works 12-hour shifts, communicating with the workers through translators. He has widened his palate by eating local foods like pig lung soup, cooked by his Kazakh colleagues, but he stays close to the Americans.
"We sit at the same table," he said of his American co-workers from Mississippi, Texas and Oklahoma. "You have somebody to talk to."
In their efforts to cope, the Joseys have found some rewards. Mrs. Josey, for instance, has developed more of her own interests. She has set up a small workshop in her home where she makes colorful ceramic bowls and lamps. But her boys get restless during the weeks of their father's absence, and when he returns she gives him three days to recover before handing them over to him. The rebonding is intense.
"It just means so much to see the boys," Mr. Josey said. And Dustin, who is 8, likes to pull the pay stub out of his father's shirt pocket and marvel that the amount on it can be as high as $1,200 a week.
 
A Domestic Industry's Shrinkage
 The need to send workers overseas is unlikely to change anytime soon, even though a small recovery in drilling in the gulf is expected later this year. The domestic energy industry has shrunk to 443,800 workers, from 920,000 in 1982, the American Petroleum Institute said. Oil prices dropped sharply in the 1980's, many domestic fields matured and hundreds of smaller companies went out of business or were sold. Domestic exploration spending, which reached $29.9 billion in its heyday in 1982, fell to $7.4 billion by 1992, according to an institute study of 18 big oil companies.
[The most recent example of how the domestic oil industry is shrinking came Tuesday as the Texaco Corporation said it would put half of its 600 domestic fields on the auction block as part of a wider effort to cut costs. It plans to cut a total of 2,500 jobs in domestic and international operations.]
Louisiana has been whipsawed by the industry's volatility. Energy-related jobs in the state had dwindled to 42,000 last year from 102,000 in 1981. One of the hardest-hit areas includes Houma and Thibodaux, which is heavily tied to oil and gas exploration.
Mr. Josey's employer, Bilco Tools, is one of the local survivors, and its president, Bill Coyle, can rattle off the names of small neighboring companies that went under or were sold at fire-sale prices during the 1980's. "People bought companies for 15 cents on the dollar," Mr. Coyle recalled.
 
'Where the Action Is'
 He decided that if Bilco was to survive, it needed new business from overseas, and he scoured the world for orders. The first came from Abu Dhabi and India. Now they range from the North Sea to the Far East.
"We had the choice of going out of business or going where the action is," he said. Today, about 20 percent of his company's revenue comes from overseas and about one-quarter of his 80 employees work abroad for some stretches of the year.
As oil companies increasingly shift investments overseas, the area around the gulf is "fighting to hold on to what it can," said Loren C. Scott, a professor of economics at Louisiana State University. "Workers have had to readjust their lives."
Mr. Josey, for one, is more than willing to do so and grateful for the work. Without it, he would be one of the tens of thousands of oil industry workers who have had to move to other states and take lower-paying jobs, flipping hamburgers or pumping gas.
"If it weren't for Bilco," he said, "I don't know where we'd be."

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
They Think, Therefore They Are Very French

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 4

 BODY:
Does knowledge inhibit the imagination? Is a coherent thought necessarily true? Can a work of art be considered immoral?
Or how about this one? Is passion compatible with wisdom? O.K. Now, over the next four hours, write a five-page dissertation on one of these topics. 
 Year in, year out, the rite of passage from France's senior high schools is unchanged, and last month no fewer than 570,000 French students around the age of 18 set about trying to show that, while perhaps not yet budding philosophers, they already knew how to discuss an abstract subject.
France is still the only country in the world that requires the study of philosophy in high school. But, more than instilling a smattering of knowledge about Hobbes or Voltaire or Locke or Marx, this policy aims to teach young French men and women how to think -- to think in the French way.
"At this stage, it's a rhetorical exercise, a question of being able to present an argument," said Luc Ferry, a philosophy teacher, "and, since Victor Cousin in the mid-19th century, this has been done through the method of presenting a thesis, an antithesis and a synthesis."
In high schools and, above all, in the "baccalaureat" examination, the topics are chosen to force young minds into new areas through analysis of, say, truth or conscience or freedom. "All my students want to discuss is love," one high school teacher said with a laugh.
In the exam room they have to be ready for more. Last year's questions included, Is reality always realistic? Among questions presented for dissection two years ago were: Can self- knowledge be sincere? And, more mischievously, How do you know that a problem is philosophical?
Yet, in the land of Descartes, it is the method that has had most lasting effect. As soon discovered by anyone who has sat in a smoke-filled Left Bank cafe or around an elegant Paris dinner table, good conversation involves taking a subject, examining it from all sides and conceptualizing it to the point that a conclusion becomes irrelevant.
Indeed, such is the fascination with philosophizing -- more than philosophy -- that each year newspapers publish the questions asked of students in their "bac-philo" exam and invite philosophers to write their own model answers. And even years later, it seems, everyone remembers the question they answered and the mark they were awarded in philosophy.
This cerebral and even ethereal approach to life's dilemmas in turn affects the way French society as a whole works, including politics and diplomacy. And perhaps here lies the secret to why the French and "Anglo-Saxons," as they call Americans and Britons, have so much trouble understanding each other.
"The French always go from the general to the particular," said Jack Lang, a former Culture and Education Minister. He promptly recalled that his "bac-philo" essay was on "Happiness" and that he got 18 out of 20 points. "The Anglo-Saxons start with a concrete fact and reason from that. They call a cat a cat. We like to blah-blah-blah."
For Mr. Ferry, the Anglo-Saxon tradition of analytical philosophy can be summarized by the phrase: we have a problem and must find a solution. "In contrast, in France, through Voltaire and Diderot and Rousseau, ours is more of a political or social philosophy," he said. "Only the Germans have created great metaphysical systems."
Mr. Ferry went even further. "We don't have any true philosophers in France today," he said. "We have intellectuals galore. We even invented the word 'intellectual.' But what we have are intellectuals who call themselves philosophers and a host of professors who are more historians of philosophy."
Dominique Bourdin, who teaches philosophy in an underprivileged Paris suburb, said she nonetheless enjoyed the recognition her expertise brought her. "My teaching colleagues are often intimidated by us," she said. "They'll come and ask us to discuss philosophical aspects of their disciplines."
The same enthusiasm is not always apparent among students, above all those studying mathematics, sciences and technical subjects. "The course was a waste of time," said Laurent Delahaye, 18, who plans to study economics in college. "Still, perhaps it developed my critical faculties, who knows."
Mrs. Bourdin, whose students are unlikely to join the French elite, said she felt that even a couple of hours of philosophy lessons a week made a difference. "Even if they don't retain much, they have asked some questions and they know there are more questions to be asked," she said.
For the "bac-philo" exam, France is divided into four regions and, within each region, there are three sets of questions, depending on whether the student specializes in humanities, social sciences and pure sciences. Each student can pick between two questions and a commentary on a philosophical text.
Humanities students, who take eight hours of philosophy a week, are expected to do best. This year, those in the Paris area had to chose between the questions, "Is a philosopher necessarily a man of his times?" and, "Is reason a guarantee against deception?" Or they could discuss a text by St. Augustine on war and peace.
Diego Bunuel, 18, a humanities student who plans to major in political science at Northwestern University, said his philosophy studies had taught him to question.
"In philosophy, you can talk about everything," he said. "The subjects I prefer are passion, religion, the state, law, violence, justice and death."
Karen Micmacher, 20, who will study law at college, said her only regret was that she had not begun philosophy sooner. "It has changed my whole way of thinking," she said. "I feel like it has been a voyage into history." Then, as if to stress she is now truly French, she added, "I have learned how to reason."

HEADLINE: Fed Fails To Move On Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve ended a two-day strategy session on monetary policy today without announcing an increase in short-term interest rates or explaining its apparent inaction.
Analysts took this to mean that the central bank, which had raised rates four times since early February, was satisfied with early signs that the economy is slowing enough to minimize the risk of resurgent inflation. 
 It had been widely agreed that the Fed's assessment of the domestic economy would outweigh its interest in supporting the dollar in world currency markets, even though higher rates, by making the dollar more appealing, would tend to enhance foreign investment and minimize inflation from imports.
 
 
Markets' Response
 The financial markets responded fairly positively, though with no great enthusiasm, to the apparent outcome of the Fed meeting. The dollar rebounded from its morning declines, blue-chip stocks rallied and bond prices showed relatively little change.
But while today's result came as no surprise, some analysts had speculated that the Fed might continue its practice since early February -- when it began its current series of rate increases -- of providing a brief rationale for its moves, or at least to make a clear declaration that it had decided to leave its stance unchanged.
Today's development did not absolutely mean that the Fed had decided to keep rates where they were. Until February, the committee's moves had to be deduced from watching the financial markets -- usually the day after it met -- since the committee did not announce its immediate intentions.
 
 
Fed Statement
 The Fed did, in fact, issue a statement today, but the statement said only: "The meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee ended at 12:35 P.M. and there will be no further announcement." The session, attended by 18 members and more than two dozen staff, ran for seven hours, starting Tuesday afternoon, and reconvening at 9 A.M. today.
Joseph R. Coyne, a spokesman, denied that any precedent had been set in announcing immediately the four earlier increases in the Federal funds rate. Nor would he comment on the possibility that the Fed today made a "contingent" decision to take action based on some future development.
"We don't have any permanent policy yet" with respect to the immediate announcement of deliberative results, Mr. Coyne said. "This is still provisional."
There was disappointment, however, at the House Banking Committee where Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who serves as chairman, has long pressed for greater and quicker disclosure of Fed actions. A committee aide said today, "They're clearly going back to their old ways."
Most analysts continued to regard further rate increases as likely, probably before Labor Day and possibly as soon as mid-July, after the Fed has digested labor market and retail sales figures for June. The job report is due Friday, the sales report next Thursday.
 
 
Consumer Spending
 A slackening in consumer spending, along with a less robust housing market, has been the chief evidence so far that the economy's growth has slowed from the torrid 7 percent growth rate of the final three months of 1993 followed by a 3.4 percent pace -- regarded by some as still unsustainable -- in the first quarter of 1994.
Lyle E. Gramley, a former Fed governor and research chief who is now with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said today that the Fed would be particularly interested in the upcoming sales report and predicted that the next move to raise rates would come at the Federal Open Market Committee's next meeting on Aug. 16.
He said the job figures could prompt a telephone conference of the committee but doubted this set of data would produce an increase by itself.
Robert V. DiClemente, a veteran Fed watcher at Salomon Brothers, also said more rate increases could be expected. He said it did not much matter whether a rise was deferred for days or even weeks, so long as the economic need for it was clearly established. On the other hand, Mr. DiClemente added, "it could be critical if they make a misstep in acting too soon."
He and other analysts also suggested it was wise for the Fed to avoid stating today it had taken no action since this could have emboldened speculators to attack the dollar with relatively impunity.
 
 
Three Votes
 Mr. Coyne said three votes were taken at today's meeting but he would not hint at the results. The committee members, 11 of them currently with votes, expressed themselves on monetary targets for the balance of 1994 and on preliminary monetary targets for 1995, in addition to policy over the next six weeks.
The voting committee is currently composed of six sitting governors of the Federal Reserve Board plus the presidents of 5 of the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks, who vote on a rotating basis; the president of the New York Fed, who also serves as vice-chairman of the committee, is a permanent voting member. This was the first meeting for the newest governor, Alan Blinder, the first Clinton appointee to the Fed.
The Fed's targets will be publicly disclosed when Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, makes his statutory semiannual appearance before Congress later this month to discuss the economic outlook and the central bank's anticipated response.
A spokesman for the Senate Banking Committee said this afternoon that the date for this hearing had not yet been determined.

HEADLINE: Japanese Made Gains In June Vehicle Sales

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 6

 BODY:
The leading Japanese auto makers posted strong sales and gains in market share in June, driving up total car and light-truck sales for the month despite a weaker performance by the Big Three.
Over all, sales sustained the moderate growth they have managed since easing off in May, sticking to a pace that analysts say bodes well for continued slow growth in the economy. Sales of cars and light trucks rose 6.8 percent compared with a strong period a year earlier. 
 Partly because of product shortages, the Big Three auto makers appeared to be sacrificing sales to the Japanese, who are offering customer incentives to exploit the opportunity.
 
Unfazed by High Yen
 "What all this means is you can't underestimate the Japanese," said Christopher W. Cedergren, senior vice president with the AutoPacific Group, an automotive consulting and marketing firm in Santa Ana, Calif. "Even at 98 yen to the dollar, they can still increase their share."
Indeed, taken together, the Japanese increased their share of the American car and light-truck market in June by 2.3 percentage points, to 23.8 percent. Combined, the Big Three lost 2.8 points, to 72.2 percent.
"They had cars," said David Healy, auto industry analyst for S. G. Warburg in New York City. "If you wanted a Mustang or a Blazer or a Neon they had waiting lists," he added, referring to Big Three products. "And you went to a transplant dealer and they had cars."
The Big Three's problem is not simply too much demand for factories strained to capacity, however. All three auto makers have closed plants for months to prepare for production of 1995 models.
 
Factory Woes at G.M.
 At the General Motors Corporation, for example, a key Canadian plant that manufactures the Lumina midsize car was shut in November to prepare for the 1995 version. The factory stayed closed for three months, and is still not expected to reach its full assembly line speed until August. By contrast, Honda's assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, was able to switch from the 1993 Accord to the 1994 model in one weekend, and was up to full speed in a matter of weeks.
With too few of its crucial midsize cars, Chevrolet's car sales fell 4.4 percent in June, and G.M.'s total car sales fell 4.6 percent. G.M., which is now in its annual two-week production shutdown, said its figures were preliminary. The company said it would have final numbers on July 18.
Sales in June of all cars, whether built in North America or imported, climbed 4.4 percent, to 876,136. Sales of pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles climbed 10.7 percent, to 576,358. (Light-truck sales are slightly overstated, because G.M. did not separate out the number of medium-duty trucks it sold; in May, G.M. sold 3,033 medium-duty trucks.)
Light-truck sales continued to provide a bright spot for the Big Three. While the Chrysler Corporation sold more light trucks than it had in any previous June, the Ford Motor Company sold more light trucks than it had in any previous month.
 
Annual Rate Unchanged
 The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for cars in June was 7 million, the same as in May.
The total sales figures disguised markedly different performances by the auto makers. Combined sales by the Big Three rose only 2.8 percent, while sales by the Japanese jumped 18.2 percent.
"The Japanese are throwing a hell of a lot of money behind their products," Mr. Cedergren said. He said the Japanese were also emphasizing leasing, which plays to their strength because lease rates are based on projections of the resale values of cars when they are eventually returned. Since Japanese cars tend to have high resale values, the manufacturers can set rates low, even though the sales price of the cars would be high.
The Toyota Motor Corporation, after an anemic May, saw its sales of cars and light trucks rise 23 percent in June, to 111,566, the company's best month since August 1990.
The Honda Motor Company also had a strong month, as sales of cars and light trucks jumped 18.1 percent, to 73,365. But there were indications that Honda made a special effort to beef up its June sales. A Honda dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the company had offered dealers special incentives to hit their sales targets for the month.
"There were probably a lot of deliveries reported in June that normally would have been sitting around the office," the dealer said.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 22.02 as Most Other Indexes Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session, with the main blue-chip indicator up and the broader market indexes down, but off the lows for the day.
Mindful of the bond market and weakness of the dollar, many investors were still unsure about the possibility of another increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, and moved to the sidelines to await the release tomorrow of employment data for June. 
 At the conclusion of its two-day meeting yesterday, the Fed's policymaking arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, left its monetary policy unchanged. The lack of a rise in interest rates was particularly good news for cyclical stocks and was a factor affecting the divergence of the Dow Jones industrial average from the broader market indexes.
Monthly auto sales data released yesterday were about in line with expectations, and as a result the blue chips continued to bounce back.
 
Nadaq Index Slips 2.59 Points

 
 The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate, with 233.6 million shares traded, compared with 194.5 million shares on Tuesday. The number of issues declining yesterday narrowly outpaced advancers, 1,082 to 1,024.
The Dow rose 22.02 points, to 3,674.50, while the Big Board composite index gained 0.03 point, to 246.54. But the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which fell 0.24 point, to 446.13, the Nasdaq composite index, which fell 2.59 points, to 701.00, and the American Stock Exchange, which fell 0.15 point, to 423.55.
After the open market committee's meeting ended yesterday without an announcement on rates, many analysts said they believed the Fed was waiting for the employment data tomorrow to decide whether another tightening of credit was needed.
"If the market learned anything today, it's that the Fed continues to place the dollar at a lower priority than inflation and economic growth," Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said.
Other analysts said the Fed might avoid an early tightening of rates only because such a move could be seen as validating what some have called a currency crisis, or an overemphasis on the dollar's role in monetary policy.
If the economic data support the view that the economy is strong and getting stronger, it could lift stocks because a strong economy translates into higher corporate earnings. But an economy that is too strong would produce inflation and higher interest rates, which is counterproductive to corporate profits.
Lawrence R. Rice, chief market strategist for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said he continued to be underwhelmed by the quality of the current market rallies. "Today is a perfect indication of how rallies are one-sided," he said.
Mr. Rice said there was also a continued divergence of the blue-chip issues from the bond market. "Historically, bonds should rally before stocks," Mr. Rice said. "What has been happening is that the spread between stock and bond yields has widened significantly within the last few months to the point where stocks have become very unattractive compared to bonds."
Texaco was up 1 5/8, to 62 1/2, after the stock was raised to a "buy" rating, from "accumulate," by Dean Witter. Texaco announced a restructuring program on Tuesday that would save it $300 million, and would involve the sale of its marginal oil fields in the United States.
Microsoft fell 13/16 , to 485/16 in Nasdaq trading. The company said it would continue its stock repurchase program through the next fiscal year.
The earnings outlook for Viewlogic Systems caused an analyst for Smith Barney to trim his earnings estimates for the computer software maker to $1.10 a share, from $1.15, in 1994, and to $1.35 a share, from $1.45, in 1995. The stock was down as much as 3 1/4, before closing down 1/2, at 14 1/2, in Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Recovers as Traders Await Rate Action by Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar recovered yesterday from an early selloff that had sent it to a 14-month low against the German mark, as traders waited to see whether the Federal Reserve would make any move to push up interest rates.
The Fed's Federal Open Market Committee ended a two-day meeting without announcing any action on its monetary policy, providing an indication that it had apparently decided to make no immediate move to raise interest rates to support the dollar. 
 Many economists have said the Fed's assessment of the American economy would outweigh its interest in supporting the dollar.
But traders said the Fed did not seem to be ruling out raising interest rates at some future date. Several said the Fed might be waiting for the Government's report on June employment before it acts.
 "People still think there might be an interest rate hike in the cards," said David Durst, a trader at Bear, Stearns & Company. "Just because the Fed didn't act today doesn't mean they can't announce a rate increase later this week."
Higher rates could buoy the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
The dollar fell to 1.5658 marks in early New York trading yesterday, its lowest level since April 1993. It was quoted at 1.5785 marks late in the day, down from 1.5810 marks on Tuesday.
The dollar also fell to 97.84 Japanese yen before recovering to close unchanged at 99 yen.
Many traders sold dollars early in the day after Germany's Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, said efforts to support the sagging currency were sure to fail. "Germany's position, that intervention against a market trend can't succeed, has been proven," Mr. Rexrodt told a German newspaper.
His comments fueled speculation that leaders from the Group of Seven industrialized nations would not take steps to shore up the dollar when they meet in Naples this weekend.
 The dollar rebounded from its lows against the mark and the yen after a spokesman for Prime Minister Edouard Balladur of France said that country would call upon the United States to "take all necessary measures" to support the dollar at the Group of Seven meeting.
Those comments lifted the dollar because "a lot of people are still looking for something substantial out of the Naples meeting," said Jim Raphael, a trader at NatWest USA Bancorp. "If there's no strongly worded communique, we'll see a much lower dollar next Monday."
Mr. Raphael does not expect the Fed or the Group of Seven to come to the dollar's rescue unless American stock and bond markets appear to be in trouble. Those markets were relatively stable yesterday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Weaken And Precious Metals Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil futures prices weakened yesterday after an oil company resumed operations in Yemen.
Precious metal futures also fell, which helped drive down the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities 1.42 points, to 225.31. 
 On other commodity markets, coffee futures rebounded on frost fears, grains and soybeans were mixed and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
Oil prices fell after Canadian Occidental Petroleum announced that it had resumed production of 150,000 barrels a day in Yemen after halting operations on Tuesday because of heavy fighting in the civil war there.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the crude oil contract for August delivery fell 38 cents, to $19.24 a barrel. August heating oil tumbled 1.23 cents, to 49.09 cents a gallon. August unleaded gasoline fell 0.88 cent, to 52.97 cents a gallon, and August natural gas fell 0.9 cent, to $2.122 for 1,000 cubic feet.
The market's failure to reach $20 a barrel in recent sessions also prompted selling, said Thomas Blakeslee, vice president of Cameron Hanover Inc., an investment research firm in Bronxville, N.Y. "Once it started to slide, you saw more and more liquidation," he said.
Crude prices have been jittery since the July contract hit a high of $20.95 on June 21. The relatively high prices in the United States have attracted shipments of oil from other countries, which has been absorbed so far by surprisingly strong demand for refined products, Mr. Blakeslee said. "At these prices, demand is starting to look a little more sluggish," he said.
United States stocks of crude oil declined by 607,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported after the close.
Silver led precious metal futures lower amid waning inflation fears and expectations for higher interest rates in the United States, said Peter Cardillo, research director for Westfalia Investments Inc. in New York.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, gold for August delivery fell $2.30, to $384.60 a troy ounce; July silver fell 8.9 cents, to $5.232 a troy ounce.
Coffee beans for September delivery soared 8.15 cents on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York to $1.945 a pound.
The gain erased most of Tuesday's 8.80-cent loss as traders focused on forecasts for possible frost this weekend in Brazil, the world's top producer. A cold snap late last month hurt the Brazilian crop.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Slip as Fed Fails to Act

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday after the Federal Reserve took no action on interest rates, raising concern among some traders and investors that the Fed was not being aggressive enough in fighting inflation.
The Fed's policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, said in a statement that its two-day meeting ended at 12:35 P.M. "and there will be no further announcement." 
 Bond prices fell on the news after rebounding to be almost unchanged from earlier losses. A stronger dollar and falling commodity prices helped bonds recover a bit late in the day be to almost unchanged. The dollar recovered to 99 Japanese yen, unchanged from yesterday. The dollar also recovered late in the day from a 14-month low against the German mark. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities, meantime, which is considered a leading indicator of inflation, dropped 1.42 points, to 225.31.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 3/32 , to 8411/32 yesterday. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.59 percent, from 7.58 percent on Tuesday.
The Fed's announcement "tells the market the Fed gave up a great opportunity to make a move that would be judged as pre-emptive," said Anthony Chan, a senior economist at Banc One Investment Advisers, a Columbus, Ohio, firm with $8 billion in bonds.
Expectations that the Fed will take its time raising rates explains why bills and notes are doing better than bonds, said Dennis Bushe, head of $12 billion in bonds at Prudential Investment Advisers in Newark.
"Everybody's been hiding in the front end of the yield curve," he said.
The yield curve is the difference in yields between short-term and long-term securities.
Some traders and analysts said the Fed might wait until the release of the employment report for June tomorrow before raising rates. A surge in job growth beyond expectations would fuel concern that an expanding economy could fuel inflation.
But Mr. Chan said the Fed would run a risk in waiting for the employment report. If it raises rates after a report that the economy created more jobs than expected, "they can't fly the pre-emptive flag," he said.
The Fed may also have its eye on this weekend's meeting of leaders from the Group of Seven industrial nations, Mr. Bushe of Prudential said. The news "makes me wonder if they're going to wait for the G-7 meeting," he said. "One thing you could read into this is that they might try for a coordinated move," with other central banks cutting rates as the Fed raises U.S. rates.
"It probably makes sense for them to hold off for the jobs report and to see what comes out of the G-7," Mr. Bushe said. "It's a rational thing for them to do. What concerns the market now is employment growth, and it's wise for the Fed to watch and wait to see what employment does."
Some investors are willing to purchase bonds at these levels because they expect higher rates to depress home sales and slow the economy, said Leslie Finnemore, who helps manage about $4 billion in government securities at Colonial Mutual Funds in Boston.
While 30-year bond yields are not likely to sink below 7 percent this year, Ms. Finnemore said, she is "cautiously optimistic" that the worst is over for bonds.
Jan Terbrueggen, who helps manage $5 billion in fixed-income assets at Flagship Financial in Cincinnati, said that because the Fed did not act yesterday, it might not move before the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in August. That is especially likely if the dollar recovers, he said. "Personally, I think on Greenspan's list of favorite indicators, the dollar is at the bottom of the list," he said.
Relief that the Fed has not raised rates will allow notes to keep doing better than bonds, said Matthew Alexy, a market strategist at CS First Boston.
Many analysts do not expect the Fed to raise rates to bolster the dollar, even though a weak dollar can add to inflation by raising the cost of imports. A fall in the value of the dollar also makes dollar-denominated securities such as Treasury bonds less attractive to investors because the value of the bonds depreciates with the currency.
"You don't try to defend your currency by sinking your economy," said Tom Carpenter, chief economist at ASB Capital Management in Washington, D.C.

HEADLINE: OLYMPIC FESTIVAL;
For Volleyball Player, a Rich Athletic Tradition

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, July 6

 BODY:
The man wearing a white T-shirt and an intense gaze leaned forward, surveying the court as the South played the East in the second day of volleyball competition at the United States Olympic Festival today.
The object of his focus was Jennifer Johnson, a tough 5-foot-10-inch outside hitter for the South squad and one of the best young players competing here. Before the match, the man had given a critical evaluation of Johnson. 
 "Her numbers aren't always gigantic but she does so many other things," he said. "She can get the ball off the floor, she's quick, she can block, she's one of the best defensive players I've seen play."
Rafer Johnson might be a bit biased: Jennifer is his daughter. Still, given his deep background in world- class competition -- and given his daughter's talent -- he knows of what he speaks.
"She's a really great all-around player," Johnson said. "She might not be individually outstanding in one area, but I haven't seen many people match her with her all-around play."
It's fitting that the defining quality of Jennifer Johnson is her overall skills. Her father was one of the greatest decathletes in Olympic history. Johnson won an Olympic gold medal at the 1960 Rome Games, breaking a world record.
More than three decades later, Johnson's 21-year-old daughter is beginning the process of reaching world-class status. Best of all, Johnson said, is that neither he nor his wife, Betsy, pushed Jennifer or her brother, Josh, toward athletics.
"My wife and I tried to involve our kids in everything," he said. "Josh played volleyball and soccer, he played Little League. Jennifer played softball and ran track. Our idea was not to find anything in particular but to give them a chance to play all the different sports. They found their own way."
Jennifer certainly has. Through the various experiments with sport, the constant was volleyball. She began playing when she was 7. By the end of her senior year in high school, Johnson was acknowledged as the California player of the year.
On Tuesday, she had 17 kills as the South overcame a 2-games-to-1 deficit and won by 3-2.
Tonight, she had 14 kills, 12 digs and 4 blocks in a losing effort: East 3, South 1.
It has been a great year for the Johnson family.
Josh is on the U.C.L.A. track team as a javelin thrower. "Personally I never thought they'd run track," said his father.
In January, Jimmy Johnson, Rafer's younger brother and a former defensive back with the San Francisco 49ers, was voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Rafer Johnson will be his brother's presenter at the induction in Canton, Ohio, on July 30.
Jennifer had a successful freshman season at U.C.L.A. and capped the summer off by making the Olympic Festival team.
"This is a big stepping stone for me," she said. "A big step toward making the national team."
Asked about the role her father played in her development, Jennifer said he was the exemplary role model.
"What he did was instill a great work ethic," she said. "He showed me the importance of working harder, hitting the weights, believing in ourselves, never giving up."
She said her dad isn't really a tough critic. "He can give me general counseling about conditioning and the mental aspects of being an athlete," she said. "But when it comes to volleyball, I'm the boss."
Johnson said the work ethic he passed on came, in large part, from his own upbringing in economically deprived circumstances and a sense that sports would somehow be a means to better his circumstances. His excellence in athletics earned him a scholarship to U.C.L.A.
He said the forces that drove him to compete are much different from those that are driving not only his children but many who compete.
"When I was competing there was no professional career," Johnson said. "I never even thought of making money as an athlete. I did it because I liked it, because I wanted to make the Olympic team.
"I wanted to be like Jesse Owens, Jackie Robinson."
Jennifer Johnson is not driven by the same forces. She just wants to win.
"The biggest thing is that we're just lucky to have two kids who love to compete," said her father.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS;
Where Textiles Tell Stories

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
IN ancient Assyria and Egypt, when women wove cloth, they were not just making skirts for the body or sheets for the bed; they were accumulating power. So concludes Elizabeth Wayland Barber, a professor of archaeology and linguistics at Occidental College in Los Angeles and the author of "Women's Work: The First 20,000 Years" ( W. W. Norton, 1994), which traces the cultural and economic importance of textiles.
In ancient times, "the ups and downs of women's rights had to do with how important to the culture and the economy their textiles were," Dr. Barber said. Four thousand years ago, women in Mesopotamia, for example, sold textiles for gold and silver. The women pictured above are shown gathering saffron to use as a yellow dye. In Egypt during the Middle Kingdom (2000 to 1786 B.C.), linen sheets were a chief means of barter. 
 Dr. Barber's fascination with weaving began in childhood, when she fell in love with folk dancing, and later, folk costumes. She saw patterns in the cloth that were very ancient. Although textiles may be ephemeral, she said, their role in history is not.
