HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Is Sports On Trial With O. J.?

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
WHILE the O. J. Simpson murder case and continuing pretrial hearing have made an immediate impact in regard to proposed legislation in some states to curb domestic violence, and while this has encouraged more women to ring hot lines to battered women's shelters, the case has, in a fashion, also put sports in America on trial.
Is this what we make of our celebrated athletes: Men who believe they have the right of entitlement, which includes the physical abuse of their spouses, or to stalk and intimidate their former wives or girlfriends? 
 Mariah Burton Nelson is among those who believe this is essentially the case. In a recent op-ed column in The Times she wrote that our sports world trains athletes "to hate women." She has since appeared on several television shows repeating this theory and relating it to the Simpson case.
In her new book, "The Stronger Women Get, The More Men Love Football: Sexism and the American Culture of Sports" (Harcourt Brace and Company) Nelson wrote: "Sports is a women's issue because on playing fields, male athletes learn to talk about and think about women and women's bodies with contempt."
This is a generalization to be sure, and, like all generalizations, a sweeping one. But like many generalizations, there is some truth to it, and she has marshaled some facts and statistics.
She cites, among others, for alleged spouse abuse the boxer Sugar Ray Leonard, the golfer John Daly, the baseball player Darryl Strawberry, the basketball player Moses Malone.
She cites statistics in which it is shown that, on college campuses, basketball and football players -- the most celebrated of the "manly sports," as Nelson terms it -- have been involved in more rape incidents than any other group, roughly equal to those by members of fraternities.
And she cites another, harrowing statistic: more than two million women are beaten each year by husbands or boyfriends. "About 1,400 women a year die at the hands of these 'lovers,' " she writes.
How many of those two million were athletes or former athletes? We know of that publicized handful. How many are involved in those 1,400 murders? Only one accusation comes to mind, that involving O. J. Simpson.
This doesn't minimize the seriousness of both the situation of women generally and the possibilities of Nelson's position regarding men and sports, but she overstates her case.
Lynn Hecht Schafran, senior staff attorney and director of the National Judicial Education Program, said that "domestic violence is a phenomenon that crosses the lines of race, ethnicity, religion, age, economic status and sexual orientation." In a paper that she distributes called "Facts on Domestic Violence," it states that in Massachusetts in recent years, to take one example, "batterers have included a business- school student, a police officer, a computer engineer, a building contractor and a college professor."
According to a Federal Bureau of Investigation estimate, 30 to 50 percent of all women in this country are abused by their husbands or boyfriends at some time in their relationships.
How many of these men could have been pampered, standout athletes? Not all of them, it seems reasonable to assume, were motivated by the so-called manly sports.
The problem is deeper than that. "Up to 80 percent of men who abuse their wives were victims of violence or witnessed the abuse of mothers," wrote Laura Crites in an article for the NOW Legal Defense Fund, "A Judicial Guide to Understanding Wife Abuse."
"Abused children grow up to abuse their children," she wrote. "And violent homes breed violent crimes."
Who truly knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? What went through the hearts of those Serbians who viciously raped innocent women? What goes on in the hearts of the gangs that rape the girls in their neighborhoods, or the rappers who condone and promulgate such violence? Or the religious zealots who cruelly suppress women?
It is more than sports, though sports in some moments mirror the larger aspects of historical and national violence. And there will always be foolish male coaches like Bobby Knight who will put sanitary napkins in a player's locker to send an ignorant message to be a tough guy.
The ideals of sports are to play by the rules, to be creative, to strive to get better. It doesn't always work that way, especially in the corrupt, win-at-all-costs high-profile sports. Bobby Dodd, the late football coach at Georgia Tech, put it best in response to a mother who wanted discipline for her son. "You give me a good boy," he said, "and I'll give you a good boy back."

HEADLINE: Debate Rages On Ball Park In Mt. Vernon

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 5

 BODY:
With its towering red brick columns and columned grandstand, Memorial Field resembles the sentimental new ball parks that have charmed fans and critics in Baltimore, Arlington, Tex. and Cleveland.
But unlike Baltimore's Camden Yards and its architectural cousins, the 6,000-seat stadium on this city's south side doesn't just look old. It is and it is showing its age badly. 
 Built in 1930, the stadium is a picture of decay. Weeds and dust choke the playing field. Paint flakes from the green railings in the concrete stands on the home team's side. The bleachers on the visitors side have been condemned.
The Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, has proposed buying Memorial Field from the City of Mount Vernon and investing $6.1 million to spruce up the park, converting its seating alignment for baseball, and attracting a minor league baseball team.
 
Mayor Likes the Plan
 Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood has embraced the county plan, arguing that Mount Vernon cannot afford the rehabilitation.
Taxpayers absorbed a 23 percent property tax increase last year, he pointed out, and would be loath to pay for the work. Still, the proposal has drawn opposition from Mount Vernon residents, many of whom use Memorial Field's running track, handball courts and tennis courts.
More than 300 residents turned out for a public meeting at the field and each of the nearly two dozen speakers denounced the sale. Taking a break from his evening walk on Memorial Field's gravel track, Steve Mitchell explained why. "Memorial Field belongs to the people of Mount Vernon," said the 57-year-old native of the city. "It's one of the few places where people can come together other than the school system. It's the lifeblood."
Mr. Mitchell said he ran track at the stadium during high school and he remembers summer evenings when the city would stretch a movie screen across the playing field and show movies. "It would be like Penn State selling Beaver Stadium to make a little more money."
 
Opponents Fears Exclusion
 Opponents of the sale fear a county-run Memorial Field would exclude them and threaten such popular events as Caribbean soccer and cricket league matches and the twice-annual African Family Day festivals held there.
While Westchester officials stress that Mount Vernon community events would have priority in scheduling, they acknowledge that there would be less every-day access to the field. The handball courts would vanish to make room for right field and more sporting events would mean more days and evenings when a redrawn track could not be used by the community.
"We feel the best use of Memorial Field is as it was built, as a stadium," said Philippe M. Gille, a senior aide to the County Executive. "Right now, it is used as a community park, not as a stadium."
Mr. Gille said the county envisions a renovated Memorial Field as the outdoor counterpart to the Westchester County Center, an indoor arena in White Plains that hosts events ranging from baseball card shows to minor league basketball games.
While Memorial Field is the site of soccer matches, Mount Vernon High School football games, and the traditional Thanksgiving Day football game between the Iona Preparatory School and New Rochelle High School, Mr. Gille said a refurbished stadium -- featuring artificial turf -- would attract a wider slate of games.
 
Looking for an Anchor
 A minor league baseball team would "provide an anchor" for the ball park, he said. The stadium would be purchased with county-backed bonds, and the purchase agreement is likely to include a clause allowing the city to buy back the field when the bonds mature in 20 or 30 years. No price has been agreed upon.
Mayor Blackwood agrees with Westchester planners who believe a revitalized Memorial Field would be an economic boon to Mount Vernon's south side. "Our best bet is with the county," he said. "We can't afford to put any more burdens on the taxpayer. People will come to the stadium, spend money in the area, increase the sales tax revenue and generally liven things up in that area."
For now, the ball is in the hands of the five-member City Council, which must approve the sale. If the city approves the plan, Mr. O'Rourke will include it in next year's capital budget, which requires action by the County Board of Legislators.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 9, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about the debate over selling a Mount Vernon stadium to Westchester County misstated the age of Steve Mitchell, an opponent of the sale. He is 51.

HEADLINE: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;
The History of Central Park Through a Handful of Benches

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER 

 BODY:
YOU may not think that seven benches could tell the nearly century-and-a-half story of Central Park. But if you know what you're sitting on, they can.
Across from the park, at the Cooper-Hewitt National Museum of Design, at Fifth Avenue and East 91st Street, is a handful of benches deceptive in their profound simplicity. A few evocative old photograghs, accompanied by some well-chosen words, capture the essence of each bench's moment in time. But essentially these seats just sit -- in the museum's elegant garden, which was first designed to set off Andrew Carnegie's 64-room mansion when the steel magnate and his family moved uptown in 1902. 
 It was a prescient act. Wealthy New Yorkers like the Vanderbilts and the Tiffanys had moved to the East 70's and 80's around the turn of the century, but Fifth Avenue was still a dirt road. Hardly 50 years before, Central Park had been carved out of 800 acres of swamp, woodland, rocky cow pastures and some settlements of the city's immigrant and black population.
The benches in the former Carnegie garden range from the rustic Adirondack style of the park's beginnings to an ornate hoop-armed cast-iron model made for the 1939 World's Fair to the 1994 look-alike that echoes the first Central Park settee from the 1870's. The Central Park Conservancy hopes to install copies of the new settee in the park this fall.
The star of the show, "Angles of Repose: A Garden Exhibition of Central Park Benches," is a 12-foot-long reproduction of one of the rustic log benches first designed by Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted to overlook the panoramic vistas of the artificial wilderness, which the two park makers constructed by moving many tons of earth and rock.
"They were supposed to transport you into a state of nature," said Michael Owen Gotkin, a landscape architect at the conservancy. "By sitting on them and viewing the natural landscape beyond, you would be propelled into the wilds of the Adirondacks."
Sit on this new old bench for a while. Let its rustic logs tickle your legs. Then, take a walk in the Ramble, looking for the few forbears that remain. The Ramble, which starts north of the Lake, at about 74th Street, is a wooded area that is best traveled with a friend during the day. Though it's important to be cautious in secluded areas of the park, it would be a shame to miss out on the sense of mystery and surprise that Vaux and Olmsted built into the Ramble.
"To ramble means to wander, to ramble about," Mr. Gotkin said. "The paths are circuitous. They come in on each other, and it's easy to get turned around. That was part of the picturesque idea -- to enter the forest with a little trepidation. To feel something ominous about a waterfall, or to be slightly fearful of rocks. And then to be amazed by some spectacular view."
At the end of September, when the exhibition closes, the rustic bench will be moved to a knoll amid the pine trees just east of Bethesda Terrace.
Mr. Gotkin didn't know much about park benches until about a year ago, when he was asked by the conservancy to come up with a new design for one. His research led him to the archives at Cooper-Hewitt, to photograph and art collections in other parts of the city, to the cellars of park-maintenance buildings and to the locked gates of Gramercy Park (where he found a couple of escaped Central Park settees).
The treasure hunt eventually led to the exhibition, which Mr. Gotkin organized with Lucy Fellowes, a history and design buff at Cooper-Hewitt.
The lineup is a kind of time line of the shifting tastes, technological breakthroughs, economic highs and lows and roller-coaster politics that have shaped the city and its most famous park.
After the rustic bench came a cast-iron settee that was mass-produced to seat the crowds that flocked to the park in the 1870's. By then, furnaces could be fired up high enough to melt iron, which was poured into a sand cast. "So everything was cast iron," Mr. Gotkin said. "From sewing machines to Franklin stoves."
Though cheap and sturdy, these benches had Greek Revival souls.
"See how they're almost transparent, how they let the light through?" said Ms. Fellowes, pointing to a circa 1870 photograph of settees bordering the Lake near Bow Bridge. "They define the edge of the landscape without drawing attention to themselves."
This was in the spirit of the Olmsted-Vaux Greensward plan of 1858, which said that "artificial structures should be subservient to the main idea" and that "the park itself should always be uppermost in the mind of the beholder."
But that was before the City Beautiful movement at the turn of the century. Manhattan had grown up. Its streets were on a grid, its buildings were taller, the car was replacing the horse. Richard Morris Hunt went to the Beaux-Arts school in Paris and returned to design the grand facade of the Metropolitan Museum. The Pulitzer Fountain and the statue of General Sherman went up on Grand Army Plaza, and Columbus at what was to become Columbus Circle.
"There were those who wanted parks to be expressions of civic grandeur rather than pastoral retreats," Ms. Fellowes said. One architect suggested selling off most of the park to build a 10-mile-long version of the Champs Elysees to bisect Manhattan.
The rocks and woods held steady. Even if they didn't look exactly like the Adirondacks, Vaux argued, they were as close as many people would ever get to the wilderness. But the benches bowed to the City Beautiful style. The two kinds of settees made between 1890 and 1910 were of wrought iron -- because cast iron had become so common -- and the arms and legs formed an elegant geometry of circles.
"Park benches were props on an open-air stage," the exhibition notes read, "where promenaders could see and be seen."
Then came the hard days of the Great Depression, and the park fell into neglect. Homeless people slept on the benches and in the rustic structures (as they do today), and taxpayers called the Mayor's office.
"Jimmy Walker, who was famous in New York as a drinker and party guy, saw an opportunity," Mr. Gotkin said. "He hired a new Parks Commissioner to design a bench that appeared larger and more substantial."
Made of concrete and wood, the new bench was probably no more durable than cast iron and wood, but it looked it. And Walker put jobless people to work building them.
When Robert Moses became the Parks Commissioner in 1934, he, too, wanted to put his stamp on the park and called for a new bench. This one was made of cast iron, with an Art Deco flair, but its basic shape harked back to the hoop arms of the turn of the century. About 8,000 were made for the 1939 New York World's Fair -- and many are still in the park today.
The 1994 bench, on the other hand, looks like the great-grandchild of the 1870's settee. The prototype has a straighter back, and it's made of ductile iron, which is stronger than cast iron. So go to the Cooper-Hewitt and try it out. See how it feels without a bustle. And let it transport you into the park beyond the garden gate.
The museum, at 2 East 91st Street, is open Tuesday, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesday through Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., and Sunday, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $3; people 65 and older and students over 12, $1.50; younger children, free. Admission on Tuesday, from 5 to 9 P.M., is free.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 14, 1994, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
The Garden Notebook column in The Home Section last Thursday, about a show of Central Park benches at the Cooper-Hewitt National Museum of Design, described one bench incorrectly. The 12-foot-long rustic log bench echoes the style of the Adirondack benches first designed for the park by Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted but is not a reproduction. It is an original design by Kim Hoyt, an architect for the Central Park Conservancy. In addition, a picture of a bench, on the front page of the section, and a picture inside the section of a bench in the Ramble in Central Park were credited incorrectly. Both photographs are from the collection of Herbert Mitchell, not the New York City Parks Photo Archive.

HEADLINE: Which Haiti Policy?

 BODY:
Give them this. This White House team knows how to upstage a Presidential trip. When Mr. Clinton was in Europe for D-Day observances, all eyes were on North Korea. Now, as he visits Poland, comes news that commando units of the United States Army and Navy have been practicing a takeover of Haiti's ports and airfields.
It is hard to believe that the Pentagon's willingness to discuss these "secret" maneuvers is not part of a plan to flush Gen. Raoul Cedras and his henchmen out of Haiti. That is a worthy goal, but the timing is amateurish and the underlying message is troubling. Washington and the United Nations have only recently gotten serious about enforcing meaningful economic sanctions. These need to be given a chance to produce political results. And a new refugee initiative unveiled Tuesday at least temporarily relieves the political pressure from that direction. 
 After months of vacillating from one policy to another, America faces the troubling prospect that Mr. Clinton is drifting into using troops in Haiti because he wants to compensate for other policy embarrassments and does not have a better idea. Armed force is a notoriously poor tool for solving political problems. Even if U.S. forces, as expected, were to make quick work of General Cedras and his crew, does Washington really want responsibility for enforcing law and order in a volatile, revenge-minded land?
Meanwhile, for Haitian refugees it is now America if by land, Panama if by sea. Under the Clinton Administration's newest refugee policy, the next 10,000 boat people qualifying for asylum will be sent to Panama. Only those who qualify in Haiti will be eligible for resettlement in the U.S.
The new policy promises larger numbers of people safe haven from terror and persecution; but it continues to discriminate against Haitians, denying qualified refugees the right to resettlement in the U.S. enjoyed by politically more popular groups.
The amended policy comes less than two months after the Administration ditched the despicable practice it inherited from the Bush Administration of escorting would-be refugees back to Haiti with no chance to explain the dangers that spurred their flight. Instead, new processing centers were opened in the Caribbean to evaluate refugee claims, about a third of which were found to have merit.
Predictably, that big policy shift encouraged many more Haitians to take to the seas, hoping to qualify for resettlement in the U.S. More boats brought more drownings. The increase also threatened to overwhelm the Caribbean facilities and re-ignited fears in Florida of a large influx of Haitians.
As it amends that policy now to bar qualified boat people from the U.S., the Administration still offers sanctuary from danger, meeting its minimal moral and legal obligations. Yet if people continue to flee at present rates, the 10,000 slots in Panama could be filled within two weeks.
Meanwhile, the new policy has one big defect. It subjects Haitians to discriminatory treatment because of their race and their lack of the powerful friends who have facilitated resettlement for comparably large groups of other nationalities. Some half a million Cuban refugees, for example, have been resettled in the U.S. since Fidel Castro came to power. More than 100,000 people have been admitted from the former Soviet Union since 1980 alone. Haitians, in contrast, have long been treated as an unwanted burden, even though many who do get in have achieved economic success. It is only very recently, after the Congressional black caucus and Randall Robinson took up their cause, that Washington's policies have begun to bend.
The Clinton Administration deserves credit for ending summary returns in May. Its new policy maintains that substantial achievement. But the Administration has done the right thing in a way that still reeks of discrimination. It thus invites criticism from all sides rather than the credit it could have gained for upholding the American principle of sanctuary for all in desperate need. And now it adds the confusion of a lurch toward military adventure without enough thought about what might come after the victory parades.

HEADLINE: At Summit, Little to Fix

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAPLES, July 7

 BODY:
As far as summit talks go, the meeting here of the leaders of seven major industrial democracies is a rather strange gathering for one simple reason: It has very little potential to do good, in large part because all seven countries already have economies growing faster than at any time in years. They really are not that broke and don't need much fixing.
But this meeting has significant potential to do bad, given the nervous state of world financial markets. The dollar's recent plunge against the yen and the German mark has roiled the currency markets, and uncertainty about the future of exchange and interest rates has global bond and stock markets on edge. 
 Any major disagreement among the leaders -- on interest rates, exchange rates or trade -- could further churn the markets, where many investors have already lost billions in the first half of this year.
The seven leaders, who began arriving in Naples today, will open their three-day conclave on Friday with an opening dinner, then focus on economics on Saturday and turn to political issues on Sunday, when they are to be joined by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
On economic matters, though, they are going to have to be careful about what they say. Looking at their own economies, they have reason to dance. But considering the state of global financial markets, they are dancing on a glass floor.
"I see very little prospect of drama on the upside at this summit," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "But I see great danger on the down side, if there is friction over exchange rates, interest rates or trade policy. The markets are not expecting any major breakthroughs on the upside, but they will be watching very, very carefully for any hint of divisions among the participants."
For the first time in years, all the nations in the Group of Seven -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- are experiencing positive economic growth. All have relatively low interest rates and inflation is hovering in the 3 percent range. Their major common problem remains creating enough new, good jobs.
But this reality has not guaranteed an amicable session. The backbiting among members over the currency issue began even before the leaders arrived in Naples.
 
German Snipes at U.S.
 Gunter Rexrodt, the German Economics Minister and a member of the small Free Democratic Party, took a swing at the United States on Wednesday when he blamed the recent weakness of the dollar on inconsistent American trade and economic policies, which, he said, were not conducted "particularly cleverly."
Mr. Rexrodt, in an interview with the Munich daily Suddeutsche Zeitung, made clear that his Government had no interest in taking part in concerted market interventions to prop up the dollar, adding that Germany had resisted joining in the recent dollar-buying spree by 17 central banks to bolster the American currency.
He said the main cause of the dollar's decline was the sharp outflow of Japanese capital from the United States as Japanese banks have pulled money home to deal with their own recession.
The United States, Mr. Rexrodt said, is highly dependent on Japanese capital to finance its huge deficit because Americans have a very low domestic savings rate, which is a "deep-seated structural problem."
American officials raised their eyebrows but stifled their voices in reaction to Mr. Rexrodt's remarks to avoid a confrontation.
Indeed, fearing such dissension at the talks, President Clinton has carefully lowered expectations so that the impact on markets of any discord here will be kept at a minimum, and the more positive aspects might stand out. Even before leaving for Naples, President Clinton said in an interview with foreign journalists that the dollar would not be a subject for discussion -- so the markets should not get their hopes up or down.
Mr. Clinton also stated that he did not expect any breakthrough in trade negotiations with Japan, given the fact that Japan's new Government has been in office less than two weeks. Just to make sure that the United States-Japan negotiations did not overshadow this summit meeting, the two sides temporarily suspended their talks on Wednesday.
 
Following Up Trade Accord
 So what will come out of the meeting? The newest idea, and maybe the most controversial, will be a call by Washington to begin thinking about what the group wants to do as an encore to the global trade agreement, which was completed in December after seven years of negotiations.
The concept goes like this: The accord, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, was primarily about lowering tariff barriers to promote free trade; 160 countries signed it.
But the biggest problem faced by the industrial democracies is no longer tariffs. It is how to protect their intellectual property -- books, software, movies, patents and videos -- from pirates in developing countries; how to get more access for their service industries like insurance, banking, brokerage and consulting; and how to lower barriers and provide more guarantees for the billions of dollars in investment capital flowing from the industrial world to the emerging economies of Asia and Latin America.
American officials say there is no way they can get 160 GATT signatories to discuss such issues now, particularly when the developing world does not share these priorities. Indeed, when the group tried to raise many of these issues during the GATT talks, they were rebuffed by the third world in particular.
But now, some American officials hope that the Group of Seven, which represent two-thirds of the world's gross domestic product but only 11 percent of its population, can develop proposals and incentives to persuade the third world nations to sign on.
"If you wait for 160 countries, it will never happen, but the G-7 countries have the power to start themselves," said a senior Clinton official.
"This will not be exclusive. We will include others as appropriate, but the old big multilateral approach won't work anymore. Our idea is that the big industrial democracies, who are the ones who started the GATT round seven years ago, should begin looking at the trade barriers that really affect them now, and they are not tariffs anymore."
Only France is resisting this proposal, arguing that until the GATT agreement has been ratified by all the signatories -- the United States in particular -- they should not be overloading the systems by starting new projects. If the French can be brought around, the summit leaders will assign their finance and commerce ministers to come up with a concrete proposal by next year's meeting, scheduled for Halifax, Nova Scotia.
 
Shadow of Chernobyl
 A second item on the agenda will aid for Russia and Ukraine to help them repair or shut down dangerous nuclear reactors.
The United States is planning to offer $25 million in seed money that it hopes will attract $125 million from the other six members and the European Union, to be used by Ukraine to make much-needed repairs on its two decrepit Chernobyl reactors and to begin laying the basis for other power sources.
Everyone in Europe wants Chernobyl to be shut down for safety reasons, but the Ukrainians will not do that without an alternative. The West, though, won't give Ukraine loans for a new non-nuclear power source until it reforms its economy and starts charging its citizens the real cost of energy instead of heavily subsidized rates.
As for economic aid to Russia, a central issue at past summit talks, there will be no new money offered this time. But the leaders will propose raising the amount Russia can borrow from the International Monetary Fund as a standby loan to $7 billion, from $4 billion.
Although President Yeltsin will join the members for a political discussion, there is no thought now of making the organization the "Group of Eight."
American officials say that until Russia's economy is fully transformed to a capitalist system and until it begins to become a serious economic power with a global outlook, it really cannot become a full-fledged member of the world's most exclusive economic club.

HEADLINE: PANAMA REFUSES TO TAKE HAITIANS; A REBUFF FOR U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Two days after the Administration announced that Panama would serve as a "safe haven" for 10,000 Haitian refugees, Panama withdrew from the plan, leaving Washington struggling to cope with a new flood of boat people.
The decision, announced by the Panamanian President, Guillermo Endara, led to a round of finger-pointing between Panama and Washington and overshadowed President Clinton's arrival in Italy for an economic summit meeting. 
 Surprised by the decision, Administration officials tried to put the best face on the setback. William H. Gray 3d, the special envoy on Haiti, said Washington would not pursue talks with Panama, but he insisted the United States would find other sites.
"We will continue forward with our policy," Mr. Gray told reporters. "Panama was an important part of it, but we are in the process of building a network to provide a response to the surge of refugees caused by the deterioration of human rights in Haiti."
Mr. Gray also announced that Grenada, like Antigua and Dominica, had agreed "in principle" to provide safe havens. Other officials said Washington was considering trying to establish camps in Guyana, Suriname and maybe even West Africa.
"Obviously we're disappointed," the White House press secretary, Dee Dee Myers, said in Naples, where President Clinton arrived today for a summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies.
American officials said Panama rejected the plan after President Endara realized he had misjudged the domestic opposition. But the collapse of the plan is likely to fuel criticism that President Clinton's foreign policy is confused. And it puts additional pressure on the White House to consider military force to oust Haiti's military leadership.
Even before the Panamanian announcement, the Administration was struggling to cope with the Haitians who have continued to put to sea. The Coast Guard announced that it had picked up 892 Haitians today by noon, and 1,731 on Wednesday. That brought the total since mid-June to more than 16,000.
To help stem the flood, the Administration announced on Tuesday that Haitians picked up at sea would no longer be resettled in the United States. And today, the Pentagon announced that it would expand its processing center at Guantanamo to handle 20,000 Haitians at a time.
"We are very aware of what the math is on this," said Dennis Boxx, the Pentagon spokesman. "We have people in Guantanamo Bay working 24 hours a day doing everything humanly possible to expand the capability of that camp."
Expanding the capacity at Guantanamo to 20,000, from 12,500 currently, will severely tax the military's ability to provide shelter, water, electricity and sanitation, military officials said. More than 10,000 Haitians are there already; more than 400 have decided to return to Haiti, an Administration source said today.
"It would be monumental," George H. Walls Jr., a retired Marine brigadier general who commanded a refugee operation at Guantanamo from November 1991 to March 1992, said in a telephone interview. During that operation, the number of refugees topped 11,000.
 
Tents on the Golf Course
 To make room for 20,000 refugees, the military will have to pitch tents on the base's golf course and football field, military engineers concluded in a study two years ago.
The base's desalting plant can produce three million gallons of drinking water a day, but the military would have to truck it to the Haitians or lay thousands of feet of pipe. The military could also bring in machines to convert sea water or brackish water into drinking water, General Walls added.
The sudden collapse of the Administration's negotiations with Panama prompted a round of recriminations.
The outlines of the plan were worked out last weekend by United States officials who went to Panama. To try to complete the understanding, Rand Beers, from the National Security Council, went to Panama early this week.
On Wednesday night, Administration officials confidently described the remaining issues as largely technical. But this morning it became clear that the differences reflected broad unhappiness in Panama.
President Endara was sworn in on an American military base in Panama during the 1989 United States invasion of Panama. And the perception that he was doing Washington's bidding appeared to be especially sensitive for the President, who leaves office on Sept. 1. Ernesto Perez Balladares, Mr. Endara's political opponent, won the presidency in early May in the first elections in Panama in more than 25 years.
 
Debating Who Blinked
 In his remarks to reporters in Panama City, Mr. Endara complained that the Administration had continually changed the terms of the arrangement and had taken Panama's cooperation for granted.
At first, Washington proposed that the refugees would be kept on an offshore island. Then, bowing to the wishes of the Panamanian political opposition, the United States said they would be kept on American bases.
Mr. Endara also said the plan to put the Haitians on bases in Panama violated the Panama Canal Treaty.
But one Administration official said it was President Endara who reneged after he realized he had miscalculated the degree of opposition.
Other changes in the refugee plan were announced today.
Mr. Gray acknowledged that Washington had relaxed its standard for determining which Haitians would be eligible for placement in a safe haven. On Tuesday Mr. Gray told reporters that only those with "a real and credible fear with regard to political persecution" would be sent to the camps. The others would be sent back to Haiti.
But officials said today that there would not be rigorous screening of Haitians picked up sea, and they would not be asked to prove they would face persecution if they returned.
Criminal and human rights violators would not be eligible to go to a safe haven.
 
Looking Closely at Force
 Though Administration officials insisted they can cope, the flood of refugees adds to the pressure on Washington to consider military action to topple the military leaders who ousted President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in September 1991. Human rights abuses by the military, combined with economic sanctions imposed on Haiti, have driven tens of thousands to flee the country.
Stepping up preparations for a possible invasion, more than a thousand commandos recently rehearsed a plan to seize airfields and ports in Haiti, Pentagon officials said on Wednesday.
Asked about the possibility of military action, Mr. Gray said today: "I think the prospect of intervention grows as the coup leadership refuses to recognize that the world community has clearly called upon them to step down and allow democracy to be restored, and for the people of Haiti to move from under the boot of repression. However the world community, along with the United States, is committed to attempting every effort to resolve this crisis through diplomacy and financial restrictions."

The Economy
The U.S. commercial real estate industry is being transformed from a collection of family-dominated fiefs into publicly owned companies. Experts say the change means new companies will be more responsive to tenants, have more money to maintain and buy properties and probably will not overbuild. [Page A1.]
The nation's leading retailers reported stronger sales in June, as warm weather increased demand for seasonal merchandise like air-conditioners, grills and casual clothing. [D1.] 
 Fewer Americans filed new unemployment claims last week, the Labor Department reported, ahead of a Government report that is expected to show strong employment growth in June. The decline of 21,000, to 332,000 last week, was the largest since April. [D12.]
 
Companies
Fidelity Management and Research bought $80 million of R. H. Macy bonds in a move to push through a merger of Macy and Federated Department Stores. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Poll on Doubt Of Holocaust Is Corrected

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY 

 BODY:
Only a small segment of Americans deny that the Holocaust happened, according to a new Roper poll for the American Jewish Committee.
The new poll was conducted to correct a flawed question in an earlier survey that had suggested higher levels of Holocaust denial and, both the researchers and sponsors say, to set the polling record straight. 
 "Committed or consistent deniers of the Holocaust make up only a small segment of the population, about 2 percent or less," said Dr. Tom W. Smith, of the University of Chicago's National Opinion Research Center, who analyzed both the new Roper poll and all other available United States surveys on the Holocaust for the American Jewish Committee.
Dr. Smith added, "There is an additional group of a few percent -- under 10 percent -- who express some doubts or uncertainty, but do so mainly from lack of information."
In the new poll, taken by Roper Starch Worldwide Inc. , 991 adults were interviewed across the country during March. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.
 
Question Is Revised
 It is a follow-up to an earlier Roper poll, taken in late 1992 for the American Jewish Committee, that seemed to indicate that 1 in 5 Americans doubted that the Holocaust had happened. Although that poll's finding about the Holocaust was widely publicized, Roper officials and other pollsters said it could not be considered accurate because the poll had used a confusing question.
In the new poll, the question was revised to read: "Does it seem possible to you that the Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened, or do you feel certain that it happened?"
Only 1 percent of those surveyed said it was possible that the Holocaust had never happened, and another 8 percent said they did not know; 91 percent said they were certain it had happened.
In the earlier poll, the flawed question used a double negative: "Does it seem possible or does it seem impossible to you that the Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened?"
In response to that wording, 22 percent of those surveyed said it was possible the Holocaust had never happened and an additional 12 percent said they did not know if it was possible; 65 percent said it was impossible that it had never happened.
"The double-negative question thoroughly confused people," said Burns W. Roper, the recently retired former chairman of the Roper polling organization. "Many may have given an answer just opposite of what they meant."
 
Correcting the Record
 Mr. Roper expressed satisfaction that the earlier inflated figure had finally been set straight. "It provided aid and comfort to the skinhead kind of anti-Semites and needlessly scared the Jewish community," he said.
The new study also found that:
*Detailed knowledge of the Holocaust had shown a modest overall gain, compared with the 1992 Roper poll. Dr. Smith attributed this to Holocaust museums and the film "Schindler's List." That knowledge was still limited, though Dr. Smith said it was comparable to Americans' knowledge of other World War II events.
*Americans were less knowledgeable about the Holocaust than the British, French or Germans surveyed in comparable polls.
*Education was a major factor accounting for Holocaust knowledge. Fifty-five percent of those with less than a high school education knew what the Holocaust was, compared with 87 percent of college graduates.
Dr. Smith's report, "Holocaust Denial: What the Survey Data Reveal," was originally scheduled to be made public by the American Jewish Committee on July 19. But Professor Everett C. Ladd of the University of Connecticut disclosed some of its findings in the July 1 edition of The Christian Science Monitor. In response, the American Jewish Committee disclosed Dr. Smith's full report yesterday.
Professor Ladd called the incident "an incredible chapter in American survey experience." He added, "People were really distressed, yet we went 14 months before we got a full acknowledgement."
David A. Harris, executive director of the American Jewish Committee, said, "Given the anxiety levels produced by the earlier poll, we felt it was worth the extra weeks needed to set the record straight with the kind of conclusive and comprehensive document Tom Smith has produced on the whole issue of Holocaust denial."

HEADLINE: In Tiny Haitian Port, Even Grief Is a Political Act

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ST.-MARC, Haiti, July 7

 BODY:
Gladys Paul lay on a bed in her two-room home groaning softly, grieving for her two children, who died on Monday when the rickety boat they were aboard capsized, killing at least 150 people.
"Oh! It hurts," she said to no one in particular, surrounded by a handful of friends and relatives. "My babies are gone." 
 Under normal circumstances Miss Paul, who lost two sons, Roygens Oscar, 7, and Ernst Oscar, 6, would expect a steady flow of visitors to pay their respects. And given the scope of the tragedy in a small city where every one is somehow related, the whole town would be mourning.
But these are not normal times: mourning the dead, particularly those who died trying to flee the island, can be seen as a political act.
 
Bodies Still at Sea
 Neither Miss Paul nor the relatives of the other victims have seen the bodies. Officials have not sent workers to retrieve the bodies, and many still float next to the capsized boat just offshore.
About six people have been arrested for organizing the journey, and many survivors are hiding in fear that they, too, will be detained by military officials.
But some remain defiant, openly acknowledging that they will return to sea at the first opportunity.
"I am not going into hiding," said Jean-Charles Oscar, who was on the boat when his sons, Roygens and Ernst, died. "I just lost two sons. If they want, they can come and kill me."
Political repression has worsened in recent months as military leaders who ousted the President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, have begin to suffer from the pressure aimed at forcing them out of power.
 
Specter of Invasion
 A force of 2,000 seaborne United States marines is to arrive off Haiti this weekend. One high-level Haitian military officer said that although the marines are only supposed to evacuate Americans in case of an emergency, army officers see the move as a prelude to an invasion.
Accidents like that near St.-Marc are all too familiar.
According to a dozen survivors interviewed today, at about 3 A.M. on Monday scores of people begin lining up to board tiny fishing boats to take them to a 30-foot vessel that was to sail toward the Windward Passage, where it was certain to be intercepted by United States Coast Guard cutters.
By 5:30 A.M., when the vessel set sail, about 300 people had crammed aboard the boat, which was built to hold 100 at most. After sailing less than 200 yards, the boat was rocked by a strong wind, and an instant panic sent people overboard.
"People started screaming," said Claudy Sylvain, 17. "I don't know how I got out. The last thing I remember I was on the shore trying to catch my breath."
Nowhere is the pain greater than in the Oscar family, which lost three small children. To Miss Paul her sons were as precious as "her two eyes." Neighbors described them as sweet, quiet and polite children. "They were nice kids," said Francoise Metellus, a friend of the family. "What has this country come to?"
The boys were nephews of Verdieu Oscar, who also lost his son. But three days after the accident, Mr. Oscar said that while he feels like a broken man, he will try again to flee by boat.
"I was looking for a better life for them, so I have resigned myself that this accident was their destiny," Verdieu Oscar said. He says he is fleeing economic turmoil and near starvation: "This morning I woke up and I didn't have a dollar to feed my child. My war has just began."
 
An Aspiring Lawyer Is Dead
 When told he might not reach the United States, he replied: "It's this country that I hate. I don't care where they send me. I will be all right, eventually."
Another victim was Rony Odige. At 25, he was the hope of his family. He finished high school two years ago and was studying sociology. In the fall, he was to begin law studies. Mr. Odige was a perfectionist who finished at the top of his classes. His passion was soccer, and after every World Cup match, he and friends would analyze the match passionately.
But as the political crisis steadily worsened, Mr. Odige began to lose faith that he would ever become a lawyer. In the last days before he died, he talked incessantly of joining his father, who emigrated to Irvington, N.J., in 1980.
"I can't explain it," said Byron Odige, Rony's brother. "I feel that a part of me has left me."
As the boat was swamped, Rony Odige, who did not know how to swim, cried out for help, and he took out a gold ring and tossed it to a nearby fisherman on a small boat as payment to rescue him.
The ring fell into the water.

HEADLINE: Parting Snapshots for the Supreme Court Yearbook

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The Supreme Court's 1994 term, which ended last week, was one of impressions rather than grand themes. The caseload was light but the going was tough. The Justices emerged somewhat the worse for wear and departed on a much-needed summer break, leaving behind the following array of snapshots.
HOTTEST NEW TOPIC: Garbage and what to do with it, the subject of three decisions, reflecting its growing role in the interstate economy. 
 LOWER COURT THAT FARED THE WORST: The Supreme Court of Oregon. The justices overturned all three of its decisions that they reviewed. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, didn't do too well either: the Court reversed it in 11 out of 14 cases.
LOWER COURT THAT FARED THE BEST: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond. The Justices reviewed three of its decisions and affirmed them all.
MOST PREDICTABLE RESULT: The Court's unanimous ruling in Dalton v. Specter that the choice of which military bases to close is not subject to challenge in Federal court.
LEAST REWARDING TRIP TO THE COURT: That of Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, who had brought the original lawsuit on military base closings in an attempt to block the shutting of the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard. The case had his name on it. He chose to argue it himself. He lost.
MOST AUSPICIOUS DEBUT: Silvia S. Ibanez, a sole practitioner and certified public accountant from Winter Haven, Fla., who had never argued an appellate case before she argued her own, a free-speech challenge to a state restriction on advertising by accountants who also practice law. She won Ibanez v. Florida, 7 to 2.
CASE THAT BROUGHT THE JUSTICES CLOSEST TO THE CUTTING EDGE OF POP CULTURE: Campbell v. Acuff-Rose Music, in which the Court reviewed 2 Live Crew's raw rap music parody of Roy Orbison's "Oh Pretty Woman" and decided unanimously that a commercial parody is not necessarily copyright infringement. There was something endearing about Justice David H. Souter, for whom 18th-century music verges on the suspiciously modern, offering a footnoted definition of rap music complete with references to hip-hop. But he could not match the enthusiasm of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, who in another copyright case a week earlier, Fogerty v. Fantasy Inc., referred to Creedence Clearwater Revival as "one of the greatest American rock and roll groups of all time."
MOST SURPRISING VOTE: That of Chief Justice Rehnquist, who left abortion rights groups cheering with his majority opinion in a final-day decision, Madsen v. Women's Health Center. The decision upheld most of an injunction that a Florida court had issued to protect an abortion clinic against disruptive protests.
MOST PREDICTABLE OPINION: That of Justice Clarence Thomas, who, in a concurring opinion in Farmer v. Brennan, reiterated his view that the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment applies to sentencing, not to conditions in a prison. Justice Souter's majority opinion held that the Eighth Amendment obliges prison officials to protect inmates from foreseeable violence by other inmates.
MOST PUZZLING VOTE: That of Justice Clarence Thomas, for concurring in Farmer v. Brennan rather than dissenting, as he logically should have done after announcing that he rejected the decision's premise and after calling on his colleagues to reconsider all the relevant precedents.
TERM'S SWEETEST VICTORY: To Chief Justice Rehnquist, whose 5-to-4 majority opinion in Dolan v. City of Tigard, a property rights case from Oregon, was a milestone in a years-long effort to give more constitutional protection to property owners fighting government land-use regulation. The decision put new limits on the ability of local governments to make public access a condition of approving a building permit.
MOST DRAMATIC MOMENT: Justice Harry A. Blackmun's denunciation of the death penalty in an emotional statement issued just weeks before his announcement in April that he would retire at the end of the term. "From this day forward, I no longer shall tinker with the machinery of death," the 85-year-old Justice said.
MOST POINTED EXCHANGE: Justice Antonin Scalia, a stylish polemicist, and Justice Souter. Justice Scalia for years has had no peer in the rhetorical riposte department, but he may have met his match in Justice Souter. They clashed notably in Board of Education of Kiryas Joel v. Grumet, in which Justice Souter's majority opinion held unconstitutional a public school district that New York State created for a village of Hasidic Jews. Justice Scalia, in blistering dissent, called the decision "astounding" and "unprecedented," saying that "it continues, and takes to new extremes, a recent tendency in the opinions of this Court to turn the Establishment Clause into a repealer of our nation's tradition of religious toleration."
To which Justice Souter replied: "Justice Cardozo once cast the dissenter as 'the gladiator making a last stand against the lions.' Justice Scalia's dissent is certainly the work of a gladiator, but he thrusts at lions of his own imagining."
MOST IMPORTANT STRAW IN THE WIND: In the Kiryas Joel case, when five Justices took the occasion to suggest that the Court reconsider two precedents in the church-state arena. The two 1985 cases prohibited public school systems from sending teachers onto parochial school premises to teach federally financed special education classes.
TERM'S HAPPIEST CAMPER: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who in her first term took the bench every morning with a smile and, by all accounts, enjoyed herself immensely.
TERM'S UNHAPPIEST CAMPER: Justice Thomas, who spoke hardly at all from the bench and who, during many arguments, looked as if he wished he were somewhere else.
WHEN IT STARTS AGAIN: The first Monday in October -- Oct. 3, 1994.

HEADLINE: Blue Chips Continue to Rise; Dow Up 13.92

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Stocks were higher yesterday, with gains posted by many big industrial companies, which are particularly sensitive to strengthening economic growth. Market analysts said the second-quarter profits of many industrial companies that have been cutting costs might be larger than expected.
Stocks of several retailers gained after strong store sales were reported for June. Dayton Hudson, which rose 1, to 81 7/8, said sales in its stores that were open more than a year jumped 12.7 percent, while Wal-Mart Stores, which rose 7/8, to 24 3/4, said its same-store sales rose 9.3 percent last month. Caldor rose 7/8, to 29 3/4, and Sears, Roebuck was ahead, 3/8, to 47 7/8. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 13.92 points, to 3,688.42. Gains posted by General Motors, Bethlehem Steel and Boeing accounted for 73 percent of the index's advance.
The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was moderate, at 259.7 million shares traded, when compared with the volume of the last few months, but was was higher than the volume of 233.6 million on Wednesday. The number of issues that advanced outpaced those that declined by 1,263 to 858.
 
Nasdaq Index Rises 5.53 Points

 
 Other indexes also moved higher. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.25 points, to 448.38; the New York Stock Exchange composite rose 1.03 points, to 247.57; the American Stock Exchange rose 1.10 points, to 424.65, and the Nasdaq composite rose 5.53 points, to 706.53.
Early in yesterday's session stocks drew much of their strength from modest gains in the dollar, Treasury bonds and overseas markets.
Many traders said they believed that while the stock market may have dodged a bullet in Wednesday's session, after the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee failed to move on interest rates, there was still one bullet left for the Fed to fire today.
The monthly employment data to be released today by the Labor Department have held traders at bay all week, keeping them from getting too excited about the market's near-term prospects. But buyers yesterday seemed to bet that the data about job growth would not be sharply above expectations, thus reducing the chances of an increase in interest rates. Too swift a growth in employment could help to raise inflation, the main economic threat the Fed would fight by raising rates.
Patrick J. Moriarty, chief investment officer for Bank Julius Bear in New York, said trading grew wary as the day wore on, with investors looking ahead to the employment data.
 
Job Gains Predicted

 
 Mr. Moriarty said economists were estimating a gain of 267,000 jobs in today's data, up from the gain of 191,000 posted in May.
Depending on today's report, Mr. Moriarty said, the Fed will probably not find cause to raise interest rates immediately. "We feel the current levels of inflation and economic growth are an aberration," he said, "and only a cyclical upturn within a long-term cyclical decline." But, he added, it will be a hard call to make if the new-jobs number is much higher than 350,000.
Beside retailers, another strong group was the automotive stocks. Chrysler climbed 3, to 49 1/8; General Motors rose 2 1/4, to 51 3/4, and Ford Motor rose 1, to 29 7/8.
Mr. Moriarty said the group was up after Wednesday's auto industry data that showed lower sales. The buying yesterday was sparked by the underlying reason for the lower sales report, he said, a lack of inventory, not a lack of demand.
"Also," he said, "all the car makers have announced price increases for 1995 and those increases are more likely to stick. And since used-car life spans are now above eight years, it means that demand will not dissipate."
Airborne Freight slumped for the second straight day after a Robinson Humphrey analyst cut estimates for its earnings because of declining package shipments and slower economic growth. The stock dropped 2 1/8, to 29 1/4, for a cumulative fall of nearly 17 percent in two sessions.

HEADLINE: Charles S. Benson Is Dead at 72; Expert on Education Economics

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Dr. Charles Scott Benson, an expert on the economics of education, died on Saturday in Carlsbad, Calif., while on a weekend visit with relatives. He was 72 and lived in Kensington, Calif., outside Berkeley.
The apparent cause was a heart attack, said the University of California, where Dr. Benson was a professor emeritus and, from 1964 until his retirement three years ago, taught educational administration and policy analysis. 
 Dr. Benson was also the director and chief investigator of the National Center for Research in Vocational Education. The center, based on the Berkeley campus, is a consortium of seven institutions financed by the United States Education Department to study the relationship between classroom studies and the workplace.
 
Models of Change
 Through his three decades at Berkeley, Dr. Benson's writings and advice contributed to public policy in America and abroad. He once said he regarded the center he headed as an instrument of changing a system that, he said, could doom a person who had no college degree to "wander from one minimum-wage job to another for about 10 years before finding a place to begin a career."
Most recently he focused on models for a vocational education that would integrate academic and vocational studies in high school as an alternative to the traditional college-preparatory curriculum.
He combined his research with public service in matters like school finance reform, social policies affecting pupils and their families, and the relationship between education and employment. He often served as a consultant to the World Bank, the Ford Foundation and American foreign aid officials, among others, on educational development planning overseas.
He played a role in the search for school finance reforms in the 1960's and 70's, and his text "The Economics of Public Education" (Houghton Mifflin) helped to define the subject. Dr. Benson, a native of Atlanta, received his bachelor's degree in economics from Princeton University and his master's and Ph.D. from Columbia University. Before joining the Berkeley faculty, he taught at Bowdoin College from 1950 to 1955 and at Harvard University from 1955 until 1963.
He is survived by his wife, Dorothy Merrick Benson; two daughters, Michele S., of Berkeley, and Sally M., of Richmond; a son, Charles S. Jr., of Pocatello, Idaho; a brother, Lawrence W., of Monroe, Ga., and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Sharp Rise Seen in Smokers' Health Care Costs

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Health care for smoking-related illnesses cost at least $50 billion in 1993, twice as much as has been estimated for previous years, according to a new Federal survey.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Atlanta-based agency of the Department of Health and Human Services, released the data today, saying that the estimate was based on a survey of 35,000 people, the most extensive to date. It is the only survey that has counted only actual medical bills, making it the most reliable estimate ever done, said Dr. Thomas E. Novotny, a leader of the study. 
 The study made these findings:
*Smoking accounts for at least 7 percent of all health care costs in the United states.
*The Federal Government and state governments pay for more than 43 percent of all smoking-attributed medical expenditures, and more than 60 percent for those over the age of 65.
*Most of the costs from smoking are for hospitalization, 54 percent; doctors' bills, 31 percent, and nursing home expenses, 10 percent.
 
Based on Multiple Interviews
 The study was conducted by the disease control agency and researchers from the University of California at Berkeley and the University of California at San Francisco, using information gathered by the Federal Government's National Medical Expenditures Survey from interviews with 35,000 people in 1987 and 1988. The figures were then adjusted for inflation to reflect the value of the dollar in 1993.
In the survey, each person was interviewed four times and each described his health problems and expenditures. The expenditures were then checked against medical records.
To estimate how much of the expenditures could be attributed directly to smoking, the researchers put those who were interviewed into four categories: those who never smoked, those who smoked for less then 15 years, those who smoked for more than 15 years, and those currently smoking. Then they added up the chief medical expenses of those with the most smoke exposure who had one of five diseases: heart disease, emphysema, lung cancer, arteriosclerosis and stroke.
The share of their medical expenses attributed to smoking was determined by first subtracting for other risk factors. For example, if a person was a smoker and also obese, the percentage of the spending attributed to smoking was less than it would be if the smoker was not obese.
 
Lower Than Actual Costs
 Dr. Novotny said the figures that resulted were "very minimum estimates" and likely to be lower than the actual costs.
He said that some medical problems attributed to smoking were not counted, like burns from fires caused by cigarettes and low birth weight or other infant health problems caused by a pregnant woman's smoking.
Dr. Novotny said the total economic burden of smoking is at least twice their $50 billion estimate. Other costs that should be included to reach a total estimate, he said, would be $6 billion more in costs associated with sick days and $40 billion in costs associated with premature death because of smoking.
The agency's figures are likely to be important to those states that have passed laws permitting them to sue the tobacco companies to recover money the states have spent for health costs linked to smoking. Dr. Novotny said that state-by-state estimates of the costs of smoking would be available within a few weeks.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Mark Time Awaiting Jobs Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday for a third straight session as the bond market remained calm ahead of today's Government report on June employment.
Since Tuesday, the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond ended each day within three basis points of the prior day's close. That is the smallest swing in the long bond's yield since the week of May 2, when it ended the day between 7.33 percent and 7.35 percent for four straight days. 
 Yesterday, the 30-year bond's yield ended at 7.60 percent, up one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, from Wednesday.
"There's no interest in trading right now," said Michael Marzano, head of bond futures trading at Yamaichi International (America). "People are waiting for tomorrow and next week."
 
Repeat of Turmoil?
 But some investors are worried that the bond market might have set itself up to repeat the turmoil in early May, when the Government shocked traders by reporting that more jobs than expected were created in April. The bond's yield jumped 20 basis points that day.
An unusually strong increase in new jobs in June could encourage the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates for the fifth time this year to keep the economy from growing too rapidly, leading to increased inflation.
A survey of economists shows that they expect the Labor Department to report that the economy added 267,000 jobs in June, up from 191,000 in May.
"I'm looking for it to be surprisingly strong, a lot stronger than people realize," said Roger Marshall, president of Riggs Investment Management of Washington, referring to the expected increase in new jobs in June.
The June employment increase could be larger than expected because the scheduling of the report gave the Labor Department one more week than it normally does to collect statistics, some economists said.
Mr. Marshall warned that Treasury bond yields could soar, possibly reaching 8 percent before the summer is over, if job growth remains robust.
Still, bond prices did not react to a report that first-time jobless claims fell an unexpected 21,000 in the latest week to 332,000, the lowest in almost four months.
 
Concern About Dollar
 Some analysts noted that the Fed was also concerned about the weakening dollar. Higher American interest rates would bolster the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive to investors.
"The Fed is looking for a reason to come in here and make a move so they have something else to point to besides the dollar," said James Casselberry, who manages about $900 million in bonds for the Chicago-based MacArthur Foundation.
But many economists have said that the Fed's concerns about the condition of the American economy are likely to outweigh its interest in supporting the dollar.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making panel, ended a two-day meeting on Wednesday without announcing any moves to push up interest rates.
This weekend, the leaders of the Group of Seven industrial countries are meeting in Naples. But there were few signs yesterday that they would take any major action to support the dollar.
Some analysts say the Fed may have decided to raise interest rates again to head off inflation and is just waiting for an appropriate time to announce it.
"If you get a strong economic number, it makes it easier politically to raise rates," said William Stevens, who manages $250 million in bonds at Montgomery Asset Management, based in Walnut Creek, Calif.
In early trading yesterday, Treasury bonds gained as much as 12/32 of a point on speculation that the Fed bought Treasury securities for other central banks.
"There's been talk of the Fed buying two-year and five-year notes, but I have no confirmation of that," Mr. Marzano of Yamaichi said. A spokesman at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York declined to comment.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Amid Signs The Group of 7 Won't Act

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell moderately against the German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday amid signs that leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations would do little at their summit meeting this weekend to support the American currency.
Many traders sold dollars late in the day after an American official said the Group of Seven would not try to stabilize the dollar. 
 "We don't expect any kind of yen-dollar coordination at this summit, be it major or minor," said the official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
 
 
Three-Day Meeting
 The comments are the latest in a series by Group of Seven leaders and senior Government officials indicating that they are not concerned about the dollar's fall and are unwilling to try to support it. The group starts a three-day meeting in Naples today.
So far this year, the dollar has fallen 9.5 percent against the mark and 11.5 percent against the yen.
"The G-7 is sending signals that we shouldn't expect any action from them in the currency market," said David De Rosa, director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "Of course, they could be trying to fake us out."
Success in propping up a slumping currency often depends on catching foreign-exchange traders off guard. Group of Seven leaders may be feigning relative indifference to the dollar's fate so they can catch traders wrong-footed later, Mr. De Rosa said.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5732 marks, down from 1.5782 marks on Wednesday. It also fell to 98.60 yen from 99 yen.
 
 
'Behind Us'
 The dollar fell earlier in the day after Italy's Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, said the world's monetary authorities had little power to support the dollar because the foreign exchange market had become too large. "That sort of ability to intervene is behind us," he said, adding that he was not worried about the weakness of the dollar.
"Everyone is waiting for the weekend," Peter Wadkins, senior vice president at MTB Bank, said. "If nothing happens, they'll sell the dollar again next week."
The dollar showed little change against the mark earlier yesterday after the Bundesbank left German interest rates unchanged after its biweekly meeting. Some analysts had expected the German central bank to cut rates as part of an international effort to bolster the dollar.
Speculation that the Federal Reserve might raise American interest rates after the June employment report comes out today kept the dollar from falling further, traders said. Some expect the Fed to act if the report shows the economy is growing fast enough to raise the risk of an acceleration of inflation.

HEADLINE: First-Time Jobless Claims Decline

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new unemployment claims showed a surprising drop today on the eve of a Government report that is expected to show strong employment growth in June.
New jobless claims declined 21,000 last week, to 332,000, the Labor Department said today. It was the largest drop since April and the lowest level since March. During the previous week claims rose by 1,000, to 353,000. 
 The report sets the stage for Friday's June employment survey, which could counter other recent Government statistics suggesting the economy may be losing momentum. "I don't think the economy has slowed down," said William Stevens, who manages $250 million in bonds at Montgomery Asset Management.
 
 
Survey of Economists
 Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News estimated that the economy added 267,000 more jobs in the month after adding 191,000 in May.
Robust job growth could encourage the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates again to keep inflation in check. On Wednesday, Fed policy makers wrapped up a two-day meeting on monetary policy without taking any immediate action on interest rates.
While many analysts expect the June employment report to show a big gain in service employment, along with more modest increases in manufacturing and construction hiring, the total number could be skewed by a seasonal quirk. "Due to the bad winter, many schools had to extend the school year, so teachers and other educational employees may have been on payrolls longer than usual," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch in New York.
At the same time, big companies announced only 35,032 work force reductions in June, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago employment firm. That is down from the monthly average of 50,843 job cuts for the last year and a half.
 
 
Moving Average
 Today's Labor Department report showed the four-week moving average for jobless claims, a more consistent gauge of employment conditions, fell to 346,500 last week from 353,250 in the prior week, also the lowest level since mid-April.
Part of last week's decline might be tied to the fact that auto makers delayed the customary summer shutdown of some factories, said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist with Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc.
Separately, the Commerce Department reported today that inventories of unsold goods at wholesalers rose 1.6 percent in May, the biggest gain in almost two years. Wholesale sales for the month rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
Wholesale inventories increased to $223.2 billion during the month following a revised 1 percent gain in April, rather than four-tenths of 1 percent as originally reported.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Long-Term Coffee Surges As Figures Hint of Shortage

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The prices of long-term coffee futures surged yesterday on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange as new supply figures suggested a shortage was possible. The surge came even though prices for near-term coffee contracts fell.
A mixed showing in other commodity futures led to only a modest increase in the Commodity Research Bureau price index, a key indicator of inflation activity. The index of 21 agricultural and industrial commodities rose 0.61, to 225.92. 
 On other commodity markets, energy futures prices slumped; grains and soybeans were mixed; livestock and meat futures finished higher, and precious metals ended mixed.
Green arabica coffee beans for September delivery fell 1.15 cents, to $1.933 a pound, but most other contracts surged 9 cents, with the December contract closing at $1.95 a pound.
Coffee prices seesawed throughout the session amid a flurry of news reports and rumors. The prices fell early in the session on rumors that Brazil planned to offer five million bags of coffee for auction during a 10-month period, which would flood the market.
They rebounded later amid reports that frost damage in Brazil would lead to the harvesting of 17 million bags, down from estimates of 22 million bags, said Sandra Kaul, a coffee analyst with Smith Barney in New York.
Later in the day, Brazil's Government said it would auction five million bags from its stocks. The Government also reduced its 1994-95 crop estimates to 17.5 million bags, a loss of 28.6 percent of the crop.
Crude oil futures prices led other petroleum products lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the August contract falling 12 cents, to $19.12 a barrel.
August home heating oil fell 0.91 cent, to 48.18 cents a gallon; August unleaded gasoline fell 0.84 cent, to 52.13 cents a gallon; August natural gas fell 0.5 cent, to $2.072 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Soybean and wheat futures prices finished mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade amid improved export demand for the crops. But exports remain well below last year's levels, which could put pressure on prices in the coming weeks as weather helps those crops grow.
Corn futures prices were mostly lower as better weather led to visions of a bumper crop. The National Weather Service's 6-to-10-day forecast called for rain and normal to slightly above-normal temperatures, which would help crops during a crucial growing period.
Wheat for delivery in July rose 1 1/2 cents, to $3.06 3/4 a bushel; July corn rose 1 3/4 cents, to $2.40 a bushel; July oats rose 2 3/4 cents, to $1.15 a bushel; July soybeans rose 4 1/4 cents, to $6.24 1/4 a bushel.
