HEADLINE: A SURGE IN HIRING ADDS TO CONCERNS ON U.S. INFLATION

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
A Labor Department report showing a sharp and unexpected surge in the number of jobs created in June gave financial markets jitters about inflation today. Traders' concerns were only magnified as the Clinton Administration tried later to allay their fears about the economy and the dollar.
While the unemployment rate held steady at 6 percent, the increase in business payrolls of 379,000 jobs was considerably stronger than analysts had anticipated. Coming on top of sizable upward revisions in the number of jobs created in April and May, the report seemed likely to push the Federal Reserve closer to another increase in short-term interest rates to prevent a surge in inflation -- a move it opted not to take at a policy-setting meeting this week. 
 Since inflation would lower the value of long-term bonds, the news caused prices of fixed-income securities to slump, driving rates up. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 7.69, the highest level since Nov. 9, 1992, shortly after the last Presidential election. [Page 35.]
Stocks initially declined but recovered and finished higher.
Within hours after the report was released, the dollar plummeted against other currencies after President Clinton, meeting in Naples with the leaders of other industrial countries, seemed to rule out support for it from either the Administration or the largely independent Federal Reserve. [Page 4.]
 When asked why the dollar was performing so poorly while he was describing the economy as on its "soundest footing in decades," Mr. Clinton suggested that there was little governments could do in the short term to bolster the currency. He said he expected the dollar would rebound on its own when the fundamentals of the American economy were fully recognized.
"It is important not to overreact," Mr. Clinton said, adding, "It would be a mistake for us to change the fundamental objectives that we all ought to have, which is to pursue global growth."
Later, when asked about the job figures, Mr. Clinton said that these did not imply resurgent inflation and suggested another interest rate increase was unnecessary. "We don't want to adopt a short-run strategy that could choke off growth in the other G-7 countries and in other parts of the world," he said.
After his remarks sent the dollar below 98 yen, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen was dispatched to reassure the markets that the United States did not welcome a weak dollar and had not ruled out action to support it.
By itself, the jobs report signaled continued strength in the economy and was hailed by officials here as evidence that expansion remained brisk. Although the job gains were concentrated in retail trade and other services, factory jobs grew by 34,000 to bring the total since October to about 100,000.
"It's a lot harder today to find people than it was a year ago," Frank N. Liguori, chief executive of the Olsten Corporation, a leading supplier of temporary business and health-care workers. He said his company had posted 20 percent year-over-year increases in billable hours since the first of the year, a trend implying continued robust growth for the economy at large.
Robust as the June job gains were, however, some special factors swelled the payroll total. Combined with contrary results in the less reliable survey of households, these factors appeared to blunt market fears that the economy might be on the verge of overheating. Most economists have been expecting the Fed to raise interest rates to curb excessive growth, and today's report, while perhaps hastening that day, was not so strong as to make a rate increase a certainty.
"The evidence, if you read it, is encouraging on the inflation front," Mr. Clinton said. "I don't think we should do anything to undermine the recovery when we have still Americans who need jobs, we have still Americans who are working part time who wish to work full time. We have parts of America that have not felt the recovery, and we have no evidence of inflation."
Indeed, wage pressures seem well in check. Average hourly earnings actually edged lower by a tenth of 1 percent last month and are up just 2.5 percent from the level of June 1993, the department's report also showed.
"Wage inflation remains very low in the face of these striking gains in employment," Norman Robertson, an economic consultant in Pittsburgh, said. He attributed this in part to exceptional growth in low-paying jobs, many of them in the service sector, and to intense competition among workers in most regions.
The Clinton Administration hailed today's report, with Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich calling it "excellent news for American workers." He noted that payrolls expanded by a million jobs in the second quarter -- 50 percent more than in each of the two preceding quarters -- and that the rise in factory jobs last month was the biggest such gain in four years.
One special factor helping to overstate the gains was that five weeks, rather than the more usual four weeks, elapsed between the department's May and June job surveys, allowing an estimated 100,000 extra payroll jobs to be counted.
When this phenomenon of a late survey week occurs while schools are letting out for the summer, officials said, the effects can be magnified. This year was particularly hard to fathom because many schools remained open longer than usual to make up for closings during an exceptionally severe winter. The effect would be mainly on students and their summer jobs, since teachers are generally under contract and considered employed year-round.
 
 
 
The World Cup Effect
 Private economists also said they thought the World Cup soccer tournament had generated additional jobs, noting that restaurants and bars alone added 69,000 jobs last month, nearly 20 percent of the total payroll gain.
Construction added 16,000 jobs last month, about half of the monthly average so far this year, as interest rates appear to have cut into home building, economists said. Temporary help, an area that has long been booming but that had only a tiny gain of 2,000 jobs in May, rebounded with a jump of 46,000 jobs in June.
The report also showed the average workweek easing a bit -- by 12 minutes, to 34.6 hours -- from near-record levels, a sign that employers had pushed their existing work forces to the maximum.
"They got to the point they decided they needed to hire more people," said Patrick Flaherty, assistant economist at the Shawmut National Corporation in Boston.
 But in sharp contrast to the results of the department's mail survey of more than 390,000 employers, which analysts consider by far the better gauge of economic performance, was its newly overhauled survey of 60,000 households.
This showed employment dropping by 442,000 in June, a development accompanied by a drop of 526,000 people in the labor force. That allowed the unemployment rate to hold at the 6 percent level to which it had fallen in May, by four-tenths of a point.
 
 
 
'Unusual' Divergence
 "Although the month-to-month movements of employment as measured by the two surveys commonly differ in size and occasionally in direction, large movements in opposite directions such as those that took place this month are unusual," a somewhat baffled Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress today.
Officials suggested that a partial explanation might be found in new methods used for the survey this year that relies on old factors for seasonal adjustment, the process of allowing for recurring variations related mainly to the calendar.
But for some reason, the labor force is smaller now than it was at the beginning of the year, a development in sharp contrast with what usually happens in a business expansion, when job growth inspires more and more of those who have retreated to the sidelines to go look for work, swelling the labor force.
A total of 532,000 people were listed as discouraged about job prospects last month, up from 436,000 in May, figures not adjusted for seasonality. Those with two or more jobs fell to 7,110,000 from 7,316,000 on the same basis, the report showed.
 Geographically, there was relatively little movement last month, with unemployment rates edging up a tenth of a point in the Northeast and West, to 6.4 percent and 7.4 percent respectively, and easing two-tenths of a point, to 4.5 percent, in the Midwest. The South's jobless rate was unchanged at 5.9 percent.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN NAPLES: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Speaks, and It's a Tricky Day for the Dollar

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NAPLES, July 8

 BODY:
President Clinton set out today to convince the leaders of the other big industrial nations that the United States economy is back in the groove, growing steadily, and that they had best heed his advice.
But in the process, the luckless President stumbled in an embarrassingly public way. 
 Mr. Clinton said he saw no short-term way to prop up the dollar, which has fallen sharply in recent weeks, especially against the Japanese yen. In earnest tones, he warned against quick fixes.
Almost instantly, as financial reporters here monitored their computer screens, the markets read the remarks as an augury of continuing weakness for the dollar.
Traders quickly sent the value of the dollar below 98 yen, near its post-World War II low. The dollar also fell to a 19-month low against the German mark. [Business Day, page 43.]
While the markets were still open, senior officials rushed pell-mell back to the briefing room to tell reporters that the President had not ruled out further action to bolster the dollar.
Speaking a few hours before the leaders of the world's seven main industrial powers began their annual meeting at a calculatedly informal dinner, Mr. Clinton said he wanted to "send a signal to the markets that we are working on the economic fundamentals."
He said he did not want them to adopt a short-term strategy that could "choke off growth" around the world through higher interest rates. Pressure to prop up the dollar or head off inflation could lead to an increase in interest rates.
In fact, few if any members of the so-called Group of Seven have shown much inclination to prop up the dollar. German officials, for example, said the dollar was now near its 10-year average against the mark, which suited them fine. Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Italy would benefit by paying for imported oil with cheaper dollars.
After meeting with Mr. Clinton for 90 minutes this morning, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan said he and the President had agreed that government intervention in currency markets would be unwise. The rapid rise of the yen has shaken Japanese industry, whose products will be more costly abroad, and that has complicated things for Mr. Murayama, who took office just 10 days ago.
 
Spruced-Up City
 Like Eliza Doolittle scrubbed and dressed in silks, Naples looked its spectacular best for the international extravaganza, which has given the city a chance to shake its reputation for crime, poverty and filth. Gone were the piles of garbage along the waterfront, gone were the demonic traffic jams.
But despite the fresh paint and newly planted flowers, the melodramatic heart of this sentimental, theatrical old port continued to beat. A few blocks behind the police cordons, horns honked and Neapolitans argued and gestured with their usual brio.
Life is as hard as ever, with 27 per cent unemployment. A guard at the San Martino monastery overlooking the city begged an American to ask Mr. Clinton to get his brother a job.
The President spent the day in a series of meetings -- first with Mr. Berlusconi, whom he met in Rome last month, then with Mr. Murayama, Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada and Prime Minister John Major of Britain.
The other leaders in Naples are Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France. President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia is to arrive on Saturday and sit in on political sessions Saturday night and Sunday as a full participant, an important departure.
 
Politics, in Passing
 There was some discussion on Bosnia, some on other political topics, but for once the focus was squarely on economics as this, the 20th annual economic summit meeting, opened on the 50th anniversary of the Bretton Woods conference in New Hampshire that set up the postwar international monetary system.
At a news conference late this afternoon, Mr. Clinton was asked repeatedly whether the withdrawal of Panama from arrangements for handling Haitian refugees made military action in the Caribbean more likely. He said he had ruled out nothing.
He carefully listed American interests in Haiti, from the million Haitian-Americans, to the American citizens working in Haiti, to the promotion of democracy in one of the two countries in the area with military governments. (The other is Cuba.)
Such litanies have been recited by other Presidents before military action, but when pressed on prospects for an invasion, Mr. Clinton insisted, "My position has not changed since I first commented on that."
 
A Bit of Braggadocio
 The news conference took place in a classic Neapolitan setting, the terrace of Zi' Teresa, one of the small restaurants that cluster around Santa Lucia harbor, celebrated in the most famous of all Neapolitan ballads.
Mr. Clinton opened with a long statement in which he bragged just a little about his country's economic performance, which has been much the best in the last year of any of the seven nations.
"America has 40 percent of the G-7's gross domestic product but provided 75 per cent of the growth and about 100 percent of the new jobs over the last year," he said. "Growing our economy and shrinking our budget deficit from the biggest among these nations to one of the smallest gives us the authority to speak and the credibility to be heard on the matters of discussion here."
But the unpleasant reality of the sagging dollar intruded upon Mr. Clinton's optimism.
Asked to explain the situation, he blamed it mainly on the persistent trade deficit with Japan. Because Japan has had so many recent changes of government, he acknowledged, "there has not been the political capacity to reach any agreements which would permit the trade deficit to narrow."
 
New Minister in Town
 In the talks between Mr. Murayama and Mr. Clinton, the new Prime Minister reportedly reaffirmed all the general promises about opening Japanese markets to more American exports, but with no guarantee that this would happen soon -- if at all.
The one new thing Mr. Murayama said publicly was that his Government planned another income-tax cut next year to stimulate consumer spending, without a compensating sales-tax increase.
In the past, the Finance Ministry has been willing to accept a tax cut only if it was matched by a rise in consumption taxes. United States officials were mildly pleased to hear that Tokyo was ready to cut taxes again next year; but without a promise not to raise other taxes later, they said, it does not mean much.
At a separate briefing, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen was asked whether figures issued today showing rising employment in the United States meant that the economy was overheating. "At this point I don't think so," he answered.
Mr. Bentsen was also asked whether he thought the Federal Reserve should raise interest rates to make sure the economy does not surge so fast that it produces inflation. He said bluntly, "Not at this point."

HEADLINE: Next Question: If Employers Don't Pay Health Bill, Who Will?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
President Clinton's goal of health insurance for all Americans is often described as a moral imperative or a political objective, but it is also a pocketbook issue.
In one sense, there is no mystery about how to reduce the number of uninsured: it just takes money. The question is who should pay. 
 In trying to achieve universal health insurance coverage, Mr. Clinton and Congress will confront an unpleasant choice in the next few weeks. If employers do not pay most of the cost, as Mr. Clinton has proposed, then the Government and consumers must pay more.
Many people describe Mr. Clinton's proposal for an "employer mandate" as an alternative to taxes. Still, the public would ultimately pay. Economists say that employers would pass on the costs to their workers by reducing the amount of money available for wages or future pay raises.
 
Guarantees, but Not for All
 Members of Congress are skittish about requiring everyone to obtain insurance, and many flatly oppose Mr. Clinton's proposal to make employers pay most of the cost. Many lawmakers now suggest that the Government should initially try to guarantee coverage for some fraction of the population, perhaps 95 percent, as the Senate Finance Committee has proposed.
What difference does it make whether 95 percent or 100 percent of the people have insurance? And who is most likely to remain uninsured? Those questions are at the heart of the current debate over how to redesign the nation's health care system.
Currently, the Government estimates that 39 million Americans, accounting for 15 percent of the population, have no health insurance. But such numbers imply far more precision than is possible with any measuring tools now available. People's insurance status is continually changing as they change jobs, marry and divorce, move from one state to another and go on and off the rolls of programs like Medicaid and Medicare.
 
Unintended Adverse Effects
 Virtually all the major health care proposals now in Congress would make health insurance more available, prohibit insurers from denying coverage to people with a history of illness or disability and prevent insurers from charging extremely high premiums to people with high medical risks.
But such changes, by themselves, would not solve the problem, and experts warn that half measures could have unintended adverse effects. Alice F. Rosenblatt, an actuary at Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, said that "a small proportion of the uninsured, probably less than 5 percent, have been denied coverage because of pre-existing conditions like cancer and cardiovascular problems."
Moreover, unless there is some mechanism for enrolling all people in health plans, millions of Americans are likely to remain uninsured because they do not want to be bothered, see no need for coverage or cannot afford their share of the cost.
"Many people may rationally choose not to purchase health insurance coverage, either because they have low income or because they believe they have a low risk of needing health care services," said William S. Custer, research director of the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonpartisan organization whose members include businesses and labor unions.
 
The Young May Go Without
 If there is no requirement for people to have insurance, many who are young and healthy will probably go without it because they see no immediate need, given the cost. If significant numbers of healthy people go without insurance, the average risk of the policyholders rises, and their premiums increase as a result.
At least 11.6 million people 18 to 29 years old have no health insurance. They account for 30 percent of the uninsured. It is desirable to have these people in the insurance pool because their medical costs are generally lower than those of older people, actuaries say.
Under most of the proposals in Congress, poor people would pay little or nothing for health insurance. The Government would pay the premiums for people with incomes below the official poverty level, now $14,764 for a family of four. Lawmakers assume that affluent people can buy private health insurance, costing $4,000 to $6,000 a year for a family, if they do not receive coverage through employers.
So, health policy experts say, if employers are not required to provide insurance to their employees, the people most likely to be uninsured are people in the middle-income range, particularly those who work for small companies.
"All the major proposals would give full coverage to people below the poverty line," said Mr. Custer of the Employee Benefit Research Institute. "That's the first group that would pick up coverage. Uninsured people at the poor end of the middle class are least likely to pick up coverage as a result of these reforms."
Eleven million people without insurance, or 28 percent of the uninsured, have incomes below the poverty level. They could get coverage at little or no charge under most of the proposals pending in Congress.
If the Government provided coverage similar to what the average employer now offers, it would cost $2,000 a year for each uninsured person. For every million people who received fully subsidized coverage, the Government would have to pay at least $2 billion a year.
Nearly one-third of the uninsured -- 12.5 million of the 39 million people without coverage -- have incomes between the official poverty level and twice that amount. Under the major proposals, these people would get some financial assistance from the Government to help them buy insurance.
 
A Cautionary Note
 Whether such subsidies would be adequate depends on many questions: the amount of the assistance, the cost of the insurance and the portion, if any, paid by employers.
Mr. Custer sounds a cautionary note. "It is extremely unlikely that simply lowering the costs of insurance will achieve universal coverage," he said.
Clinton Administration officials say that universal coverage is not only good health policy but also good politics. Health care is a pocketbook issue, they say, because people can be impoverished by medical bills.
"People who work should not be left behind when we reform the health care system," said Gregory E. Lawler, a lawyer coordinating the health care campaign at the White House. "They should have guaranteed private insurance."
More than half of the uninsured are working adults. Eighty-four percent of the uninsured live in families headed by workers. But in recent years, there has been a decline in coverage provided by companies with fewer than 25 employees. Such companies say they are often unable to obtain affordable health insurance for their workers because insurers charge them higher premiums, reflecting the risks and the administrative costs associated with small groups.
 
Concern for Children
 Congress has for years shown special concern for the medical needs of children, and that impulse is clear in many proposals to overhaul the health care system. The Finance Committee, for example, accepted a proposal by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, to provide extra subsidies to help pay insurance premiums for children in families with incomes up to 2.4 times the poverty level.
Nearly 10 million children under 18 years old have no health insurance coverage, and most of them could obtain it under the bills now pending in Congress.

The Economy
 
A Labor Department report showed a sharp and unexpected surge in the number of jobs created during June, giving financial markets jitters about inflation. Traders' concerns were magnified as the Clinton Administration tried later to allay their fears about the economy and the dollar. While the unemployment rate held steady at 6 percent, the increase in business payrolls of 379,000 jobs was stronger than expected. [Page 1.] The jobless rates in New York City, New York State and New Jersey remained higher than the national rate, the Government reported. [47.]
 

President Clinton set out to convince the leaders of the other big industrial nations that the U.S. economy is back in the groove, growing steadily, and that they had best heed his advice. [1.]
 
An independent U.S. trade panel agreed that Canadian wheat imports were hurting American markets, but disagreed about how severe the problem was and what kind of action to take. [36.]
 
Federal Reserve officials voted unanimously at their May 17 policy meeting to raise short-term interest rates because of concerns about inflation, the minutes of the meeting shows. [44.]

A Federal judge accepted the guilty plea of Swaleh Naqvi, one of the two top executives of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, on sweeping charges of fraud, racketeering and conspiracy, despite sharp criticism by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, that the deal was too lenient. [1.]
 
A crucial group of R. H. Macy's creditors moved closer to a deal that would clear the way for a merger with Federated Department Stores, even though Macy's board postponed a decision on supporting a combination of the two retailers. [35.]
 
Panamsat launched the first of three big communications satellites. The company has signed long-term contracts with more than 30 corporate customers. [35.]
 
Britain awarded licenses to AT&T and some other companies for operating long-distance services in the country. [37.]
 
Jamesway filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan that would give its creditors a majority of the stock in the retailing company but would pay them only about half of what they are owed. [37.]

International
 
Gibes are greeting the introduction of Brazil's new currency, the real, but Brazilian financial officials see the currency switch as the last best hope of driving down the country's inflation rate. [35.]
 
British authorities are investigating the author Jeffrey Archer for possible criminal insider trading violations. [44.]
 
 
Markets

The dollar fell to a 19-month low against the German mark and neared its record low against the Japanese yen. [43.]
 
Prices of near-term cattle futures surged on the Government's plans to buy $50 million more of beef for school lunches. [43.]
 
 
Your Money

Selling an investment that has declined in value to lock in a loss for tax purposes may be worth considering. [33.]

HEADLINE: Panama's People Don't Want Haitians, or 'Gringos'

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PANAMA, July 8

 BODY:
In the neighborhood known as El Chorrillo, destroyed but only partly rebuilt after the American invasion of Panama in 1989, Orlando Gil and his neighbors were in a celebratory mood today, delighted that their Government had decided not to allow the United States to bring Haitian refugees here. "It's about time somebody in this country said no to the gringos," the unemployed laborer said.
To Washington's great dismay, the Western Hemisphere country most recently invaded by the United States proved unwilling this week to ease the pressure of a crisis that may well result in America's next military adventure. And to a large extent, Panamanians agree, it was the legacy of that invasion and 90 years of American involvement here that forced President Guillermo Endara to rescind Panama's offers of a temporary safe haven for up to 10,000 Haitian boat people. 
 "After the invasion, people thought the money would flow like manna from heaven," said Cecilia Smith Ayarza, owner of a small restaurant in El Chorrillo. "But things are as bad as they ever were, maybe even worse. The Americans want us to help them with their problem, but they still haven't cleaned up the mess they made here."
 
Complaints About Invasion
 Since the invasion in December 1989, the United States has authorized more than $1 billion in aid and credits to the Government of Mr. Endara, who defeated the candidate backed by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in a vote in May 1989 and took office after the invasion. But families whose homes were ruined or whose relatives were killed, as well as owners of businesses destroyed during the invasion, complained that they have not been properly compensated, and wonder where all the money went.
Indeed, unemployment here remains nearly as high as during the Noriega era. There is also a shortage of housing, a rising crime rate and serious health and drug problems, all of which, many Panamanians say, would only have been worsened if Mr. Endara had acceded to the Clinton Administration's request for help with the Haitian refugee crisis.
"I believe in charity, but charity begins at home," said Maria Morales, who was among a group of protesters picketing the Panamanian Foreign Ministry when Mr. Endara announced Thursday that he would not allow the refugees to come to Panama. "There's not enough jobs to go around, and everything you buy is getting more expensive. We have enough problems of our own."
 
Warring Political Parties
 In large part because of such dissatisfaction, the Presidential election held here in May resulted in victory for the Revolutionary Democratic Party, a strongly nationalistic group organized to support the military dictatorship that lasted until 1989. The party's candidate, Ernesto Perez Balladares, who is scheduled to take office on Sept. 1, criticized Mr. Endara's handling of the situation after the agreement collapsed on Thursday.
By first agreeing to accept the refugees, and then just as suddenly changing his mind, Mr. Endara exposed Panama to "international ridicule," Mr. Perez Balladares asserted. "If such a situation presents itself during my administration, I will consult a great number of Panamanians, rather than arriving at a decision I will have to regret three days later," he said.
Revolutionary Democratic Party officials said Mr. Perez Balladares, who was scheduled to meet with President Clinton in Washington on July 20, did not want to antagonize the United States before being sworn in, and therefore did not oppose the refugee agreement openly. But a strong streak of anti-Americanism has always run through his party, and Mr. Perez Balladares had no desire to support a deal that was clearly unpopular with ordinary Panamanians.
 
Endara Felt Mistreated
 Mr. Endara complained about the treatment he received from American officials over the Haitian refugee issue.
"I felt mocked and intimidated," Mr. Endara said in a telephone interview with Telemundo television news. "I negotiated with them till midnight and they mistreated me. They treated me as if this were a banana republic."
American officials, on the other hand, said they had been "exceedingly deferential" to Mr. Endara because they realized the delicacy and the sensitive nature of the agreement the two sides were seeking.
For many Panamanians, Washington's eagerness to unload Haitian refugees on them recalled a similar situation in 1979, when the deposed Shah of Iran came here at the height of the hostage crisis. Carter Administration officials, several of whom are now back in power with the Clinton Administration, later boasted that they had solved the problem of a safe haven for the Shah with "a single phone call" to Gen. Omar Torrijos, the country's ruler at the time.
Since the overthrow of General Noriega, however, Panama has been a vibrant, if somewhat tumultuous, democracy, with the National Assembly challenging the executive branch at every turn. Mr. Endara announced the offer of a safe haven for the Haitians after a phone conversation on July 2 with Mr. Clinton and discussions with American diplomats, but without consulting legislative leaders here, who were deeply offended at being left out.
 
Anti-Immigrant Sentiments
 Mr. Endara's willingness to offer a safe haven to 10,000 Creole-speaking refugees also wakened even older and equally disturbing memories here. Despite pledges by the Endara Government that any Haitian refugees would remain here no longer than one year, many Panamanians were openly skeptical, recalling earlier episodes in which "temporary" influxes of foreigners proved permanent.
During the building of the Panama Canal, for instance, the United States brought thousands of English-speaking blacks from the West Indies to do much of the most dangerous and physically demanding work, promising they would be repatriated after the project was finished. Most of them stayed on, however, making surnames such as Kelly, Parker, Duncan or Cooper common here and giving Panama a mixed cultural identity that persists to this day.
In recent years, Chinese, Arab, Indian and Pakistani immigrants and refugees have also settled here in large numbers, some of them with false visas or passports they purchased from corrupt government officials.
"These are people who know how to build boats, so how can you keep them on a small island?" Herminia Espinosa, a housewife in the capital, said of the Haitians. "They're going to have children who will be Panamanian citizens, or they will escape from the encampments and take away jobs from Panamanians. Because they look like Panamanians, they're going to be able to melt right into the population."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Players' Salary-Cap Fears Confirmed by Management Explanations

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Negotiators for the Players Association spent the better part of a three-hour meeting yesterday asking questions of their management counterparts to make sure they understood the owners' salary cap proposal.
"Our views of how certain things would work were certainly confirmed," Donald Fehr, head of the players' union, said. "We were afraid our views were going to be confirmed." 
 In other words, yesterday's bargaining session did nothing to make the players' hearts grow any more fond of the salary cap the owners want to institute as a new economic system for baseball. The players haven't rejected the proposal, but they long have stated their opposition to a salary cap.
In this proposal, the owners have offered to give the players 50 percent of their annual revenue and guarantee $1 billion a year as long as revenue doesn't fall below the total revenue the clubs have this year. The clubs estimate that revenue at $1.8 billion.
During yesterday's meeting, the two sides also discussed the owners' proposal to reduce from six to four the number of years of major league service needed for free agency. The drawback, from the players' viewpoint, is that players with four or five years of service would be subject to right of first refusal, meaning their former club could retain them by matching an offer made by another club.
Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, called the meeting "useful," prompting Fehr to respond, "He obviously has taken a course in how to write press releases following diplomatic meetings."
Ravitch said the two sides also discussed a drug policy. Baseball hasn't had a joint policy since October 1985, but the clubs have expressed interest in formulating a new one and the union has said it, too, would like a joint program.
This was the last bargaining session before the players' executive board meets in Pittsburgh Monday, the day before the All-Star Game.
"We'll go through where we are on everything," Fehr said. "We'll talk the issues through and make sure everybody understands the proposals we want to make. I'm sure there will be discussion of setting a deadline, but I don't expect we will set one."
The players are expected to make their initial proposals at a negotiating meeting next Thursday.
Ravitch has indicated some impatience with the union's pace, but Fehr has pointed to the delay in the clubs' presentation of their salary cap proposal.
It was made five months after the clubs adopted their own revenue-sharing plan, which is contingent on the players' acceptance of a cap, and 18 months after the owners reopened the collective bargaining agreement.

HEADLINE: New Money No Novelty in Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BRASILIA

 BODY:
With six different currencies having passed through their hands in the last decade, Brazilian comics are comparing the July 1 introduction of Brazil's new money unit, the real, to Elizabeth Taylor's latest marriage.
The Unified Workers Federation, Brazil's most powerful trade union, has already coined its protest slogan: "It looks like a nightmare, but it's real." (The Portuguese word for "real" is the same as the English.) 
 Here in this city of technocrats, where officials are shepherding Latin America's largest economy into its latest anti-inflation program, thin smiles greet such gibes.
Brazilian financial officials see the world's largest currency switch -- 3,000 tons of new bills and coins, worth $7 billion -- as the last, best hope of driving down a 5,000 percent annual inflation rate.
Indeed, many economists agree that the process, loosely modeled on the successful anti-inflation program of Argentina, might finally bring price stability.
 
Parity With U.S. Dollar
 Brazilians have until July 15 to trade in the cruzeiro real -- a currency that lost half of its purchasing power in June -- for the real, a new currency that is to stay on a par with the dollar through the end of the year.
"Our commitment is to intervene by selling dollars so that the relation stays at one to one," Pedro Malan, the president of the central bank, warned speculators recently.
Mr. Malan controls Brazil's largest foreign currency reserves ever, $40 billion. This mountain of dollars is one of several factors that make Brazil's financial officials optimistic about engineering a price turnaround in an economy now larger than Russia's. For example, in a measure of the nation's industrial might, Brazilians this year bought a record 573,849 automobiles and 21 million Brazilian-made television sets, largely to watch World Cup soccer.
Also, the federal budget, at the heart of any inflation, is balanced this year, they say. But as is often the case with politics in Brazil -- where general elections are to be held on Oct. 3 -- budget balancing is a messy, temporary affair. One decree has curbed election-season spending by governors, mayors and congressmen. Another cut federal revenue-sharing -- but only through next spring.
"The deficit in services is going to explode in next year's budget," predicted Miro Teixeira, an opposition congressman who presides over the Economy Committee of the Chamber of Deputies. "Hospitals can't close. Roads can't continue with potholes."
But Brazil's Finance Minister, Rubens Ricupero, believes that the success of the plan will generate support for continued budget balancing.
"The success of stabilization makes it irreversible," Mr. Ricupero declared in a recent interview here. "No government that enters in January with low inflation can afford to throw it away." A survey of Brazil's largest retailers predicted that next year Brazil will have a monthly inflation rate of 7 percent -- the lowest level in nearly a decade.
In contrast to previous attempts at controlling inflation, the conversion to the real does not involve a price freeze. Still, reflexively fearing a freeze, merchants have pushed up prices. At one fruit market in Rio, the asking price for melons was $5 apiece; at another, a dozen cherries cost $9.80. On Ipanema beach, the price of coconut jumped from 83 cents to $1. At Sugar Loaf mountain, the aerial tramway went from $4.50 to $7.50. But with Brazil's minimum salary pegged at $65 a month, consumer resistance is forcing prices to more realistic levels.
 
Pressure From Imports
 Another difference from the past is that this conversion comes at a time when Brazil's economy is fully open to imports. Where cartels once colluded on prices, they now look warily over their shoulders at imports.
"The faster the imports come in, the better for me," Mr. Ricupero said. "Brazilians have lived with inflation for 30 years. Like addicts, some people will always want their daily fix."
A freighter recently docked at a Brazilian port with the nation's first shipment of Vietnamese rice, he noted. Suddenly, Brazilian rice growers stopped raising their prices.
After Mexico, Brazil is Latin America's largest importer of goods from the United States. American exports to Brazil were rising even before the conversion, largely because of low tariffs and because of Brazil's surging economic growth rate -- at 5.7 percent in the first quarter, one of Latin America's highest.
With inflation predicted to drop this month to 5 percent, from 50 percent in June, merchants predict a rise in consumption as credit cards and installment plans return to use.
 
Few Shortages Expected
 But economists do not forecast the kind of inflationary bottlenecks that derailed past currency switches. Brazil had a record grain harvest of 76 million tons this year, and Sao Paulo industries have the idle capacity and supplies of raw material to allow quick production increases. And to hold off an inflationary boom in consumer spending, the Government is keeping interest rates high -- 5 percent a month above inflation.
In the short term, the major threat to the new currency would be a surge of dollars from overseas to take advantage of Brazil's high interest rates. But each dollar that enters Brazil must be matched by a real. And the Government says it has no intention of breaking its target for the monetary base -- 8.5 billion reals by the end of this year.
To discourage deposits from overseas, the Government has driven down the price of the dollar here to 85 centavos. Although an estimated $2.5 billion surged into Brazil in June, flows have virtually dried up since the introduction of the real.
The long-term threat to Brazil's anti-inflation plan would be the election this fall of a presidential candidate without a commitment to balance the federal budget.
Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who stepped down as Finance Minister in March to run for president, is staking his campaign largely on the plan's success. Overwhelmingly favored by business executives in surveys, Mr. Cardoso, who places second in overall opinion polls, saw a rise in his poll standing recently, to about 22 percent from the high teens.
But Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, the socialist career unionist who is leading Mr. Cardoso by 15 percentage points, dismisses the new Cardoso showing.
"People are believing in the money, not the man," he said in an interview on a campaign stop at Montes Claros, an agricultural center in Minas Gerais, the state with the nation's second most powerful economy. Indeed, some wonder if low inflation will be enough to help Mr. Cardoso win an electoral runoff.
"I would be surprised if stabilization, without salary increases, left people euphoric," said Mario Henrique Simonsen, a former Planning Minister who is a Cardoso supporter. "People who call the real plan an electoral trick are mistaken. It is the typical kind of plan done at the beginning of a mandate and harvested at the polls at the end of a government."

HEADLINE: Fiscal Board Chief Takes Harvard Post

 BODY:
Allen J. Proctor, the head of the state agency that oversees New York City's finances, announced his resignation yesterday after more than four years in the post.
Mr. Proctor, 42, is leaving the State Financial Control Board to teach at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. As executive director, Mr. Proctor was a frequent critic of New York City's budget plans, and he prodded state and local politicians to bring the city's long-term spending projections more into balance with its underlying economic and fiscal situation. 
 "In the last year or so, there's been a sea change in the way political leaders on all sides have approached the structural budget crisis," Mr. Proctor said. "I'm proud that we did our part to help bring that about."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, in accepting Mr. Proctor's resignation, praised him for "strong and effective leadership at the control board" and said he "took an already proficient operation and, with dedication and hard work, made it better."
Mr. Proctor, who was a deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget under Mayors Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins, said he was resigning out of a desire to do something different in his career, not out of any policy disagreement with either Governor Cuomo or Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. "An interesting offer like this doesn't come along all that often," Mr. Proctor said.

HEADLINE: Newts and Metal Projects Ride Columbia Into Space

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 8

 BODY:
Rising on a golden tail of billowing flame, the space shuttle Columbia carried a crew of seven into space today for a two-week mission to study both the subtle and the grand effects of gravity on materials and living things.
The experiments involve work with exotic furnaces that can produce unusual alloys and with a rotating centrifuge that can simulate different levels of gravity. The equipment also includes aquariums teeming with thousands of animals, including goldfish, killifish, jellyfish, sea urchins and Japanese red-bellied newts. 
 Columbia, carrying a bus-sized module called the International Microgravity Laboratory in its cargo bay, took off on time at 12:43 P.M. after there were initial concerns about showers and thunderstorms building up near the Kennedy Space Center and at two emergency landing fields overseas.
Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said they had been able to handle a few minor problems with ground sensors, computers and power fluctuations. Although a puff of smoke or mist was seen near the shuttle about a minute into the flight, an official said it did not seem to indicate a problem.
 
Going Right to Work
 After the astronauts were safely in orbit, they immediately got down to a busy schedule of activating the laboratory for continuous operation. Working around the clock in two shifts, the astronauts will conduct 82 experiments involving more than 200 scientists from 13 countries. The experiments, in materials and life sciences, include 22 provided by the German Space Agency, 18 from the United States and 12 from the National Space Development Agency of Japan.
The mission focuses on studying the effects of the limited gravity of orbital flight on the processing of materials and on living things, particularly the growth of plants and aquatic animals. Officials of the space agency say the multinational research is a prelude to the kind of work that will be done after the turn of the century, if all goes as planned, on the international space station.
Experiments in processing metals without using containers will employ a special furnace that electromagnetically levitates the metal samples. That allows them to be melted and solidified without the walls of a vessel either contaminating them or affecting their crystalline structure, researchers said. Another physics experiment will examine the transitional states of a material as it changes from solid to liquid or from liquid to gas or vapor.
Dr. Harry Holloway, NASA's associate administrator for microgravity and life sciences, said the work with aquatic animals, looking at the effect of gravity on their balance, orientation and physical development, represented fundamental research that might also have implications for humans. Fish and amphibians swim in water in much the way astronauts float in space because of reduced gravity, he said, so studying the evolution of the animal cells that sense motion and orientation has obvious implications.
However, he said, studies done in the absence of gravity can also shed light on the effects of gravity on people on Earth. "All of us, in our mothers' wombs, developed as aquatic animals," Dr. Holloway said.
 
Japanese Woman on Board
 The international flavor of the mission is reflected in the crew, which includes six American men and Japan's first woman astronaut, Dr. Chiaki Naito-Mukai, a heart surgeon from Tokyo. Dr. Mukai, who also has a doctorate in physiology, is the second Japanese astronaut to fly on a shuttle. The first was Mamoru Mohri, who flew in 1992 on a mission dedicated to Japanese life science research.
Dr. Mukai, already a celebrity in Japan for her role in the space program, said earlier that she hoped her flight "encourages other Japanese to do things they might hesitate to do because they are women."
Other crew members aboard the mission, the 63d of the shuttle program and the 17th for Columbia, include Col. Robert D. Cabana of the Marines, the mission commander and a veteran of two previous flights, and Lieut. Col. James D. Halsell Jr. of the Air Force, the shuttle pilot, who is making his initial voyage. Richard J. Hieb, the payload commander, has flown two previous missions, and Lieut. Col. Carl E. Walz of the Air Force, a mission specialist, flew once before. The rookies aboard include Dr. Leroy Chiao and Dr. Donald A. Thomas, both science specialists.
The puff of smoke or mist was seen by some ground observers near the upper part of the exhaust plume of one of the two solid-fuel booster rockets, which are attached to the shuttle. Loren Shriver, a shuttle program manager, said the puff had apparently resulted from the interaction of normal shock waves caused by the shuttle moving through the air at supersonic speed, with a wave of condensed, moist air rolling down the vehicle.
Mr. Shriver said no one monitoring the shuttle or its engines reported anything unusual at the time of the puff, but he said he had made an informal request for engineers to recheck their data. "Personally, I don't think it's anything more than the shock wave going through condensation," he said after a news briefing.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
"How many divisions has the Pope?" Stalin is supposed to have asked, but it is not hard to imagine Franklin D. Roosevelt or Henry A. Kissinger saying much the same thing. They too, at times, were exasperated by the idea that in world of politics, religious ideals could outweigh military might or material interests.
It is also not hard to imagine such dismissive sentiments issuing from the corridors of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington research institution with a reputation for harboring tough-minded scholars and diplomats. 
 But tough-mindedness isn't always what it seems. Scholars and diplomats affiliated with the center have just produced a study saying religion has been systematically neglected as a factor in international affairs.
They contend that policy makers, embassy aides, strategists -- and journalists, too -- have given minute attention to economic assets, military forces and social and political rivalries while scarcely noting the role of religion. When a Central Intelligence Agency analyst proposed an examination of the leading religious leaders in Iran under Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi, the idea was rejected as mere "sociology."
This kind of criticism may fall on receptive ears now that the cold war has been replaced by so many conflicts between groups divided by religious or ethnic loyalties.
But in "Religion: The Missing Dimension of Statecraft," a collection of studies that Oxford University Press plans to publish in August, the center's scholars go further. They fault not only the underestimation of religious differences as a source of conflict, but also the neglect of religious institutions and leaders as catalysts in ending warfare or bringing about peaceful democratic change.
Why, in the view of these scholars, has religion been slighted by America's foreign policy specialists?
One reason is the longstanding principle of the separation of church and state and the resulting tendency of American culture to relegate religion to the realm of the personal.
Douglas Johnston, the center's executive vice president and chief operating officer who is a former Defense Department official, says many Americans are desensitized to the fact that much of the world does not operate this way.
A second reason is the school of realism, which has loomed so large in the study of international relations. Realism emphasizes the primacy in international relations of "national interest" defined in terms of power and material advantages rather than cloudy ideals.
It is not surprising that the index of Mr. Kissinger's new book, "Diplomacy" (Simon & Schuster), a massive realist study of modern world politics, contains no entry for religion or Christianity, Judaism or Islam. Nor does it contain any entry for Mohandas K. Gandhi, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. or Pope John Paul II.
A third reason that religion remains "the missing dimension of statecraft" is what the military strategist Edward Luttwak bluntly calls the "Enlightenment prejudice."
"Even as the Enlightenment swept away clerical obscurantism," he writes, "it imposed its own restrictive prejudice on the scope and content of scholarship." The advanced thinkers of the 18th century rejected the Inquisition's methods of torture, Mr. Luttwak said, "but when it came to religion in all its aspects, they strangled free inquiry just as effectively by the commanding force of the fashion they imposed." Religious motivations in secular affairs, he said, "were disregarded or dismissed as mere pretense."
Mr. Luttwak and Barry Rubin, a professor of international studies at Johns Hopkins University, enumerate instances, particularly in the Middle East, when American policy may have been misled by the disregard of religious realities. The point of the book is not to indict American policy, however, but to provide a scholarly basis for considering the nearly unthinkable -- that religion could actually be a positive force for peacemaking.
The book provides seven case studies of efforts by religious groups or leaders to reconcile enemies or to achieve peaceful rather than violent political change.
One study describes the largely unreported success of the Moral Re-Armament Movement in bringing together thousands of French and German citizens, including influential politicians, trade unionists, industrialists, educators, clergy and journalists, for extended and intense meetings in Switzerland from 1946 to 1950. The gatherings laid the groundwork for the 1950 initiative of Robert Schuman and Konrad Adenauer to establish the European Coal and Steel Community, a major step toward the reconciliation of France and Germany and a united Europe.
Other case studies focus on Nicaragua, Zimbabwe, Nigeria, East Germany and the Philippines. One essay traces the role of South Africa's Dutch Reformed Church in first justifying apartheid, then turning against it.
The authors strive not to overstate their thesis, and one contributor warns against literal-minded efforts to translate these ideas into action. "The world is obviously not clamoring for Washington or other capitals to shanghai platoons of clerics into their service in order to support a global pacification mission," writes Stanton Burnett, a senior adviser at the center.
In fact, many believers will have mixed feelings about Mr. Luttwak's suggestion that "religious attache's" be assigned to countries where religion is particularly important "to monitor religious movements and maintain contact with religious leaders, just as labor attaches have long been assigned to deal with local trade unions."
But "Religion: The Missing Dimension of Statecraft" holds lessons not only for government officials but also for religious leaders willing to take initiatives for peace. It should encourage the growth of diplomatically engaged religion as well as religiously informed diplomacy.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Starts Interviewing Candidates for Governor

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began formally interviewing the Republican candidates for Governor of New York yesterday, holding out his support as the coveted prize of an unusual, politically delicate dance.
For months the Mayor has annoyed state Republican leaders because of his reluctance to endorse the party's nominee, George E. Pataki -- a stance the leaders fear may play into the hands of the man they are trying to defeat this fall, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
 Yesterday morning, Mr. Giuliani met for 45 minutes with Richard M. Rosenbaum, the former judge who is mounting a petition drive to force a primary against Mr. Pataki, the state Senator from Peekskill.
The leaders say that Mr. Pataki, who is scheduled to have his own meeting with the Mayor next week, is the best hope for the party that elected Mr. Giuliani New York City's first Republican Mayor in a generation. He is also, perhaps not incidentally, the protege of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mr. Giuliani's sometimes political rival.
 
Looking for Most for City
 The interview with Mr. Rosenbaum was the first of what Mr. Giuliani said would be a series of meetings with the two Republican candidates to determine, as the Mayor reiterated yesterday, who would deliver more for the city. And in a manner befitting someone who is being courted by dueling suitors, Mr. Giuliani made it clear yesterday that he was keeping his options open.
"This is not to favor one candidate or another," Mr. Giuliani said after his meeting with Mr. Rosenbaum yesterday morning. "It's to give both candidates an equal opportunity to explain to me, since they're running for Governor of New York State, what they would do with regard to the issues that are of importance to New York City."
(As for Mr. Cuomo, whom the Mayor has even hinted that he might ultimately endorse if he is the best candidate to help the city, Mr. Giuliani explained that he knew where the Governor stood on those issues and would call him if he needed a clarification.)
Though his aides say it speaks for itself, the Mayor's strategy also underscores the political realities that face Mr. Giuliani, a Republican who barely won the Mayor's race in an overwhelmingly Democratic city and who prefers to portray his administration as nonideological.
"He has to operate in a constituency that is 5 to 1 Democrats," Jay Severin, the Republican political strategist, said.
 
Eye to His Future
 "By choreographing the courting of him by candidates across the spectrum he is playing his cards well," he added. "He enhances his own political stature and that of New Yorkers."
Other strategists and leaders from both parties say that Mr. Giuliani also appears to have one eye on his future, which includes almost certainly a re-election campaign in 1997 and possibly a race for Governor.
Whatever the case, in these early days of the race for Governor, Mr. Giuliani has stayed out of the roiling fight among Republicans vying to take on Mr. Cuomo, who the party believes is as vulnerable as ever. The Mayor said yesterday that he did not expect to endorse any candidate in the Republican primary, though he is almost certain to endorse a candidate in the general election.
And Mr. Giuliani has had a prolonged flirtation with the Governor himself, appearing often with Mr. Cuomo at news conferences and ribbon cuttings and offering kind words.
"The only concern he's got is the people of New York City," Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said yesterday. "There's not much more to say than that."
The strategy, particularly his appearances with Mr. Cuomo, has won little sympathy from the state's Republican leaders and others supporting Mr. Pataki, including Mr. D'Amato.
 
Clearly Angry Officials
 Many Republicans are still angered that though the Mayor remained aloof, Mr. Powers lobbied at the party's convention in May for another of Mr. Pataki's opponents for Governor, Herbert London, a New York University economics professor. One Republican official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the leaders perceived the Mayor's actions and inactions "as a sort of slap in the face."
The state chairman of the party, William D. Powers, declined through a spokeswoman yesterday to discuss the Mayor's meeting with Mr. Rosenbaum.
But officials were clearly angered by the meeting with Mr. Rosenbaum because of the prominence it gave his insurgent effort. Mr. Rosenbaum, who supported Mr. Giuliani's campaign last fall, has raised more than $1.6 million and collected about 37,000 signatures on petitions, more than three times the number needed to qualify for the Republican primary.
The Mayor's meeting with Mr. Rosenbaum covered a range of issues, both men said, and Mr. Giuliani said he gave Mr. Rosenbaum, and would also give Mr. Pataki, a scorecard of sorts of "the issues that I consider important to the city."
The list included aid for education, reform of welfare, a takeover of the city's Medicaid costs, anti-bias legislation that includes protection for gay men and lesbians and reform of the criminal-justice system.
Mr. Rosenbaum used the occasion to release his proposal to change welfare that, among other things, would require recipients to work or attend classes 40 hours a week and cut benefits for women who have additional children. Another provision said, "If father's identity is unknown, recipients should be required to provide the names of all possible fathers or face cutoffs of benefits for that child."
Asked about the candidate's proposals, Mr. Giuliani said: "Those are all things that are certainly worth proposing. You don't have to agree with all of them."
Party officials say that Mr. Giuliani would be foolhardy to support any candidate other than the Republican on the ballot in November and that in spite of whatever signals he might send, they expect him to be loyal to his party.
"I honestly believe he's going to support the Republican candidate," said Frances Werner, the party chairwoman for Queens. "It was the Republican Party that made him Mayor."
